column1: In a time when reformed theology is on the rise
column2: Pinnock and his co-authors seek to provide an Arminian understanding of Scripture.  However
column3: the book is strewn with problems.  The authors claim that God's love trumps other attributes like holiness and justice
column4: but they give no scriptural support.  Their arguments are based simply on our western sense of fairness.  They make such appeals because they believe our moral sense reflects truth
column5: instead of recognizing our fallen nature.  In addition
column6: they advocate "making peace with the culture of modernity" (27).  Instead of letting God's Word shape our thinking
column7: they allow our lost culture to shape our view of God's Word.    The result is a presentation of a weak
column8: helpless God.  In fact
column9: the authors state "it is more important for God to give himself to his creation than to rule the world or to be worshipped" (35).  He is described not as ruling
column10: but as "limited by humanity" (40)
column11: vulnerable
column12: and "the defenseless superior power" (175).  The book has weak
column13: humanistic argumentation
column14: little scriptural support
column15: and a harsh tone toward those who embrace reformed views
column16: views said to be "theologically repugnant" (84).  Do not waste your time with this book.  While there are legitimate differences between Arminian and Calvinistic views and a place for dialogue
column17: this book does not give dialogue but instead gives unsubstantiated claims that leave you with a helpless God not in control and not worthy of worship.    In case you do not know
column18: the editor of this book embraces the view that God does not know the future.

I'm not going to rip this album apart because it's just a small blip on the the legacy of a band that I couldn't hold any higher regard for.

column1: I am a big Percy Blakeney/Scarlet Pimpernel fan and have read Orczy's book at least 3 times.  Based on the strength of a customer review on this webpage
column2: I purchased the boxed DVD edition
column3: featuring Richard E. Grant & Elizabeth McGovern.  The scripts were written by Richard Carpenter.    I was VERY DISAPPOINTED by this screen version of the story.  I do NOT recommend it to any true Percy fan.  I have viewed 3 movie versions of the Scarlet Pimpernel
column4: and this one is by far the worst.  Perhaps screen-writer Carpenter never read the book; perhaps he simply decided to take ENORMOUS LICENSE with the characters.  In either event
column5: the script eliminated much of what was delightful about Orczy's Percy and turned Marguerite into a mild-mannered wimp without the wit or resources to save herself from her own stupid decisions.  Even worse
column6: Marguerite was constantly in need of being rescued by her husband or
column7: ironically
column8: her former lover/the series villain
column9: Chauvelin.  Here are some reasons for my conclusions:    Percy Blakeney
column10: whom Orczy described in her book as the "master of disguise" never ONCE dons a disguise in this movie series (unless you consider wrapping a black scarf around the lower face a disguise).  And **HELLO!!** wouldn't the French be a tad bit suspicious of 3 black-cloaked
column11: black-masked figures strutting around the streets of Paris in broad daylight?  (The French certainly arrested other characters for less!)  These scenes were so contrived
column12: they were painful.  And yes
column13: while it was certainly clever to have Percy escape ala James-Bond gadgetry -- this contrivance negated Orczy's portrayal of Percy as a man whose WIT was his first and primary weapon for defense and escape.  In fact
column14: I found Percy (in this DVD collection) to be more fond of slicing and dicing enemies
column15: than of using his unmatched cunning to save himself and his compatriots.  This twist on Percy was truly
column16: truly disappointing -- the author must be turning in her grave.  As for the romance in Orczy's story...  Neither the actor nor the screen-writer were EVER able to convince me that Percy was the kind of man whom a woman (or a nation) could adore.  Richard E. Grant portrayed Percy as cold & verbally abusive to Marguerite.  Percy ridicules her publically several times -- and Marguerite's dialogue is written so that she never quite "gives" as good as she gets.    But Marguerite's dialogue is not the point.  THE POINT is that Percy
column17: in the book
column18: was a tormented man who loved a wife whome he feared he could not trust.  Never once did Grant's acting convey such breadth; his verbal sniping (as written and acted) was cruel and self-aggrandizing.  Even when Percy is supposed to be "play-acting" this ridicule of Marguerite in DVD #3 to set up a plot element later in the story
column19: the contempt in the dialogue
column20: as delivered by Grant
column21: felt very REAL.  Screen-writer Carpenter's rendition of the so-called "romance" in this movie version touches the very uncomfortable theme of emotional abuse
column22: especially through Grant's interpretation of the dialogue.  Rather than delivering his lines with subtlety (a nod to his hidden feelings of affection for his wife)
column23: Grant's Percy most often comes across as a high-handed male autocrat who expects Marguerite to submit meekly to his rule.  While this type of husband/wife relationship may have been historically accurate in 18th Century Britain
column24: I do not believe that the Percy of Orczy's book would have handled himself in this way.  Indeed
column25: Percy was supposed to be the consummate gentleman underneath all the frippery.  And he was supposed to be genuinely in love with his wife.  One of the rare
column26: potentially romantic moments in DVD #1 was completely bungled by both leading actors.  Grant's one-liner about Marguerite being his "life" is delivered with such unbelievable dispassion that it borders on mockery.  (And please:  Marguerite's dimwitted mutterings about unrequited love at this crucial point in the plot -- when Percy is accusing her of complicity in a French family's murder -- was INSULTING to every woman of intelligence in the audience! I just wanted to throttle actress McGovern AND the screenwriter.)  Yes
column27: yes
column28: the original book hinged on this ongoing misunderstanding in the Blakeneys' marriage
column29: but the dialogue could have been written and acted much better.  But if you don't consider the lack of plausible romantic elements a good reason to avoid this series
column30: read on.  The problems with this verison of Orczy's Pimpernel go far beyond the love story.  For starters
column31: Percy is often unsympathetic as a human being:  in addition to sniping at his wife and behaving in court like a smart-alecky prig
column32: he shows a dearth of compassion at the death of his loyal lieutenant
column33: Lord Anthony Dewhurst.  When Dewhurst is murdered by Chauvelin (in cold blood
column34: I might add)
column35: Grant (and the scriptwriter) devote exactly 3 seconds to grief in DVD #1.  Grant cavalierly delivers the following dialogue: "Well
column36: Tony knew the risks."  (And this Pimpernel is supposed to be a hero whom a nation adores?  Whom 20+ young British hotbloods would give up their LIVES for?! Sorry.  Didn't buy it.)  If Percy's casting was bad
column37: Marguerite's was even worse.  In the book
column38: Orczy's Marguerite was a flamboyant French actress
column39: full of life and passion & hopelessly in love with a husband who
column40: she believes in despair
column41: no longer loves her.    In this DVD collection
column42: Elizabeth McGovern most often appears as a frumpy hausfrau rather than a sparkling coquette.  McGovern played Marguerite without wit or common sense
column43: & Carpenter's script didn't help.  For example:  Marguerite (a bourgeois who should have known better) tries to pass herself off at the gates of Paris as a seamstress.  Five seconds later
column44: her lily-white
column45: uncallused hands are inspected by the captain of the guard
column46: and she is hauled off to prison.  Carpenter didn't even let Marguerite's character -- the consummate actress -- PROTEST this treatment
column47: much less run
column48: struggle
column49: or attempt to bluff her way out of her predicament.  Marguerite simply walks off between her guards!!  (::groan::)  In DVD #2
column50: she sits meekly in a convent
column51: waiting for Madame Guillotine's troops to discover her and drag her away.  In DVD #3
column52: she spies on 2 characters
column53: learning the double-identity of the villain.  The villain leaves
column54: but the sidekick remains; several minutes later
column55: Marguerite returns from a chat with Percy to rummage through the villain's belongings.  At this point
column56: neither the actress nor the screenwriter allow Marguerite the common sense to first SEARCH THE AREA FOR THE SIDEKICK to make sure that her snooping goes unobserved.  Naturally
column57: this plot contrivance leads to Marguerite's capture later.  ::double groan::  I could go on and on about the characterization of Marguerite as a stupid female

column66: either by word or by sword

column1: In the introduction (pg.6) Ms. Hoppen notes
column2: that after 11 September..."a perfect show house no longer mattered. Having a home that really was a home that really was a home did." So I wonder why all the really gorgeous photographs in this book really do not demostrate that people actually live in these homes. The rooms are devoid of individual personality and really do appear to be perfect show rooms. Personal artifacts are removed from the photographs
column3: replaced with props and items that are fabricated for Ms. Hoppen and for sale on links on her web sites or by the vendors listed in the "Address Book" section of her book (read product placement). With that said there are a worthwhile morsels in this book and the photographs are wonderful
column4: especially if you are looking for interesting and minimal examples of door and window trim
column5: floral arrangement ideas
column6: or you are designing a spiral staircase.  The text portion of the book is very useful for the design process of building a home and the photographs seem to be blue prints come to life
column7: but without any sentimental indications of the lives of the people who might be moving into these homes. The window treatment section should be licenced by Smith and Noble and used in their catelog.

column1: This is one of those films I've been waiting to see for years.  Almost 27 years.  I love Disney
column2: including their live-action films.  I'm a sci-fi fan.  I'm fascinated by the idea and theory of black holes.  Over the years
column3: I've come to be a fan of Robert Forster
column4: and I like the rest of the cast alright insofar as I'm familiar with their work.  Maybe it was all the anticipation
column5: but I was extremely disappointed on finally watching The Black Hole.  It's pretty much a mess that's transparently derivative of a number of other films.  It feels like calculated product when you watch it.  And it has a very odd cast for a sci-fi film.  That could be a pleasant surprise
column6: but here
column7: it never stops feeling odd.  You get the feeling that everyone got lost on their way to sets for other films.  Or that it was some kind of quirky practical joke.  The script is another big problem.  You're plopped into the middle of the lives of a crew exploring deep space in a modest ship with little exposition.  We don't know when this is supposed to be
column8: what the crew is supposed to be doing
column9: really
column10: or what their relationships are.  We just get plunged into a dilemma with lots of gobbledy-gooky dialogue and the kind of sci-fi physics for which many people would have nominated Armageddon (1998) for a Razzie
column11: if only that were a category.  Of course
column12: I don't mind fictional physics
column13: but the spinning and lurching and all kinds of other
column14: later events just tended to be ridiculous in a way that I wouldn't call "good".  In any event

One thing that really drove me crazy was the floating R2-D2-ish robot whose speech capabilities consisted almost entirely of somewhat obliquely selected Bartlett's Quotations and clichés.  Robert Forster's character kept saying
column18: "Right"
column19: in response to these
column20: as if the robot had just explained some complicated scientific principle or otherwise said something profound.  Other people and robots got into the Bartlett's and clichés act later.  The script references a couple more technical aspects of black hole theory

column1: This book is
column2: unfortunately
column3: suited more for "arm-chair" survivalists than people really seeking a working knowledge of wilderness survival skills. Most of the skills "covered" may help the inexperienced person feel confident until they actually attempt them. Case in point: Cordage or natural string...yes they cover it
column4: but so sparingly as to be ineffective. "The inner bark of trees make the best fibers to use." (page 7-4) That is all it says about using bark. There is nothing about what trees are best
column5: or how to harvest or prepare the bark. The bulk of the "skills" in this manual are lacking in a manner similar to that illustrated above. As a former soldier and a current survival instructor I can say with the utmost confidence that this book is good for starting fires and not much else. The lack of many details provides a challenge to anyone attempting to complete a skill from start to finish. Try it and you will see! Reviewers giving it high marks clearly have never been in a true survival situation. Thumbs down

column8: I took the path and stopped at Schuller's lemon tree.  Unfortunately the lemons were not good.  I then tried to make lemonade.  Unfortunately the lemons were so bad that no amount of sweetner could make them palatable.  In fact
column9: it became unhealthy.  I tried several other uses
column10: but all were equally unproductive and unhealthy.  I began to wonder why--then I realized that lemon trees
column11: in order to produce palatable fruit
column12: must be trimmed regularly.  The lemon tree at the side of this particular road is in need of serious trimming.  There is better and more nutricious fruit to be found elsewhere.  Even the old cliche "when life gives you lemons
column13: make lemonade" is of no use when the tree itself is no good.  It is this last part that Schuller fails to adequately address.  Too bad.  I strongly suggest you take a different and more scenic road that bears much better fruit

column1: First
column2: let me say that I don't read tech books cover to cover.  I use them as a reference when I need info on a specific subject.  After buying this book

Under those 6 lines is a Note:    "Appendix A contains an overview of the way a terminal server works in Windows Server 2003."  I immediately flip to Appendix A.  I begin reading..."Appendix A: Internet Information Services 6.  DOH!"  Not a single word about Terminal Services in the Appendix.  I immediately lost my faith in this book
column4: and I haven't looked at it since.  I can't comment on the rest of the book

column7: when I need answers I have to trust the source.  And after this

column1: DRUMMING is Steve Reich's longest work
column2: two full discs of minimalist rhythms performed by an occasionally changing ensemble. This installment in Deutsche Grammophon's "Echo 20/21" series of contemporary music reissues provides a rare complete performance of the work with no cuts
column3: recorded in 1974. In the end
column4: I found "Drumming" to be minimalism at its worst.  During the late 1960s Steve Reich had worked in a studio for electronic music. In 1970 he visited Ghana
column5: and there found confirmation of his suspicion that acoustic instrumentation contained all the possibilities of music by itself. Stylistically "Drumming" is a continuation and final refinement of the phasing technique that Reich had been working with since 1965. This is a process in which "two or three identical instruments playing the same repeating melodic pattern gradually move out of synchronization with each other." Yet
column6: three new techniques are here. The first is that the timbre gradually changes while pitch and rhythm remain constant. The second is that the human voice is used to imitate the exact sound of the surrounding instruments in the ensemble. This has an effect similar to Ligeti's "Clocks and Clouds"). Since the glockenspiels are too high for the human voice to mimic
column7: whistling accompanies the lower registers of the instrument
column8: and a piccolo the higher. The third innovation is the process of substituting beats for rest or vice versa within a repetetive rhythmic cycle. Though there is development of the theme
column9: there is yet only one basic rhythmic pattern for entire two discs of the work.  The ensemble is a showcase of early 1970s avant-garde performers. Cornelius Cardew
column10: who went on to become England's first Maoist composer
column11: plays marimba's here. I think that a similar section of Cardew's work "The Great Learning" (also in "Echo 20/21") is much
column12: much more successful than "Drumming" and encourage all to check it out.  I admit it
column13: I think minimalism is the greatest disaster to befall contemporary music
column14: and has provided more charlatans than any other style. I prefer the zahlenmystik of Gubaidulina
column15: the frenetic business of Lindberg
column16: or even the academic dryness of the lab coat-wearing composer Boulez. Yet
column17: I can appreciate some works of Reich. The other Reich disc in the Echo 21/21
column18: with his "Variations for Winds
column19: Strings
column20: and Keyboards"
column21: "Music for Mallet Instruments
column22: Voices
column23: and Organ"
column24: and "Six Pianos" is quite enjoyable. "Drumming"
column25: on the other hand
column26: is so dull that I felt no compulsion to return to it except the curiosity to know if there was something in there after all. Yet
column27: after many listenings
column28: I find that the work is still without any captivating qualities. The development of the music seems to take longer than in any other minimalist work
column29: and two hours of music have a range so limited that you won't believe you just paid so much for this release.  I really cannot recommend this disc to anyone except those who
column30: like me
column31: are collecting all of the "Echo 20/21" series
column32: or those who want to fill holes in their Reich collection. I was greatly disappointed by "Drumming"

column1: I read this book on the strength of the author's "See no evil." Worried about a sense of deja vu
column2: I waited five months.  That was not necessary: This book provides little sense of place or character
column3: seeming to depend upon your having read "See no evil" for that.  If it hadn't been for "See no evil"
column4: I would have stopped reading after the first few chapters.  Although the first chapter was promising
column5: I quickly lapsed into speed reading (just short of skimming).  Just over halfway thru
column6: I became so disappointed
column7: I stop reading.  However
column8: my curiosity - inspired by the author's previous work - got the better of me
column9: and I picked it back up and skimmed to the end (encountering nothing to cause me to read for enjoyment).  The book's genre is the spy version of "detective thriller" - the hero runs from place to place collecting information from various "colorful" sources
column10: with various "old friends" providing critical information that would have otherwise disrupted the frenetic pace.  The author does not have the kind of  writing skills needed to pull off a book in this genre.  I expected (and desired) some exposition on Middle East politics
column11: but it often came across as excessive and preachy (obsessive?).  Novels can provide a simplified version of a situation to reveal underlying truths
column12: but this book provides only a simplistic version - readers of "See no evil" may feel insulted
column13: not just disappointed.  I expected that part of the book would center on bureaucratic politics and infighting within the CIA and intelligence community
column14: but what was here was disappointing
column15: poorly set up and very badly rendered.  The ambiguities and uncertainties I would have expected were slight and peripheral to the main thread of the book.  Dialogue is often poorly rendered - it took effort to track which character was saying what - but this was a symptom of the bigger problems.  If you have this problem in an extended exchange involving only two characters
column16: there is a problem with the characters themselves and with the plot point that the dialogue is attempting to advance.  But some of the exchanges were so trite
column17: I didn't bother to make the effort.  Characters are minimally rendered.  The plot is slight.  Transitions between scenes are often jarring.  Too many of the situations strain credibility.  The ending made me feel not just cheated
column18: but betrayed (appropriate behavior for a Case Officier
column19: but not for an author).  Read "See no evil".  Skip this book - It could have just as easily been produced by a writer whose only experience was reading other books in this genre

column1: Overall this series is quite good.  As a former Marine
column2: I've found that the authors do a bang-up job of recalling long-forgotten memories of service and sacrifice.  They've managed to combine snappy action and plotting with well-realized characters.  Characters (such as Charlie Bass) who's fate we deeply care about.  That being said
column3: "A World of Hurt
column4: the tenth and latest in the Starfist"  series is a distinct disappointment.  After the last two books in the series
column5: "Kingdom's Fury" and "Lazarus Rising
column6: we had the chance to really get to know several of the main characters: Charlie Bass, Lew Conorado, Brigadier Sturgeon, Cpl. Doyle, etc.  They really came alive and of course there was the entire subplot with the supposed death and disappearance of Bass on Kingdom.    This was a major story arc, with the Marines grieving terribly at his loss."  However
column7: his return from the dead is barely mentioned or explored in this novel.  His promotion to officer status was similarly glossed over.  It would have been quite interesting to have seen the reaction of the Marines to his return
column8: rather than the matter of fact acceptance of his miraculous
column9: "Lazarus" like revival.  Or failing that
column10: I would have enjoyed seeing the internal conflicts that Bass experienced as he assumed his new role of officer rather than enlisted man. They were hinted at in some of the throwaway lines in the book but nothing more. The Bass storyline is but one example of many that could have been fleshed out in this book.    Overall
column11: it seems that the authors simply phoned this one in.  Especially telling is the excruciating detail with which everyday activities are described.  For Heaven's sake!  If readers have been with the Marines of the 34th FIST to this point then they don't need to read the line "fast ride on a rough road" one more time.  Ugh.  Here's hoping that the next installment serves to advance the overall story rather than serving as a placeholder

The best part of this book is the bibliography; it is clear that the author performed extensive research into the history of automatic firearms.  The breakdown of the book is pretty much as follows: 1st 1/3rd: fairly thorough if necessarily brief biographies of Samual Colt [who would normally merit no more than passing mention in any other book on automatic weapons]
column2: Richard Gatling
column3: and Hiram Maxim. 2nd 1/2 of text: political history of the development (or rather
column4: lack thereof) of the tactical and strategic use of machine guns by Western powers
column5: esp. Great Britain up to and including the 1st World War [aka "The Great War
column6: The War to End all Wars"] - this section is the tedious part complained about by other reviewers. With reason! It is highly repetitive
column7: is weighted with judgmental hyperbole
column8: and overall contributed little to the value of the book. The remaining 1/6th of the text is devoted to cursory overviews of Isaac Lewis [of Lewis Gun fame]
column9: John M. Browning [perhaps the most gifted & prolific gun designer ever
column10: if only because it seemed to have been the sole focus of his professional life]
column11: and Mikhail Kalashnikov.  The book has a few minor factual or technical errors in it
column12: but overall is well-written and never "talks down" to the reader
column13: but with an inadequate title; it should alternatively be titled _The Development of the Machine Gun and Its Affect upon the Great War_ or perhaps _Why the British Fear Guns
column14: esp. Machine Guns_
column15: especially since developments after 1920 are given such short shrift
column16: merely touching upon a couple of the automatic arms developed during WWII
column17: with not even mention of anything developed post-1950 (ie

column3: Beyoncé has virtually no knowledge of the language and had to be taught phonetically to sing the Spanish lyrics. This hardly sounds like someone who has a long time  appreciation for the language.  This may be an opinion held by only a few
column4: but these Spanish language tracks are nothing more than a business move and a shameless attempt to capitalize on the recent surge in sales of music made popular by Latino audiences. She is only fleecing this sector of the music buying public.  It would be almost a certainty that
column5: if music popular with Russians was currently dominant on the charts
column6: Beyoncé would be on TV expressing she has always had a love of Russian culture and "this is for all my Russian listeners!" If there should be a lull in Latin music popularity in the future
column7: she will quickly change her tune.  As detestable as it might have been
column8: it would have been better for Beyoncé to confess that this Spanish phase on the "Deluxe Edition" is a mere marketing ploy instead of disguising it as a sincere love for the culture. The title of her recent single may aptly describe Beyoncé at this point in time: a "Beautiful Liar"

column14: of course) Versaille

column17: I forgot
column18: Teabing's crippled so I should feel bad about talking bad about him. Anyway
column19: this trio of prententious intellectual clods sit around do what pretentious intellectual clods do -- make lofty
column20: self-affirmed pronouncments about how the world's going to turn upside down when this cat gets out of the bag. The point is that these characters aren't very approachable and Brown does little to convince me that this secret will destroy Christian faith as we know it. Hell

column22: yet the Christian faithtul still pack churches around world. But back to how bad this book is. Trite doesn't begin to describe some of the wincing turns of phrase. I would give you some examples but
column23: like I said

column25: Sophie and Langdon have somehow eluded the grasp of professional killers several times
column26: been on the run and are exhausted. With a straight face

column28: crumpets. Hell
column29: Teabing
column30: shut up about your conspiracy theories

column1: I have to preface this review by saying that I am not a Caroline Myss fan.  This is not based upon my past religious upbringing
column2: but rather on her approach to an attempted synthesis between the Jewish
column3: Christian and Hindu teachings on metaphysics and energy systems.  In short
column4: I think she missed the mark and tried to force fit areas together based more on her assumptions about reality than a natural meshing together of concepts.  I am educated both as a scientist and in the area of psychology
column5: including sacred psychology across world traditions.  It was very difficult for me to even listen to the logic underlying the author's arguments.  However
column6: by synthesizing these disparate traditions in a credible sounding manner
column7: she has tapped into a very large market of people searching for meaning.  I am not saying that this book is completely without merit
column8: but I would take much of it with a grain of salt.  I also think there are better books out there that are better researched
column9: more thorough and less contaminated with a lot of the authors own assumptions about reality.  Two examples to look at while you are evaluating this book are FORGOTTEN TRUTH by Huston Smith and a BRIEF HISTORY OF EVERYTHING by Ken Wilber.  There is a saying that most people would rather be entertained that educated.  I think this basically sums up my experience of this book
column10: except I didn't find it very entertaining either.  I know that many loyal readers of Ms. Myss will disagree with me
column11: but this is my honest opinion of her work.

column1: Harvard psychologist Howard Gardner's book on the art of changing minds and affecting opinions has an appealing pull. Written by a qualified professional in the field
column2: the book is another output of the impressive Harvard Business School Press. The book advances the view that there are seven
column3: what it calls
column4: "layers" or "levers" that affect a change of opinion. These factors
column5: whose titles all begin with `re' are: -Reason -Research -Resonance -Resistances -Real World Events -Resources And Rewards and -Representational Redescriptions   Gardner subsequently proceeds to elaborate on each of the factors within contexts such as an institution
column6: among a population
column7: up close or as relate's to one's own mind.   So far
column8: so good
column9: many would say; alas the reader is compelled to add `so what?' to the phrase. Changing Minds is indeed the work of a qualified professional
column10: but the reader is neither provided evidence nor shown the techniques and history behind the author's conclusions. Furthermore
column11: being the work of a researcher in an academic setting
column12: readers should not expect practical instructions or employable techniques. Rather
column13: Changing Minds concentrates on the mechanics and psychological hypothesis. In this manner
column14: the book is very much a scholastic paper. Finally
column15: there is scant evidence that the author employs his own teachings. Little proof
column16: research or reason is offered here to be convincing or allay any of the readers' resistances. Similarly dismissed is the need for charts
column17: sub-titles
column18: illustrations
column19: indented or highlighted points or synopses.   Furthermore
column20: and more ominously
column21: the author makes several practical mistakes in the way he reads or interprets the world rendering some of his data and experiences suspect. He claims that schools are agents of change and serve to instill different opinions in youngsters. Those are his opinions and not supported by any empirical data. He does not provide any supporting data either. In fact
column22: the contrary is true. Schools are designed to breed uniformity and teach adherence
column23: obedience and group activity. Barely a student will pass physics class were he to challenge a prevalent theory. A law student will probably find himself choosing a new major should he differ with prescribed laws. Similarly
column24: imagine a student disagreeing with the outcome of World War II
column25: an astrology student disputing the form of nova stars or
column26: at an elementary level
column27: a high school student butting heads with his classmates and instructors. Another error is the assumption that events have lead to fundamental change even in thought process of political leaders. Let me quote from the book. While Gardner cites the example of George W Bush following September 11
column29: many scholars and historians have shown that far from changing his mind
column30: the US president instead leveraged the event to more resolutely drive his pre-existing agenda. Much of what transpired following the events of the day were the accelerations of the American president and his officials' overt and covert ideas and strategies. Gardner terms the new Bush
column31: a "multilateralist"! Uncomfortably
column32: 132 sovereign countries and a lack of support from the United Nations would disagree. Moreover
column33: despite such fierce opposition
column34: Bush proceeded with his plans nonetheless. Further down the pages
column35: the author condemns Stalin's pact with Hitler as "cronyism." He conveniently forgets or omits the allies' earlier pact with Hitler or the West's subsequent treaty with the "extremely paranoid" Stalin. In short
column36: being a tenured academic Gardner himself seems most susceptible to institutional tunnel vision and in need of constructive cognitive dissonance.   Lacking the appeal of practicality
column37: the burden of proof or applicable relevance set in actual events Changing Minds: The Art And Science Of Changing Our Own And Other People's Minds is solely of interest to researchers in need of alternate sources on the topic.  Gardner does not provide any empirical basis for his opinions
column38: which also deviate from the title and stated scope of the book

column1: White-washed with a heavy coat of feminist wistfull thinking
column2: "Missing Mary" is a New Age fictional concoction at best and outright heresy at worst.  Spretnak blatantley lies when she states that Mary's presense in Catholic theology has been "played down" from the pulpit by decree of Vatican II.  Never has the church made any official statement that Marian statues were to be removed from churches and that prayer to Mary and the Rosary be given a kind of Protestant-like boot out the door.  One need only look at the papacy of John Paul II and his devotion to the Blessed Mother to see that Spretnak's assumptions are completely false.  Pope John Paul even put "M" in his coat of arms to represent Mary and he credits her with saving his life after the assassination attempt on his life.  While Spretnak was "missing Mary" in her particular church there were plenty of other churches where Marian devotions continued unabated.  Too bad she never found one
column3: but it does not justify her shoddy research and false accusations.  Spretnak quotes theologically fuzzy Catholics like Matthew Fox and Andrew Greeley and she constantly slams Cardinal Ratzinger (now Pope Benedict XVI) in the typical liberal dissendent-catholic manner.    But it's when Spretnak starts to ascribe pagan "Goddess" qualities to Mary that she goes out on a limb and saws it off.  Never in the church's history has Mary been portrayed as a goddess
column4: a near-goddess or "the Goddess."  She is Theotokis
column5: the "light bearer" meaning that she carried the light (Jesus Christ) in her womb.  Mary is the Mother of the Church
column6: given to the Church by Christ as he was being crucified ("Son
column7: behold your Mother").  She is the Ark of the New Covenant and she leads her children to Christ as any good mother does
column8: but she is not a Goddess to be worshipped and the church has never taught that she should be worshipped
column9: only venerated because she is the first Christian and a perfect Christian.  Mary was never GONE from the Church. She doesn't have to make a COMEBACK. Mary was never minimalized or whatever cockamaymie words Spretnak uses.

It is my general policy not to write a negative review of a book. As an author
column2: I try to support other writers and not tear them down. However
column3: I occasionally make an exception
column4: and Troll is one of them. I decided to write this after I committed to reviewing all the short-listed Gaylactic Spectrum Award nominees for Best Novel
column5: and because I have yet to read or hear anything negative about this book. I think it's time another point of view is heard.  First published in Finland where it won the coveted Finlandia Prize for best novel
column6: and then translated into English
column7: Troll has received almost nothing but praise. The book came to me highly recommended
column8: but I simply hated it. My first challenge was the writing. The style is simple and direct
column9: almost too simple at times. It's also written in the present tense
column10: an unusual choice and
column11: for many readers
column12: rather disconcerting. It's not an easy book to get into. The highlight for me was the alternating chapters that were "taken" from various resources on trolls. The encyclopedia and book entries were so well-written that you almost believed that trolls could be real. If only the actual story was that compelling.  I found the story itself to be extremely disturbing. The author goes out of her way early in the book to establish that Pessi is a wild animal on a par with a gorilla
column13: and a juvenile animal at that. When the mounting sexual attraction culminates in a sex scene of sorts
column14: I wanted to throw the book across the room and wash my eyes out with soap. In the end
column15: the author tries to challenge your thoughts on what is culturally acceptable and warn you against making pre-judgments
column16: but I thought the attempt was clumsy at best. Even if you assume that trolls are the equivalent of humans and therefore Angel is not into bestiality
column17: he would still be a [...] since it was well-established that Pessi is immature
column18: barely more than a toddler from the descriptions. Other readers have addressed none of these issues
column19: so I can only assume that they only bothered me.   There is no doubt that this is an unusual and original book
column20: but that doesn't necessarily mean it is good

column1: Do not believe the manufactures claims that you don't need a jacket if you have this bunting. We had a 7am Enfant bunting for our daughter for her first winter and loved it.  It had a hood (that could be unzipped) and completely covered her up and kept her toasty warm without any extra clothing. Now she has outgrown it and I bought one of these as a replacement. There is no way by any stretch of anyones imagination that you can use this bunting without needing a coat and hat as well.  The zip only zips to about half way up the chest of my one year old.  Yes you could pull up the flap to cover her chest but she just pushes it down again since there is no way to keep it up! It did keep her just about warm enough with a coat
column2: hat and mittens at a temp of 35F
column3: but I want something that you can use without a coat.  After much research I am returning this (after a single outing) and getting a Little Kazook instead (which zips all the way up and has a hood)

column1: What happens when you cross Friday the 13th with "The Running man"?  The Jason strain reveals a reality show that pits death row convicts against one another until there is only one left
column2: as an added bonus Jason is thrown into the mix to make it more interesting.  Now take this and throw in an outbreak angle(this happens when a scientist creates a designer serum and mixes it with Jasons blood creating a virus that oozes from jason and affects all of his victims and all of their victims).  Turning all of em into what jason is.....a powerful undead.  the rest of this book is a survival jaunt in the costa rican islands that has echoes of any zombie movie ever made. Survive and cut their heads off!  I thought this book was o.k.
column3: the first half of it was all character history for the dozen or more characters. Jason takes a back seat until the second half and even then he's in the passenger seat where he should have been driving.  Christa Fuast paints some really interesting background pictures for the characters
column4: along with some snappy dialogue
column5: although with a couple of steamy scenes laced throughout. I felt like I was reading some cheap harlequin romance books. The Jason Strain didn't feel like a true friday the 13th story.  Die hard Fans I think will be disappoited.  Bottom Line....Jason wusses out a few times in this book...Not bad and certainly not good

column1: When I found out that John Legend did a cover of Stevie Wonder's "Don't You Worry 'Bout A Thing" I said to myself

column1: If it were possible to give an author zero stars
column2: I would have.  This book is seriously flawed for two reasons:  First
column3: Ms. Shamblin has a very limited if not confused understanding of Christian doctrine.  For example
column4: she rejects the concept of the Holy Trinity and uses many fallacious arguments to support her beliefs.  I don't feel comfortable reading anything written by a supposed Christian with this brand of faith.  Second
column5: her main principles for losing weight include only eating when physically hungry and stopping eating when full.  The majority of people suffering from overeating don't care if they are hungry or full or not.  They eat for other reasons
column6: including but not limited to numbing fears
column7: dealing with resentments or to forget past relationship issues.  Compulsive Overeaters
column8: of which I am one
column9: will not only eat when they are not hungry
column10: but will continue to eat far beyond feeling full -- sometimes to the point of physical pain and discomfort.  I truly believe that faith
column11: especially Christianity
column12: can help those suffering from overeating
column13: because recovery from overeating requires physical
column14: emotional and spiritual recovery.  But this book and "The Weigh Down" movement is NOT the one to help you do this.  Your best bet is to find an Overeaters Anonymous meeting in your area and start going to their meetings instead

column1: This book is absolutely flawed in its arguements.  Schlesinger ignores the context of the times; he ignores basic truths; he is jaded in his outlook.  By all accts.
column2: Mr. Schlesinger is a New Deal Democrat who tries to firmly tie in the New Deal Democrats into the Democrats of old.  This is not feasible as the Democrats of old and the New Deal Democrats had differing perspectives and ideals.  He reaches and stretches with the intent of the Democrats in the Age of Jackson
column3: that they were always for the laboring classes
column4: when this is not the case
column5: especially in Southern Democrats who were aristocratic in nature and outlook.  They could not comprehend the plight of the ordinary laborer
column6: as their world view was quite skewed.  Further
column7: divisions that were slowly emerging between Northern and Southern Democrats
column8: primarily over the slavery issue
column9: are discounted and Schlesinger merely goes back to his jaded perspective that the Democrats were the champions of the common people.  Schlesinger imposes his own view of politics and parties on politicians from the Age of Jackson.  There are other works out there that are 100 times better on the Age of Jackson that this work
column10: such as The House Divides: The Age of Jackson and Lincoln
column11: from the War of 1812 to the Civil War edited by Paul Wellman and Lewis Gannett or The Era of Good Feelings and the Age of Jackson
column12: 1816-1841 by Robert Remini.  However
column13: I will give the man credit where it is due
column14: he does his research.  Pity he doesn't know what to do with it

column3: well that is becuase of the story line and plot.The story line of any movie is much more important to me than the animation. The movie left me with a odd emptiness from begining to end. I just kept thinking there has to be more. But there wasn't. The best way I could describe it would be to say it was as if the movie were a lost child at the carnival that no matter how hard it looked it just couldn't find its parents. This movie is for the person who likes action and no character development fluff. But if you are the person who likes well developed characters and story line please don't buy it rent it first. I'm not saying its a bad movie by any means
column4: just a bit empty for me.Just one more thing the Escaflowne series is very very good don't let any bad reviews of the movie discurage you from getting the series

column1: A few weeks ago
column2: I happened to pick up a couple books by Ted Dekker
column3: mainly because the plot summaries made them look interesting.  The first of these books
column4: Three (or more properly
column5: Thr3e)
column6: was a disappointment
column7: but Dekker did at least show some ability with his plotting
column8: so I decided to give my other book of his a chance.  Sadly
column9: while Obsessed is slightly better than Three
column10: it is still a weak effort.  The hero in Obsessed is Stephen Friedman
column11: a realtor in 1973 Los Angeles.  Friedman - a secular Jew - is living a fast and fun life which is about to be turned upside down when he finds out his mother
column12: who he never knew
column13: had died.  Among the items she bequeathed to a Holocaust Museum was a Stone of David
column14: one of five rocks that legend says David used to slay Goliath.  With the other four
column15: the set could be worth a hundred million dollars.  The history of the stones goes back to a Polish concentration camp run by Gerhard Braun in 1944.  Braun is not only a Nazi
column16: he is also a serial killer
column17: a trait his son Roth has picked up as well.  In 1973
column18: Roth comes to Los Angeles in search of the Stones and crosses paths with Friedman
column19: who has learned a lot about his mother's history and of a girl named Esther who he seems destined to know.  Like the movie Laura
column20: Friedman falls in love with a picture
column21: in this case
column22: that of Esther's mother Ruth (who he assumes Esther resembles)
column23: which will soon obsess him.  This novel has a lot of problems
column24: principally because Dekker is not a very good writer.  For one thing
column25: he is sloppy:  at one point he discusses Friedman worrying about streetlights at 7:30 on a summer evening
column26: a time which would still be quite light out.  More significantly
column27: Friedman is mentioned as being 31 years old
column28: yet the story makes it clear he was born in 1944
column29: making him only 28 at the beginning of the novel.  Plot points are left completely unclear
column30: such as the fate of Friedman's friend
column31: Sylvia.  Beyond the sloppiness
column32: Dekker has more fundamental writing problems.  Despite the bulk of the story taking place in 1973
column33: the reader rarely gets the sense of the time; sure
column34: there are references to eight-track players and there are a couple stereotypical hippies
column35: but for the most part
column36: this could take place in 2007 with almost no noticeable effect.  And Friedman himself is a really weak character:  he's not very bright and he usually is reacting to situations instead of acting on them (actually
column37: that's just as well
column38: because when he tries to take action
column39: he usually proceeds rather cluelessly).  I suppose that this can be categorized as Christian fiction (that seems to be the genre Dekker is associated with).  This has less to do with thematic material (however
column40: religion does have something of a role in this story) than with the fact that the violence is strictly PG-13 and the romance (and language) is G-rated.  I've always had a wariness about this genre
column41: not because of the subject matter
column42: but because I feel that Christian fiction publishers don't focus as much on quality (although I'm sure some gems slip through) because they cynically assume they have an audience that is not as discriminating as long as the story is labeled "Christian" (the science fiction/fantasy field suffers a lot from this as well).  Unfortunately
column43: Obsessed has done nothing to make me think any better of the genre.  If you like suspense fiction
column44: read Michael Connelly
column45: Lee Child
column46: Jon Land or David Morell or a few dozen others
column47: but avoid Dekker.

column1: I agree with the reviewers who found this series "stuffy

column3: "You might as well buy a romance novel." (Or a super-heroes comic book for the action parts.) What horrified me was that one reviewer mentioned Peters in the same sentence with Jane Austen and the Brontes!! Austen did not condone much of the absurdity and pomposity of her time
column4: but chose to demonstrate it
column5: rather than rant or lecture against it
column6: as many authors and poets were doing.  In a few simple sentences she skewered inheritance laws' cruel unfairiness to women. The little girl asks
column7: "Why do we have to move?" and her mother explains simply
column8: matter-of-factly
column9: that's the way it is.  As outrageous as the law itself is the docile
column10: (seemingly) unquestioning acceptance of it.  Austen didn't go into an enraged diatribe
column11: just assumed her readers were perceptive enough to get the message.  Peters would do well to emulate really good writers: demonstrate talents and other qualities with actions and events
column12: rather than repetitive
column13: tiresome descriptions

column1: The book poses a very good question
column2: one that most people are thinking about - "What will the future of work be in an outsourced global environment? "  But sadly Malone never risks making any futuristic predictions. This book captures the history of functional organizations and a some recent radical organizational models.    Internal trading concept for sharing scarce resources within an organization was rather interesting. In the final chapters Malone goes in-depth about the consulting industry's model of resource deployment
column3: but he seemed to have missed out the key role that Resource Deployment Managers play in serving customers. As an earlier reviewer mentioned the concepts are over simplified and repetitive. It was an interesting read for me until I finished 2/3rd of the book
column4: when I started to slowly discover that the book was repeating concepts and the author is reluctant to be making bold predictions as the title suggested. If you just want an interesting presentation on different organization models currently in practice then this book may be for you but if you are looking beyond the present then you will be disappointed.

column1: Amongst scads of positive reviews
column2: it's a pleasure to offer a dissenting voice. What is this book?  The book's jacket sez: "this hyperkinetic and relentlessly inventive novel ... a narrative particle accelerator ... cooler than zero and unaffectedly affecting
column3: a hilariously funny and deeply serious meditation on the nature and uses of the mind." Cooler than zero? That's called hype
column4: and even though it reads like the shameless promotion for something hollywood
column5: it might be the best writing to be found in this book.    The basic premise & narrative structure of "Hard-Boiled Wonderland
column6: while not especially original or inventive, does hold potential for a meditation on the mind. But Murakami thoroughly fails to touch this space. The characters are caricatures, one-dimensional, facetiously portrayed, and defined entirely by eccentricities. They lack any real sense of an inner life (despite the premise), and are, in most cases, some variation on stock cliches (the deranged scientist
column7: the undemure granddaughter
column8: and various thugs" (this from the book's jacket again)). The narrative itself is also beset by cliché and caricature
column9: not "genre-bending" but derivative
column10: a poorly realized reguritation of big-movie & mass-market conceits.   In fact the very language is often a weary assemblage of catch phrases and common combinations
column11: sometimes laughable in their anesthetizing overuse: "I stood there dumbfounded
column12: as if I'd been hit by a blunt object
column13: overcome by the chilling realization of my utter helplessness" (Ch.3). This is a sense even better conveyed by reading a few pages. And although it's said to be "adroitly translated
column14: Alfred Birnbaum appears to be trying to capture the sense of Murakami's style by casting it in a kind of hackneyed American vernacular.  The science-fiction or cyberpunk elements are watery at best; the book basically equates the mind with a kind of clever computer system that operates according to some fuzzy Freudian misunderstandings. And after living in Japan for a year, its clear that this novel has nothing insightful to offer about the culture or sensibilities of the Japanese, one of Murakami's alleged assets. (For that I recommend Abe or Mishima instead.) The Murakami book-covers are beautifully designed and blurbed with a cooler than zero" edginess
column15: but after reading this one
column16: its seems clear that Murakami is largely the buzz of a successful marketing engine
column17: rather than an innovator of language and literature.

column1: You'll never get the straight story about nationalism out of Eric Hobsbawm
column2: who himself appears to try to reconcile his own ethnic identity with the topic.  David Pryce-Jones once noted that in Hobsbawm's own autobiography: "he [Hobsbawm] boasts of a visit to Bir Zeit University on the West Bank to display solidarity with the Palestinians.  Why Palestinian nationalism is valid
column3: and Jewish nationalism invalid
column4: is something else Hobsbawm fails to analyze and explain. Quite crudely
column5: he approves of nationalism in countries which proclaim themselves Communist and anti-American
column6: like Cuba or Vietnam
column7: while rejecting nationalism in countries which are not Communist and are pro-American
column8: like Israel" ([...]
column9: Jan. 3
column10: 2003).  Such twisted thinking is evident through "Nations and Nationalism
column11: where Mr. Hobsbawm spares no effort, however subtle, to demean nationalism that doesn't conform to his pre-existing prejudices.  In short, when writing about nationalism, Mr. Hobsbawm allowed his considerable analytic and writing skills to become corrupted by his religion, communism.  Therefore, unless you are an acolyte of that religion, this book is not worth your time, money or effort to read, and if you *are* a member of that religion, I suggest you broaden your intellectual horizons a bit, perhaps by reading Liah Greenfield's Nationalism: Five Roads to Modernity" or Benedict Anderson's "Imagined Communities.

column5: I sent my camera in for repair.  It was under warranty
column6: and I had not done anything to break the camera.  Well
column7: they voided my warranty stating that it was "Impact Damage" and my repair bill was $111.00.  You have got to be kidding.  I called to question the voided warranty since I had not dropped the camera.  The technician I spoke to explained that "Impact Damage" could happen if the camera bumped up to something in your purse.  So I asked to speak to a manager. I am sorry
column8: but if I am going to spend this much money on a camera
column9: I expect a little better quality.  I have called and email the Kodak Company several times to have someone talk to me.  Nobody has bothered to return either my calls or emails. I would SERIOUSLY think twice before spending money on a camera that can break by no fault of your own only to have the warranty voided and billed an amount comparable to a brand new camera.  I have discovered that the quality of a product is only as good as the company that will stand behind it.

 This is just a PR piece for the Disney company, a way to build hype so more people will buy their products and see their shows.  I was hoping for some nuts & bolts advice on designing theme parks and theme park rides.  Everybody knows how to brainstorm;  everybody knows the importance of color and lighting and music;  everybody models on computers before they make physical models.  What do Imagineers do that's different?  Do they have special techniques for brainstorming, or for choosing colors, or stage lighting?  The answers are not here.  Also, what have Imagineers learned from their mistakes?  If you take this book at face value, Imagineers have never made mistakes;  everything they've done is perfect, and any criticism leveled at Walt Disney world was later retracted or countered

column1: This book was clearly written for profit. Many sections of the book are only weakly connected back to the main theme and nowhere does Helen Thomas make her case-in-chief directly. Instead
column2: the reader is treated to a series of vignettes which all too frequently bear only a tenuous relationship to one another and which make no effort to maintain continuity. While each chapter has a reasonably strong cohesion (though those boundaries frequently intersect in a way which would make any Venn diagram lover proud)
column3: they work together not as a fine Swiss watch
column4: but instead more like a Rube Goldberg machine. 	There is one theme which appears time-and-again: the idea that an objective and vigorous free press is a necessary part of democracy. This point is made consistently throughout the book from a cornucopia of different
column5: albeit predicable
column6: angles
column7: and is artfully shown both implicitly and explicitly through excellent and enjoyable anecdotes accumulated during the author's sixty years as a White House correspondent. Unfortunately for the reader
column8: her anecdotes frequently seem to be included for their value as self-platitudes rather than for intrinsic value or thematic attenuation. Also unfortunate is the inconvenient truth that Helen Thomas is no longer the type of reporter she praises
column9: but the type she opines against: an opinion columnist. 	There are certainly gems in the rough scattered throughout the 201 pages
column10: but the author's tendency both to ramble and babble makes them difficult to find and detracts from their value. With regard to Thomas' periodic attempts a historical organization
column11: her comments at the conclusion of chapter four are revealing: "There were other press secretaries and other spokespersons. I have mentioned only a few who stand out in my mind
column12: for better or worse." Indeed
column13: it seems she deemed fit to simply write down a train of thought as it occurred to her in the shower; that is to say
column14: while not devoid of organization
column15: the linking up of subjects is tenuous at best. Perhaps the most interesting and enjoyable aspect of Helen Thomas' writing style in this book is her robust use of vocabulary
column16: which includes a scattering of excellent words on every page (some of which I even had to look up)

column1: I ordered the book expecting the breakthrough system advertised on the cover.  Instead
column2: the book is about going to networking events to meet people to trade referrals with.  I guess that's ok if that's your thing but it's not mine
column3: it sure never got me anywhere
column4: heck
column5: the top sales guys I know won't even bother with those events.  The first 100 pages are spent just trying to convince you that referral selling is the only way to sell.  Ok so cold calling is out but I don't think referral selling is the only option.  I might have given the book a better rating if the cover told the truth and I knew I was buying a book about going out to networking mixers. Referral selling is old news and there are plenty of other books about it.  I feel let down by what I got.  And you know what?  The book isn't half bad if going to networking events is your thing.  That's why I gave it better than one star.  But why not tell people what they're getting up front?  The author needs to study up on relationship selling because you sure don't build good relationships by promising one thing and delivering another.  And why are all the 5-star reviews from people in her area in CA

column10: because I have bipolar disorder myself
column11: I question whether she really has her illness under control.  Waking up each morning in a state of utter despair does not sound to me like someone has found satisfactory treatment.        It also bothers me that it is implied that mentally ill people simply don't use their will enough to better themselves.  While this may often be true
column12: it is also often true that these people are exerting truly heroic willpower each day simply to stay alive.  To call them "wimps" really does not help anyone.      While her descriptions of severe depression are more or less convincing

column18: often unecessarily.  Being insensitive to their suffering only makes the problem worse.  Judging a person who takes medication

column1: I was very pleased to finally acquire this book
column2: having heard of it several years ago. Although I'm not an expert in history
column3: I have read a lot of books concerning this period
column4: and always look forward to reading more. My pleasure soon turned to dismay as I started reading. Through the first few chapters I had a growing but unspecific feeling of unease - something about the prose didn't ring true. It was nothing I could put my finger on; aspects of the writing didn't feel authentic.  I persevered. Eventually I stumbled across details that I knew were wrong. For instance
column5: in this period the term "Your Majesty" to address the King or Queen had not yet been introduced. This didn't come about until the time of the Tudors. Plantagenet monarchs were content to be addressed as "Your Grace". Next
column6: Edward IV was several times described as wearing a collar of interlinked S's. Unlikely. Yorkist collars tended to consist of roses and suns - the interlinked S collars were favoured by the Lancastrian nobility. Then in book 2 of the series we were asked to believe there was a Jewish money-lender in Whitby. As this story is set slap bang in the middle of the three hundred and fifty year period during which all Jews were banned from England
column7: I find this hard to believe. Book 3 (which I've read
column8: living as I do outside the US) would have us believe a crescent moon sailed the sky for an entire night. I ask "On which planet?!" A crescent moon when new is seen only at the start of the night
column9: and when waning is only seen in the hours before dawn. The only moon that is seen all night is a full moon.  These known inaccuracies ruined the book for me. I found myself questioning every detail I read. Was it true? Was it authentic? Or was it just a flight of fancy or wishful thinking on behalf of the author? In the end I was unable to finish the 3rd book in the series because I found myself irritated to the point that I no longer cared about the fates of the characters. I'm only grateful that I got the books out of the library rather than spending hard earned cash on them.   I'm left wondering how such glaring errors could make their way into a published book...or am I expecting too much that a work of historical fiction should reflect its setting accurately

column1: This was one of the few books on Japanese history available in my local library
column2: so I read it second (the first was "Embracing Defeat
column3:
a history of the post-WWII Occupation) in trying to learn more about Japan.  Unfortunately, on the one subject I do know in detail, Pearl Harbor (any and all books by Gordon Prange are excellent) the authors were just plain wrong. The errors were all in one direction, too -- dismissing the dull facts in favor of kewl conspiracy theories. I couldn't find out where they got their errors, either, since the attributions both in the text and in footnotes were vague to the point of uselessness.  The result is that I've soaked in a gripping political thriller whose background I _know_ is distorted by an unknown amount in the direction of conspiracies -- and there's a lot of conspiring in this book. I'm not optimistic about how many of the other conspiracies are made up, too, and it's going to take me a lot of research in better books to come to an intelligent conclusion. Thanks so much. Very few books leave the reader feeling dumber than he started out 
 I've already alluded to these terrible performances in my review of his even more outrageously anemic performance in his Rachmaninov disc.  I don't know what to say. column1: Let me say at the outset that I am not a macroevolutionist.  However
column2: Morris' simplistic caricature of biologists ("Darwin's theory of evolution is universally accepted among biologists"
column3: p3) is far from the only factor that makes this a disappointing book.  Morris is simplistic and repetitive
column4: and in addition to the typo's already mentioned by other reviewers)
column5: there are several examples of outright contradictions and misinformation that leave me scratching my head.  On page 21
column6: Morris states that "carbon-nitrogen dating...can rarely be used to determine the ages of rocks in geological formations."  In fact
column7: it cannot be used to date rocks at all
column8: only organic materials.  On page 25
column9: Morris states that "The solar system is full of such [organic] chemicals
column10: including amino acids-the components of proteins..."  I am not an organic chemist
column11: but to my knowledge none of the amino acids found in the proteins of living things have been found anywhere else in the solar system.  If they have
column12: it would certainly be in very limited places and quantities
column13: not littered about the whole solar system
column14: as Morris implies.  In addition
column15: only 6 pages later
column16: Morris states:  "Localized areas rich in organic chemicals are found in the fossil record.  These chemicals must have been produced by microbes of some kind."  Gee
column17: I thought you just said that the solar system was full of them!  On pages 33-34
column18: Morris states:  "It should not be imagined that they [the mammals] survived because they were somehow better adapted than the dinosaurs."  This statement directly contradicts the principle of natural selection
column19: which is the guiding light for evolution and is even accepted in a general sense by creationists.  On page 44
column20: Morris attempts to defend evolution by saying:  "Although many different kinds of genetic codes are theoretically possible
column21: all organisms use the same one."  He uses this as an argument for macroevolution.  However

 Originally written as a college paper, this book takes the author's personal beliefs and poorly attempts to make them the entire history of a loosely defined set of musical and cultural styles that began probably long before the author was old enough to speak. He's a hippie punk with crusty leanings, which means love, peace, anarchy and not bathing too often, and the whole history of punk is redefined to the point of pretending most everything else doesn't exist. It's hysterical reading his mental gymnastics when describing Anarchy as both violent and peaceful. Anyone who gives this a good review has to be blinded by their own political ideology since this book is soooooooo poorly done. It's not a history at all. It's an editorial steeped in too much wishful thinking

Not recommended even (or perhaps especially) for Koontz fans.

For the next 9 chapters Mr. Clarke writes about his role in the US Government from a first person view
column8: from the beginnings of his career in the Reagan administration to the end in the Bush administration. When Alejandro Jodorowsky's debut Fando y Lis was originally released back in 1967
column2: a full-scale riot broke out in the audience
column3: the director barely escaped the theater with his life
column4: and the film was banned. That has got be the best
column5: most intriguing publicity I have ever heard of any picture receiving. Of course
column6: when I heard about this
column7: I simply had to see it. I mean
column8: what could this film possibly contain that could provoke such an extreme reaction?  After watching it
column9: I honestly have to say that I really don't know.  Fando y Lis is by far the strangest
column10: most bizarre film I have ever seen. There is no cohesive narrative
column11: no coherent style
column12: and in the end
column13: no real point. The movie feels like some incredibly strange spawn of The Texas Chainsaw Massacre (1974)
column14: Eraserhead
column15: and 8 1/2
column16: though it is very different (and far more bizarre) than any of those films. This is an art house flick
column17: through and through. Fiercely experimental and filmed on a shoestring budget
column18: its unbelievably loose (almost non-existent) plot follows Fando and his half-paralyzed girlfriend Lis as they search a wasteland inhabited by hoards of...erm...interesting characters for the mythical city of Tar
column19: a paradise on Earth. Or are they even on Earth? In this film
column20: nothing is for certain.  When one watches an obtuse art film such as Fando y Lis
column21: one's first reaction is most likely to try and decipher it and unlock its "message" or "meaning"
column22: so to speak. However
column23: there is no such thing in Fando. Jodorowsky himself said that he finds what he doesn't understand to interest him the most
column24: so in reality
column25: no one is going to understand this film
column26: because I'm not really even sure there is anything to understand.  That said
column27: there are still some rather intriguing visuals and scenes in Fando
column28: such as an incredibly striking sequence involving black paint (at least I think it's black paint - the black and white cinematography makes it hard to tell). Actually
column29: this brings me to the point of the cinematography
column30: which
column31: in my opinion
column32: is the most unsettling aspect of the film. Though it was filmed in the 1960s
column33: the black and white is bleached and brightened to an uncomfortable degree
column34: giving one the impression that the film was shot in 1920s. For some reason
column35: it gives the whole picture something of a disturbing aura.  Unfortunately
column36: the fact that this is Jodorowsky's first film really shows. The whole thing seems more like a big experiment than anything else
column37: and some rather amateur editing and borderline laughable sequences ruin a lot of the interesting segments. That's not to say the film is without worth; it makes for a rather interesting watch. But overall
column38: it just feels like a heavily experimental student film with no real purpose. It can be hard to sit through occasionally
column39: but at 93 minutes
column40: it doesn't drag for too long
column41: and it is worth viewing if only for its historical value

column1: I started this book with anticipation and the further I went the more disappointed I became.  Whybrow makes an interesting arguement that Americans are slamming up against limits they refuse to recognize - biological limits like how much change the mind and body can absorb.  He calls this the Fast Society and his argument builds upon earlier historians who noted the psychological effect of the closing of the frontier in the 1870's.    Whybrow's primary hypothesis
column2: however
column3: is that there is something GENETICALLY special about Americans because we are descended from restless people.  He traces both innovation (good) and inability to handle limits (bad) to this genetic material.  There are two big problems with this thesis:  First
column4: Brazil
column5: Argentina
column6: Chile
column7: Australia
column8: and Canada are all immigrant societies
column9: too.  For Whybrow's hypothesis to hold
column10: they must also manifest these traits - irrespective of their political and social institutions.  Whybrow does not think to ask.    Second
column11: Whybrow quotes deTocqueville's Democracy in America at least three dozen times in defence of the special (genetically based) character of Americans.  Yet deTocqueville's most passionate (and perhaps famous) chapter compares the people living on both sides of the Ohio River
column12: in Ohio and Kentucky.  Tocqueville notes that these are ethnically the very same people - often closely related
column13: yet the two societies differed drastically with respect to innovation
column14: industriousness
column15: independence and initiative.  He was disturbed by the slovenly habits of Kentuckians
column16: their disdain for work
column17: their lack of initiative or enterprise.    From this observation
column18: deTocqueville argued that slave-owning was profoundly enervating and corrupting
column19: even of the vast majority who owned no slaves.  That Ohio and other parts of America owed their creativity and restless energy to democracy itself - and that the slave-owning south was not completely democratic
column20: but stunted.  This is one of DeTocqueville's most famous arguments and it directly contradicts Whybrow's hypothesis.  Whybrow never confronts this.  After awhile I started to wonder if he really had read DeTocqueville
column21: or whether some graduate student was supplying him with quotes.    Finally
column22: Whybrow appears unfamiliar with previous (famous) critics of the soul-destroying aspects of American society - Whyte's Organization Man and Roszak's Where the Wasteland Ends come to mind.

column1: The Crossing by Cormac McCarthy is an interesting but somewhat confusing look on the early west of America. The story begins with a father and two brothers trying to track and trap a wolf that had crossed over from Mexico. The Wolf is a mother and is supposedly carrying around pups with her. This part was particularly well written
column2: but became confusing when Spanish was being used heavily. In review of this part I believe that there was something deeper in the crossing of the wolf and thought of it as a metaphor to immigration issues. The short-lived story of the capture of the wolf was ended by a cleverly placed trap by one of the sons. 	Instead of killing the wolf as some would have expected (though that would have ended the book rather abruptly) the two sons decided to return the wolf to Mexico. After this happening the brothers go on various adventures including running away with a heartthrob
column3: attempting but failing to join the U.S. army and crossing in and out of Mexico a total of 3 times.  	This was a well written book but there were many useless characters in it that just seemed to distract you from the actual point. The over use of the Spanish language confused me and would confuse anyone who doesn't speak it. I thought this book lacked motivation and suspense
column4: but because of the author's brilliant mastery of the English language he was able to entangle me enough to finish it all the way through

`"I'm of course aware that some believe that Herta von Walther played the Dietrich role in the Garbo film Die freudlose Gasse
column2: "The Joyless Street"
column3: ' so writes Diana McLellan.  Despite the author's claim that Marlene was in Pabst 's "The Joyless Street
column4:
there is absolutely no evidence that any actress other than Herta von Walther played the part of the woman in the butcher line.   McLellan certainly has no proof that Marlene played the part. Therefore any thing she says about her in that role is opinionated speculations.   There is, however, much evidence that Herta von Walther was in that role.    Marlene and Herta did appear together in one film in 1923, Tragï¿½die der Liebe.  There is no evidence that Greta Garbo and Marlene Dietrich ever appeared in any films together.   The fact is that Herta made four films with the director of The Joyless street between the years 1925 and 1928. The four are Joyless Street, Secrets of a Soul, Love of Jeanne Ney, Abwege.   There is no record of director Georg Wilhelm Pabst having ever made any films with Marlene Dietrich

column1: Native Son is a book that I was required to read for school. I had high hopes for the book
column2: but they were dashed as I read on. The writing style is extremely sub-par. Wright struggles to get his point across succinctly. The book is characterized by muddled and repetitive narrative. I kept trying to like the character of Bigger throughout the novel
column3: but I was unable to do so. His apparent lack of remorse for his actions is apalling. The argument that his fear and society is the cause of his murders can only apply to his murder of Mary Dalton. His willingness to profit from the murder and sense of pride about it afterword is sick. I see no literary value in this book. We read it because in public schools today we are forced to read literature about how America is racist towards blacks every year. Schools try to jam the theme of racism against blacks down our throats every year in an effort to "emotionally move us" and make us feel guilty for something that occurred long before we were born. I assure you that this book would not have achieved the title "classic" if the author was white. In America we ignore the plight of other ethnic groups and focus solely on the cause of the African American. I get the point we studied it enough already.

column1: Although this book has been released for quite some time I am just now reading it and I was initially excited to read this novel.  It is the first novel that I have read by this writer.       The basic premise sounded interesting...black and white related through blood who have to unite and put aside their differences in order to defeat a great evil.       Well I felt that alot of the plotted storyline was forced in order to advance the story.  I hate to say it but it was like Barnes was too lazy to exercise his creativity and create a way that made more sense to connect some points in the story.  Some parts were just too tidily handled.  He wasn't creative in the way that suspense in the story was resolved either.  You're on the edge of your seat trying to figure out how they are going to get out of the conflict this time and then something happens that is just too tidy and too convenient to really suspend disbelief.    Also
column2: this is not necessarily Barnes's fault
column3: probably more the editor(s)
column4: but the book was full of typos.  And some words were overused in the story.  It was hard to follow sometimes who was speaking during the dialog scenes as well.  Again
column5: more the editor(s) fault?  The character development was "okay."  Barnes was overconcerned I felt with physical descriptions of the characters but he did a fairly decent job from time to time of getting the reader into the character's head.  All in all
column6: I know I will probably not read another Steven Barnes novel.  My time is limited to read though this is one of my favorite pasttimes.  I hate finishing a novel that I am not really all that impressed with feeling like it was a colossal waste of time and that I could have been spending my time reading something more worthwhile.
