 I don't keep up with every single Ludlum book, and when I bought this in paperback I'd just assumed it was one of his earlier ones that I'd missed--since I was aware that he'd died.  About 15 pages into it I found myself looking back at the front to make sure I had the right book--the writing style was juvenile.  It felt like a high school kid's first attempt at a spy novel.    Then I looked at the printing date and realized I'd been ripped of by the publisher!  Ludlum did not write this, and it is so painfully obvious.  I trudged through another 100 pages or so--you know--figuring that I'd invested some time in it and it might get better. It never did.    I admit to not finishing it and I know I'm not missing anything. Just to get as far as I did was a tedious chore.    Robert Ludlum would be writhing in his grave if he knew the slop that St. Martin's Paperbacks is peddling in his name

column1: Longtime fans of Scott O'Dell's classic Island of the Blue Dolphins
column2: do yourself a favor and avoid this lackluster sequel.  Island of the Blue Dolphins was one of my favorite books as a kid.  I must've read it at least a dozen times.  Somehow
column3: I didn't find out that it had a sequel until years later.  Intrigued by the idea of a sequel to Island
column4: which kind of ends on a cliffhanger
column5: I read Zia.  I was interested in seeing how Scott O'Dell would handle what happens to Karana when she is finally rescued off the island after being stranded for 18 years.  As you probably know
column6: Island of the Blue Dolphins was based on a true story
column7: but the facts are few about the real Lost Woman.  So how would the talented writer Scott O'Dell concoct what happens to Karana?  The result
column8: Zia
column9: is terribly disappointing.  For starters
column10: fans of Karana won't have much to read about.  At least half of the book deals with her niece and nephew trying to go to the island to rescue her.  The story is told completely from the niece's point of view.  We never get to hear what Karana herself thought about experiencing a new land and being reunited with people after so many years
column11: and the sadness she must have faced at finding that her tribe was gone.  We learn almost nothing about what happened to Karana's father and sister
column12: just that her sister's children have ended up orphans in a missionary.  And sadly
column13: there's nothing interesting about Karana's niece Zia and her brother.  They merely serve as plot devices to stretch this paper-thin story out over 100 pages or so.  I now appreciate the "cliffhanger" ending of Island of the Blue Dolphins in its perfect simplicity.  It is better to leave the story when Karana leaves the island
column14: and let it be.  Your own imagination about what it was like for Karana to live at a missionary where no one spoke her language and there was no trace of her tribe left is better than the depressing depiction of her life in Zia.  I wish I could erase Zia from my mind.  Zia truly is a sequel that should not have been written

column1: Here is the original review of this machine I wrote on June 17
column2: 2006:  We bought this machine just over a year ago (a year and two weeks

column6: it has begun making noises when starting up and shutting down
column7: and now it occasionally has problems reading the disks
column8: ejecting them
column9: and even playing them.  At first we thought this might be because we'd recorded over the DVD-RAMs so many times.  But today we tested one of them in the other machine
column10: which has never made any similar noises
column11: and the E55 had no problems with it.  Needless to say
column12: we're not happy that the ES10S seems to be dying
column13: especially since the 1-year warranty just ended.  If you buy or own this machine
column14: follow up on any strange noises as soon as you hear them if you're within the warranty period
column15: because the noises and problems just get worse.  Panasonic is usually a reliable brand
column16: one we've used for many years
column17: but this machine seems to be a lemon.  We're actually going to write to Panasonic about it--I'll try to post again with the results.  Here is my update
column18: which I wrote November 3:  This is a follow-up review to the one above
column19: which I wrote on June 17. I wrote to Panasonic after my machine had stopped working just after the warranty ended. They sent me a nice letter authorizing a free repair
column20: including labor
column21: of the machine at one of three places they listed. The places were all within a half-hour drive of my home. After doing some research
column22: I chose one and brought in the machine. They fixed it by replacing "the entire internal mechanism" (I don't know what that means). We got the machine back from the repair shop near the end of July; it's now the beginning of November. The fixed machine worked fine for a while
column23: but in the past few weeks
column24: we've been hearing the same old noises that were the beginning of the end for it before. I'm going to try writing to Panasonic again and asking for a refund
column25: because this machine really seems to have something fundamentally wrong with it. It's still working
column26: but I know from the last time with these noises and efforts to read the disks that soon it won't. Avoid this machine. Again
column27: the previous Panasonic model (DMR-E55) we bought hasn't had any of these difficulties and continues to work great. We're still big Panasonic fans
column28: but this particular model is a lemon.

column1: Visuals are stunning
column2: editing is superb - so if you need a visual guide to the Bible
column3: this is pretty good. Unfortunately
column4: that is where the good ends.  Bruce Feiler sets out on a quest to visit all the biblical landmarks of its first five books
column5: but the trip has an inherent weakness - Mr. Feiler is a skeptic. He is taking a journey of faith but rationalizes each and every step he takes. For example
column6: ascending the Mt. Ararat
column7: where the Bible says the Ark of Noah rested; he wonders where all the waters would have come from in the first place. He wonders - melting ice-caps? In other words
column8: Bruce Feiler is looking for a rational explanation for the Great Flood!   If Bruce Feiler believes that there was a garden of Eden as the Bible says (his very first stop)
column9: then he must also believe that God made the heavens and the earth
column10: as the Bible says! If HE can create the Heavens and the Earth by the Word of HIS mouth
column11: HE can also perform miracles. You cannot pick and choose what you believe based on your so-called rationality - either the Bible is true in its entirety
column12: or it is not. If it is not true
column13: then it does not need Bruce Feiler's help to prop up its so-called "stories".   This aspect of Bruce Feiler journey is oft repeated - and very perplexing.  Why set out on such a journey if you do not believe your Guidebook? More examples? Bruce Feiler suggest that since the Sinai wilderness could not support the number of people the Bible says crossed over from Egypt
column14: therefore the numbers must be wrong. How about the Manna being nothing but the gum of some wilderness tree in Sinai? I could go on....but you get the point. After a while
column15: this becomes very annoying.  If you are a believer
column16: this is not for you. I would not recommend it for my children.

column1: I will start by admitting that I am not a Catholic
column2: and not a Chrisitan.  I was raised Protestant
column3: and thus a lot of energy that I've put into studying Christianity was focused on Protestantism.  A Catholic friend of mine recommended me this book
column4: as I was looking for some factual history on the church.  That background being given
column5: this book is dangerous.  It is extremely conservatively biased
column6: almost completely one sided.  However
column7: it is presented as God's Gospel Truth and many people will read it that way.  Crocker's book does not lie (at least not much) persay- his bias is not in reinventing the truth
column8: but rather in re-framing it in a way that makes his case sound convincing.  This makes it very seductive to logical people who haven't heard the other side of the story.  One of the continuing trends in this book is the outright demonization of non-catholics.  Any catholic can be forgiven his downfalls
column9: which are mentioned offhandedly
column10: if at all
column11: while non Catholics are almost always incapable of being decent people.    Here are some of the beliefs that Crocker (an amusingly ironic name
column12: I might note) has steeped into his history: -In the opening quotation
column13: he advocates the abandoning of reason and a return to faith.  Reason has been the spark for all of the developments of the modern world.  At the same time
column14: he pushes Catholicism as the sole source of reason
column15: without really showing how the religion is rational.  When reason disagrees with him
column16: he sees it as evil; when Catholics forge their own reasons
column17: he lauds them as the only ideas that make sense.  Near the end of the book (p. 413)
column18: he states (almost explicitly) that non-catholics are incapable of reasonable
column19: intelligent discussion. -He advocates monarchy over democracy.  "Monarchy and monotheism go together
column20: he writes.  He basically blames democracy and nationalism for everything that went wrong in the twentieth century- as if his beloved Christian kings didn't start wars for power or land.  He glorifies the crusades, and it actually sounds like he wants more of them.  He lauds the dark ages as a high point for Christianity.  He applauds Napoleon.  While he is always ready with the number of deaths caused by things like the Reformation, he never ever gives a death toll for the wars he supports. -He supports a very conservative view of women, lauding Paul and Napoleon's views- in Napoleon's words, the weakness of women's brains
column21: the instability of their ideas... their need for perpetual resignation... all this can only be met by religion."  Crocker says that in this Napoleon "Sounds like a father of the church." -He is against the rule of secular law: "Every recourse to the law and courts is a calamity."  -He justifies the inquisition
column22: which I'll admit makes some sense in terms of putting the inquisition into context.  But he steps over the line when he says on page 392 that if the inquisition had not been stopped
column23: the Holocaust would have never happened.   -He barely mentions other Church sponsored sins
column24: like the selling of indulgences.  These are but a few of the serious issues that I had with this book.  I truly hope that most Catholics do not believe in Crocker's history
column25: because it is not a history.  A history needs to be objective.  Crocker denies any progress made in modern times and prefers a return to the injustices of monarchy.  Ultimately
column26: the hisotry of the Catholic church is worth studying.  There is no doubt that it has had a profound impact on the world.  But the history of the Catholic church is really just like the rest of the world- a history of politics and power- gaining power
column27: extending it
column28: and not letting any other religious groups have any access to it.  There have been very good catholics
column29: there have been very bad catholics
column30: just as can be said for every other gorup of people. Don't believe the propaganda.   If you must read this book
column31: please
column32: please read it with a large grain of salt

 I am being generous with my two stars, in deference to the man who wrote Harvest.  Simply put, Neil needs a lyricist, and perhaps a muse. In acting, they call this mailing it in, and Neil mailed these lyrics in-or at least that's the better view to the one that suggests he has become lyric-deaf after all his years.  This could've been a four.  It just needed some words

column1: "A Death in Belmont" is a misleading untruthful exploitation of a murder which took place in 1963.  The new paperback version of the story is identical to the hardcover.  THE FACTS On March 11
column2: 1963 Roy Smith was sent to the Goldberg home by the Division of Employment Security
column3: a state employment agency
column4: as a day worker to clean the house.  The interviewer at the agency
column5: Mrs. Martin
column6: later testified that she thought she had smelled liquor on Smith's breath.  When she asked him if he had been drinking
column7: he replied
column8: "No" and took a step back.  Smith was given an identification card and instructions to 14 Scott Rd.
column9: Belmont.   Although three witnesses testified that Smith arrived at the Goldberg home between 12:45 and 1:00 p.m. Smith told police he had arrived before noon.  Smith told police he knew he had left the Goldberg home at about 3:45 because the clock at the nearby pharmacy where he stopped to buy cigarettes read "quarter to four". Neighborhood children coming home from school at 3:05 p.m. saw Smith walking quickly away from Scott Road. Witnesses at the pharmacy testified that Smith made his purchase shortly after 3:00.   Smith told police he had finished the cleaning
column10: left the house in order and had been paid $6.30 ($1.50 per hour for four hours plus 30 cents for transportation).    When Mr. Goldberg arrived home at 3:50 he found his wife's body and quickly called the police.  The house was in disarray.  Only one room (the sunroom) of the three rooms Smith claimed to have cleaned was actually in good order.  The police found that the living room was in the process of being cleaned
column11: as most of the furniture was in the middle of the room
column12: the couch was pushed to one corner
column13: living room ornaments were on the dining room table and the vacuum cleaner
column14: with attachments was in the center of the room. Alfred King of the Belmont Police Department stated
column15: "A broom with a cloth over the broom end was at the entrance." Evidence from [350 Mass. 600] COMMONWEALTH vs. ROY SMITH.   On page 54 Junger states
column16: "Smith was refusing to admit to the murder
column17: but neither could the police catch him in a significant lie."  On page 256 Junger says
column18: "The cops wanted to know what time he left the Goldberg house
column19: and he told them the truth."  "The fact is he never lied about what he did that day."  1.	Smith lied about his time of arrival at 14 Scott Road (never mentioned in book)  2.	Smith lied on two occasions about his time of departure from 14 Scott Road. He spent two hours at the Goldberg home instead of the four he had claimed. (Smith lied on this point immediately after his arrest in Cambridge and again when interrogated in Belmont)   3.  	Smith lied when he told police the house had been cleaned and everything was in order. (never mentioned in the book)  4.	Smith told police he had been paid $6.30 at a rate of $1.50 per hour.  Had Mrs. Goldberg been alive when he left he would have been paid for only two hours or $3.00. (Smith lied on this point immediately after his arrest in Cambridge and again when interrogated in Belmont.)  5.	Smith's handprints were found on the vacuum cleaner
column20: the living room mirror and the mantel over the fireplace.  Smith said he never touched the mirror or the mantel. (Smith's lie omitted from book)  Before Mr. Goldberg left for work he gave his wife a ten dollar bill and five singles to pay the cleaning man.  The day before
column21: March 10th
column22: he had left her $7.00
column23: but she had not spent all of it.  Smith told police he had $2.00 with him when he arrived in Belmont and he had been paid $6.30.  When Smith was arrested on March 12th he had in his possession $3.20.  Using Smith's statements to the police and the testimony of his friends during the trial it was clear that Smith spent approximately $15.00 between the time he left Belmont and the next day when he was arrested.  A salesman at a liquor store testified he saw Smith with a ten dollar bill
column24: a five dollar bill and some singles on March 11th.  Smith could not account for the $15.00 he spent plus the $3.20 found on his person.  Smith spent the evening of March 11th drinking with friends in Cambridge.  Smith's friends offered to drive him to his home in Boston.  As the car slowed down in front of Smith's apartment house Smith noticed two plainclothesmen. Smith told the driver to "speed up".  After some drinks at a nearby bar Smith's friends once again attempted to drive him home.  They all returned to Cambridge after Smith told them
column25: "Go faster
column26: they are still here."  Smith spent the night in Cambridge with his friends.   He was arrested in Cambridge on March 12
column27: 1963.  Smith was tried for 1st degree murder
column28: rape and larceny in November
column29: 1963. He was convicted of murder and robbery
column30: but acquitted of rape. President John F. Kennedy was assassinated the day before the jury retired to reach a verdict.

 This book contains SOME very good information. Overall, I am glad to have purchased it for some of the information it contained. However, the author repeats himself constantly. Sometimes he changes the wording and sometimes he doesn't bother, he just repeats himself. If I could count the number of times he claims that things don't exist, and that every perceived thing is a concept, I'd guess it to be near one hundred.  Toward the end this book becomes even more weird and reundant as he attempts to tell you that the book you hold in your hand isn't really a book. He uses a graphic illustration about a cow, and none of us have even been able to see the cow in the picture he's talking about.  You may find some useful tips, but this can be a very boring read in places, and if you're like me you will be frustrated with the redundancy and all the concepts that seem to go nowhere... 
 Mark Twain once said that (and I paraphrase)the definition of a classic is something that everyone wants to have read and no one wants to read. That is my experience with this book. For some reason, A Tale of Two Cities never made it onto any of my high school reading lists, and I figured it was one of those books I should have under my belt. So I picked it up. What a slog! A book that might have been fascinating due to its French Revolution subject matter was a mass of rambling descriptions and melodrama. We were supposed to shed tears for Sidney Carton, a character who you barely get to know, and root for Lucie Manette...the highly unrealistic paragon of unspoiled goodness. The only thing I liked about this book was how Madame Defarge knitted a list of people on which she planned to take revenge. An admittedly cool concept. Maybe this book speaks to another era, maybe it's past its prime, maybe I don't have the required literary sensibilities, or maybe I couldn't relate, but A Tale of Two Cities bored me to tears. 
 Many reviewers compared this novel to Jurassic Park, saying it was a better book than Crichton's. What absurdity. I am not saying that JP is an awesome book, but it was far better than Tyrannosaur Canyon.  Tyrannosaur Canyon is a fairly intriguing story, but poorly executed and VERY poorly ended. It's as though Preston suddenly realized that he was going to have to get his characters out of the predicament he had put them in, and didn't know how to do it. The ending is too fast, too unlikely and too unrealistic.  The book closes with a theistic comment by one of the characters, which I believe is Preston's way of attempting to belong to both camps, having his science AND being religious.  Overall, I had high hopes for this book and I am sorry to say that in the last 100 pages, I was greatly let down

column1: White-washed with a heavy coat of feminist wistfull thinking
column2: "Missing Mary" is a New Age fictional concoction at best and outright heresy at worst.  Spretnak blatantley lies when she states that Mary's presense in Catholic theology has been "played down" from the pulpit by decree of Vatican II.  Never has the church made any official statement that Marian statues were to be removed from churches and that prayer to Mary and the Rosary be given a kind of Protestant-like boot out the door.  One need only look at the papacy of John Paul II and his devotion to the Blessed Mother to see that Spretnak's assumptions are completely false.  Pope John Paul even put "M" in his coat of arms to represent Mary and he credits her with saving his life after the assassination attempt on his life.  While Spretnak was "missing Mary" in her particular church there were plenty of other churches where Marian devotions continued unabated.  Too bad she never found one
column3: but it does not justify her shoddy research and false accusations.  Spretnak quotes theologically fuzzy Catholics like Matthew Fox and Andrew Greeley and she constantly slams Cardinal Ratzinger (now Pope Benedict XVI) in the typical liberal dissendent-catholic manner.    But it's when Spretnak starts to ascribe pagan "Goddess" qualities to Mary that she goes out on a limb and saws it off.  Never in the church's history has Mary been portrayed as a goddess
column4: a near-goddess or "the Goddess."  She is Theotokis
column5: the "light bearer" meaning that she carried the light (Jesus Christ) in her womb.  Mary is the Mother of the Church
column6: given to the Church by Christ as he was being crucified ("Son
column7: behold your Mother").  She is the Ark of the New Covenant and she leads her children to Christ as any good mother does
column8: but she is not a Goddess to be worshipped and the church has never taught that she should be worshipped
column9: only venerated because she is the first Christian and a perfect Christian.  Mary was never GONE from the Church. She doesn't have to make a COMEBACK. Mary was never minimalized or whatever cockamaymie words Spretnak uses.

Immortel (ad vitam) (Enki Bilal
column2: 2004)  While I was not overly impressed with Bilal's Nikopol Trilogy on the page
column3: I figured a film made out of it could be a pretty fun ride
column4: and with Bilal himself at the helm
column5: I had high hopes for it. Most of them
column6: unfortunately
column7: were dashed in the first few minutes.  The one thing everyone agrees on is that the film looks quite nice. And it does-- some of the CGI faces are so realistic they put me in mind of the best scenes in the Final Fantasy film. And the integration of actual actors and CGI characters is often seamless. The "sets
column8:
though, are second-rate Bladerunner wannabes. There was a lot of potential in them, and most of it was wasted.  The acting, even when delivered by some pretty high-powered acting talent (Charlotte Rampling, for example), is atrocious. The two main actors, Linda Hardy (who, aside from this, has yet to land a major role) and Thomas Kretschmann (soon to be seen  in the film adaptation of The Celestine Prophecy) are both wooden. Rampling injects a touch of vivacity into her role now and then, but it's not nearly enough.  The plot is... well, I can definitively say there is a plot. And that it is, in fact, connected to the Nikopol Trilogy in some way. But when you don't meet the character of Nikopol until half an hour into a hundred-minute film, that should tip you off that things aren't staying completely faithful to the book. There are scenes you'll recognize, if you've read the Nikopol Trilogy, but I can tell you from experience: having read it does not make this movie any more lucid. In fact, it may add to the confusion.  In short, aside from the visually appealing aspect, I can't find a single thing about this movie to recommend to, well, anyone.  
 If your main objective, is the study of human relationships, social rapports between humans, and conquering and seducing other people, this movie is for you.  Not an embarrassing movie, at all, for any of the actors. Just, a nutty story, and enfatuation of the author of the script with people, relationships, seduction, etc.   This is not to say that the above aspects are unimportant. Not true. Just that, perhaps a movie about such a theme might be more fun for some people than others

column4: it has since been superceded by "Enter the Kettlebell" in which Pavel contradicts himself.)  I was confused by the many typographical errors with whole paragraphs being repeated out of sequence in non-related chapters and the lack of photographs required to do a good job of conveying how to properly execute the various movements.  This could be quite dangerous for the trainee who doesn't have the time
column5: money or inclination to spend $1500-2000 to take a beginners kettlebell course.  Surely this must be a Russian plot to bilk hard-working Americans out of their money and send them on a mission of useless training programs?  I got the distinct impression that Pavel's books are written in serial fashion to either 1) convince you that you MUST take a "certified" kettlebell course or (2) get you to buy more expensive books or (3)get you to buy expensive DVD's. column1: This book has the noblest of intentions
column2: and I cannot fault either its authors or the women they interviewed for trying to help men understand women better. Unfortunately
column3: a better title for it would be "What Some Women Want Men To Think They Want"
column4: because the book's approach to answering its title question is flawed. It assumes that women say what they mean
column5: especially when they are told that their responses will be read by an audience they hope to influence for their own ends. And it assumes that women themselves know just what they want
column6: which few of us
column7: male or female
column8: actually do (when I mentioned this book to a female friend
column9: she asked me to let her know what women wanted when I was through reading it
column10: because she and all her female friends had no idea).  That is not to say that the book is devoid of helpful advice
column11: because there is some good stuff here
column12: particularly that given in the "Can She Ex?lain It" sections. Kate Fillion's contribution
column13: for example
column14: which pointed out the impossible standard women today are called upon to meet
column15: was fascinating and eye-opening. But in general the quality of advice in "What Women Want" varies widely; the emphasis on respect and communication can only help men in marriages or other committed relationships
column16: but the advice on how to meet and court women is useless in the extreme and could well be read as advice for men on how NOT to get a date (though celibate guys can use it to make female friends who will see them as one of the girls).  There is a further flaw that must be mentioned: it is clear that the authors do not understand men
column17: for this book assumes that all men are the same and want the same things. Even as it attempts to convince men of the complexity of women
column18: it ignores the fact that men are no less varied
column19: which diminishes its value for much of its intended audience. The "guy-talk" tone is often irritating
column20: and never helpful.  The greatest value of "What Women Want" does not lie in its advice but in its very failure to accomplish what it set out to do
column21: and with a little digging we can see just why it all went so wrong. There is no doubt but that the women interviewed in this study thought they were answering the questions honestly
column22: just as there is also no doubt that the behavior of women in the real world frequently does not match those answers. Part of the reason for this is
column23: I believe
column24: our society. America is the wealthiest nation in world history
column25: and we are all
column26: men and women alike

column28: not reality
column29: dominates gender relations in America today
column30: and this leads to unrealistic expectations about the behavior of our partners
column31: even as the fantasy of perfection cripples our ability to communicate (if Leonardo DeCaprio and Jude Law don't have to have intimate talks with their lovers
column32: why should we?). The comments in this book are a prime example: men must be perfect
column33: like the heroes in romance novels (correctly called female porn by the authors)
column34: or they will be discarded and ridiculed. Many women
column35: like many men
column36: judge potential partners based on how well they match up to criteria developed in sexual fantasy
column37: not reality
column38: and so real partners will never measure up. And because society tells us daily that the "customer is always right"
column39: it makes sense that the women interviewed in "What Women Want" seem to feel that they bear no responsibility for their own happiness
column40: as according to this book it is always men who must compromise
column41: but never women.  Ultimately
column42: then

However his attempt to compare the prison garb style to the previous styles is like comparing apples to oranges.  A zoot suit was compared to a conservative suit.  The prison garb should be compared to a simple pair of jeans with a belt.  The youth are not in "sympathy dress".  They are dressing in a trend with no meaning

I think we should embrace our youth and the poor.  However if they are taught as Dr. Dyson does in this book that you're okay where you are and with what you're doing

column1: Joe Carpenter lost his wife and two daughters when the plane they were traveling in crashed. A year later Joe is still grieving

Joe can't figure why they would be so happy. Then the family members start commiting suicide.   Joe decides to go back to the place where is plane crashed since he has not been able to face it before now. He meets a family at a ranch near the crash site. column1: The flight into New York had been a long one; but I was gently revived when Kirsten Dunst met me at the airport.  She was to be my escort that night at the Lincoln Center where the President would present me the Distinguished Writer's Cross-the highest award this nation can bestow on an author.  I quickly slipped my only suitcase in the backseat and sat next to her as she drove her Mercedes S class sedan to the Waldorf Astoria downtown.  "I have to admit that I didn't you who you were until I read STARLESS GRASSLANDS.  I don't mean to embarrass you; but that book changed my life."  I tried to be polite and gracious toward the compliment.  For the remainder of the trip we had a nice conversation while I approved the fluid motion of her hands and legs as she maneuvered the controls of the automobile.  I very much approved of her legs.  As I departed the car
column2: Kirsten leaned toward the open door to catch my eyes.  "Don't forget.  I'll be by at seven so we can go to the ceremony together.  Please be ready."  I expressed gratitude for her generosity and promised to be waiting for her seven sharp.  The hotel staff greeted me and soon I entered the elevator for a quiet ride to the eighty sixth floor. column1: I think that Cole is trying to explain something big here. You'll wait at least 50 pages before you start learning real science. It must have been fun for Cole to play with the idea of nothing in riddle-like prose
column2: but it really takes away from the science of the book. I say skip to the bibliography and read the books cited. They may be more concise

column1: I reluctantly give this book one star only because it provides some interesting information. Please be aware

column4: such as the source of the phrase "bobe mayse." However

I was extremely upset that he presumed to speak for anyone but himself and did not clarify that he was doing so.   The most egregious example concerns his comments about "goyim." He starts by referring to a "goyishe kop" which according to him means an idiot or simpleton
column6: rather than someone who does not necessarily think the same way a Jew might (and why should a non-Jew think like a Jew
column7: when their experiences may be vastly different?). He then writes
column8: "On the great chain of Yiddish being
column9: gentiles fall somewhere between Francis the Talking Mule and Bigfoot
column10: and goy is almost always as much as to say uneducated
column11: uncouth
column12: uncircumcised--". In my opinion
column13: this  inflammatory statement marks Wex himself as decidedly uncouth
column14: although apparently educated and perhaps circumcised. I don't know why he chose to make statements like these
column15: but he does NOT speak for anyone but himself. In the glossary he translates "goy" as "non-Jewish man" ("goye" being the female equivalent). I was astonished that he did not provide the literal translation
column16: which is "nation." Look up
column17: for example
column18: Exodus 19:5
column19: in which God tells Moses to tell the people of Israel: "Now therefore
column20: if you will obey my voice and keep my covenant
column21: you shall be my own possession among all peoples... [6] and you shall be to me a kingdom of priests and a holy nation." The Hebrew for "nation" is "goy."   Further
column22: in Exodus 34:10: "And he said
column23: 'Behold
column24: I seal a covenant. Before your entire people I will do marvels
column25: such as have never been created in the entire world and among all the nations'..." -- the Hebrew for nations is "goyim."  So non-Jews are no more nor less than parts of goyim/nations
column26: and Jews are part of a goy/nation called the Children of Israel. Therefore
column27: a Jew is just as likely as a non-Jew to behave like an idiot; and since Jews have been charged by God to keep His covenant in order to be considered His people
column28: it is perhaps less forgivable when a Jew behaves badly.   The author's comments in the next few pages about "shikses" are equally abhorrent
column29: but I will aggravate myself no further with attempts at clarification. I hope readers understand that they should read this book with caution

column1: Other reviews of this book have done a good job of summarizing its thesis
column2: which is that dogs were "previously" bred for physical labor and are now primarily in the business of serving their owners' emotional needs.  I've really enjoyed some of Katz's previous books.  I am not a "dog person
column3: but I have found his analysis of dog/human interactions to be well-documented and surprising. This book, however, was a big disappointment. Katz provides little evidence for his historical generalizations, and, by focusing largely on suburban owners who have unbalanced relationships with their canines, he overstates the significance of the new work" he identifies for dogs.   Katz focuses almost exclusively on middle-class American dog owners
column4: with little attention to urban dwellers (save one chapter)or rural dog-owners who still use their dogs for farm labor or hunting
column5: not "show" sheepherding.  What about dogs in other countries and locales
column6: who still perform work in a variety of contexts?  We don't even have to leave the US for examples.  How are dogs in Alaska or Wyoming or the Jersey Pine Barrens different from dogs in the smug 'burb of Montclair?   Dogs have labored as part of the family for centuries
column7: and they still do in many parts of the world.  But that doesn't mean they also haven't served as loved and loving companions as well. Literature from previous eras is full of examples of how domestic pets have meant more to their humans than just "go get the sheep
column8: Spike."  (And not just in children's books; check out poet Christopher Smart's seventeenth-century poem "In Praise of my Cat Geoffrey.")  Katz doesn't talk about the history of dog/human relationships in depth; he simply argues by assertion that dogs were "previously" used for physical labor and are are "now" primarily engaged in emotional labor.  I think a wider perspective and a "both/and" focus would be more informative for Katz to pursue. Today
column9: serving humans' emotional needs may be the primary task of suburban dogs - but it's not the ONLY THING. Sometimes humans' relationships with dogs are balanced rather than pathological or subtly abusive (like many of the owners he portrays in his book).  Some dogs aren't just "used" by humans
column10: but develop powerful attachments to people - in spite of Katz's assertion
column11: based on advice from a breeder friend
column12: that dogs will forget a vanished human almost immediately.  Finally:  when humans observe emotional responses in animals
column13: this doesn't necessarily mean we're anthropomorphizing.  Perhaps emotions aren't a uniquely human province.  Perhaps humans as a species aren't as exceptional as we like to think we are. Perhaps there is a much wider territory out there than Katz maps here.

column5: but you can stay "suspended" only so long until it becomes boredom.  The main character is the worst one Baldacci has ever created.  One minute she is crying her eyes out
column6: and puking her guts out totally paralyzed by fear
column7: and the next minute she is tracking down trained bad guys and saving the lives of the inept FBI agents and police.  This is repeated throughout the story.........I would think she had worn out all the emotional crap by the end of the book.  She makes one blunder after another resulting in the deaths of innocent people
column8: but at the same time comes up with brilliant deductions that help her stay one step ahead of the mastermind killers.  By the end of the book I found myself pulling for the sadistic killer to finally finish this stupid [...] off.    This is one of those books to keep next to the bed in case you are having trouble sleeping.

column1: Plain Truth
column2: set in Lancaster County
column3: Pennsylvania
column4: would be better entitled
column5: Fancy Lies. An eighteen-year-old Plain woman wakes up with labor pains
column6: gives birth in a calving pen
column7: cuts the umbilical cord and prays
column8: "Lord
column9: please make this go away." When she awakens and the baby is no longer with her
column10: she whispers
column11: "Denke
column12: and goes on with her day. Later, after the deceased body of an infant is found and the police are called to investigate, she tells them I didn't have a baby
column13:
as blood trickles down her leg. Without providing spoilers, two (of many) implausible situations follow. First, two women, one old, one young, both separately become pregnant through one act of intercourse, defying the odds of fertility. Second, a criminal defense attorney who made a name for herself getting an acquittal for an elementary school principal who molested six students is actually very maternal and willingly leaves big city life with a boyfriend of eight years to live on an electricity-free farm out of the kindness of her heart. In summary, a two-page italicized section mid-book along with the first and last chapters provide enough details of the basic plot to save the reader from 400 implausible pages. Those interested in reading just one book by Jodi Picoult should choose My Sister's Keeper. Chris Bohjalian's Midwives is better. 
 I'm really not sure how anyone could give this 'book' 4 or 5 stars???  Have any of you people writing these reviews actually seen other books on the medium.  Must be not.    It's just a small collection of tattoo photos with little or no text accompymining them and no theme or direction to the photos and 'book' at all.  Before I bought the book I was fooled by the rave reviews and the $6.00 price.  I'm thinking, 'How could a tattoo book with such great quality be only $6.00?'  Now I know.  Just like your Momma warned you, If it sounds too good to be true it probably is".  Moms was right.  Stay away from this book and do yourself a favor--go down to your local magazine shop and shell out the $5 or $6 for a quality tattoo mag.  You'll get about 10 times the bang for your buck.  If you really want a killer book on tattooing (albeit in the Japanese style) shell out the extra $$$ for Bushido.  Now that is what a book on tattooing should look like and read like.    This was garbage.

column1: I often cringed while reading Mancur Olson's Power and Prosperity. This book
column2: published posthumously
column3: lacks the clarity and force that are typical of the author's other works.  Olson sets out to explain why countries formerly under fascist governments have generally experienced economic growth while former socialist countries have not. He elaborates his "stationary bandit" theory of the state
column4: which argues that a government that is wholly self interested still has an incentive to provide some collective goods in order to increase the pot from which it can take. Olson then takes the reader through different examples
column5: derivations
column6: and implications of the stationary bandit theory. This is perhaps the best portion of the book.  Olson concludes that "incomes are low in most of the countries of the world
column7: in short
column8: because the people in those countries do not have secure individual rights". He believes that if rights are secure and well defined and if individuals are free from predation
column9: then economic growth will result from a market economy.  Alright. I agree with the conclusion
column10: but Olson does not succeed in building a compelling argument or in making clear why some countries are like this and others are not. Furthermore
column11: Olson quickly dismisses a world with no government without facing any of the best arguments in favor of anarchy. This keeps the reader wondering what "market-enhancing government" really means.  I highly recommend two of Olson's other books -- The Logic of Collective Action and The Rise and Decline of Nations. As for Power and Prosperity
column12: skip it entirely. I was surprised to see such a mediocre book from such a great mind
column13: and I can only guess this is the result of inadequate preparation due to his untimely death

column1: Many years ago I enjoyed reading Ivins' columns but unforunately her brand of independent liberalism has turned into just another mainstream media voice parroting the Democrats. Her personal hatred of George Bush has become distracting and embarrasing. Strangely enough she reminds me of Rush Limbaugh. When he began doing political commentary on the radio Limbaugh was an independent with a conservative streak and was comfortable attacking Republicans. Similarly Ivins was originally an independent with a liberal streak who was comfortable attacking Democrats. Now Limbaugh is as firmly ensconced in the Republican camp as Ivins is in the Democratic camp.  What a shame

column1: The introduction starts out with a defense of anthropomorphization as an important tool in scientific study

Her pregnant female dog is stressed so Thomas tries to soothe her telling her it is alright
column3: but the dog "doesn't believe" her-- alternative interpretation
column4: she reinforces the dog's anxiety by rewarding her
column5: and the dog stays anxious.  Duh.  You listen to her describe what she sees
column6: and then she launches into kookoo interpretations and ponder how she reached that conclusion.    One of the other reviewers gave higher marks because he viewed the book as a fascinating look into the pathology of Ms. Thomas as a nutcase.  I wish I had looked at it that way.  I spent way too much time venting at her stupidity.  I'm not quite as intensely offended about the responsibility implications of Ms. Thomas' book as other reviewers-- maybe I am not thinking globally enough.  Of course
column7: I certainly wouldn't leave my dog with her.

column4: Keynes totally disagreed with Lerner's approach.Keynes's approach is an advanced version of the cyclically balanced budget first laid out in clear terms to the Pharaoh by Joseph some 3
column5: 700 years ago-build up a surplus in the good years that will cover the deficits of the bad years.This is the first statement of what economists call a countercyclical fiscal policy.Keynes's additional provision is that the budget be split into two categories-one of which would be a capital budget.The government could only run deficits in the provision of capital projects in public infrastructure(building dams

column1: This book fails my simple test for utility: The writer never gets around to describing
column2: detailing
column3: or otherwise explaining how you can get the results she gets. The book comes without user instructions.   No clear schematic and instructions is a common problem with self-help books. Most people are oblivious to exactly what it is they do well because the behavior is habituated. Consequently they cannot transfer the process to others because the process is outside of conscious awareness.  The book reminds me of an infomercial. It's almost entirely testimonials about how wonderful life can be if youre "In the Flow." But it never maps how you get from HERE to the FLOW

column1: One of the first genres moviemakers turn to
column2: when wanting to stir up a little historical or emotional reflection
column3: is war.  Films about war make up some of the oldest in the history of the media
column4: many of them about battles that never took place.  But throw in a dash of historical accuracy here and there (and at the producers' discretion) and you have a recipe for "classic" status.  Exhibit A: "Zulu."  Nevermind that this is the retelling of a senseless battle fought in the name of British colonial expansion
column5: in which countless men died
column6: Brits and Africans alike.  Who cares that the Zulu empire was as oppressive and unforgiving as any tribe on the continent.  Forget that the ultimate outcome - "victory" at Ulundi - resulted in British control of Zululand and naturally
column7: a barbarous system of apartheid for the next 100+ years.  (As one reviewer pointed out
column8: the Africans who played extra roles in the 1964 film weren't even able to go see the movie under the current policies of apartheid.)  Nevermind all that.  Tally ho
column9: mates!  This is war
column10: and war is classic.  Gather round and hear a tale of glory
column11: courage and heroism... again.  Sure
column12: the heroes in question are fighting in the name of racism and greed
column13: but fighting bravely nonetheless.  And to counter any suggestion that the filmmakers condescend to the adversary
column14: the Zulus are presented as equally brave.  Yes
column15: bravery abounds.  After all
column16: what better match for the white man's unflinching imperative than another power-hungry
column17: merciless (but brave) army: that of the Zulus.  Make no mistake
column18: this war story is told from the perspective of the white minority in Southern Africa; there are no significant individual characters on the African side.  And looking at things from that angle
column19: one would have to spin the British effort in a somewhat positive light
column20: or never sleep another night.  But to pretend that it is accurate or just to arbitrarily assign themes like "glory" and "patriotism" to what adds up to brutal militarism
column21: is to deceive one's self utterly.  If anyone can tell me how the effort to defend British fortifications in South Africa in 1879 has made Africa (or the world) a better place
column22: I will gladly take it all back.    In the meantime
column23: filmmakers will continue to rouse passionate armchair patriotism
column24: recalling the brave men who sacrificed their lives for the greater good
column25: whatever that might have been.  Unfortunately
column26: it is the public willingness to accept these tales as accurate
column27: these missions as noble
column28: and these surges of testosterone as plenty justification
column29: that many more men and women will be needlessly sacrificed for years to come.  "Zulu" is indeed a classic war movie.  But ask yourself: is that always a good thing

column1: Albert Hourani's A History of the Arab Peoples is a widely regarded general history of the Arab world. This is too bad
column2: since as history the book is of low quality
column3: with significant problems of organization and
column4: where relevant to Hourani's apparent biases
column5: factual accuracy. It does have its redeeming elements
column6: but on the whole is for a variety of reasons not a reliable source as a general history of the Arab world
column7: especially for the beginner.  Being the author of a general history of the Arab world myself
column8: before I explain why I evaluate the book negatively I would like to suggest some alternatives
column9: lest I be accused of attacking a rival publication out of self-interest. Philip K. Hitti's The History of the Arabs is a very detailed history which runs from pre-Islamic times to the 19th century. Arthur Goldschmidt's Concise History of the Middle East covers Turkey
column10: Iran and Israel as well as the Arab world and is well-organized for beginners. It was the first general history of the Middle East I read as an undergraduate. Bernard Lewis' The Middle East focuses more on concepts and the flow of history but is also appropriate for those without a strong background in the region.  This book was first published in 1991. This review is based on the 1992 paperback version by Warner Books.  The initial weakness of this book begins with the very first chapter; although containing 458 pages of main text
column11: Hourani's history devotes a mere seven pages to the pre-Islamic period. This is pretty amazing
column12: for anyone familiar with that period
column13: since Arab history prior to Islam is roughly as long as Arab history after it. Exactly how far back Arab peoples go in history is a matter of dispute
column14: but certainly there were people one could call "Arabians" as far back as the beginning of the first mellinnium BC
column15: or 1
column16: 600 years prior to Muhammad. The evidence is sporadic for sure
column17: and no writer would give it equal prominence with later times
column18: but seven pages is pretty paltry.  One might suspect an Islamic bias here
column19: but the problem continues in the key early periods of Islam. The life of Muhammad and his immediate successors who established the basis for the Muslim world
column20: spanning about a half century from Muhammad's first vision to the death of his son-in-law and successor Ali
column21: get only 11 pages. The first Arab empire
column22: the Umayyads (661-950)
column23: gets seven pages
column24: and the Abbasid Empire (750-circa. 945)
column25: which is usually thought of as the "Golden Age of Islam
column26: gets only six. This means 37 pages for the first 2,000 years of Arab history, including its framing epoch, and over 400 pages for the next 1,000. This would leave the uninitiated reader entirely without much sense of proportion.  What makes this book highly unrecommended for the beginner is its weak sense of organization. The middle time period between the collapse of Abbasid authority - roughly AD 950 - and the ascendance of the Ottoman Empire over the Arab world in 1517 is intrinsically a difficult time period to understand and a more difficult one on which to write a history. This is due to the fact that rather than there being one dominant power or a few powerful states, there is instead a multiplicity of dynasties with genuine authority in some areas not extending beyond the town level with a multifarious mixture of Sunni and Shia, Arab, Persian and Turkic ruling groups, not to mention the Latin states. Hourani makes no serious attempt to help the reader keep all of it straight by moving from a chronological approach prior to 950 to a topical one. There are ten chapters covering this time period and the social history of part of the previous two periods (the Umayyads and the Abbasids). There is one chapter which discusses the major power struggles of the time. If you want to understand the relative historical roles of the Buyids, the Fatimids, the Zengids, the Ayyubids, the Mamluks and their contemporaries, read something else.  It is within these ten chapters that this book contains its major strength - its social history
column27: or its description of the development of the Arab world. In fact I cited Hourani on the social history sections of my own book. In this regard, Hourani really is better than the alternatives. Over 200 pages of the book is devoted to detailing various aspects of how the Arab world came to be prior to the Ottomans. So for those who have already read a general history of the Middle East or the Arab world and want a more specialized knowledge, these chapters are quite useful.  I have several objections to how this book handles a variety of issues of current interest. This book was written during a time period when there was a great emphasis on negating certain negative images of Arabs and Muslims, to the point of deemphasizing any aspect of the Arab world which might be interpreted negatively. The word jihad" doesn't even have an entry in the index
column28: although it is used
column29: or perhaps
column30: misused. On page 247
column31: Hourani describes a traditional view stipulating that the ruler has an obligation "to pursue jihad by maintaining the strength of the kingdom's defense..." This gives a misimpression
column32: because legally jihad has two military meanings - the defense of Muslim lands and the Muslim community's collective obligation to spread Islam through conquest. Although jihad has a spiritual as well as martial application
column33: its use is overwhelmingly in the military context
column34: and while Muhammad's battles probably could be described as defensive
column35: the vast majority of military actions between that time and the 19th century involved offensive operations (the Christian counter-offensives known as the Crusades being a major exception).  More broadly
column36: the single most influential Islamist movement of the modern age
column37: the Wahhabis
column38: get only a few scattered mentions
column39: and there is no real indication of the wave of extremism which by 1991 had been felt for some time. The primary non-Islamist ideological influence
column40: Marxism
column41: is discussed of course
column42: but the influence of Nazism during the 1930s and 1940s is left out. Nazi Germany is mentioned once in passing
column43: and in the same paragraph on page 331 Palestinian leader Amin Husseini is mentioned
column44: but it isn't mentioned that he was a strong supporter of Nazis
column45: that he moved to Germany during the Second World War and played an active role in the Holocaust
column46: or that despite this he was made leader of the Palestinian cause by the nascent Arab League after the war.  Hourani's account of the 1967 is incredibly inaccurate
column47: giving the impression that Egypt engaged in some bluster and then Israel started the war. He mentions Nasser's demand that the UN clear out of the Suez Canal zone
column48: and includes the defense pact with Jordan
column49: but omits a key fact - the mobilization of Egyptian forces in the Sinai. Once Egypt did this
column50: Israel had no choice but to attack
column51: because of its small population its economy could not handle an extended mobilization
column52: while Egypt could. Hourani also doesn't mention the statements by Arab leaders to the effect that all Jews would be wiped out in the coming war.  On the whole
column53: this is a useful book if one already has a framework understanding of Arab history and if one understands the slant that is being presented on issues of contemporary concern. Otherwise
column54: I do not recommend buying it

column1: Books of political position ought be fact ridden.  They should move you to the author's point of view
column2: if not the author's conclusions
column3: by marshalling facts first; then an author can supply analysis constrained by supplied facts.  Only then should we be given some further speculation
column4: unless moving directly to reasoned conclusions.  Mr. Horowitz does none.  Instead he starves us for facts.  He substitutes instead only editorial cant.  I can conclude only that he aspires to persuade no one.  The audience is not the inquiring
column5: the undecided or the doubting.    For example
column6: he contrasts
column7: on the first page the Iraq war as "so successful in its results."
column8: with the Vietnam conflict as an unsatisfactory result -- renaming in the process what we thought to be a war.  Mr. Horowitz insists on weapons of mass destruction in Iraq.  He states explicitly and blanketly that the execution of American power is a bulwark of national security.  He insists that American Presidents have been either the toys or the allies of terrorists.  I kept waiting for evidence of any kind.  He even says the twin towers were destroyed in only minutes
column9: yet were more important than Pearl Harbor.  My guess is that WW II was not so cheap or unworthy.  Neither were the more than sixty boys from my high school killed in the World Trade Center; at least I can reference Time magazine as the source.  Mr Horowitz cheapens their deaths by saying it was the work of Democrats allied with moslems in their struggle with the Neo-conservatives whose birthright is the unfettered use of American soldiers and guards.    Mr. Horowitz has plenty of notes of a sort.  Many are only self-referential as opposed to supportive from other sources.  He quotes the New York Review of Books
column10: but leaves out words he does not like.  Oddly he describes 9/11 as putting the Bush administration "on the run".  He probably meant something else
column11: but is simply incapable of precision and accuracy in general.  I cannot even recommend the book to those who oppose his purposes because they are so incoherently hysterical

column1: This has to be one of the worst casebooks I have ever read. The biggest complaint I have is that
column2: for some reason
column3: the author feels compelled to reveal the entire legislative history for every statute or immigration guideline. So if you are studying INA 237(x)(x)(x) you will not only get the very recent changes that led up to the statute
column4: but the last 30 years of history. For true scholars of the law who have nothing better to do with their lives than read irrelevant legislative history I am sure this will please them. For actual law students who think succinctness is a virtue
column5: stay away. Another minor problem is that the author has failed to label his notes. Labeling notes is a very common practice and is very helpful in summarizing what the note is about without having to first read it. Of course
column6: I find the very subject of immigration law to be about as boring a class in law school as I have ever taken so maybe this casebook is just making the best out of a bad situation

column1: This book is almost useless for helping someone understand how to use acupressure to alleviate physical symptoms. As a licensed massage therapist who already knows quite a bit about acupressure
column2: I am always willing to learn  more about any kind of bodywork. I had hoped to be able to pass on some ideas to my clients for self help but this book was definitely not it. The book gives some accupoints for specific problems
column3: some of these are "golden points" able to stand alone in use
column4: but others are not. The book gives no order to use these in and furthermore does not specify if all or any of the points are to be used together in sequence
column5: or not. Also
column6: it does't tell where the points are EXACTLY. There are really too many flaws to go into here. Acupressure is very complex
column7: this book tries to simplify it to the point that it looks like some goofy folklore advocating some bad mojo

column1: Although there are a few good recipes
column2: I found this cookbook to be disappointing overall.  I'll start off with the good: The lemon tart recipe is not only delicious
column3: but a breeze to make and worth the price of the book.  The chocolate sorbet is also delicious.  The quality of the paper and photographs are excellent
column4: with many beautiful color photographs illustrating the finished product.  Now the bad:  There is at least one glaring typographical error in this book.  The recipe for Linzer Cookies calls for over 2 sticks of butter
column5: 1 cup of hazelnut flour and 1/3 cup of flour.  These proportions simply do not work.  I had to add at least 1 1/2 cups of flour to prevent the cookies from melting into puddles of butter in the oven.  Given that the cover price is $35.00 and the author is a prominent N.Y.C. pastry chef
column6: this alone justifies the two star rating.  There simply should not be any recipes whose failure is not attributable to any individual person's taste preferences but to incorrect ingredient proportions.  In addition
column7: for what it's worth
column8: three other recipes that I tried (Apricot Tea Cakes
column9: Pineapple Tea Cakes

by Dorie Greenspan instead

 i've been reading the reviews for this book, and I wanted to offer up my own opinion.  I first read this book as part of my high school 11th grade english cirriculum.  And as a warning to others, I just wanted to say that reading this book was like watching paint dry.  There is no structure, and after a while it seems like your just reading page after page but are retaining nothing.  Though there are some very interesting funny parts in the books, the overall dullness of it all overpowers the good.  At some points, I wanted to claw my eyes out in despair.   I admit, I do love Mark Tawin, but this is in Noo sense, his best work.   Ones again, this is just my opinion.  Read it and see for yourself

Mr. Irving is a renowned writer who has pleased readers with books like
column2: The World According to Garp
column3: Prayer for Owen Meany and Cider House Rules.  There is a creativity about his writing and a quirkiness in his characters that I find appealing.  What happened here?  I was so mired down in wordiness and child sexual abuse that my commitment to the book ended with the protagonist's early grade school sexual experiences.  If somebody walked into a person's home and found drawings of what was verbalized in the book
column4: they would probably consider the individual a pedophile and his home would be marked on public records as housing a pervert.  It seems strange that a brilliant writer could go on ad infinitum
column5: describing the same things in words and be considered worthy of praise.  Anything the book had to offer was lost on me because I couldn't get past being inundated with pages and pages dedicated to pathetic images of a young boy's penis; crude and rude
column6: abusive adolescent girls; and body hair fetish.  Maybe had I been pulled in enough to read further
column7: I would have found redeeming value in Until I find You.  As it played out for me
column8: the book is not worthy of John Irving.

column1: I suppose I'm going to be alone in these reviews in complaining loudly about Ellis's stylistic sloppiness.  I recall a particularly amusing section in the introduction in which he describes Jefferson's message in the Declaration as "a recipe for anarchy
column2: and proceeds to note that a government which attempted to operate in accordance with these principles would be committing suicide."  Yes
column3: Joseph
column4: a government attempting to implement no government would be doing itself in.  Is this what passes for lofty criticism these days?  I picked up this book in an effort to become more interested in--and more fair to--Thomas Jefferson.  I went in believing him to be a cold
column5: conniving man whose life was a long exercise in "do what I say
column6: not what I do."  This book did nothing to change that impression; if anything changed
column7: it was my opinion of Ellis
column8: of whom I'd had somewhat higher hopes.  His writing is not nearly good enough to cover up his attempted slights of hand in excusing Jefferson's worst characteristics; in my book
column9: "psychological agility" isn't distinguished from hypocrisy--it IS hypocrisy.    The book's tone reminded me rather startlingly of the modern theory texts I was once forced to read; full of unprovable suppositions and distinctions without differences.

column1: Apparently the difference between a criminal act (theft) and moral redistribution of income is 1) who you steal from (stealing from the wealthy
column2: of course
column3: is moral -- according to Rawls and Bolsheviks)
column4: and 2) who receives the loot (the non-wealthy makes it moral)
column5: and 3) who commits the act (the state/society
column6: of course also makes theft moral; example - taxation)
column7: and 4) your intentions (redistribution of income). To look at this another way
column8: if your neighbor breaks into your house and steals your money
column9: that's a crime (unless your neighbor is poor -- which would then be moral and Justice
column10: according to Rawls' formula). If the community comes into your house and steals from you
column11: it's legal and moral Justice
column12: again
column13: according to Rawls. Because
column14: according to Rawls
column15: if
column16: before you were born
column17: you were to vote with everyone on how physical world society should be structured
column18: you'd vote to have the state guarantee that everyone was equal
column19: or they would be compensated somehow for being born (unjustly) less-equal. How? By compensating those with less by stealing from those with more. So those with more would be like oh
column20: say ... a milk-cow who gets milked to serve those with less. So those with more would become a resource
column21: or state-owned slaves to those with less ... because "society" (the Robin Hoods and Rawls of the world) deemed this as moral Justice. Rawls does not take into account those who are willing to take on risk
column22: entrepreneurs
column23: students of life who work to earn an "A" vs. students who earn an "F". He points out that many people are born into difficult situations through no fault of their own. True. But that does not implicate those within society who are born into better situations as the cause
column24: nor are those who are born into better situations responsible for making up the difference. Forcing the "wealthier" ones to be accountable for the unfairness within life and pay the bill isn't Justice or moral. It would simply be an unjust law. Some people see Rawls' theory as a blueprint for a future generation utopia (like the Bolsheviks envisioned Marxism). I see it as an insane blueprint for slavery
column25: and a powerful dis-incentive for earning personal reward and merit. In a sense
column26: this book is an argument against the individual. It sees the world through a blurred lense where the author only recognizes masses of people -- he doesn't recognize any individuals (unless they were born as victims). Curious. How do you experience life ... as a group-mind (an oxymoron if there ever was one)
column27: a collective? Or as a unique
column28: isolated
column29: independent
column30: individual? There should be societal incentives to help each other. Okay. But when it is forced (theft of property always implies force)
column31: it is no longer an issue of morality or justice -- it's simply a law. Without personal choice being involved there is no morality as an issue
column32: by definition. Transforming advantaged individuals into mules forced to carry the burdens of the world is a definition of justice for whom?

column1: It is movies like this that make me wonder if the writers/directors/producers of these Lifetime movies think about what they are implying before they just fling it up on the screen. Here we have "Odd Girl Out" the story of a high school girl who a popular clique of mean girls turn against and make her life a living hell by calling her fat and easy. And with that basic concept the filmmakers decide to call for fascism all because of their ridiculous slippery slope theory. In the world they live in
column2: to pick on a fellow student leads directly to said student attempting suicide. Further more
column3: their idea of a happy ending is when the principal steps in and outlaws teasing (so much for free speech). Plus
column4: all this is on top of the fact that the victim in question
column5: Vanessa (Alexa Vega)
column6: is weak
column7: needy
column8: and straight up duuuuum. The only reason the torture in allowed to endure for the entire film is because she keeps begging for it. Of course the general idea is that she just needs the approval of her peers so much that there is no limit to the amount of times she will let them crush her. Throughout the film the aggressors keep sending her links to a "Hating Vanessa" website. Vanessa
column9: dim bulb that she is
column10: not only takes part in her own abuse by opening them
column11: also acts genuinely shocked by what she finds and bursts out into tears. Late in the film one character makes the fairly obvious observation of "She is so pathetic." This comes after Vanessa has cut off her hair
column12: showed up to a nonexistent party
column13: skipped school to avoid the harassment
column14: and ODed on sleeping pills all while pining to be best friends with the popular girls in school. . .so it goes without saying that I agree with the statement.  The filmmaking itself was textbook Lifetime schlock. They take an issue they don't like and attack it with a stone cold seriousness. It is kind of like a Public Service Announcement only 180 times longer and minus the camp value. I would argue that their fear of anything light does hurt the point they are trying to make. For instance
column15: the girls doing the bullying were painted as spawns of Satan without any appealing qualities. Why would Vanessa want to hangout with these humorless droids. In "thirteen" Nikki Reed's character was at least somewhat cool. It also follows the exact same formula of every other film just like it. Girl has cool friends
column16: cool friends turn against girl
column17: we're supposed to feel bad that girl doesn't get to have cool friends any more. I was a victim of bullying in school (who wasn't) and I think that I am a stronger person now because of it. Our public school system now only peddles uniformity not education
column18: so all these kids can hope to really learn is people skills. How to deal with bullies
column19: office politics
column20: etc. After all
column21: suffering makes us who we are. And for these irresponsible filmmakers to serve up the idea of limiting free speech just to prevent hurt feelings to an audience not known for their free thinking skills is borderline evil **1/4

column1: I reviewed this book a few years ago
column2: and I came back to see what meaningful might have been said in the interim. The answer echoes back from the Internet
column3: "Nothing significant." So here are the basic points once again:  1. This book was NOT originally written by Kenneth Hagin. It was written by CMA minister and missionary John A. MacMillan as "The Authority of the Believer." Hagin's original book had the exact same title.  2. Not only did the book have the same title
column4: it had - literally - most of the exact same words
column5: the only exceptions being the self-authenticating stories that were a Hagin specialty.  3. This is the book where Hagin claims that he cast out a demon that was interfering with a personal message from 'Jesus.' Jesus looked at Hagin and said
column6: "If you hadn't done that
column7: I couldn't have done anything about it." Jesus COULDN'T have done anything about it? I'm guessing the cessationists are right: Jesus somehow lost his zip over the last 2
column8: 000 years. I mean

column1: Before I review
column2: I'd like to clear something up: I am a very latecomer in seeing this movie. I was introduced to the Ghost in the Shell franchise through the new Anime series airing on Adult Swim
column3: Ghost in the Shell: Standalone Complex. I absolutely love that show
column4: and so I figured eventually I'd have to get around to seeing the movie
column5: which I knew full well shares no connection with the show. They're both seperate interperetations of the comic series of the same name
column6: (which I have not read
column7: so I don't know which is more accurate) but the TV series is exponentially better than this movie in almost every concievable way.  There are many things I don't like about this movie
column8: the biggest being poor pacing. The plot for the movie is actually surprisingly straightforward once you cut away all the filler
column9: but that's the biggest problem. There's not really enough story to last a full-length feature
column10: because it seems almost like it was originally written with the intention of being a 30 minute short. And since they didn't have the budget to load the movie up with action scenes (there are barely any
column11: and they aren't very impressive for the most part) they had to slow the story down with drawn out conversations that you won't understand more than 60% of
column12: and camera shots that last for what feels like minutes where we're looking at either nothing
column13: or a woman's nipples. That's not cinematic artistry
column14: that's being either lazy or perverted.  The animation itself isn't even that good
column15: especially considering that this is was a theatrical release from only 10 years ago. It's choppy
column16: and there's not really a whole lot of detail (except when it comes to women's nipples). Looking at just the animation
column17: if I didn't know better
column18: I'd have thought this movie was an OVA from the 1980's.  The only thing I can really say I liked about this movie was that it was Ghost in the Shell. It's probably kind of like how I didn't see the 1989 Batman movie until years after I'd been spoiled by Batman the Animated Series
column19: and couldn't bring myself to like it for any reason other than that it was Batman. Everything about the TV series is superior to this movie: the animation
column20: the stories
column21: the character developement
column22: the production values... I could go on for an entire page about how much better the TV series is.  In short
column23: if you're you're at all interested in the GITS franchise
column24: do yourself a favor and rent the DVDs of the TV show instead. You'll find a lot to love
column25: but I can't say the same about the movie. My dream is that someday Alex Proyas will give us a GITS movie that lives up to what I would hope for after watching Standalone Complex

column1: Reading the first chapter was the only time I actually enjoyed this book. Everything went downhill afterwards
column2: when I realized this was just a retelling of Emily Bronte's Wuthering Heights. Wuthering Heights is a well-told classic
column3: timeless
column4: raw
column5: and beautiful. Here On Earth
column6: however
column7: is just a poor rendition
column8: very contrived
column9: no spontaneity whatsoever.  The almost-complete cast of characters in Wuthering Heights is present in Here On Earth. I don't remember the names of the characters in Here On Earth but I remember their counterparts pretty well. There's your modern-day version of Catherine Earnshaw
column10: there's the modern-day counterpart of her brother Hindley. Then there's the counterpart of Heathcliff! Surprise! Surprise! A foundling with a dark and ominous character! And then there are the neighbors: the counterpart of Edgar Linton (whom Catherine's counterpart marries)
column11: and the counterpart of Isabella Linton (whom the counterpart of Heathcliff marries). And then there's the counterpart of Catherine Jr (Catherine-counterpart and Edgar-counterpart's daughter)
column12: who falls in love with cousin counterpart of Hareton (son of Hindley's counterpart). There's also Nelly Dean's counterpart
column13: and Linton Linton's counterpart
column14: but that's all I'm going to say. Those of you who've read and loved Wuthering Heights
column15: you know the rest.  It's a sad thing that this is the first Alice Hoffman novel I've read. I'm now inclined to ignore the rest of her novels. Maybe. Or I might be open to her other novels if I've finished reading all the other books I really wanted to read first

column1: Ballard makes several keen insights in this book (many of them startlingly prescient).  However

column3: their motives
column4: and the surrounding events.  And perhaps that was intentional
column5: but it doesn't make for a satisfying read.  "The Assasination of John Fitzgerald Kennedy Considered as a Downhill Motor Race" was one of the few bright spots in the narrative
column6: but not quite bright enough for me to consider this book as anything more than a failed experiment

column1: There is some very helpful information in here about how a woman's cycle works. I would be very cautious
column2: however
column3: about the nutrition information. Here is my story:  I was ovulating every 16-18 days with a 11-day luteal phase. Hoping to ovulate closer to every 14 days and lengthen my luteal phase
column4: I began taking the vitamin Optivite
column5: so heavily recommended in the book. I took Optivite for four months
column6: and in that time I would either ovulate extremely late--30+ days followed by a 9 or 10 day luteal cycle-- or NOT AT ALL.   For whatever reason
column7: I didn't immediately connect my ovulation problems with taking the Optivite (seems so obvious now). Then I read something from another source about how excess vitamin A can inhibit ovulation. I then QUIT taking Optivite. My first cycle off of Optivite
column8: my ovulation returned to normal-- and THAT IS WHEN I FINALLY GOT PREGNANT.  It may be that Optivite has helped other women who were really deficient in some of those vitamins. But
column9: in my case
column10: I guess I was healthy to begin with
column11: and it just screwed with my body

column1: Roberts' little fable pits a wholly benign free-trade against absolute protectionism and guess which one looks better.  Based on the theories of David Ricardo
column2: the fable assumes that every worker in the world is always treated fairly and every boss is kind and responsible.  In The Choice there are no sweat shops and no corrupt CEOs.  Fables like The Choice (or the "free-market economy" for that matter) are easy to believe because we want the world to be that simple.  That's why the book is dangerous.  The Choice has almost nothing to do with the real world
column3: but it sounds good.  The argument is so seamless that it appears almost unassailable.  If you buy Roberts' version of Ricardo
column4: however
column5: you must accept Wal-Mart as the epitome of business virtue.  Roberts may be a great guy
column6: and he certainly writes well.  Unfortunately
column7: his book begins with a series of fallacious premises and works its way toward a conclusion that is simple
column8: elegant
column9: and horribly wrong
