column1: "Well-behaved women rarely make history
column2: a quote by Laural Thatcher Ulrich, American Historian, are the first words of this book.  That may very well be, but I don't think we have to try so hard to show children just how shocking some of our famous women were!  Lives of Extraordinary Women is a compilation of twenty short biographies of important women in the world's history: such well-known names as Joan of Arc, Marie Antoinette, and Harriet Tubman, as well as lesser-known individuals such as Nzingha, Gertrude Bell, and Aung San Suu Kyi.  Although it looks like biographies, there is really little intellectual value to the book.  It is merely a hodgepodge of trivia and unrelated gossip.    The first chapter is called Cleopatra: Life at the Library."  Now
column3: you would think that this would explore her love of reading and dertmination to build a world-famous library in Alexandria.  Instead
column4: it is all about her numerous love-affairs
column5: particularly the one with herself
column6: experimenting with hairstyles
column7: make-up
column8: and perfume.  The author tells us
column9: "...she coped with the required marriage to her ten year-old brother.  He turned up drowned
column10: and another one was poisoned."    There is a chapter on Nzingha - a West African queen.  Some important aspects of her life we just must know are: "Rumor had her also murdering her nephew - and eating his heart
column11: and ...she kept fifty young men as bodyguards...she made her favorites wear women's clothes."    It gets even better!  We simply can't live without knowing that Catherine the Great's husband
column12: Peter
column13: "heaped abuse on her
column14: tortured their dogs...and brought his toy soldiers to bed
column15: forcing her to participate in mock military maneuvers."    If the purpose of this book is to sensationalize the names of women in history

column17: however

column23: and interesting table of contents

column1: This book is *very* selective in the issues it takes on.  Now my review may well be seen as pointless whining
column2: because it is quite common in the feminist movement for people to get irritated that their own causes are not well represented.  However
column3: I so strongly believe this to be the case here that I'm going to complain anyway.  The feminist issues I care about most are rape and child sexual abuse (which often includes rape
column4: but not always).  Guess what:  they are barely mentioned.  Rape is mentioned twice:  once in the context of abortion
column5: and once in the context of violence against women.  It gets a cursory listing along with a bunch of other types of violence
column6: such as domestic violence and hate crimes.  Both these exceedingly brief listings give a very false picture of what rape is.  It is not a situation that usually leads to abortion:  the majority of rape victims do not become pregnant.  Some do
column7: but most do not.    Also
column8: rape is not an issue of violence against women.  It is an issue of violence from the powerful directed at the powerless.  So women
column9: children (of both sexes
column10: girls more often
column11: but boys as well) and powerless men
column12: such as those in prison
column13: are victims.  Rape victims (as reported by the Justice Department) tend to be quite young
column14: with the vast majority under age 30
column15: a large percentage under age 20
column16: and an all-too-high number of children under age 12.  Viewing this as "violence against women" when so many of the victims are children or teenagers
column17: obscures the issue.  But if this book is a guide
column18: the feminist movement doesn't care at all about rape/child sexual abuse victims
column19: and they are not discussed.  None of the excellent books out there are listed (and there are many far more recent than The Courage To Heal

column1: The author is a biologist
column2: but wasn't able to explain the science behind the story in a way that I could follow.  That's not usually fatal
column3: since I'm used to being left behind when the hard scientists start talking
column4: but it certainly doesn't help. And I remain puzzled by her creatures who have only two genders although their DNA is a triple helix.  She tried to explain the mating and reproduction
column5: but it seemed forced and unneccessary.  Her prose
column6: at best is servicable.  Again
column7: it's not fatal (Asimov is no great sylist
column8: either)
column9: but the combination of impenetrable science and clunky writing kept getting in the way of the story.  The worst flaw is that her characters do not develop at all.  Most of the time I found myself simply not caring what happened to them
column10: particularly since they were pretty much either all good or all bad.  And there was never any doubt in my mind that the goodies would prevail.  The most interesting character--a six year old girl with a fantastic penchant for prime numbers--was introduced in the first sentence but soon was shuttled off to a mad scientist's lab and only appeared occasionally after that.  One of the reasons I managed to get all the way to the end was that I kept hoping she'd reappear and take center stage.  Not worth reading
column11: IMHO

column6: orthopedic soft goods
column7: braces
column8: supports
column9: hot/cold therapy items

column1: This book is pure heresy clothed in feel-good
column2: new age sounding terminology. The author blatantly states that he doesn't believe in the basic dogmas of the Christian faith
column3: such as the virgin birth
column4: the physical resurrection
column5: or what he calls the "traditional" redemption and atonement of Jesus Christ. He also does not take the bible at all literally. Granted
column6: there is much spiritual depth to scripture; however
column7: excessive spiritualizing of scripture can lead to this type of "enlightened" Christianity.  His concepts are not Christian
column8: but emphasize the divine nature of mankind while downplaying the role and true divinity of Christ. This is all subtly concealed under the guise of a re-interpretation of the "true" gospel message.  Anyone with even a cursory knowledge of scripture can see the errors in the author's observations and conclusions.   The author has dabbled in mysticism - unfortunately not Christian mysticism as experienced by the myriad of saints of the Roman Catholic Church. This book should in no way serve as a reflection of catholicism for anyone seeking to discover the true Roman Catholic faith.

It is not His bleeding that saved me

column149: February 22, 1857, from Hebrews 9:22. He describes the suffering and death of Christ, and says, Mark his brow-they have put about it a crown of thorns

column188: while what MacArthur has said is false. No one can deny that MacArthur is a gifted and talented speaker. He is the Senior Minister of Grace Cathedral
column191: and the popular speaker on the widely distributed radio broadcast entitled
column192: "Grace To You." He has built a tremendously large church
column193: and he has a very large radio audience. This is all the more reason why someone should expose his false teaching on the blood. No doubt we shall lose some friends over this exposure of error
column194: but we hold truth dearer than we do friends. The cause of truth must ever be first. -From Plains Baptist Challenger 8/86  JOHN MACARTHUR AND THE BLOOD OF CHRIST A few months ago a pastor friend and I visited a John MacArthur meeting in Vancouver
column196: and I purchased a copy of MacArthur's commentary on Hebrews with the desire to see exactly what he says about the Blood of Jesus Christ. This commentary was published in 1983 by Moody Press. Moody Bible Institute holds the copyright.  There can be no mistake about MacArthur's position that the Blood itself does not save us
column197: that the Blood is SYMBOLIC of death. Words could not be plainer. In a mere three pages of this book MacArthur uses the term "symbolic" no less than thirteen times:  "Blood is a SYMBOL of death
column198: and therefore follows closely the idea of a testator's having to die in order for a will to become effective. ...  "It is possible to become morbid about Christ's sacrificial death and preoccupied with His suffering and shedding of blood. It is especially possible to become unbiblically preoccupied with the physical aspects of His death. It was not Jesus' physical blood that saves us
column199: but His dying on our behalf
column200: which is SYMBOLIZED by the shedding of His physical blood. ...  "The purpose of the blood was to SYMBOLIZE sacrifice for sin
column201: which brought cleansing from sin. Therefore
column202: without shedding of blood there is no forgiveness.  "Again
column204: we need to keep in mind that the blood was a SYMBOL. If Christ's own physical blood
column207: how much less did the physical blood of animals. It is not surprising
column209: that the Old Covenant allowed a SYMBOL for a SYMBOL. ... This exception is clear proof that the old cleansing was SYMBOLIC. Just as the animal blood SYMBOLIZED Christ's true atoning blood
column210: so the ephah of flour SYMBOLIZED and represented the animal blood. This non-blood offering for sin was acceptable because the old sacrifice was entirely SYMBOLIC anyway.  "Yet this was the only exception. And even the exception represented a blood sacrifice. The basic SYMBOL could not be changed because what it SYMBOLIZED could not be changed. ... Since the penalty for sin is death
column213: can atone for sin. ... the only way we can participate in the New Covenant
column214: is through the atoning DEATH of Jesus Christ
column215: made effective for us when we trust in Him as saving Lord" (John MacArthur
column217: pp. 236- 238).  MacArthur's position on the Blood of Christ is a great heresy. It is precisely the same heresy promoted by the translator of the Today's English Version
column218: who replaced the term "blood" with "death" in most key passages.  Edit

column1: As the title says the book is rife with Catholic apologetics.  Catholicism is the touchstone used to compare pretty much every belief and "ism" to (i.e. protestantism
column2: arianism
column3: etc...) This review is not to make a case for or against Catholicism
column4: but to demonstrate the ludicrous "scholarship" of this work
column5: as opposed to what one would expect from any work claiming to be a "dictionary."  Instead of spending it's words on the historical aspects/development of a given belief
column6: the entries are dominated by apologias for
column7: or against
column8: said belief from the Catholic point of view.  This behavior is exemplified in the treatment of the Trinity doctrine entry
column9: and oddly
column10: a venomous attack on Jehovah's Witnesses  (while giving fair accounts to pretty much every modern religious movement that Catholicism generally deems: "heretical.").  The Trinity:  More than half of the entry is dedicated to exegesis of New Testament passages according to modern Trinitarian thought following the claim that (pg. 1394): "Though the word 'Trinity'.. is not found in Scripture
column11: the conception is there both implicitly and explicitly."  Also
column12: the very first sentence of the entry calls the Trinity doctrine: "The central dogma of Christian theology"
column13: however
column14: in providing an argument
column15: instead of historical facts
column16: the work relegates itself to the category of apologetics
column17: not scholarship.  As an argument
column18: it naturally downplays the significance of the opposing viewpoints
column19: in this case: the "heresy" of Subordinationism (a topic that doesn't even receive it's own entry in this "dictionary"!)
column20: its proponents
column21: Gnosticism
column22: and the prevalent Arianism.  The author violates the context of the historical development of what it calls "the central dogma of Christian theology" by glossing over centuries of the doctrines' development;  even going so far as to label some of the defenders and propagators (pre-Nicea) of early Trinitarian thought: "unorthodox" (despite the fact that "orthodoxy" hadn't been established yet). (pg. 1394 - "Where the doctrine was elaborated
column23: as e.g. in the writings of the Apologists
column24: the language remained on the whole indefinite
column25: and from a later standpoint
column26: was even partly unorthodox.  Sometimes it was not free from a certain subordinationism..")    On Christian Science (pg. 279): "Its teaching on the unreality of matter
column27: sin
column28: and suffering conflicts with the Biblical doctrines of the Creation
column29: Fall
column30: and Redemption."  The author fails to note that this is opinion (regardless if accurate or not).  Jehovah's Witnesses (pg. 729): "This Adventist teaching was developed by his successor
column31: J.F. Rutherford on lines professedly subversive of civil authority...  They can hardly be regarded as a religious society.."
column32: "Jehovah's Witnesses is an organization with printing establishments all over the world.  They carry on an effective propaganda among an uncritical public and attract esp. the dissatisfied elements of society by preaching hatred of all existing institutions."  Of the founder
column33: Charles Taze Russel
column34: the author again levels the charge of subversive teachings
column35: and again makes the implication that Witnesses are civically disloyal anarchists (pg. 1210): "His teaching... lends itself to political propaganda of a subversive type...  His ideas were developed in a still more anarchist direction by J.F. Rutherford."    Again

column1: I read someone's comments that "it's the world's worst phone" and I thought
column2: "Nah
column3: that can't be." Alas
column4: it is. Where do I begin?   Let's start with the fact that there's no caller ID on the base - so when the kids have left the phone in another room
column5: my wife or I cannot see who's calling... until we find the phone!  There's no blinking light to indicate that someone has left a message. If you step outside for a few minutes
column6: you have to remember to pick up the phone when you get back inside
column7: just to hear if someone called.   I was amused to see that when you silence the ringer - like when you're in the bedroom at night and your wife is sleeping - it cheerfully acknowledges your muting of it with a LOUD beep
column8: thereby waking up your loved one. Who says phone design people have no sense of humor?  Most serious
column9: though
column10: is the once-a-week flaking out
column11: where all the handsets suddenly display "Searching" (including the one that's sitting right in the base) and we cannot make calls. It took me awhile to figure out that we have to unplug the base from the A/C outlet for about 3 minutes. Then we can make calls again.  I notice that someone else mentioned the small size and that "it takes some getting used to". Well
column12: we never did - not even my daughters. For them
column13: trying to go over homework on the phone with a friend
column14: they cannot hold the little handset with their shoulders and go "hands-free" (and I sure can't
column15: either).  It's mind-boggling how the company tossed away so many good features of the previous line. That previous model is now discontinued
column16: according to Motorola themsselves. In fact
column17: they were the ones who talked me into "upgrading". (Never has a word been so misused). So
column18: this was our second
column19: and last
column20: Motorola  - though they do make nice cell phones!  I now have the latest Uniden cordless on order (the Consumer magazines say it's quite good) and will let y'all know about that one. Fingers crossed..

column1: If you're going to read one of the great classics of literature-and you should-don't pick up this edition.  It is a reprint of a version that dates back to the 1870s and was exposed more than 40 years ago for cutting nearly one-quarter of Verne's story and mistranslating much of the remainder.  Its reappearance in this edition is all the more amazing considering Tor's status as a leading science fiction publisher
column2: and the company's willingness to perpetrate this fraud on is many readers is truly stunning.  If you want to truly get to know Verne's novel
column3: pick up the elegant Naval Institute Press edition
column4: in a modern
column5: complete
column6: updated translation
column7: with commentary by the leading American Verne expert today
column8: Walter James Miller.  That book also comes with many of the artistic engravings that illustrated the original French first edition (no illustrations are to be found in the B&N Mercier reprint).  Less attractive but more academic is the Oxford Classics version of Twenty Thousand Leagues.  This review is posted on behalf of the North American Jules Verne Society by Jean-Michel Margot
column9: president NAJVS

column4: a youthful looking Kate Beckinsale (she has come a long
column5: long way since this film)

column7: "What other movie did I see that actor in?"  But the rest of the film fails to live up to this monumental promise.  For much of the movie it looks and feels like a made-for-television romp through medieval times.  It has a small cast of haggard-looking extras in peasant clothing
column8: royalty that
column9: if not for the crowns they wore
column10: would be indistinguishable from the common herd
column11: and some very predictable and flawed direction. The followers of the king
column12: peasantry included
column13: number about thirty in total and they all live in this small wooden village.  The director makes the mistake of using a large amount of voice-over narration to propel the story
column14: which by the end was whittled down to about 90 minutes of Masterpiece Theater shot in the countryside.  One scene has Hamlet dashing from a buring hall
column15: sword in hand
column16: but when he rounds the corner of a building his sword is missing; cut to the following scene of Hamlet confronting the new king
column17: his murderous uncle
column18: and the sword reappears in his hand.  That kind of blatantly poor film editing is unforgivable.  The acting ranges from good to passable
column19: but no amount of thespian zeal could have or did save this project from gradual diminishing returns.  Except for the sighting of a schoolgirl version of Kate Beckinsale
column20: prim and proper as all young lasses tend to be
column21: this film is sadly a waste of time and money.

column1: This is one of those books that appeal to the pretentious.  The author is self-conscious and clever and has obviously written it with literary critics and English teachers and the sort of pseudo-intellectual that hangs out in New York cafes in mind.  The actual story was the last thing on his mind and it shows--the whole thing is a pastiche with what plot there is used to parade his annoying characters (Camus or Satre heroes in Victorian dress) and to make annoying observations (all the last word in philosophy circa 1960 but really dull in 2006).  Nothing could be more contrived than the alternate endings that one must pick from.  The reader does not want to pick an ending
column2: to be truthful
column3: because the author has not made the reader CARE.  I think I will continue reading actual Victorian novels
column4: by the likes of Dickens
column5: Trollope and Eliot rather than ever bothering to re-read this nonsense

Berkhof's Systmatic is of course a classic text that is a gem.  I had the old Banner Of Truth edition for years but like a dope sold it for pennies on the dollar.  This edition from Eerdmans is truly abominable.    Where do I start?  First off
column2: the font size is terrible.  So if you are over 58 the eye strain is quite significant.  Then comes the print type.  It is almost as if someone churned out copies in his garage.  The printing is extremely bad.  Sentences contain words that after a letter or two turn light and then dark and in a few instances downright smudgy.  Was the typeset dirty?  Did you run out of ink?  True
column3: this edition contains Berkhof's introductory section which is a bonus.  But what good is it if the production quality is abysmal?  How unfortunate that such a magnificient work is so insulted.   Mr. Publisher
column4: check out Shedd's Dogmatic Theology by P and R Publishers.  That is how one presents a text of significance.    If you have the Banner Of Truth edition do not trade it in lest you rue the day.

column1: Like much of the rest of the Power Japanese series
column2: this book does a good job of introducing vocabulary that you may not find in other sources. However the vocabulary is so high level that beginning and intermediate learners will have a hard time memorizing it and using it in conversations. On the opposite end of the spectrum
column3: the book covers such a wide variety of specialized fields that the terms may be inadequate for an advanced learner. Advanced learners may be better served by reading books written for Japanese people about a particular subject. If you find books written for adults too difficult
column4: books written for children and teens may be helpful. Beginning and intermediate learners might impress some people by reading sentences out of this book
column5: but you'll probably never use a lot of this vocabulary
column6: and hence will probably forget it. There are better books to spend your money on

column1: As Abraham Rabinovich
column2: author of The Yom Kippur War: The Epic Encounter That Transformed the Middle East
column3: said: It is easy to be annoyed at this flawed attempt at a comprehensive account of the Six-Day war. But the book does carry the reader along and can serve as an introduction for those unfamiliar with that landmark event and
column4: also
column5: as a reminder for those who have forgotten.  The absence of a preface in which Bowen
column6: a BBC journalist
column7: should have spelled out what he was attempting to achieve and how he intended to go about it is an immediate warning of a lack of weightiness. Another sign is the absence of maps
column8: except for two unhelpful regional maps.  To his credit
column9: Bowen appears to have read dozens of the books written on the war
column10: including the most recent
column11: as well as relevant government archives
column12: particularly of the United States and United Kingdom. He has also interviewed military and civilian personnel on both sides although he does not indicate how many. But his account remains that of a journalist making notes from the sidelines
column13: not of a researcher who has immersed himself in the heart of the matter
column14: who can make informed assessments
column15: and has original insights to offer. He misses central elements in the story
column16: such as the fascinating objections in the Israeli cabinet to the capture of Jerusalem's Old City-and the Western Wall-by ministers from the National Religious Party
column17: who maintained that it was too politically and ideologically hot to handle; this from a party that would soon after spearhead Israeli settlement efforts.  The battle descriptions are incomprehensible
column18: and Bowen
column19: in searching for the illuminating detail or pregnant quote
column20: more often ends up with banality and schmaltz. Nevertheless
column21: there are interesting glimpses of the players
column22: particularly in the Egyptian camp. Bowen's description of how Egypt and the Arab world worked their way up with ever expanding rhetoric into war fever despite their near-total lack of preparation remains
column23: even four decades later
column24: an astonishment.  Abraham Rabinovich author of The Yom Kippur War:  The Epic Encounter That Transformed the Middle East

column1: Rand is ever the hyper-rationalist
column2: believing that all problems can be solved by using humankind's unique endowment of "reason." After all
column3: didn't Boethius claim mankind is the superior species
column4: because "man is a rational animal?" Rand certainly agrees with Boethius' apotheosis of reason.  But
column5: what KIND of reason? There are at least TWO types of reason: (1) hyper-reason based on a priori
column6: deductive
column7: syllogistic logic
column8: and (2) ordinary reason
column9: based on a posteriori
column10: experiential
column11: inferential logic. (There is a third kind of reason
column12: called mathematical propositional calculus
column13: that is a blend of the two
column14: while heavily favoring the latter.)   Rand is certainly in the first camp
column15: and that's her problem. Almost anything can be deduced syllogistically as Aristotle and Aquinas amply demonstrate. Pick up either author's tomes on how the world "is
column16: and you'll quickly find out they were consistently wrong. They both started from one or more false premises, that lead to false conclusions. More importantly, people, no matter how rational" they may appear
column17: do not used deductive
column18: a priori logic as consistently as Rand would suggest
column19: much less like. It's not in our nature. The very few that do are "hyper-rationalists
column20: and they are more annoying than satisfying.  Most people, if they use logic at all, use the SECOND kind, and this is the kind that is based on experience, on inferences drawn from direct experience with the senses. It is the development of this kind of reason that has led to the most ambitious outcomes in the history of mankind. But this reason admits up front that nothing is certain, all knowledge and morals are contingent, and that there are no eternal truths. This is the logic Rand deplores. Not because it isn't the most appropriate, but because everything is contingent -- there are no objective" or "absolute" conclusions. Rand cannot assert her dogmas under this kind of logic. Only "hyper-rationality" of the FIRST kind will allow her to do that!  Most philosophers and scientists have minimized or abandoned the first kind of logic for all the myths
column21: false dogmas
column22: and irrational conclusions that ensue from it. Read Aristotle or Aquinas to see just how wrong they are on practically everything
column23: yet these are the two best paradigms of the first kind of reason. Rand is one of the last holdouts for this kind of irrational logic. That is why the "objectivist" project is doomed from the start; it merely changes the "old" dogmas for "new" ones
column24: "old" myths for "new" ones. That is why here project is doomed from the start
column25: and why reading her "new" claptrap is no better than reading the "old" ones. No serious student of philosophy or science uses "her" kind of logic anymore
column26: and nor should we

Even when we are presented with the most unusual character in this story (in this case it seems pointless to try to hide anything) it's nothing most people couldn't have figured out. I won't deny that there are some good moments in this movie. (For undoubtedly the first time, Scooby and Shaggy go to a restaurant and want nothing!)  But even the old episodes were usually better than this movie. Parents may not have to screen this movie, but it is  likely that even children will fall asleep during this one. Thank goodness for the eventual Legend of the Vampire" and "Aloha Scooby Doo."

But the shining feature of this book is the "case study" of a company adopting the particular flavor of Enterprise Architecture that Scott Bernard is trying to sell
column12: something called EA3.  He follows this ficticious company through the entire course of the book

Any business school or MIS student who tried to hand in this pollyanna sales pitch as a "case study" would only get an F because the grade scale doesn't go to "G."  Perhaps the only value in this book is that
column21: if read critically
column22: it will teach you a great deal about why "Enterprise Architecture" has such a poor reputation in certain sectors of industry today.  I really think that a lot of EA is about self-aggrandizement on the part of IT professionals
column23: who think the entire business should revolve around their pretty diagrams and three-ring binders.  We in the IT community need to get our minds right: we are here to support and enable the business
column24: not impede it or
column25: worse
column26: subordinate it to its tools.  If something like Enterprise Architecture is good for business
column27: then we need to find ways to do it that don't involve saying to the people we are supposed to be helping: "Wait!  Stop what you're doing and redefine everything you do according to MY methodology!"  Read the first five pages of the "case study" in this book to see the new CIO do EXACTLY THAT.  He should have been laughed out of the boardroom.

column1: I recently purchased - and returned - a Bowflex Ultimate 2 and I wanted to convey just how disappointed I was with the whole experience.    My equipment arrived on January 10th.  As I opened the boxes
column2: I realized that not only were there no assembly instructions
column3: there weren't any user instructions on how to modify the machine to do the different exercises.  I contacted Bowflex immediately and was told that a mistake had been made
column4: but that I could download the assembly instructions from the website.  I was also told that a user manual would be sent to me.    One week later on January 17th
column5: I contacted Bowflex because I had not yet received the user guide and because during the assembly of the Ultimate 2
column6: I noticed that one of the plastic balls that prevents the cables from coming off the cables was broken.  The representative I spoke to again pledged to send me a user manual and a replacement ball so that I could use the machine.  I asked if they could be overnighted because the machine was unusable to me with the broken ball (which allowed the cable to pull through) and without a users guide.  The representative said she would expedite the order but that she could not overnight it.  She told me she  could not tell me for certain when it would arrive.     By the end of day
column7: Friday
column8: January 19th
column9: it was apparent to me that the items would not be arriving before the weekend and that it would be more than three weeks from the day I ordered the machine before I would be able to use it.  It was very frustrating to me that Bowflex would not overnight these items so I could fix and use the machine as soon as possible.  These items did not arrive until 7 days later
column10: making it a full month from the date of my order before the equipment would have been functional.    For these reasons
column11: I elected to return the equipment to Bowflex.  I was expecting far better customer service for something that cost over $2
column12: 000.  Making matters far worse was the cost for me to return the items to Bowflex.  Using UPS as Bowflex recommended and knowing that the cost for Bowflex to ship the items to me was about $200
column13: I expected it to cost about $200 to ship the items back to Washington.  However
column14: because all returns must go to Virginia
column15: the cost to ship the items via UPS Ground in the original boxes to Virginia was $489 - more than double the original amount.  I'm assuming that two reasons explain the cost difference 1) Bowflex must get some sort of discount from UPS for all of its shipping traffic 2) naturally
column16: it is more expensive to ship from California to Virginia than it is to ship to Washington.  Regardless of the reason
column17: my Bowflex ownership experience was only made worse by the fact that I had to spend 25% of the original purchase price to ship the item back.    This whole experience has made it very difficult for me to ever have anything good to say to anyone about my experience owning Nautilus equipment.

column1: HERE IS SOME USEFULL INFO I FOUND first D-Link makes some great stuff but the D-Link DGS-2208  is not one of them    first tech support is useless they know nothing untill you get a 4-5 level of support (45 min.) the way to get info out of them is to call the (LOCAL) sales desk punch in the keys for presales question   and from that sales desk call "IT WILL NOT WORK WELL IN MIXED MODES"  from this info i sent mine back to for a full refund  here are 2 reviews i found   Pros: Fanless. Seems sturdy enough.  Cons: Won't work well for a mixed network.  I bought this swtich hoping to use it with my gigabit connected computers along with my 100mbit connected computers. I checked ahead of time
column2: making sure the description for the product said it could work in a mixed speed network. What they didnt mention
column3: is that if used in a mixed speed network (100mbit and 1000mbit connections to it at the same time) it will run at the slowest connected speed. I found out by noticing it wasnt any faster than my previous 100mbit network. I emailed their tech support asking and they respondeded with  It will run at the slowest speed connected   So this means that if your router
column4: computer
column5: AP
column6: or ANY ethernet device that runs at 100mbit is attached to it
column7: it will make all 8 of its ports run at 100mbit
column8: regarldess if all the other ports have 1000mbit connected devices.   here is another bad one i found  Pros: Jumbo frames
column9: cheap Cons: Doesnt work worth beans in a mixed speed environment. If you have 2 computers with 100mbit adapters and 2 with 1000mbit adapters
column10: the switch will run ALL ports at 100mbit
column11: effectively making the gigab... More » it adapters run at 100mbit. Have a 10/100 router or 100mbit adapter in ANY of the computers thats going to be connected to this switch and your wasting your time if you think you can hookup your gigabit adapters and expect gigabit speeds.  Other Thoughts: I wish someone else had mentioned its problem in a review before I bought it. I had checked their product sheet and read through reviews about this switch with no mention that it shunts all ports to the slowest connected speed. There isnt any support on Dlinks website for this product nor knowledgebase. I found out that it shunts the ports to the slowest speed by emailing them and getting a single line response of "It is limited to the slowest connection." with a "internet email confidentiality statement" indicating that the information in the email is intended only for my personal use and is private/confidential. Brilliant

 I thought this book was good but then all her others were too. I guess when you are a popular author the fear of failure may be so strong that you will stick to what works and what sells - the same alpha male and sassy female. Usually, I have no problems with this because given the same type of people in different situations and surroundings, they may develop differently or respond differently, but unfortunately, the surroundings are just masked differently but are actually the same. Now that is where the problem lies - its the same book with a different jacket and not the same characters within different situations (which I would be ok with). I think Laurens has become commercialized - too commercialized. When you grab a book and it feels like going to the supermarket and grabbing a brand of cereal - you know you are in trouble. Try Teresa Medeiros (love this woman), Elizabeth Thornton, Laura Lee Ghurke, Barbara Dan (newcomer) - you won't be disappointed. For some reason, Christina Dodd, Nora Roberts, Jennifer Blake, Virgina Henley, Stephanie Laurens, Lisa Kleypas, Cathy Maxwell, Connie Mason, Jo Beverly, Connie Brockway, and a few more I cannot remember seems to be very popular but for me, so hard to like any of their books. Does anyone else out there feel the same way

column2: so if you want to know how to build a box
column3: this is the book for you.  When it comes to design
column4: this book is very lacking.  There is a fair section on cross over design (1st & 2nd order only).  But when it comes to enclosure design
column5: the author suggests the reader use speaker design software (not provided) with no guidance on what these programs do.  Nice!  The book does a great job of emphasizing frequency response and efficiency matching
column6: but some of the design examples are are a little unorthodox.  Specifically
column7: there is a 12" PA speaker design where the author recommends a 6dB cross over point of 4kHz.  This may protect the horn
column8: but sacrifices off axis frequency response.  Most commercial 12" PA speakers will use a lower cross over point ~ 2kHz and use a 2nd or 3rd order cross over.  Bottom line
column9: if you want to know how to build boxes
column10: this is a good book.  If you want to know how to design enclosures
column11: you will need another book or software.  I rated this book low because the title "Design and Build . . ." suggested to me that there would be better design guidelines.  So while I rated this book one star
column12: other readers may find this a useful reference for pro speaker construction.

column1: I originally wrote a review of this book in 1999
column2: titled "This is a racist book disguised as a work of art."  It seems that I didn't explain well enough my objection to Styron's co-opting of the story of a real human being
column3: Nat Turner
column4: whose story was more accurately depicted in the 1831 book
column5: "The Confessions of Nat Turner
column6: by T.R. Gray.  Not only did Styron steal the title of Gray's book, in which Gray recounts his interview with the real Nat Turner, but the incidents Styron invents for the sake of drama reveal his southern-bred racism.    Unlike his depiction in Styron's book, Nat Turner was married.  Styron's invention of Turner's pivotal and conflicted relationship with a white woman, Margaret Whitehead, is entirely fictional.  So is any self-doubt that Turner did the right thing by leading the revolt.  In Gray's account, Turner did not express regret. There is so much more depth to Turner's life that is either fictionalized beyond recognition or left unexplored in this book.  Do those facts make a difference in a work of fiction?  Yes. The parts Styron has unnecessarily fictionalized are key to the story he invented.  Turner's fictional relationship with Margaret is saturated in the southern myth that black men are obsessed with white women -- lusting for the forbidden fruit, for which they must die.  That Styron crawls into Nat Turner's skin in order to infect him with self-doubt about his mission emasculates Turner and diminishes his cause.  What offends me most is that Nat Turner's life deserves to be explored by a modern author who does not condescend or patronize this African-American hero.  Instead, we have William Styron's version of Turner's life, taken by many readers as fact.  If one prefers racist fiction posing as a legitimate account of a life, then one might enjoy wallowing in this version of Confessions."  But if one prefers reality
column7: I recommend Gray's book as well as other accounts available about the slave revolt at Southampton
column8: Virginia.  Styron's book does not provide significant insights into Nat Turner
column9: slave revolt or slavery itself.  His book clouds the truth with the same kind of Reconstruction era distortions that spawned the hideous phenomenon of lynching

column1: This is the story of Sheriff Bell
column2: an insufferable dullard who won't shut up about how criminals these days are really evil (as opposed to all the lovely ones he knew of when growing up?).   He's also a world-class boaster
column3: never going more than a few pages without telling us how fantastic is wife Loretta is. The same Loretta who spends most of her time baking for or writing to evil criminals -- which tells me all I need to know about that marriage.  The yakkity-yakking doesn't stop there. An even bigger gas-bag is Chigurh
column4: the motor-mouthed murderer. In fact
column5: he kills people twice. Before he shoots 'em
column6: he bores 'em to death. His weapon of choice: Lectures about coins. (His final kill took so long
column7: I had to restrain myself from flingling the book across the train carriage.)  On the technical front
column8: McCarthy does not structure the drama in the Classical way. He chose the Boring way. The majority of scenes end exactly as you expect and only one character (Moss) has a believable goal. McCarthy also omits the obligatory final scene
column9: between Chigurh and his prey Moss
column10: which was the only reason I kept reading the book. No doubt this is to defy the expectations of the reader. Expectations that this might turn out to be a decent story
column11: in my case.   What's more
column12: Sheriff Bell has no scenes with either Chigurh or Moss
column13: making him a narrator with zero personal stake in the action. Because McCarthy writes good
column14: visual dialogue
column15: he gets away with an inconsequntial narrator for the first half of the story. But when the man on the run (Moss) exits the story
column16: there is no other character to invest in
column17: so the plot grinds to a halt. McCarthy cannot resusitate it because there is no connection whatever between the two remaining main players.  So
column18: does McCarthy put us out of our misery? No. Sheriff Bell waffles on for pages and pages about Vietnam
column19: not unlike John Goodman's character Walter in the Big Lebowski. And that's it.  My verdict: I hope Loretta runs away with a criminal. Preferably one of them new evil ones

column1: Although I believe this book helps enlighten one to the reality that our soul and deepest longings as women are interconnected with the Creator and His passionate love for us...MUCH of it's "theology" is flawed.  I felt an appeal to self exaltation and a humanizing of God that is clearly anti-biblical.  I would guide any of my fellow Christian readers to remember that all false doctrine is effective because it is dressed up in truth....but it's heart message is false and usually self exhorting.
Apparently the difference between a criminal act (theft) and moral redistribution of income is 1) who you steal from (stealing from the wealthy
column2: of course
column3: is moral -- according to Rawls and Bolsheviks)
column4: and 2) who receives the loot (the non-wealthy makes it moral)
column5: and 3) who commits the act (the state/society
column6: of course also makes theft moral; example - taxation)
column7: and 4) your intentions (redistribution of income). To look at this another way
column8: if your neighbor breaks into your house and steals your money
column9: that's a crime (unless your neighbor is poor -- which would then be moral and Justice
column10: according to Rawls' formula). If the community comes into your house and steals from you
column11: it's legal and moral Justice
column12: again
column13: according to Rawls. Because
column14: according to Rawls
column15: if
column16: before you were born
column17: you were to vote with everyone on how physical world society should be structured
column18: you'd vote to have the state guarantee that everyone was equal
column19: or they would be compensated somehow for being born (unjustly) less-equal. How? By compensating those with less by stealing from those with more. So those with more would be like oh
column20: say ... a milk-cow who gets milked to serve those with less. So those with more would become a resource
column21: or state-owned slaves to those with less ... because "society" (the Robin Hoods and Rawls of the world) deemed this as moral Justice. Rawls does not take into account those who are willing to take on risk
column22: entrepreneurs
column23: students of life who work to earn an "A" vs. students who earn an "F". He points out that many people are born into difficult situations through no fault of their own. True. But that does not implicate those within society who are born into better situations as the cause
column24: nor are those who are born into better situations responsible for making up the difference. Forcing the "wealthier" ones to be accountable for the unfairness within life and pay the bill isn't Justice or moral. It would simply be an unjust law. Some people see Rawls' theory as a blueprint for a future generation utopia (like the Bolsheviks envisioned Marxism). I see it as an insane blueprint for slavery
column25: and a powerful dis-incentive for earning personal reward and merit. In a sense
column26: this book is an argument against the individual. It sees the world through a blurred lense where the author only recognizes masses of people -- he doesn't recognize any individuals (unless they were born as victims). Curious. How do you experience life ... as a group-mind (an oxymoron if there ever was one)
column27: a collective? Or as a unique
column28: isolated
column29: independent
column30: individual? There should be societal incentives to help each other. Okay. But when it is forced (theft of property always implies force)
column31: it is no longer an issue of morality or justice -- it's simply a law. Without personal choice being involved there is no morality as an issue
column32: by definition. Transforming advantaged individuals into mules forced to carry the burdens of the world is a definition of justice for whom?

column1: I installed this machine on a home office network via Ethernet.  The install took awhile
column2: and changed registry settings without asking.  Uninstall did NOT restore the system to it's original state; only hours of manual resetting did that.  How many users can restore the registry?  Further
column3: the software/drivers do not like the printer turned off or missing.  If you install this on a road laptop
column4: you can expect a program
column5: HPZinw12.exe
column6: to search for the missing printer every 100 seconds or so using all available CPU time.  If you are unlucky enough to be in the middle of a client presentation
column7: the chances are good that you have just lost the job.  If you turn off the printer in the office
column8: your office systems will also search for the printer and display an unclosable dialog asking you to switch to an unknown program while using most of their available CPU time. (Please note that 6 hidden dlls are also running at all times.)  This software is totally equivalent to a virus except for duplication.  I returned this system and will never buy another HP product

column1: This book is the continuation of the story of Tiny Tim but as an adult. The part where we see who Tim really is
column2: as opposed to who Tim's parents wanted him to be
column3: was by far the best part of the book.  The "mystery" though was just silly; there is no way that someone in England at that time when confronted with a child rapist wouldn't have murdered him on the spot.  And Tim not doing so went completely against who the author had developed as Tim's true nature.  There were actions such as this one throughout the book that seemed obviously placed in order to drive the plot forward.  Exasperating and annoying.

I give this 2 stars for originality and 0 stars for detail and character development

column1: Why would people spend their lives obsessing over issues for which there is no objective evidence?  A cursory review of the literature about the mind will reveal that dreams are random and without predictive or any other kind of meaning.  Certainly dreams can be about stressful situations in one's life
column2: but they will be mixed with all sorts of extraneous things
column3: people and events that have no significance...viewed properly
column4: they can provide good light entertainment.    Simply put
column5: during consciousness the mind has an inhibition system that is activated so that cognition can proceed in an orderly fashion.  During sleep this system is shut off and all bets are off.  That's all there is to it!  I am tempted to give this book a 1
column6: but will give it a 2 because I don't think she's trying to be deceitful.  For current info
column7: see July '05 issue of the mag

column1: "The Future of War" predicts US dominance of warfare throughout the 21st Century
column2: as a result of US advanced technology in general and precision weaponry in particular. Their train of thought has considerable merit
column3: and deserves reading and thoughtful attention. However
column4: the book suffers from the same two major flaws as most books by visionaries without enough practical experience: misunderstanding of specific happenings in the past
column5: and unlikely projections into the far future. Having been involved with US defense for 50 years
column6: as a member of the military
column7: as a designer and developer and advisor on US weaponry
column8: and as an advisor on strategic
column9: operational and tactical issues
column10: I read this book with considerable amusement
column11: although I do take seriously much of what it says. I shall give specifics on two failures to understand the details of the past
column12: and then offer criticism of two of the book's projections
column13: as examples.  Past episode #1: The 1991 precision strikes against Iraq. There is no doubt that our air strikes and land attacks in the 1991 campaign to liberate Kuwait were exceedingly effective
column14: and there is no doubt that this effectiveness was largely due to our precision weaponry. However
column15: to do precision strikes
column16: whether with airborne munitions or ground forces
column17: it's necessary to know what targets to attack
column18: where they are
column19: and what weapons are likely to be effective against a particular target. In the 1991 campaign
column20: this effort was undertaken by the "Jeddi Knights"
column21: largely under the guidance of Col. John Warden. The key role of the "Jeddi Knights" was to establish priorities and mission profiles for which targets to strike when with what munitions
column22: and they did this extraordinarily well. What the Friedmans obviously don't know is the amount of detailed information that was available to the "Jeddi Knights"
column23: carefully acquired over the 70 years preceding the campaign
column24: first by the British until about 1950
column25: and thereafter by the US military. The armed forces of major powers assume they may have to fight wars on short notice aganst opponents who have been designated shortly before by national authorities
column26: so they invest a great deal in gathering information pertinent to how various campaigns might be conducted. In the case of Iraq
column27: the British did very careful mapping from 1920 until about 1950
column28: producing "ordnance" maps of higher detail and accuracy than exist even for some parts of the United States
column29: and these were invaluable to planners. Then
column30: starting in about 1950
column31: when it began to seem possible that the US might someday have to fight somewhere in the Middle East
column32: the US military carefully gathered information relevant to how a campaign might be fought
column33: and which potential enemy targets should be candidates for destruction. These studies resided in US intelligence and military archives until the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait
column34: and were then used as the basis for planning the campaign.  Two examples of this. First
column35: the destruction of certain bridges was given high priority not to impede vehicular movement
column36: but to sever the communications cables running under the bridges; our planners knew which cables important to Iraqi Command and Control were buried too deeply to destroy easily except where they were routed under bridges
column37: and therefore which bridges to take out to disrupt Iraqi military communications. Second
column38: the swing by US
column39: British and French forces far to the West
column40: the "Hail Mary" gambit
column41: would not have been possible in that harsh terrain unless viable routes for armor and supply vehicles were known
column42: and the Iraqi Army either didn't know of such routes or didn't believe we could know of them. There are exactly two feasible routes
column43: and both were used; they can both be determined in complete detail from careful study of the British Ordnance maps prepared in the 1930s
column44: and (although I wasn't involved in the campaign planning) I had no difficulty in finding and plotting the only two feasible routes before the ground campaign began
column45: from the good maps in my possession. I also understand why it was necessary to bring the two prototype JSTARS systems to the theatre
column46: to detect and allow blocking of any Iraqi strike intended to sever the Tapline Road; this was also evident from the maps.  By contrast
column47: we had no success at all in locating and destroying mobile Scud missile launchers
column48: because they moved around with great frequency. If you don't know where something is
column49: no precision of your weaponry
column50: and no amount of technical sophistication or military skill
column51: will allow you to destroy it.  Past example #2: The SAFEGUARD BMD system. The Friedmans say
column52: on the basis of assertions by people who may or may not be experts
column53: that SAFEGUARD was deactivated because it wouldn't work. In fact the situation was exactly the reverse
column54: but one must know the purpose of SAFEGUARD and its mode of operation to understand what actually happened. The mission of SAFEGUARD was to prevent complete success of a Soviet counterforce first strike against our Minuteman ICBM fields
column55: by opening a "launch window" for a retaliatory strike by the Minuteman missiles in the face of a full-scale Soviet strike. I helped to plan and design that system
column56: and it would have done what it was intended to
column57: although at a horrible increased toll of death and destruction
column58: which I dreaded
column59: but could see no alternative to in the face of rapidly increasing Soviet capability. Far more important than the fact that we knew SAFEGUARD would work was the fact that the Soviets concluded it would work; that realization brought them back to the bargainng table at the Helsinki talks
column60: and led to the SALT I treaty
column61: which I rejoiced about. Provisions of that treaty made SAFEGUARD unnecessary
column62: and that's why the one completed SAFEGUARD site was deactivated and construction on the other sites was stopped.  Also on the subject of balistic missile defense
column63: the Friedmans assert that midcourse discrimination and destruction of incoming warheads is infeasible. This is simply not true
column64: although there is an exceedingly serious problem associated with doing it. I know three quite different ways of doing midcourse discrimintion and destruction of enemy incoming warheads
column66: given that I've been out of that business for more than 10 years
column67: I expect that other ways are known by now. The problem is that
column68: at least for the three ways I know
column69: one is politically unacceptable to the US Congress and the US public
column70: one is so expensive that it's unlikely Congress would ever fund it
column73: would be usable for certain other military purposes that would probably lead to a renewed arms race as our potential major opponents sought to counter it. (I was one of a small group of scientists who successfully recommended to Congress that development of that third approach be stopped
column74: to avoid the resulting foreseeable escalation; scientists and military professionals
column75: despite various comments in the Friedmans' book
column76: work closely together over years and decades
column77: and come to have considerable knowledge of each other's fields.) Whether at some future time it may become desirable to develop and deploy a BMD system that does midcourse discrimination and destruction of warheads is a political and diplomatic question to be decided by the public and its elected leaders
column78: on which I have no insight
column79: but it is technically feasible.  Now
column81: what the Friedmans fail to understand in their glowing vision of US technology dominating future warfare
column82: is that for every technical advance
column83: opponents can devise at least partial countermeasures
column84: and that therefore no amount of technology as such can determine the outcome of a campaign. The Coalition conquest of Iraq in 2003 provides an excellent example. Although large parts of the Iraqi army
column85: and all of its top leadership
column87: other large parts of the Iraqi army were composed of thoroughly trained officers and enlisted men
column88: who fully understood that if they confronted US forces nose to nose
column89: they would be destroyed. Understanding this
column90: very many of the best Iraqi units simply demobilized themsleves and disappeared into the civilian population as Coalition forces approached
column91: in many cases taking their weaponry with them. One entire Iraqi division near the border with Iran totally vanished before we got to its bases; everyone from the division commander to the most junior private. Professional soldiers
column93: have no more desire than anyone else to be killed pointlessly in a situation where they are unable to resist effectively.  A substantial fraction of these well-trained
column94: motivated Iraqi forces subsequently emerged as part of the resistance movement that continues in Iraq. How many of the resistance fighters come from that crowd is obviously impossible to know for sure
column95: but my personal estimate is that about 30
column96: 000 of Saddam Hussein's best and most loyal troops and officers became part of the resistance movement. And our overwhelming superiority in all aspects of conventional warfare have been far less effective against current Iraqi resistance methods; the resistance movement seems to be gradually weakening and fragmenting
column97: but it's a long slow process
column98: in which our precision weapons and our advanced communications and intelligence give us far less of an advantage than they do in conventional warfare.  There are various other gaps in the Friedmans' assessment of the future. I'll mention only two of many. First
column100: often touted as the most effective weapon of the 21st Century
column101: have had only relatively diappointing results so far. Why? Partly because technical improvements to vircators are needed; those will surely come along in due course. Much more serious is the fact that battle damage asssessment after a vircator strike is at present almost impossible to do with any degree of accuracy
column102: so after a target has been attacked with one or more vircators
column103: there is no practical way to know whether the strike was successful or not. Presumably some day we will overcome this particular problem
column104: but it illustrates that new and potentially formidable technology may find relatively little application because of purely tactical and operational problems that arise in using it.  As my second example
column105: I'll remark on the Friedmans' vision of US infantrymen as being in effect "cocooned" in future to protect them from the enemy's weapons. This vision ignores two serious problems. First
column106: no "cocoon" imaginable can protect an infantryman against certain weapons such as a fuel-air bomb if the enemy knows approximately where the infantryman is. Second
column108: anyone with substantial experience in concealing himself in a hostile environment
column110: knows all too well that the more accoutrements one has
column111: the harder it is to hide and not be observed. In light clothing and carrying only light personal weapons
column112: I can disappear into the landscape almost anywhere
column113: and move around unnoticed; burdened with excess equipment and elaborate protective clothing
column114: only certain carefully selected spots can offer concealment. Everyone with experience in this matter knows as much as I do on this subject
column115: so infantrymen whose lives depend on not being observed will move far more cautiously when heavily burdened than when lightly armed and lightly protected. That doesn't mean infantry should be sent into combat inadequately equipped
column116: but it does mean that the increased effectiveness of some given number of trained infantry when provided with extra combat capability and protective equipment is far less than one might otherwise suppose.  I could cite dozens of other matters
column118: which the Friedmans book misunderstands or overlook
column119: but this is enough. I'll just say that the book is an excellent source of ideas
column120: but should be viewed with practiced skepticism

column1: All these reviews are right on the MONEY!! IT GETS TOOOO HOT!! I bought this crock-pot to replace my old Rival crock-pot that is the same size because I liked the idea of the timer and keep-warm setting. column3: because of her busy schedule sometimes she does not get home in time to turn her crock-pot off and thought the KEEP WARM setting would be GREAT for her. I rated this one star because the website would not let me rate it ZERO

column1: Albert Hourani's A History of the Arab Peoples is a widely regarded general history of the Arab world. This is too bad
column2: since as history the book is of low quality
column3: with significant problems of organization and
column4: where relevant to Hourani's apparent biases
column5: factual accuracy. It does have its redeeming elements
column6: but on the whole is for a variety of reasons not a reliable source as a general history of the Arab world
column7: especially for the beginner.  Being the author of a general history of the Arab world myself
column8: before I explain why I evaluate the book negatively I would like to suggest some alternatives
column9: lest I be accused of attacking a rival publication out of self-interest. Philip K. Hitti's The History of the Arabs is a very detailed history which runs from pre-Islamic times to the 19th century. Arthur Goldschmidt's Concise History of the Middle East covers Turkey
column10: Iran and Israel as well as the Arab world and is well-organized for beginners. It was the first general history of the Middle East I read as an undergraduate. Bernard Lewis' The Middle East focuses more on concepts and the flow of history but is also appropriate for those without a strong background in the region.  This book was first published in 1991. This review is based on the 1992 paperback version by Warner Books.  The initial weakness of this book begins with the very first chapter; although containing 458 pages of main text
column11: Hourani's history devotes a mere seven pages to the pre-Islamic period. This is pretty amazing
column12: for anyone familiar with that period
column13: since Arab history prior to Islam is roughly as long as Arab history after it. Exactly how far back Arab peoples go in history is a matter of dispute
column14: but certainly there were people one could call "Arabians" as far back as the beginning of the first mellinnium BC
column15: or 1
column16: 600 years prior to Muhammad. The evidence is sporadic for sure
column17: and no writer would give it equal prominence with later times
column18: but seven pages is pretty paltry.  One might suspect an Islamic bias here
column19: but the problem continues in the key early periods of Islam. The life of Muhammad and his immediate successors who established the basis for the Muslim world
column20: spanning about a half century from Muhammad's first vision to the death of his son-in-law and successor Ali
column21: get only 11 pages. The first Arab empire
column22: the Umayyads (661-950)
column23: gets seven pages
column24: and the Abbasid Empire (750-circa. 945)
column25: which is usually thought of as the "Golden Age of Islam
column26: gets only six. This means 37 pages for the first 2,000 years of Arab history, including its framing epoch, and over 400 pages for the next 1,000. This would leave the uninitiated reader entirely without much sense of proportion.  What makes this book highly unrecommended for the beginner is its weak sense of organization. The middle time period between the collapse of Abbasid authority - roughly AD 950 - and the ascendance of the Ottoman Empire over the Arab world in 1517 is intrinsically a difficult time period to understand and a more difficult one on which to write a history. This is due to the fact that rather than there being one dominant power or a few powerful states, there is instead a multiplicity of dynasties with genuine authority in some areas not extending beyond the town level with a multifarious mixture of Sunni and Shia, Arab, Persian and Turkic ruling groups, not to mention the Latin states. Hourani makes no serious attempt to help the reader keep all of it straight by moving from a chronological approach prior to 950 to a topical one. There are ten chapters covering this time period and the social history of part of the previous two periods (the Umayyads and the Abbasids). There is one chapter which discusses the major power struggles of the time. If you want to understand the relative historical roles of the Buyids, the Fatimids, the Zengids, the Ayyubids, the Mamluks and their contemporaries, read something else.  It is within these ten chapters that this book contains its major strength - its social history
column27: or its description of the development of the Arab world. In fact I cited Hourani on the social history sections of my own book. In this regard, Hourani really is better than the alternatives. Over 200 pages of the book is devoted to detailing various aspects of how the Arab world came to be prior to the Ottomans. So for those who have already read a general history of the Middle East or the Arab world and want a more specialized knowledge, these chapters are quite useful.  I have several objections to how this book handles a variety of issues of current interest. This book was written during a time period when there was a great emphasis on negating certain negative images of Arabs and Muslims, to the point of deemphasizing any aspect of the Arab world which might be interpreted negatively. The word jihad" doesn't even have an entry in the index
column28: although it is used
column29: or perhaps
column30: misused. On page 247
column31: Hourani describes a traditional view stipulating that the ruler has an obligation "to pursue jihad by maintaining the strength of the kingdom's defense..." This gives a misimpression
column32: because legally jihad has two military meanings - the defense of Muslim lands and the Muslim community's collective obligation to spread Islam through conquest. Although jihad has a spiritual as well as martial application
column33: its use is overwhelmingly in the military context
column34: and while Muhammad's battles probably could be described as defensive
column35: the vast majority of military actions between that time and the 19th century involved offensive operations (the Christian counter-offensives known as the Crusades being a major exception).  More broadly
column36: the single most influential Islamist movement of the modern age
column37: the Wahhabis
column38: get only a few scattered mentions
column39: and there is no real indication of the wave of extremism which by 1991 had been felt for some time. The primary non-Islamist ideological influence
column40: Marxism
column41: is discussed of course
column42: but the influence of Nazism during the 1930s and 1940s is left out. Nazi Germany is mentioned once in passing
column43: and in the same paragraph on page 331 Palestinian leader Amin Husseini is mentioned
column44: but it isn't mentioned that he was a strong supporter of Nazis
column45: that he moved to Germany during the Second World War and played an active role in the Holocaust
column46: or that despite this he was made leader of the Palestinian cause by the nascent Arab League after the war.  Hourani's account of the 1967 is incredibly inaccurate
column47: giving the impression that Egypt engaged in some bluster and then Israel started the war. He mentions Nasser's demand that the UN clear out of the Suez Canal zone
column48: and includes the defense pact with Jordan
column49: but omits a key fact - the mobilization of Egyptian forces in the Sinai. Once Egypt did this
column50: Israel had no choice but to attack
column51: because of its small population its economy could not handle an extended mobilization
column52: while Egypt could. Hourani also doesn't mention the statements by Arab leaders to the effect that all Jews would be wiped out in the coming war.  On the whole
column53: this is a useful book if one already has a framework understanding of Arab history and if one understands the slant that is being presented on issues of contemporary concern. Otherwise
column54: I do not recommend buying it

column1: The Motely Fool has never shied away from congratulating itself
column2: in an entertaining sort of way.  The trouble comes in when the reality fails to live up to the authors' claims.  Their style of rah-rah anyone-can-make-a-million investing appeals to some novice investors for obvious reasons.  But as Malkiel points out in the classic A Random Walk Down Wall Street
column3: there will always be a few people who have a fortunate run for a few years.  Today
column4: sadly
column5: after the crash of 2000
column6: the Gardners' conclusions in Rule Breakers Rule Makers seem to be more misleading than helpful
column7: especially for someone just starting out.  If investing were only as easy as the Gardners make out then their own "Rule Breaking" portfolio might have continued to work.  They have tried to selectively cite certain of their more recent portfolios to make it appear that they're continuing to "beat the market like a drum"
column8: while sweeping under the rug their losing portfolios.  But as the reality of their results stands
column9: they ought to be ashamed of themselves for hyping up stocks and making themselves sound like the next Warren Buffett.    There will always be people on Wall Street like the Gardners
column10: inflating expectations and temporarily taking in some newcomers.  In contrast
column11: real investors like Buffett and Graham are modest about their results.  They stick to a realistic expectation of returns
column12: and realize that today's hot stock is often tomorrow's set of crashed dreams.  A beginning investor would be much better served reading Graham's The Intelligent Investor
column13: or another classic of the Street
column14: rather than being drawn into a charming but unrealistic look at the high hopes of what are ultimately mere self-promoters

Nor has she really provided any insights into the works that she uses nor many links between the relevance of these specific works with her students. I know I may get lambasted for saying so

The strongest parts of the text lie with her description of university life and the political complexities that emerge surrounding being a literature teacher educated in the West who comes back to Iran to teach. I think one of my problems was the way which the book is marketed as a celebration of sorts of the way literature is important within any context

column1: I was deeply disappointed in this book.  As a young(ish) woman on a career track who is anticipating also being a mom in the next 2-5 years
column2: I have thought a great deal about what parenthood will mean for my career as well as how my career will impact my child/children.  I heard about this book on MoveOn.org's website.  Since I feel fairly well informed about what America's moms don't have and what they want (from independent sources and friends)
column3: I was anticipating more emphasis on the "what to do about it" part.  The book had numerous case studies to pull at the heart strings paired with middling to flimsy statistical data (with several dubiously supported claims repeated multiple times throughout the book).  There was a lot of "what we want" with only a few concrete idea on HOW to implement these things other than the usual extreme liberal bread and circuses approach.  Even the good ideas in the book (e.g.
column4: focus on how your employer will benefit from family friendly policies
column5: not on how it will benefit you as the employee) are undermined by the statistical "evidence" that had hole big enough to drive a train through.  I actually feel less confident in building an articulate argument in support of better policies than before I read the book.  I knew before I read the book that there are significant problems with the current American workplace system (both for mothers and beyond).  So I was truly disappointed that so many pages in this short book were dedicated to long winded and often repetitive descriptions of the state of the world.  I want a better world for myself and my family and was hoping for constructive advice for making my world a better place.  This book didn't have it

column1: I agree with the reviewer who felt that Ms. Shires's textual analysis didn't flow well.  I found the majority of this book to be rather dull
column2: tedious
column3: slow-going
column4: and uninvolving.  It was an original idea to tell the story of her conversion by relating issues she had difficulty with or areas she found inspiration in to certain passages of Torah and the similar writings of others
column5: but it just didn't seem executed well.  If this is supposed to be a conversion memoir
column6: why does so little of the book actually concern her conversion or even her herself?  The sections when Ms. Shires is writing about herself
column7: such as in the beginning section
column8: the ending chapter about her visit to her husband's native Germany
column9: and the middle chapter about the mikvah
column10: are quite good and interesting
column11: because they're actually related to her life and to her conversion and not just tediously rambling on about certain Torah passages.  From reading this
column12: it seems as though she were the classic child who does not know enough to ask.  She says she did a lot of reading prior to her conversion because she really wanted to know the religion and to approach it from a variety of disciplines
column13: but in many sections she admits that she didn't know about some pretty important things or issues till after she converted.  For example
column14: she says that she hadn't had a lot of education about the mikveh and had been too embarrassed to ask her converting rabbi
column15: and therefore went into her conversion day feeling she had to immerse herself because she was thought to be "contaminated" and "dirty" as a non-Jew and had to cleanse herself before being admitted to the tribe.  How could anyone in any denomination
column16: particularly if she's had such a long process of education and learning as Ms. Shires evidentally had
column17: reach conversion day thinking such a thing and not having learnt more about the custom of mikveh?  (I was also annoyed that her chapter on the mikveh used the dated and inaccurate translations "contaminated" and "unclean" for the Hebrew words "tumah" and "tamei."  That continues to give the completely false impression that menstruating women are thought to be dirty and unclean
column18: when in actual fact the words surrounding this state of being are translated more like "ritually impure
column19:
and the impurity refers to a spiritual, not a physical, state of being.)    I was also left wondering why she converted under the auspices of the Conservative Movement when she so clearly feels ill at ease with many of their official positions, or at least the positions her own community seems to take.  She really seems like she'd feel more at home in a Reform, Reconstructionist, or Renewal community.  I'm also baffled as to why she frequently says that the Conservative Movement hasn't done enough for the inclusion of gays and women, unless her community isn't as liberal as many other Conservative communities are.  Or are the changes of the past few decades not radical and sweeping enough for her?  I also share her belief that women, gays, the disabled, and other groups that traditionally haven't always been included fully in Jewish life need to be completely integrated and granted full equality and participation in the community, but at times her call for this reads more like a political polemic and speaking from personal experience as opposed to really representing the great strides the Conservative Movement has made in these areas in the past few decades.  I'm not doubting her personal experiences with people she's known and what she's dealt with in her own community, but it just seems baffling if she's trying to say the entire Conservative Movement takes those positions as well.  A couple of interesting chapters do not a very recommendable book make.  Most of this was just very slow going for me, and the divrei Torah weren't that novel or insightful either.  I've heard most of these interpretations and analyses before, only not in such dull language.  I'm actually disappointed I bought this book, though at least I got a cheap used copy.  I'd looked forward to reading a conversion memoir, but instead got a tedious exercise in boredom that had almost nothing to do with the author's life, either before, during, or after her conversion 
 While the writing was acceptable, I felt that the juxtaposition of the classes in this novel was very forced.  The differnce between the classes is too obvious.  The contrast between the rich world (the students in the Wilcox school and the Cornhills) and the streets of London (and Isa's forced marriage to the grocer, and Mrs. Cornhill's predictable and obvious snobbery) was not one that led me to feel any of the injustice.  I was left cold by the overall plot.  One thing that truly bothered me was the fate of Mr. Cornhill and Isa.  I felt that the way it happened in the book left something to be desired, and was not in true Bronte style.  The characters and their development also left something to be desired.  They were too predictable at times, and Mr. Ellin was just annoying.  There were few occasions when I sympathized with any character, other than Isa (and only at certain points in the plot). There was nothing spectacular about this novel, though I won't discourage anyone from reading it.  It was fast paced and it did hold my interest.  
 This book is so flawed in every which way, it is hard to know where to begin. First of all, we are living in the end times, and when Jesus comes, that's all she wrote, folks. There's no seven years, no Christians being zapped up, etc. This is our Second Chance on Earth. No tribulation. This book takes figurative visions and tries to apply it literally, and does it poorly. Reading this book made me think that if this was true, then what's the point of trying to be a Christian. Why not just live your life the way you want to, and then when people zap out of thin air, change your life. It's ridiculous and sends the wrong message. Plus, the writing is for second graders with no redeeming characteristics to it. But I really don't think the author's care at this point (seeing how many millions they've made printing lies). My recommendation is to read the bible instead of this series; then you'll get truth and the bible is probably shorter (and much better writing). Man, not even Kirk Cameron could save this train wreck.

column1: GWTW certainly was one-sided in its portrayal of the Old South
