column2: that Greg Toland was director of photography while Robert Wise was responsible for the editing. SO what did Welles do? He directed! Apparently
column3: that's not enough to make Kane his movie
column4: his masterpiece
column5: among others. Well if movies were only based on photography
column6: scripting and editing
column7: then why would directors be needed?  Thomson insults Welles in every paragraph; he hammers him over and over
column8: relentlessly. He focuses on the less successful aspects of his life and exaggerates them. He ridicules him
column9: makes fun of his weight
column10: says he's egotistical
column11: a liar
column12: a misogynist
column13: an unfaithful friend
column14: a machiavellic mischievous man who uses people
column15: cheats on his wives
column16: dates married women
column17: eats like a pig and stuffs his face with anything he could find (he talks a lot about that)
column18: a pretend genius or would be genius who thinks he's the victim of evil Hollywood moguls. What other bad things could be said about Welles? Basically
column19: any insult or evil thought you would ever have towards your worse enemy would not match up to the way Thomson writes about Welles.  Welles is not the only target of the author's wrath towards famous people. Any dead actor that was a friend or acquaintance of welles is also treated unkindly
column20: as for the ones who are still alive
column21: Thomson refrains himself from making a judgement. What a coward! Dead celebrities are such easy targets to criticism aren't they?  When Thompson runs out of evil things to say
column22: he talks about his childhood and when he went to see The Third Man with his grand mother who for some reason has a claw instead of a hand. Oh poor little David
column23: he could not hold his grandma's hand
column24: only a claw! Tear. Who cares! Also
column25: he has the annoying habit of interrupting every other chapter with imaginary conversations between the writer (?) and the publisher (?). It's never quite clear and really pointless. It's a way for him to put himself in value and shows how he can also criticize his own work. What a decent man!...  I was not expecting a hagiography
column26: I know Welles was not godlike. Thomson explains at the end of the book that he does not mean to put Welles down
column27: but only attempts to humanize him. Well there's a difference between humanizing someone and destroying the truth. Also
column28: a biography should include anecdotes
column29: facts
column30: it should be detailed and accurate. Thompson writes some kind of very superficial
column31: selective
column32: inaccurate story
column33: with imaginary dialogues about what people could have said to welles or thought of him. You can't assume things in a biography.  The author is too involved with his own thoughts instead of sticking to the facts in an objective manner. If you want to learn about Welles
column34: read "Road to Xanadu' by Simon Callow
column35: which focuses on Welles life up to Kane. Or "This is Orson Welles" which is a series of Welles interviews conducted by Peter Bogdanovich in which Welles tells the story of his life. Sure he had a tendency of lying about his past

column1: It is unfortunate that Diane Stein titled her book "Essential" Reiki as there is a lot of her own innovation and syncretism with other healing and spiritual disciplines in it.  Ms. Stein was very cutting edge at the time for publishing reiki symbols and opening up what was a previously more secret practice.  However
column2: I would recommend this only to advanced students
column3: such as reiki master level students
column4: as an example of how not to write a reiki manual for this reason:  Ms. Stein is a Wiccan.  I have no problem with her being a Wiccan.  I am a Christian and I hope that no one would have a problem with that.  However
column5: I find it problematic that she blends some of her Wiccan beliefs
column6: such as a clockwise "invoking energy" in the Northern hemisphere
column7: into an originally Japanese practice
column8: and therefore arbitrarily changed the direction of the first reiki 2 symbol.  If I wrote a book on reiki
column9: since it is now confirmed that Usui-sensei was a lifelong Buddhist
column10: I wouldn't put the Lord's Prayer into my attunement process.... I believe Reiki should be for those of all faiths.  Ms. Stein's reiki attunement methodology borrows heavily from the Raku Kei/Arthur Robertson lineage and also has some elements of William Rand's "tibetan" lineage.  Neither is acknowledged as at the time she wrote the book
column11: she didn't know the origins of much of her material.  Additionally
column12: since the publication of her book
column13: there has been much discovered about reiki history and Japanese practices.    I have no issue with the book as a snapshot in time
column14: but that she continues to sell and distribute the book over a decade later without crediting some of the sources of her material and without updating it
column15: is problematic.  I believe a second edition should have been provided if the book was to remain in print.  As an example of someone who has changed his material
column16: William Rand has revised his Reiki Handbook for levels one and two to include the Japanese techniques and information.  In short
column17: what was cutting edge and creative in 1995 is no longer accurate or cutting edge and I would caution beginners to look elsewhere for a more traditional
column18: basic introduction to reiki as "Essential Reiki" as a title is misleading.  I recommend the works of William Rand
column19: Frank Arjava Petter
column20: Hiroshi Doi
column21: Frans and Bronwen Stiene
column22: and Tanmaya Honervogt for starters

David Fromkin's "Peace to End All Peace" is simultaneously a comprehensive and very flawed work. Many of the reasons for it being one can be found in the other.  Fromkin attempts to examine how the modern Middle East (extending as far as Afghanistan and some sections of Central Asia) was created during and after the First World War. Obviously
column2: in order to do this
column3: the fall of the Ottoman Empire in that war must be considered. This is where Fromkin's unusual methodology comes into play. Focusing on the European political machinations to resolve the "Eastern Question" in their favour
column4: the sorry tale becomes one more of Churchill and TE Lawrence than of the Arabs and Turks who were also involved in the process. Admittedly
column5: it was the Europeans who wielded the whip hand in deciding just where the borders were to be drawn
column6: but reducing key figures such as the CUP Triumvirate in the dying Ottoman Empire (and Kemal Ataturk in Turkey immediately thereafter) to the status of supporting players ultimately skews the focus of the book too much.  Never let it be said that this is a simple story to retell. A complex web of national and personal political interests in both Europe and the Middle East combined to make the region what it is today
column7: and any study of all of these will be faced with the need for convoluted explanations. The problem that Fromkin has
column8: however
column9: is that he does not make these very well at all. The story is told in a roughly chronological manner
column10: which means that we jump from place to place and meet a bewildering array of characters. Ultimately
column11: the only real result is confusion on the part of the reader
column12: who is constantly flipping backwards to see who the latest figure to make an appearance actually is.  Additionally
column13: Fromkin frequently confuses his readers with references to geographical features which are not well-shown on the maps provided. Indeed
column14: one map (showing Enver Pasha's advance on Baku and his campaigns in Central Asia) is laughable in the extreme. The legend explains that the direction of the arrows is the direction of the various advances - which would be significantly more useful were the arrows in fact arrows
column15: and not equilateral triagles.  Where Fromkin does well
column16: however
column17: is in his use of purely European sources. It is perhaps unusual to say this of a book intending to tell the story of the modern Middle East
column18: but I have considerable doubts about the depth of his research into the Middle Eastern aspects of the events in question. In terms of Europe
column19: however
column20: his research seems to cover the major bases of exactly what the key figures believed and did.  Ultimately
column21: "A Peace to End All Peace" is a difficult and not particularly rewarding work. A diplomatic history of Europe during the Great War can be written much better than this
column22: and a history of the development of the Middle East following that conflict already has been (the chapters in Margaret Attwood's "The Peacemakers" or William Cleveland's "Modern Middle East" both easily outshine this)

column1: RC Sproul Jr. makes a compelling argument as to why Christian parents should homeschool their children.  His primary text is Deuteronomy 6 where God commands His people to teach His Law to their children.  Certainly the best place to teach
column2: train
column3: and raise godly children is in the home.  Parents aren't competing with  "the world" and children aren't confused by the two drastically different approaches to the way they see things and the way they are called to live.  I totally buy that.  What I do not appreciate is how simplistic Mr. Sproul Jr. can be when it comes to the "how" of homeschooling.  I understand that this is not the main focus of his book.  Certainly he is more interested in telling us why it is important.  However
column4: I cannot sit back and accept ideas like the only textbook you really need is a Bible.  He says things along these lines over and over and over again
column5: making his point that we need to be teaching our children the Faith and that this must be their primary curricula from which all others stem.  And yet
column6: he downplays all other subjects as though they were an aside.  We are commanded by God to value the life of the mind and to love Him with all of our minds.  One way
column7: perhaps even the primary way we do this is by learning and not only about the Lord.  The "how" is more than a conversation.  Yes
column8: school is all of life.  He makes this big case for that and then stuffs in a line or two here and there that his kids do learn math and receive "formal" schooling.  I guess my biggest problem is the writing style.  Sproul rambles
column9: like he's having a conversation with himself.  I think this leads to a lack of clarity and makes his book difficult to follow.  While his main point is the "why" of homeschooling
column10: he often tacks on several points on the "how" that made me quite frustrated in attempting to follow his argument.  All in all
column11: I don't really recommend this book.  I would recommend instead _Recovering the Lost Tools of Learning_ by Doug Wilson instead

column1: In Piano Tuner
column2: Daniel Mason (an American medical student who went to Myanmar to find himself)
column3: presents a clear picture of a liberal Englishman in the late 19th century
column4: who travels to Burma to repair a piano. He apparently hated himself and his culture so much that
column5: within weeks of arriving in exotic colonial Burma
column6: he craves for a new identity as a Burmese. Without any hesitation
column7: he cheats on his wife (exotic Asian women are so sexy)
column8: abandons his previous life
column9: and rebels against the British authorities in Burma.  This genre is very old and quiet stale. Ever since Europeans "discovered" Asia
column10: there have been books about going to the orient and finding meaning in a life that was meaningless in Europe. Daniel Mason trudges down this weary path once more one hundred years later.  Not only does he spin out an old formula
column11: he does so with very little sophistication. In the novel
column12: a Burmese woman accuses the English newspapers of caricaturing local women as dancing girls and men as barbarians. Mr. Mason does the same thing in his novel. There is not one Burmese male character in the novel who is intelligent or endearing
column13: and the one Burmese female character has a fetish for European men. She can't get enough of them.  A dominant character in the book is an English doctor (Mr. Mason's fantasy alter ego?) who is a lover of the arts
column14: a scientist and a thoroughly decent chap. This doctor is protecting the region from British aggression
column15: studying local flora and fauna
column16: saving lives of the Burmese with his medical ingenuity
column17: and truly appreciating the beauty of the country.  While Mr. Mason seems to oppose the military aggression and rule that the British used in that part of the world
column18: he openly endorses the idea of a white savior doctor who can teach the locals how to live in a civilized manner. This is so old
column19: that it hurts me to write about it.

column1: After reading five of her novels
column2: I have become a fan of Jodi Picoult. I will admit (and this probably proves that I am a sucker for marketing rather than letting the literature speak for itself) that I've deliberately read all of her best sellers before reading the books that didn't make it on the list.   Initially I liked the book and it kept me reading
column3: though maybe just out of habit. I enjoyed reading about the Amish way of life and the Amish traditions - though it did make me think of that Harrison Ford movie
column4: Witness (circa 1989 or something). I like that she used one first person voice as well as the third person narrative in a well crafted and varied way.  I like that her main character has a powerful job that challenges gender stereotypes by being the morally questionable lawyer. That being said
column5: she doesn't explore this as well as she could. We sort of forget that Ellie has blatantly suppressed evidence and watched as little girls saw their rapist acquitted. Rape
column6: she can defend
column7: but infanticide creates some problems for the notorious defense attorney.   Something about the book bothered me. Maybe I am reading too many of her books too fast but I am seeing a formula here.  - Many of her plots include a court room drama.  - All of her plots feature romance or end with the obvious potential for one.  - Mothers and their powerful (all encompassing
column8: self-sacrificing) love for their children are a theme in all of her books I've read.  - There is usually a "twist" at the end. She's becoming Koontz like in her formulaic predictability and I stopped reading his novels as a teenager.  Most of her books left me content
column9: like I'd eaten a good
column10: hearty meal. However
column11: this book left me hungry and searching for critical reviews to see if others shared my dissatisfaction.   So: - I was unimpressed with the "twist" at the end of this one - I knew "whodunit" about 1/2 of the way through. I was getting bored with that part of the story. The red herrings are too obvious and her suggestions that Katie didn't do it were there from the beginning. She should've stopped the heavy handed attempt to make us question that and just made it known through the 3 person narrative exactly who did the killing or hiding. Then she could have explored that character in depth instead of hiding her and others she wanted you to be suspicious about. Just because we
column12: the readers knew
column13: didn't mean that Ellie had to know - or anyone else for that matter.   - The characters in this novel were a tad generic. I am sorry
column14: I like her
column15: but they were boring.   For instance
column16: I was bored with Ellie's dilemma over Coop - to the point where I often skipped the interaction they had when they discussed their potential future together. Duh
column17: I knew they were going to get together after a little drama from Ellie through which Coop - being the quintessential "sensitive ponytail guy" - would wait
column18: albeit in pain. It was just too predictable.  Hannah's ghost; she has a ghost hunter in a later novel and I was a disappointed to see another one. But other than that
column19: Hannah's ghost seems a bizarre and meaningless addition. Is it to suggest that she
column20: Katie
column21: might be crazy and a murderer? Is it to explain why she was so drawn to Adam? Katie being the good Amish girl could only fall for someone who could share her secret ability to see her sister... In a book that is so Amishly pragmatic and logical in every other way makes it so the supernatural element clashes with the rest of the novel. Maybe Hannah's ghost killed Katie's baby or hid it.  I liked the details. The Amish and their daily lives
column22: those who assimilate and those who don't
column23: and how the religion and way of life affect one's thinking offers a neat
column24: un-scholarly insight into a different culture. I liked the culture clashes and I wondered how they would be resolved. But what I did like
column25: doesn't measure against my dissatisfaction.  My most recent book purchase included three works of fiction; two by Picoult and one by Atwood. I think I'll shelve the unread Picoult for a while. I'll have some time to forget her modus operandi. I'll read the Atwood and then I'll buy a book by a different author

column1: The first thing I didn't like about this book was the number of non-crock-pot recipes.  It's disconcerting to be reading a slow-cooker cookbook and find salad recipes.  Other books I've read give suggestions (such as
column2: serve this with rice and a salad) but this is the first one to actually include directions for salads and rice.  If I want to make fried corn fritters I will refer to The Frequent Fryers' Cookbook and not a slow cooker book.  The second thing - and what prevented me from even attempting any of the recipes - was that I found inaccuracies in the book.  For example
column3: the first recipe to catch my eye was "Lemon Chicken with Potatoes and Mushrooms."  Yet
column4: when you read the recipe - there are no mushrooms!  Also
column5: the steel-cut oats recipes suggest cooking one cup of oats for 2 servings.  My package directions and personal experience say that a cup of steel cut oats serves 4 once cooked.  These inaccuracies make me wonder what other typos are tucked away in the book.

column1: I just watched this movie version of the classic childrens' book with my wife.  Here are my gut impressions:  First
column2: very little is true to the book.  That's not really a gut impression.  That's the impression I got hearing my wife say "That's not in the book...that's not in the book..."  Actually this movie is more like a computer animation demo than a vehicle for story telling.  It makes for beautiful stills and pictures
column3: and those made me want to see the movie.     I expected a heart warming Christmas story
column4: and what I got was about an hour of frantic scenes of out-of-control railroad and other technology animated like never before with just enough pauses betwen them to remind me why I'm watching.  You get to see...   A kid chasing a ticket through a train
column5: A kid chasing a ticket over the roof of a train
column6: A ticket making its way through the forest -- Rube Goldberg style -- back to the train
column7: (Forty minutes into this movie and one girl's train ticket is the star of the show!)  OK
column8: the ticket sub plot is resolved and we have...  A train sliding out of control on the ice
column9: A train trying to outrun cracks on the ice
column10: A train going full throttle out of control and racing up and down mountain valleys like a roller coaster (fans of the "coaster tycoon" series of computer games will feel right at home) until finally it arrives at the North Pole.   Then
column11: the train car with the central character kids gets detached so we have...  A train car running out of control through Santa's village
column12: Kids getting lost in the Christmas present manufacturing plant and falling through the chutes and machinery of the factory
column13: and then...  Kids getting lost in a bag of presents that is taken by a flying machine to Santa's sled launching pad where the star at the top of the tree is dislodged and nearly impales an innocent elf.  Ho ho ho.  At least let me have a joystick and a couple of buttons so I can help these kids out!  It's like a computer animated train wreck in fast motion.  You know it's awful but you can't look away!    And
column14: you'd better think twice before letting any very young children see this.  It could be very frightening on a big screen with the volume turned up.  My wife and I were going to watch it with our three and six year old sons
column15: and we were very glad that we didn't.  So
column16: what could have been a classic
column17: enduring
column18: and endearing compliment to a classic childrens' Christmas story is little more than a great line for some computer animator to have on his or her resume.  Two thirds of this movie is devoted to stuff that doesn't advance the story or develop the characters one bit.  Whatever a "character driven" story is
column19: this is the opposite.  Never have I seen so many rendered pixels doing so much and accomplishing so little.  I'd rather set up my old American Flyer electric trains and let them run around the tree while I read the book to my kids.

 I believed that I buyed a book of history, but it isn't. From almost the first page the book is full of personal opinions and few history.  The opinions of Anna Reid are simple, the ucranians are very good and the russians very bad,three undred and fifty years together is nothing for her, and in many parts of Ucrania the russian are new occupants - from mid XIX century (sic )- !¡. I hope that Mrs Anna Reid fight for the independence of Scotland with the same strenght she do for Ucrania independence.  I'm sure that Ucrania and Russia will be togheter again in the future, but books like Borderland, cause more pain that it seem at first sight.   If you look for diferences you will find everywhere, but one country is a country because there are more thing that keep united to the people that diferences.   Definitively a bad book of history.   Yours faithfully.   Francisco Martínez Alcalá ( Madrid. Spain )

 I've owned a number of Krups products, including a 17 year old steam espresso maker, and over the years have been consistently very pleased with the design, quality and reliability of the Krups products.  So I decided that it would be nice to have a new espresso maker, perhaps one that has more options and can brew more a bit faster.  After looking at the various products and the reviews of the XP4050 here on Amazon I was somewhat concerned but nevertheless ordered this machine because it appeared to be about what I was seeking.  The reviews gave me some pause but in the end I dismissed them, crediting Krups for past performance and assuming the reviewers were just incompetent or were not patient enough to learn to use the product properly.   HAH!  Boy was I wrong.  My first clue that there was something different about this item was the instruction manual.  I am able to read several languages and was amused to see that the instructions, while close, were not the same in each language.  In fact there were recipes in some languages that were missing from the English version.  What's THAT about?  Then we I tried making my first batch of espresso I found that, as others have complained, I made a mess trying to load the filter.  The next disappointment was the brew... I followed the instructions to the letter (such as they are) and the result was a pretty poor example of espresso.  The attachment for frothing/steaming the milk was not much better and also made a mess.  I put the liquids together for a latté.  Okay... I was impressed with how smooth the taste was, but the espresso itself was just plain pathetic; weak, especially compared to the output of my old machine.  So I gave it another try, this time with twice the coffee and tamping it down more and created another counter-top mess.  This time the brew was stronger, still very smooth, but only about 2/3 the quantity.   Consternation was setting in.  Then I discovered that the drip tray was FULL of liquid!?!  What the heck?  I tried every darn way I could come up with to brew a decent latté over the next couple weeks.  Alas, it was to no avail, each attempt was disappointing in some crucial aspect.  I called Krups and the very nice people suggested that if I was actually doing everything correctly then the unit must be faulty and I should send it in.  I knew that one of my attempts should have been somewhere close to the realm of doing it correctly so I doubt that there is anything faulty with my machine.  I also suspect this since my complaints echoed those I had read.  What a failure this thing is!  I am happily back to using my antique Krups unit that cost me $49, 17 years ago and the XP4050 is in route back.  Each morning I produce a wonderful, adequately strong espresso and the steamed milk is perfectly frothed.  I should have been happy with the old machine all along.  I am so sorry I doubted the other reviewers

column1: This mis-titled book is probably the worst book I've ever purchased from that most respected technical publisher
column2: O'Reilly.  I say the book is mis-titled since it weasel-words the title of "Learning PHP 5" (and all the new OOP re-write) into a few hundred pages devoted to the standard language constructs available in previous versions
column3: and all but omits the real changes incorporated in the new version.  In fact
column4: of the 254 pages in the chaptered part of the book only two pages even mention object oriented programming in this context
column5: and simply recommend other O'Reilly books as reference.  I'm disappointed that O'Reilly would have let this book reach distribution

column1: This is a very strange book: it isn't a book of philosophy and it isn't a book for practice on Personal Time Management.  If you are a CEO or a Vice president you could find something useful (but we hope you've a philosophycal background far more interesting than this book suggests..) but if you're a down on the earth worker .... forget it! When your chief demands the impossible ... explain her/him that  you're a value oriented people and .... find yourself ... fired in 2 seconds!!!

I really don't mean to sound judgmental but this was the very worst book I have ever read.  I mean even Nancy Drew books have more of a mystery than this one did.    I have always heard good things about the Jesse Stone Novels.  This was the first and only one I will read.  I don't know if the grammatical errors were the author's fault or the editor's.  Even the dialogue between characters didn't even have complete sentences.  Very poor sentence structure.  I agree with C. Richard's review..."Distracting" in that there are terrible grammar errors throughout this entire book and was hard to focus.  Ths story was contrite and very easy to figure out way before the end of the book who the culprit was.  This is the only review I have given that has been a poor one.
I highly suggest anyone who wishes to believe the information in this book examine her sources of evidence
column2: statistical studies
column3: clinical trials
column4: and objective studies.  As with most critics of stimulant therapy in ADD patients

column1: Let's get a few things straight. I am a Randy Rogers fan. In fact
column2: a BIG Randy Rogers fan. I was also
column3: at one time
column4: a huge Radney Foster fan
column5: even going so far as to proclaim his albums "See What You Want To See" and "Another Way To Go" (as well as "Texas in 1880" with Pat Green) as some of the best country music ever made. That's a statement I don't make lightly
column6: and I stand by it. I would also include Randy Rogers' albums in that same company. Now before you go all half-cocked telling me that I shouldn't compare an artist's previous work to their new stuff
column7: and that I need to get with the program
column8: let me say that I normally would agree with you. I made every effort to get into "Just A Matter of Time" on its own terms. But the problem here is that "Just A Matter of Time" isn't a Randy Rogers album at all. It isn't even a Randy Rogers BAND album. It is
column9: in fact
column10: a cruel and embarrassing force-feed of everything that Radney Foster wants Randy Rogers to be
column11: right down to vocal inflections
column12: cheesy choruses
column13: and some of the worst and most cliched lyrics imaginable. It is an outright shame that this album should have ever seen the light of day
column14: and I have an awful feeling that we may never see the potential Randy Rogers once had as one of the brightest stars in Texas country.   This isn't the first time a producer has wreaked havoc on an artist's sound
column15: drowning it in their own vision so much that the artist himself becomes a parrot of the producer's ideas and sound. Listening to some of Nickel Creek's albums
column16: for example
column17: you hear so much of Alison Krauss' style and influence that Nickel Creek themselves almost disappear. This is the case with "Just A Matter of Time" in a major
column18: major way. There is so much evidence of Radney Foster's recent love-affair with bland
column19: schmaltzy contemporary adult-pop cheese that there isn't really anything specifically Randy Rogers about the album at all.   The song that will no doubt be singled out as evidence of this trend is "Kiss Me In The Dark"
column20: which is the absolute worst song in Randy Rogers' entire career
column21: and for reasons that may have very little to do with him. I defy anyone to listen to the vocal parts and the bridge and tell me that you're not listening to something from a Radney Foster album. It almost sounds like Rogers is consciously trying to IMITATE Radney Foster's style. In fact
column22: when Rogers isn't singing
column23: I can almost see Foster sitting there salivating in the control booth to get on the mike. And how about the discouraging similarity between "You Could've Left Me" and Foster's "Tired Of Pretending"? Then there's the title track
column24: a song that sounds peeled from Foster's catalog of oversentimentalized acoustic balladeering. By the time we get to "You Don't Know Me"
column25: the closest approximation of anything Randy Rogers-like on the album
column26: you can almost sense that Foster would've vetoed the placement of this song on the album at all
column27: instead opting for a (possibly his own) sapply love ballad in its place. Even when these guys act like they're kicking out the jams
column28: such as with "You Could Change My Mind"
column29: they sound uninspired and bland
column30: like a third-rate battle-of-the-bands contestant at the Potter County Fair. Such a shame.  And to read these lyrics is to turn red with embarrassment. Let's just say that the greater problem with Foster's influence on Rogers when it comes to lyrics lies in an album called "This World We Live In" which came out last year
column31: and demonstrated a massive and sad step backward for Radney Foster's songwriting. Every single lyric on that album is sickly sweet and cliched
column32: like an explosion in a Hallmark Card factory
column33: right down to the meaningless album title. Well
column34: the same is true for Roger's latest
column35: and it's obvious who's to blame. The titles of the songs
column36: the album title
column37: the trite choruses
column38: everything is almost interchangeably bland and silly. It doesn't even matter what song these cliches come from
column39: because they could be from any one of them: "girl
column40: we don't even have to pretend"; "why can't I make up my mind"; "would you steal my heart again and set me free"; "hit me with your heart"; "you're gonna see it your way
column41: I'm gonna see it mine"; and my absolute favorite
column42: "till the morning light". Folks
column43: to hear a guy who once brought me to TEARS with his songs "Can't Slow Down" and "They Call It The Hill Country" reduced to singing stuff like this makes me so disappointed that it's a wonder I can even restrain myself from sending the damn thing back.   What a sad
column44: disappointing tragedy this album is. Some folks are gonna call it a sellout
column45: that's fine. Some people are gonna LOVE it
column46: and that's okay too
column47: since he deserves success
column48: and I'm happy for him. But as for me
column49: you can count me out. It was bad enough seeing Radney Foster disintegrate into the Barry Manilow of Texas country last year

column51: and I ain't liking it. Not one bit

column1: I had to read Jared Diamond's Pulitzer prize winning book because of the rave reviews and acclaim. The thoughts that he introduces in the book are certainly interesting and he presents us with a new way to interpret history which is certainly important. However

column7: "Collapse" - a terrific read that should be of interest to everyone -it relates our industrialization to every aspect of the environment and show historically how this has shaped history. It has major rammifications for our situation on this earth right now. -RK

column1: I originally wrote a relatively favorable review for this book because it seemed to incorporate the best of the original Butler's Lives (a focus on meditating on the life of the saint) and the new calendar of saints (including many recent canonizations).  While it does do the second
column2: I am afraid to say that it is woefully inadequate regarding the first.  In fact
column3: it is probably just as bad as the Atwater/Thurston edition.  For instance
column4: here is part of the section from January 27th on St. Angela Merici: "Accounts of her [St. Angela Merici's] childhood make her pious
column5: rebelling against the fashions of the age
column6: devoted to the legend of St. Ursula
column7: and the recipient of a vision showing a great company of virgins and other saints coming down from heaven to her.  They included a dead sister
column8: who invited her to form a great 'Company of Virgins
column9: ' which was what Angela had actually done by the time the account was written."  In other words
column10: the author wants to point out that the story "must" not be true because it wasn't written down until after the alleged vision had been fulfilled.  Now
column11: we are certainly not bound to believe all the accounts in the various lives of the saints
column12: but I do not understand the point of drawing attention to the alleged falsity of a tale in the context of a meditative reading.  If the work seeks to be encyclopedic
column13: it is much too short and you should check on the 12-vol. counterpart
column14: but for a daily meditation (which it seems reasonable to assume such a work is designed to be)
column15: such statements are misplaced.  If the story is too absurd to be believed
column16: just don't include it.  As a result
column17: it is disappointing because it would be useful to have a modern Butler's that can be used for a daily devotional or meditation.  Instead
column18: we are left with the old works that do not match the current calendar

column7: the other

column1: In short
column2: the film does a fairly good job of getting the message across
column3: as it should do
column4: in making people aware of the evils of war and the fact that the international community is often slow to act. At the same time
column5: however
column6: it does not provide a balanced examination of the situation on the ground
column7: which only weakens the very effect it is trying to create. What the film ends up doing is the one thing it must avoid at all cost in order to be effective: NOT to choose sides.  The Catholic Croats and the Muslims are the "victims
column8: while the Orthodox Serbs are wholly to blame...  That is neither witty nor wise when trying to carry out a noble cause."  There is a term used in such situations and it's called... propaganda! A more balanced and objective approach (i.e. there are no good guys and bad guys in such conflicts) with less bias and closed mindedness would have made the film more effective and therefore
column9: more successful. The ultimate goal is good
column10: but the method used is not necessarily the correct one. Another setback is in relation to the acting (or lack of it); that is to say that the cast are badly in need of acting lessons (with the exception of Woody Harrelson)!  The acting-oh my- the acting is beyond words...  School plays (and pre-school for that matter) have better actors!  It is truly sad... Yet another weakness is in relation to the very poor dialogues and the weak plot/storyline for which the writers and director are to blame. In conclusion
column11: the potential for a good movie was there if only the writers/director had the ability to... write and direct!  A shame really...

column1: I'm not a member of Douglas' target audience.  That much is obvious as soon as the book opens.  Nevertheless
column2: I was willing to give her the benefit of the doubt.  I don't consider myself to be a sexist
column3: though I wouldn't label myself a feminist
column4: either.  I'm sympathetic to some of the goals of the feminist movement: equal pay for equal work; non-discrimination in employment; basically
column5: equal rights across the board.  What Douglas advocates in her book
column6: however
column7: is not equal rights.  It is special rights
column8: and I believe that women like Douglas are the reason the feminist movement often gets such a bad rap.  Government-funded child care
column9: taxpayer-supported abortions
column10: national health insurance
column11: Social Security for homemakers
column12: and many other socialist policies are proposed as solutions to what were predominantly cultural issues
column13: not legal impediments to equality (though I'm not denying that they existed
column14: and still exist in some cases today).  She often uses her book to make ad hominem attacks against anyone further right on the political spectrum than Ted Kennedy
column15: at one point calling Walt Disney a "right-wing reactionary" for his support of Barry Goldwater in 1964.  She further declares that Richard Nixon's election in 1968 convinced her that "America was not a democracy at all" and that "the status quo was inhumane and monstrous."  She uses her book as a forum to protest the Vietnam war
column16: lend support to black radicalism
column17: and basically do anything she can to distract attention from the fact that the feminist movement was extremely radical and that perhaps the ERA went down to defeat because people truly did understand what was at stake and chose to reject it.  As for the main subject matter of this book
column18: any movie
column19: TV show
column20: or song which did not depict women getting the best of men had deleterious effects on the female psyche and made her feel worthless as a person.  The most absurd moment
column21: for me
column22: came when Douglas felt the need to refer to all sorts of phallic symbols in various westerns.  I'm sorry if it offends her
column23: but the cowboys' "shiny metal oblongs" were not designed to oppress women
column24: they were designed to shoot small oblongs at other cowboys with oblongs.  It's one thing to see a sexist message in I Dream of Jeannie; it's quite something else to be pig-headed for its own sake.  Douglas' failure to remain objective makes this book an unenjoyable read for anyone whose politics are not those of the extreme left.  ..

column5: a famous writer.  Unlike Bonfire of the Vanities
column6: this book has no compelling narrative - the voice" shifts from one character to the next and the story ambles along as these young adults try to figure out what they want

column10: the daughter betrays her father by marrying the man who would dethrone the "Emperor" etc. etc.) -- and all the mess just goes away after the attacks on September 11
column11: 2001.  But we never learn how September 11 affected Messud's characters - she uses that fateful day as an excuse to bring the curtain down on this stupid story going nowhere.

column1: After hearing so much about the book
column2: I must admit to a disappointment in its contents.  As a Belgian that has immigrated to the USA
column3: I am well familiar with the many contrasts between Europe and the US and found Mr. Reid's observations to be lacking both in perspective and completeness.  For example
column4: Mr Reid appears enamored with the European welfare state
column5: vaunts its many virtues and describes it as a central pillar of the new "European identity" that is superior to the barbarous American model
column6: but admits in small print in its Appendix that the European welfare state faces a crisis that far surpasses the US social security system in magnitude and will not survive in its present form.  I felt that a fair discussion on the topic should have included a discussion on the countless challenges to the welfare state.  I thought that many of his other observations lacked the same kind of roundness.  I felt that the book lack depths and was primarily suitable to a reader in search of a caricature on the relationship between Europe and America.

column2: there are companies that specialize in data mining as much information on us as they can.  The present administration is drooling over the possibility to use this information. column11: Maine
column12:
whom he admits was probably accused and convicted of a crime other than witchcraft.  Had Mr. Stevens done his homework, he would have included the fact that the Rev. George Burroughs, one of the men hanged at Salem in 1692, was living and preaching in the Casco Bay area of Maine at the time he was arrested for the practice of witchcraft.  Additionally, Maine is famous for its lighthouses, many of which are said to be haunted.  I can name 10 haunted lighthouses in Maine without even thinking yet, Mr. Stevens comes up with only five.  Either he has no interest whatsoever in the supernatural and/or folklore, or he lacks the ability to research a subject.  There are some wonderful books about supernatural events in Maine, but this isn't one of them.

 This was recommended to me by someone on LiveJournal. I hate to say this, but I really didn't like it at all. I thought I would, but after the first few pages I knew it was going to be difficult to get through it. The major problem is that I couldn't relate to the author at all. I think it may be because I don't take reading as seriously as she does. All the books she referred to were classics, heavy reading for intellectuals. Then she spent some time talking about how she thought movies weren't a worthwhile form of art and how horrible it was that some books were made into movies. These viewpoints go completely against what I believe and the way she put them across made her come off rather haughty. The book also seems a bit like someone talking about their own vacation. By the middle of the book, I realized I would rather be reading a good book than reading about somebody reading

 I like to use the Amazon reviews when purchasing books, especially alert for dissenting perceptions about higly rated items, which usually disuades me from a selection.  So I offer this review that seriously questions the popularity of this work - I found it smug, self-serving and self-indulgent, written by a person with little or no empathy, especially for the people he castigates. For example, his portrayal of the family therapist seems implausible and reaches for effect and panders to the  shrink" bashers of the world. This "play for effect" tone throughout the book was very distasteful to me

column1: DREAM CATCHER
column2: by Margaret A. Salinger
column3: is easily the most loathsome book I've read in a decade.  Ms. Salinger
column4: J. D. Salinger's daughter
column5: is so unsympathettic an individual that by the halfway mark of this disjointed and far-too-long narrative
column6: I was finding fresh cause for disgust on every page.  Her parents weren't perfect
column7: no
column8: but my sympathies are with them nonetheless.  Ms. Salinger's problems are often normal growing pains.  When they are not
column9: they stem largely from being the product of an unhappy marriage and from the isolation of a rural upbringing (as has been noted in other reviews).  Her problems are decidedly not due to her father's celebrity
column10: a non-issue as he has so laboriously avoided those trappings for decades.  Ms. Salinger is a malcontent: she can't stand her parents' attention; she can't stand her parents' perceived neglect.  She is a hypocrit: she steals $150 from her brother's bank account (for which she never expresses any remorse) to pay for an abortion
column11: but years later
column12: pregnant again
column13: single and with no appreciable income
column14: stridently condemns her father for mentioning abortion as an option.  She is self-destructive: her initial bouts of "madness" are clearly alcohol-related blackouts
column15: yet it never occurs to her to stop drinking.  She has reached middle-age still believing that every bad thing that ever happened to her is someone else's fault
column16: and this is both the saddest and most annnoying part of the book.  Ms. Salinger is not a tremendously talented writer.  However
column17: she is done an atrocious disservice by her editors.  The footnotes are silly
column18: the narrative digressive to the point at times of incoherence
column19: some of Ms. Salinger's comments nonsensical.  In a passage quoted here by other reviewers
column20: in which Holden Caufield imagines himself a catcher in the rye
column21: Ms. Salinger writes: "When I read this passage as an adult with a child of my own
column22: my first reaction was outrage...Where were the grown-ups? Why are those kids allowed to play so close to the edge of a cliff?"  Hmmm...I thought that passage was the fantasy of a fictitous
column23: troubled teenager.  Perhaps J. D.'s intent there was to write not a parenting tip
column24: but something true to Holden's character.  If the purposes of writing this memoir were
column25: as Ms. Salinger claims
column26: for personal catharsis and as a lesson for her son
column27: both those aims would have been fully realized by completing the manuscript and handing it directly to her son.  Ms. Salinger does more than that
column28: however.  She publishes.  And this smacks not only of cashing in on her surname with the only form of her writing ever likely to see the light of day
column29: but of a vindictive slap in her father's face
column30: yet another round in a family feud from which we'd all best keep our distance

column1: "The Future of War" predicts US dominance of warfare throughout the 21st Century
column2: as a result of US advanced technology in general and precision weaponry in particular. Their train of thought has considerable merit
column3: and deserves reading and thoughtful attention. However
column4: the book suffers from the same two major flaws as most books by visionaries without enough practical experience: misunderstanding of specific happenings in the past
column5: and unlikely projections into the far future. Having been involved with US defense for 50 years
column6: as a member of the military
column7: as a designer and developer and advisor on US weaponry
column8: and as an advisor on strategic
column9: operational and tactical issues
column10: I read this book with considerable amusement
column11: although I do take seriously much of what it says. I shall give specifics on two failures to understand the details of the past
column12: and then offer criticism of two of the book's projections
column13: as examples.  Past episode #1: The 1991 precision strikes against Iraq. There is no doubt that our air strikes and land attacks in the 1991 campaign to liberate Kuwait were exceedingly effective
column14: and there is no doubt that this effectiveness was largely due to our precision weaponry. However
column15: to do precision strikes
column16: whether with airborne munitions or ground forces
column17: it's necessary to know what targets to attack
column18: where they are
column19: and what weapons are likely to be effective against a particular target. In the 1991 campaign
column20: this effort was undertaken by the "Jeddi Knights"
column21: largely under the guidance of Col. John Warden. The key role of the "Jeddi Knights" was to establish priorities and mission profiles for which targets to strike when with what munitions
column22: and they did this extraordinarily well. What the Friedmans obviously don't know is the amount of detailed information that was available to the "Jeddi Knights"
column23: carefully acquired over the 70 years preceding the campaign
column24: first by the British until about 1950
column25: and thereafter by the US military. The armed forces of major powers assume they may have to fight wars on short notice aganst opponents who have been designated shortly before by national authorities
column26: so they invest a great deal in gathering information pertinent to how various campaigns might be conducted. In the case of Iraq
column27: the British did very careful mapping from 1920 until about 1950
column28: producing "ordnance" maps of higher detail and accuracy than exist even for some parts of the United States
column29: and these were invaluable to planners. Then
column30: starting in about 1950
column31: when it began to seem possible that the US might someday have to fight somewhere in the Middle East
column32: the US military carefully gathered information relevant to how a campaign might be fought
column33: and which potential enemy targets should be candidates for destruction. These studies resided in US intelligence and military archives until the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait
column34: and were then used as the basis for planning the campaign.  Two examples of this. First
column35: the destruction of certain bridges was given high priority not to impede vehicular movement
column36: but to sever the communications cables running under the bridges; our planners knew which cables important to Iraqi Command and Control were buried too deeply to destroy easily except where they were routed under bridges
column37: and therefore which bridges to take out to disrupt Iraqi military communications. Second
column38: the swing by US
column39: British and French forces far to the West
column40: the "Hail Mary" gambit
column41: would not have been possible in that harsh terrain unless viable routes for armor and supply vehicles were known
column42: and the Iraqi Army either didn't know of such routes or didn't believe we could know of them. There are exactly two feasible routes
column43: and both were used; they can both be determined in complete detail from careful study of the British Ordnance maps prepared in the 1930s
column44: and (although I wasn't involved in the campaign planning) I had no difficulty in finding and plotting the only two feasible routes before the ground campaign began
column45: from the good maps in my possession. I also understand why it was necessary to bring the two prototype JSTARS systems to the theatre
column46: to detect and allow blocking of any Iraqi strike intended to sever the Tapline Road; this was also evident from the maps.  By contrast
column47: we had no success at all in locating and destroying mobile Scud missile launchers
column48: because they moved around with great frequency. If you don't know where something is
column49: no precision of your weaponry
column50: and no amount of technical sophistication or military skill
column51: will allow you to destroy it.  Past example #2: The SAFEGUARD BMD system. The Friedmans say
column52: on the basis of assertions by people who may or may not be experts
column53: that SAFEGUARD was deactivated because it wouldn't work. In fact the situation was exactly the reverse
column54: but one must know the purpose of SAFEGUARD and its mode of operation to understand what actually happened. The mission of SAFEGUARD was to prevent complete success of a Soviet counterforce first strike against our Minuteman ICBM fields
column55: by opening a "launch window" for a retaliatory strike by the Minuteman missiles in the face of a full-scale Soviet strike. I helped to plan and design that system
column56: and it would have done what it was intended to
column57: although at a horrible increased toll of death and destruction
column58: which I dreaded
column59: but could see no alternative to in the face of rapidly increasing Soviet capability. Far more important than the fact that we knew SAFEGUARD would work was the fact that the Soviets concluded it would work; that realization brought them back to the bargainng table at the Helsinki talks
column60: and led to the SALT I treaty
column61: which I rejoiced about. Provisions of that treaty made SAFEGUARD unnecessary
column62: and that's why the one completed SAFEGUARD site was deactivated and construction on the other sites was stopped.  Also on the subject of balistic missile defense
column63: the Friedmans assert that midcourse discrimination and destruction of incoming warheads is infeasible. This is simply not true
column64: although there is an exceedingly serious problem associated with doing it. I know three quite different ways of doing midcourse discrimintion and destruction of enemy incoming warheads
column66: given that I've been out of that business for more than 10 years
column67: I expect that other ways are known by now. The problem is that
column68: at least for the three ways I know
column69: one is politically unacceptable to the US Congress and the US public
column70: one is so expensive that it's unlikely Congress would ever fund it
column73: would be usable for certain other military purposes that would probably lead to a renewed arms race as our potential major opponents sought to counter it. (I was one of a small group of scientists who successfully recommended to Congress that development of that third approach be stopped
column74: to avoid the resulting foreseeable escalation; scientists and military professionals
column75: despite various comments in the Friedmans' book
column76: work closely together over years and decades
column77: and come to have considerable knowledge of each other's fields.) Whether at some future time it may become desirable to develop and deploy a BMD system that does midcourse discrimination and destruction of warheads is a political and diplomatic question to be decided by the public and its elected leaders
column78: on which I have no insight
column79: but it is technically feasible.  Now
column81: what the Friedmans fail to understand in their glowing vision of US technology dominating future warfare
column82: is that for every technical advance
column83: opponents can devise at least partial countermeasures
column84: and that therefore no amount of technology as such can determine the outcome of a campaign. The Coalition conquest of Iraq in 2003 provides an excellent example. Although large parts of the Iraqi army
column85: and all of its top leadership
column87: other large parts of the Iraqi army were composed of thoroughly trained officers and enlisted men
column88: who fully understood that if they confronted US forces nose to nose
column89: they would be destroyed. Understanding this
column90: very many of the best Iraqi units simply demobilized themsleves and disappeared into the civilian population as Coalition forces approached
column91: in many cases taking their weaponry with them. One entire Iraqi division near the border with Iran totally vanished before we got to its bases; everyone from the division commander to the most junior private. Professional soldiers
column93: have no more desire than anyone else to be killed pointlessly in a situation where they are unable to resist effectively.  A substantial fraction of these well-trained
column94: motivated Iraqi forces subsequently emerged as part of the resistance movement that continues in Iraq. How many of the resistance fighters come from that crowd is obviously impossible to know for sure
column95: but my personal estimate is that about 30
column96: 000 of Saddam Hussein's best and most loyal troops and officers became part of the resistance movement. And our overwhelming superiority in all aspects of conventional warfare have been far less effective against current Iraqi resistance methods; the resistance movement seems to be gradually weakening and fragmenting
column97: but it's a long slow process
column98: in which our precision weapons and our advanced communications and intelligence give us far less of an advantage than they do in conventional warfare.  There are various other gaps in the Friedmans' assessment of the future. I'll mention only two of many. First
column100: often touted as the most effective weapon of the 21st Century
column101: have had only relatively diappointing results so far. Why? Partly because technical improvements to vircators are needed; those will surely come along in due course. Much more serious is the fact that battle damage asssessment after a vircator strike is at present almost impossible to do with any degree of accuracy
column102: so after a target has been attacked with one or more vircators
column103: there is no practical way to know whether the strike was successful or not. Presumably some day we will overcome this particular problem
column104: but it illustrates that new and potentially formidable technology may find relatively little application because of purely tactical and operational problems that arise in using it.  As my second example
column105: I'll remark on the Friedmans' vision of US infantrymen as being in effect "cocooned" in future to protect them from the enemy's weapons. This vision ignores two serious problems. First
column106: no "cocoon" imaginable can protect an infantryman against certain weapons such as a fuel-air bomb if the enemy knows approximately where the infantryman is. Second
column108: anyone with substantial experience in concealing himself in a hostile environment
column110: knows all too well that the more accoutrements one has
column111: the harder it is to hide and not be observed. In light clothing and carrying only light personal weapons
column112: I can disappear into the landscape almost anywhere
column113: and move around unnoticed; burdened with excess equipment and elaborate protective clothing
column114: only certain carefully selected spots can offer concealment. Everyone with experience in this matter knows as much as I do on this subject
column115: so infantrymen whose lives depend on not being observed will move far more cautiously when heavily burdened than when lightly armed and lightly protected. That doesn't mean infantry should be sent into combat inadequately equipped
column116: but it does mean that the increased effectiveness of some given number of trained infantry when provided with extra combat capability and protective equipment is far less than one might otherwise suppose.  I could cite dozens of other matters
column118: which the Friedmans book misunderstands or overlook
column119: but this is enough. I'll just say that the book is an excellent source of ideas
column120: but should be viewed with practiced skepticism

column1: Although this book was recommended to me by a professional I must say that I was terribly disappointed. Out of the entire book the only part I actually did agree with was that in general a lot of us treat dogs as humans when they really should be treated like the animals that they are.   With that in mind
column2: Donaldson believes dogs to be quite stupid and not capable of working for anything other than food. I have had and trained dogs for years and have never had to result to such pandering. Dog's are extremely intelligent and can be taught anything without giving a treat every few seconds. (She even suggests using cut up hot dogs to 'motivate' your dog. Those hot dogs with all the perservatives and additives are going to do more damage to the dog than whatever the behavior is worth.)  She focuses an inordinate amount of time to teaching a dog to fetch saying that this one move will solve most other problems. I can't disagree more. The things that works best for dogs is exercise and strong leadership. Besides
column3: some breeds are generally not interested in playing fetch but rather doing the activites for which is bred in the first place.  Also
column4: Donaldson tries to refute Pack Theory
column5: which takes into account the fact that dogs evolved from wolves and hence have a strict social hierarchy
column6: by showing her own ignorance on the subject. In her view she only sees dominance as being cruel and punishing your dog into submission. When in reality it alleviates the need for punishing since your dog will do what you say because he knows that you are the boss.  Throughout the book she contradicts herself constantly on her own points. This shows me that she does not have a great deal of self examination of her own information and that it isn't worth much.  I believe that her book does very little to help people with dogs that have any issues whatsoever.   I recommend Cesar Milan's book and his approach. I have used several of his techniques with no damage to my dog
column7: as Donaldson would have you believe
column8: and I got the results that I wanted.   Do not buy Culture Clash as it is really only good for being recycled.

And at some point I just grew sick of the characters and their weird little lives.   Ultimately

column6: it wasn't so terribly rewarding for the reader.

column1: I have long considered myself a Christian with moderate theological views
column2: standing between the extremes of both right wing fundamentalism and liberalism.  So when I saw this book on the shelf I looked forward to reading it.  Unfortunately Bawer's idea of a "fundamentalist" is anyone to the right of the notorious Bishop Spong.  Time and again he employs the "either/or" fallacy: either one is an enlightened
column3: left-wing
column4: revisonist
column5: touchy-feely
column6: creed-hating "Christian" or a naive
column7: dim-witted Bible thumper.  Nowhere in Bawer's prejudice is there any sign of the tolerance he lambasts others for lacking.  Nor is there any mention of believers such as Tony Campolo
column8: Jim Wallis
column9: Luke Timothy Johnson or Ron Sider
column10: who stand in the center of many political and theological issues. According to Bawer such individuals simply don't exist.  In addition he makes numerous false statments.  A glaring example in on page 40
column11: where he claims that the doctrine of the substitutionary atonement was invented by Augustine in the fifth century.  He ignores Jesus' own statements  throughout the four gospels on the meaning of his death.    In fact he shamelessly employs a pick and choose approach to Christ which ignores anything the Lord said that doesn't fit his politically correct conception of the Saviour.  The result is a Jesus that resembles Alan Alda far more than the character portrayed in Scripture.  I could go into detail about these weaknesses
column12: but to do so would simply be a repetition of prior reviewers.  Suffice it to say that those looking for a balanced treatment of Christian fundamentalism should look elsewhere.

column1: Like most reviewers
column2: I grew up with this book and loved it as a child.  However
column3: even then I had one question:  why call him "Little BLACK Sambo"?  Why not just "Little Sambo"?    Many reviewers here have defended this book against the charges of racism.  One guy even goes so far as to say if you think it's racist you hate other cultures.  I don't have a clue as to what that is supposed to mean
column4: but this book is racist.  Just is.  However
column5: instead of saying "is" or "is not"
column6: I'm actually going to explain my opinion.    This book was written by a Scottish woman living in India in 1899.  The original illustrations
column7: presumably replicated in this edition
column8: feature Sambo
column9: Mumbo
column10: and Jumbo as having inky black skin and big red lips.  Subsequent American volumes had drawing of the characters in blackface.  As a result of these exaggerated illustrations
column11: the word "Sambo" became a racial slur in America directed at African-Americans.    Now
column12: as another reviewer noted
column13: this is set in India
column14: not Africa.  I'm not sure how that is meant to excuse the book
column15: but I'm guessing that since the word Sambo was directed as a slur against African-Americans
column16: we can safely chock that up to a misreading of the book by Americans.  Not so.  A glimpse at the history of race
column17: and specifically "blackness" will show that Indians
column18: Africans
column19: and even the Irish were considered "black".  "Black" in this sense meaning both a physical characteristic as well as a way of saying "other than Anglo".  It was a claim also that was disparaging to their "perceived" level of sophistication as human beings.  As such
column20: words such as the "n-word" (I won't spell it out since this is a page for a kid's book) were levelled at Africans and Indians (and Irishmen) equally.  It stands to reason
column21: then
column22: that "Sambo" was a derrogatory term lobbed at all who were looked upon as savage
column23: different
column24: or unequal to "white" folks.  This cannot be ignored
column25: nor excused.  Ms. Bannerman's Sambo stories have historically done a lot of damage
column26: and even added a racial slur to American speech.  This is not just
column27: as one person says
column28: over-sensitive adults overreacting.  If you are an African-American and have been called a "sambo" it's hardly overreacting to take offense.  This book
column29: historically
column30: has had a place in the canon of racist western literature
column31: and no amount of charm the story has can change this unfortunate fact

column1: President Ulysses Grant called the 1846 U.S. invasioin of Mexico
column2: "the most unjust war ever waged by a stronger against a weaker nation."  I see whatever piece of the "American Dream" that immigrants (legal or not) get from coming here as a sort of reparations for all the harm our military empire has caused other nations.  Pat Buchanan has said
column3: "if people don't want terrorism
column4: we have to give up our empire."  I think he's right
column5: I'd just add that the same goes for immigration.  To curb the influx of economic refugees
column6: we have to reform NAFTA
column7: end the exploitative behavior of transnationals (many US-based) in the maquilladoras
column8: support Fair Trade
column9: end the dirty work of places like the School of the Americas and figures like "Economic Hit Men
column10: and so forth.  Moreover, Wooldridge and others often speak as if the Minute Men" are the only civic group working on the issue of immigration.  Thankfully
column11: there are groups like the American Friends Service Committee and Border Links that have a much more intelligent analysis of migration
column12: and far more humane approaches to this complex issue.  As General Smedley Butler said
column13: "war is a racket
column14: and that includes this war on immigrants.  There is a lot of money that is being made from the building of a high-tech fence, aerial drones, motion sensors, videocameras, detention centers, and the other equipment of a police state.  If we let that industry grow because of one scare or another . . . well, we won't recognize this country as the land of the free and the home of the brave.  Rather than Wooldridge's fear and resentment-mongering, I'd recommend the upcoming boook by Free Speech Radio News host, Deepa Fernandes, which is titled, Targeted: Homeland Security and the Business of Immigration."  We could also learn a lot by listening to the leaders of Mexico's own movements for justice.  There are many books and DVDs available regarding the courageous efforts of the Zapatistas.  "I would rather die on my feet
column15: than live a lifetime on my knees."  -Emiliano Zapata

column8: there is no bluntness
column9: and everything must be doused in the most stringy and free-formed words he can think of. Why? In some cases it adds to the story... in this

column11: they are all surrounded by a lot of words that don't really say anything.  Bottom line: you can skip this book. However
column12: those interested in religion and questioning said relgion will probably read it anyway. I would suggest you get a durable copy because you will want to throw it against the wall a few times. column1: I read so many good reviews of this book that I had to get it for the Halloween season. It begins with an interesting and mysterious premise but soon evolves into pages of story with little excitement. I am at the last 5o pages of the book and perhaps I will find out why everyone else found this book so good. An antique book seller and his daughter operate a dusty old shop with valuable books. The daughter is invited by one of the top authors of the day to write her biography although she has been a recluse and resists others attempts to find out the truth of her life. The common thread between the author and biographer is that they are both twins. I am married to an identical twin and I am baffled by the excessive concentration on this one topic. Wait for it to go on the discount table

column1: If you're lookiing for valuable insight into how great businesses were conceived and executed this is not the book for you. Each business is given only a few pages of what essentially amounts to fluff. Most of the information is anecdotal in nature and rarely goes beyond the sort of superficial treatment one might get in People magazine. The articles reminded me of something a high school student might turn in as a short essay assignment. The roster of companies chosen is rather suspect. There is disproportionate representation by the cosmetics and fashion industries. I think that every company that sells makeup is covered here. Many of the other selections are some of the more glamorous and obvious success stories. C'mon
column2: we ALL know the MicroSoft story by now. I was also puzzled by the lack of variety in the writing. Time and time again profit is referred to as "turnover"
column3: going public is referred to as "floating"
column4: a line of products is called a "range" -- was this book edited? I cannot recommend this book for business persons. It may be appropriate for a young person who has not been exposed to these canned legends before.

column1: This book would be really wonderful for kids who are going through a divorce where their daddy is a louse.  The book portrays the father as a deadbeat who doesn't bother to show up for visitations even though he only has them one night a week.  What does this book say that a divorce is?  "A divorce meant that Daddy would not live with Mama
column2: Ruth
column3: and Dinah anymore." I know how impressionable kids are
column4: how is this supposed to be an unbiassed view of divorce?  In my mind this book is designed to taint the mind of impressionable children to make them wonder whether their daddy was going to treat them with the same carelessness as Daddy Bear.  I would warn fathers who find themselves in a divorce to think carefully before allowing their children to read this book

column1: Iles tries to imitate Michael Crichton with bits of Dan Brown's Digital Fortress in this book.  Unfortunately this book does not make it.  The NSA is backing a project called Trinity which is to develop a super quantum computer that is controlled by a brainscan of a human mind.  Two of the individuals involved with the project want it halted and one dies in an apparent stroke which was actually induced by the NSA bad guys (why does the NSA always have to be portrayed as the bad guys in these books?).  David Tennant is the other individual and he gets away by stopping an unstoppable hitman and then persuades his psychiatrist to run with him
column2: even though she thinks he is mentally unstable.  The plot really gets out of hand with Tennant having visions of being Jesus
column3: being portrayed to the Secret Service as the next Oswald and escaping the entire Washington DC police and SWAT units and ultimately getting out the country with a false passport
column4: going to Israel and then persuading the head of the Moussad to help him.  As crazy as it sounds the end is literally unbelievable that would even make a James Bond fan cringe.  The author has written some great tense books (24 Hours
column5: Sleep No More) so I just chalk this one up to an experiment gone awry.

column1: They were on sale
column2: and I ordered 2. They arrived separately in two HUGE boxes - via UPS - and looked like they had both been dropped from about 10 stories up. Sigh... The mats themselves had broken and cracked rubber backing. I guess they got beaten up in transit. The actual pattern in the mats is beautiful and the fiber is nice and dense. So - I kept them. They are outside and hopefully they won't fall apart too quickly.  If you are really picky
column3: you better take a good look at these when they are delivered

column1: CoT is a rather disjointed attempt at a historical narrative that I strongly suspect was culled from a dozen or so different journals from settlers. This is not well done history and a rather tiresome read. I found it amazing that there was almost no discussion of the culture or way of life of the aborigines. The discussion of the English settlers seems to focus on sex and punishment. What about the organization of the colony? How did the colonists manage their day-to-day lives to survive those first worst years?  For anyone who has a serious interest in history
column2: CoT misses the mark by a wide margin. Not recommended

column3: combined with weak character development and far too many adjectives in every sentence

Morgan is a middle aged man who leaves his wife and many children for a much younger woman (that he seems to stalk for a while).  There are so many disturbing factors in this book that revolve around the main character (stalking of his new wife
column2: impersonating a doctor
column3: impersonating a postal worker
column4: etc) that it made it very difficult to empathize with any of the emotions he might have had.  The book also seems to 'glaze' over the 'weirdness' of these behaviors.

column1: As a classics major in college
column2: I have been regularly referred to the Roman section of this work to gain increased general knowledge over later classical antiquity. After thoroughly reading and rereading many sections
column3: I can scarcely say I've gleaned anything close to that.  The "chapters" read more like non-peer reviewed articles that are virtually impossible to understand for the casual reader
column4: and very difficult for classics students. They constantly diverge from their central theses
column5: lack chronological sequence both within themselves and in relation to other chapters
column6: use highly colloquial terms and accentuate seemingly arbitrary themes throughout history while ignoring others.  Cases in point: Marius' name is mentioned about 3 times
column7: and never in regards to his own exploits. Cinna is missing entirely as far as I can tell. The Catilinarian conspiracy receives about half a paragraph (even though Sallust devoted a book to it and Cicero couldn't shut up about his own involvement)
column8: as do the Gracchi brothers
column9: and Cato the Elder
column10: but we receive heaps of names about obscure groups in the Italian peninsula during Rome's expansion
column11: whose importance as individual tribes is obfuscated by varying levels of information which seem to lead nowhere
column12: while their individual legacies are absent. The exact identities of  "Roman"
column13: "Etruscan"
column14: "Latin"
column15: and "Italian" are anyone's guess. When the political division between the "populares" and "optimati" are introduced
column16: the latter term is left undefined. Very
column17: very shoddy.  I have not read the Greek section yet and refrain from commenting upon it.  The Roman section of this text
column18: I think
column19: is a disgrace to the Oxford University Press. If you want to learn about classical history
column20: I suggest you read an array of entries from the Oxford Classical Dictionary
column21: a thick but condensed reference work that cuts through much of the subjective interpretation of events to the meat of the matter
column22: giving you the "who's who" and "what's what" in concise entries

column1: Unlike most reviewers here
column2: I really disliked this book.  The main reason is that the entire novel is a gimmick without any real substance.  There is no reason to tell such a dull story except for the fact that there is some mysterious story-within-a-story complexity.  The characters
column3: especially the protagonist Iris
column4: are bores.  Iris is like a 300 page wet blanket.  Most of the other characters are 1-dimensional cut outs.  Her sister Laura is the exception
column5: but she got on my nerves too with her one-note quirkiness.  The story-within-a-story is more a gimmick than anything else.  The science-fiction meta-story within that story I thought was the most interesting part of the book
column6: but it goes nowhere and its purpose is even more tenuous than its parent.  Finally
column7: this is my second Atwood book
column8: and I really dislike her writing style.  It reads as if she is trying too hard
column9: and even the simplest situations feel forced.  I don't understand why everyone seems to like this book
column10: but I would just suggest not to believe all the hype.
