column1: This book wants to make you a Christian
column2: it tells you that Mo is bad and Jesus is good. It's very unfair as it trumpets the merits of Jesus while saying Mo was cruel and self-indulgent.  ..but it makes no mention of Jesus's bad points and the nasty bits in the New testament where for instance Jesus encourages the beating of slaves (Luke 12:47) and the bit where Jesus tells you to burn unbelievers (John 15:6
column3: Matthew 13:41-42).  Dr Gabriel obviously loves Jesus and hates Muhammad but for all Muhammad's faults he wasn't dumb enough to curse a fig-tree for not bearing fruit while it was out of season (Matthew 21:18-19
column4: Mark 11:13-14).  Dr Gabriel also tells you with relish that Muhammad stole from trade caravans by going on ghazi raids on enemy merchants but he fails to point out that Jesus broke the law by stealing corn on the Sabbath (Mark 2:23)
column5: and he encouraged his disciples to take a horse without asking permission (Matthew 21).  The point i'm trying to make (rather laboriously) is that neither Jesus or Mo were perfect and that both men did some awful things in their times and great suffering has often resulted from their respective legacies and folks like Dr Gabriel don't help us understand things by selectively reading the bible and quran and dissing one guy while extolling the merits of the other.   this really is a stupid and infantile book ...does this guy really have a PhD?

column1: Take a step back from your revulsion (a healthy human reaction

Anna Pigeon as a person is fast becoming a 1-dimensional charicature of the person we met in the first few books; at the same time the author is digging a Natchez Trace of a rut in plot progression - repackaging over again the crazed killer whose insanity is able to drive him through repeated injury to keep after Anna page after page after page. column5: and not a personal problem of the author's.   If one separated the pages of character development from the pages of "insanity-driven bogeyman keeps coming toward Anna" in any recent Nevada Barr book

column1: A carjacking case and a missing 4-year-old boy trigger tension in a fictional town of New Jersey. "Freedomland" which is based on Richard Price's book and stars Samuel L. Jackson and Julianne Moore
column2: could have been a gritty thriller with a better hand like Spike Lee (who did "Clockers" based on Price's book). Unfortunately
column3: in spite of its occasionally interesting moments
column4: "Freedomland" falls flat with lack of sure-handed direction.  Julianne Moore plays Brenda whose four-year-old son is missing. Police detective Lorenzo played by Samuel L. Jackson thinks something is wrong with her testimony as to how her boy was kidnapped
column5: but finding the missing child is not easy as the injured mother suffers severely from the shock and her traumatic past. The film also involves several scenes of racially-triggered violence.  Every part of the film is decently made. They are shot with authentic locations
column6: good supports (from Edie Falco
column7: Ron Eldard and William Forsyth) and intense acting from Moore. She is so intense at times that some may think she is overdoing it
column8: but anyway she is credible as tormented mother. Still something is not just right like Brenda's testimony.  [CLUMSY STORYTELLING] So many things are going on at one time. The film at first centers around the mystery of a missing boy
column9: and then it raises a question about the conflict among the Afro-Americans. Instead of developing these ideas
column10: director Joe Roth introduces new topics one after another into the story. As a result the mystery of the kidnapped boy never becomes intriguing. Lorenzo's inner struggle as black detective is not explored enough. You expect surprises from the solutions of the mystery
column11: or cathartic effect after seeing tense acting from the leads. Sorry but you cannot have either of them.  "Freedomland" includes more than one socially relevant issue. Film's "Friends of Kent" is based on the real group "Friends of Jennifer for Missing Children
column12: volunteer group that searches missing persons. Edie Falco's character is based on Donna Cutugno, leader of the group Friends of Jennifer for Missing Children
column13: who also appears as Elaine in the film. Here Freedomland" is given a chance to be original
column14: but Joe Roth somehow wastes it with among the jumbled storytelling. The film has excellent ingredients to make a superb thriller
column15: which you don't see in "Freedomland.

A number of people have stated that this is the weakest of Stevie Ray Vaughan's CD's.  When that many people make a comment like that
column2: it is important to take notice.  Reviews on Amazon are skewed towards the high end (the average review is 4 stars).  Typically
column3: reviewers on Amazon write reviews on the things they love.  This CD is certainly different than any of Vaughan's other work.  It is mostly
column4: shorter
column5: less emotional tunes.  It comes closer to rock/pop
column6: if anything of his is close to pop/rock.  Also different is that the band includes keyboards and sax.  This shouldn't impact the quality of the music; it all depends on how they are used.  The original CD started out fairly well
column7: but declined as it moved on.  The last half was mostly a waste.  If you bought this as an LP
column8: you would never play side 2.    There are some very good tracks on this CD.  It starts out with the very energetic Say What.  Gone Home is a very nice blues instrumental featuring the keyboards.  This is an example how the new instruments have added some depth to the band.  Also good are Look At Little Sister and Ain't Gonna Give Up on Love.  Which feature some nice blues vocals and guitar work from Vaughan.  The rest of the tracks are emotionally flat and sometimes just tedious.  The addition of the honky tonk piano on some the tracks sounds of place and just poorly played.  The CD has come out in a remastered version with some bonus tracks.  There is a one minute track of Vaughan talking
column9: followed by Little Wing/Third Stone From the Sun.  This is an interesting track
column10: but not worth buying this CD.  You can also get a similar version of those 2 tracks on the 4 CD set SVR.  The final track is one minute of Vaughan fooling around on the slide guitar.  With the additional tracks
column11: the total length of the CD comes to about 57 minutes (up from the original 39).  This was the first album I bought by Vaughan after my friends raved about him.  It almost turned me off of Vaughan completely.  Then I tried some other albums
column12: like Couldn't Stand The Weather
column13: and changed my mind.  Many people might like this album
column14: for it's light
column15: unemotional tracks.  But
column16: many people hate to be challenged and enjoy white bread.

column1: For twenty years or longer
column2: Martha Grimes has been one of my favorite mystery writers.  Furthermore
column3: in recent years
column4: particularly in her Emma Graham series
column5: she has emerged as an eloquent and graceful wordsmith.  Her ability to create a mood
column6: from sleepy and laid-back to threatening to comical
column7: with a few well-placed impressionistic brush strokes sets her apart from other writers of the genre.  Unfortunately
column8: her emergence as a word stylist has been more than offset by her decline as a constructor of plots.  There is almost enough of a story line here for an economical
column9: 200-page novel.  Almost.  Unfortunately
column10: what we get is nearly 400 pages with no plot resolution; the story merely proceeds to a point and stops.  I assume that Part 2 will be forthcoming -- for another 20 bucks
column11: of course.  Instead of a completed narrative
column12: we're treated to half a story and a whole boatload of filler.  She gives us one too many performances of "Medea: The Musical." It only works once per book
column13: Ms. Grimes!  Ditto the upstairs visits to alcoholic Aunt Aurora; the cab rides with the moronic Delbert; the trips to the diner in Cold Flat Junction
column14: the musings on what lies beyond the line of trees at the horizon; the put-downs of Ree-Jane; the sabotaging of Miss Bertha's meals; and on and on and on. I often found myself thinking
column15: "Not another one!"  Since Ms. Grimes' latest Richard Jury novel
column16: The Old Wine Shades
column17: suffers from the same defects as Belle Ruin -- no plot resolution and reams of marginally relevant filler -- I conclude that she has made some sort of deal with the devil to serialize her novels.  Furthermore
column18: the multiple editing errors that other reviewers have noted indicate the same thing - that Ms. Grimes is now cranking out her books assembly-line style
column19: a la Tom Clancy.  What a shame.  What a loss

column1: Mark Twain called the Book of Mormon "chloroform in print" and he wasn't kidding.  It is by far the most boring read I have encountered (I could barely get through it).  I am a woman of faith - faith in God and faith in Christ and I don't know how anyone could believe this rubbish.  PLEASE
column2: anyone who is taking this at all seriously - do some research on the church.  Ask some hard questions (you will likely get a rehearsed answer
column3: but it's worth a shot).    Joseph Smith was accused (and fined with a misdimeanor) of being a "glass looker" - hired by a man to help him find buried silver mines started and left behind by the Spanish. He would use "magic stones" that were placed in a hat to tell him where to find the location.  So convenient that he later found "gold plates" and used what he called the "Urim and Thum" (which
column4: by the way are actually gemstones that were carried by the High Priests of Israel in biblical times) to translate these plates (he describes them as stones he looked at in a hat).    There are SO many myths that are told by members of the church "most men were SO distraught at the thought of polygamy"
column5: the age issue of Joseph translating the Book of Mormon
column6: Joseph Smith's actual role in polygamy (which really should be called polandry - when a woman has more than one husband...  11 of Josephs 33 wives were actually married to other men first and then married to him
column7: having NEVER divorced the first husband - what's up with that???).. etc.. and the list goes on and on...  I am not disputing that Mormons take care of their own... that they are often kind people who have good hearts
column8: I think that is all wonderful and if you want to join their church for those reasons that's great! Just PLEASE do some homework first and don't just rely on the "power of prayer".  There is a reason that Utah is the [...] capital of the USA (I'm sure every one of those people "prayed" about that big business decision - it can OFTEN be mis-intrepreted).

column1: As a Christmas gift
column2: I received the book *Dojo Wisdom for Writers* by Jennifer Lawler
column3: a Tae Kwon Do practitioner who makes a living as a freelance writer--largely writing about martial arts (viz
column4: this book
column5: a similar one for mothers
column6: a couple "Dummies" books
column7: etc.).  Being as this was given to me
column8: a wannabe writer
column9: by a relative who's taken up a martial art
column10: there's no doubt Ms. Lawler nailed a market niche.  Kudos to her on that.  The book itself is a pretty vapid collection of fortune-cookie wisdom stretched awfully thin to connect maxims from contemporary martial arts training to the pursuit of paying writing gigs.  I've always found attempts to extrapolate general life lessons--or even worse
column11: business strategies (shudder)--from Asian martial philosophies pretty tedious.  An investment banker who quotes Sun-Tzu (and I've met a few) just seems like a yutz to me.  Simply because you know what someone said
column12: or what some translator said they said
column13: doesn't mean you understand what was meant well enough to shoehorn it into any context you like.  The value of a piece of advice lies not in who said it or why
column14: but in what it inspires you to do (I think I got that from a SpongeBob cartoon).  As for this book
column15: there are tidbits of practical wisdom ostensibly gleaned from martial arts practice that basically boil down to the importance of perseverence
column16: but there's really nothing of concrete value to a would-be professional writer.  No technical advice on diction or syntax.  No samples of successful query letters.  No recommendations for constructing character-defining dialog
column17: or avoiding hackneyed descriptions
column18: or arranging plot points.  Acutal disscussion of craft is beyond the scope of this book.  Interestingly
column19: Ms. Lawler 'fesses up that she originally wanted to write fiction but gave it up for more saleable magazine articles.  She's a writer in the same way that a guy who makes a good living narrating fire saftey videos is an actor.  In a nutshell
column20: she's someone who figured out a way to retool her interests into a career pumping out disposable little volumes filled with personal anecdotes and shallow observations--even elevating herself to "brand" status (the Holy Grail of trade publishing) in the process.  That's certainly an impressive professional achievement; don't mean her books are all that great.  You could say I'm just envious.  Durn right
column21: I am

column1: When this book came out it garnered a lot of respect within the poker world. Even today his section on the standard deviation and it's importance to poker players understanding how good or bad they can run just as a function of luck  as well as "non-self weighting poker ideas" are still considered required reading by many players..   Unfortunately
column2: much of the rest of the book is outdated and of little use to today's players: He discusses lowball and jacks or better draw
column3: he discusses "bingo"
column4: he talks about the "new games" of PaiGow and Pan 9. This book is almost 19 years old now much of the original text is outdated or obsolete. Another section that seems a bit suspect is his discussion of tournaments. Although it contains some interesting mathematical ideas
column5: it seems of little use in the "real" world of tournament poker. The fact that Malmouth chooses not to play in tournaments has stirred controversy over the years from those whose primary involvement in poker is tournaments. This text( with the noted exceptions in paragraph one) is in need of an overhaul in my opinion and is not much more than an interesting philosophical or theoretical overview of gambling. One other section that is actually of value is his review of many of the popular gambling and poker titles by other writers. A number of players I have talked with like this section the best as it gives them direction in their book reading and buying decisions

column1: As a serious amateur woodworker who has also studied the design and building of wooden boats
column2: let me say that beechwood is by far one of the inferior materials one could choose for making wooden spoons.  Olivewood is by far the superior material for this sort of common yet critical kitchen tool. Should you doubt this
column3: please visit the kitchens of France
column4: Italy and Spain to see what's stirring the pot.   Additionally
column5: fabricating the spoon by gluing multiple pieces together is a lesson in engineering failure. It violates the most basic principles of woodworking.  Wood
column6: because it is made by nature and not man is not uniform.  Wood not only expands and contracts as it heats and cools
column7: but also as it draws up moisture and dries.  Multiple pieces equals multiple rates of expanding and contracting
column8: working against the glued joint.   While Oxo makes and sells some very fine kitchen tools (I have a vegetable peeler by them that's the best I've ever owned and it's about a decade old)
column9: this is sure not among them.  A product to avoid

I won't go into a synopsis of the story since that's been done quite enough already here. I bought the book because I was looking for a Regency that was a bit steamy but this book is really only for someone who enjoys the steam and not the story.  I have a lot of trouble with writers who place their stories in an historic era without doing any research nor enhancing the story in any way besides throwing in a carriage ride here or a quizzing glass there.  Suffice it to say that there is very little historical value to this book and nothing really that would tie it to any distinctive era of history.  The characters were interesting enough
column2: but I found myself skimming quite often and lost interest after the 2nd steamy scene
column3: somewhere around page 15 or so.   Why oh why do good writers like Ms. Hunter insist on skipping the essence of a story in favour of over-abundant sex scenes!   Romance is supposed to be just that. Regency says enough as well.  This book has little of either.   I'm giving her two stars because she is obviously capable of more and hopefully will one day deliver.

column1: I have been a subscriber to TIME for over 15 years and before that a reader of my parents' subscription. It pains me to say that this magazine has forgotten what it is about. Frankly
column2: the only issues worth their salt are those resulting from a major world event such as a natural disaster or a terror attack; such events seem to energize an otherwise listless staff of seemingly bored editors and newswriters.  A newsweekly has the obligation to go beyond the newspapers--to use the extra couple days to provide a more balanced and analytical view. Unfortunately TIME fixes its editorial position at the beginning of a story--any future coverage is designed to prove TIME's initial position correct. The immediate taking of an editorial position is then carried into all future coverage of the event; stifling analysis and preventing any analytical development beyond the first few stories--"we told you so
column3: we told you so." Even worse
column4: the coverage of a lengthy story peters out until something sensational happens at which point the sensational event becomes the ultimate interpretation of the entire story. Can't the magazine occasionally admit it was wrong rather than turning its eye away from the story that continues to burn? Out of sight
column5: out of mind is the mantra...  In fact
column6: I sometimes debate whether the decline of this magazine mirrors or outpaces the general decline in our media; newspapers are failing
column7: television news can't seem to get away from the gory or sensationalistic
column8: even academic journals have specialized themselves into irrelevance. We seem to have a greater appreciation for comedy than analysis.  Neutrality is dead. Frankly
column9: I don't care so much about any perceived editorial slant as I do about the fact that the magazine is increasingly boring and irrelevant. TIME used to have excellent coverage of trends and events outside of the United States--no more. Iran is building nuclear weapons but merits the occasional blurb on a world summary page. African states are making vast strides towards democracy
column10: we get an article about Nigerian computer fraud. Russia is emerging from the turmoil of perestroika and its painful transition has much to teach about the costs and value of democracy
column11: but we seem to focus only on the latest roadbomb in Iraq. Japan
column12: one of the world's most influential cultures
column13: in the week I originally wrote this review (see 12-month subscription) merited only a snippet regarding a royal marriage and an analysis of foreign intrusion into sumo wrestling. Somewhere in the wide world is a fascinating place or culture to which TIME could send a correspondent and bring the place and people alive to its readership
column14: instead we get tabloid excrement in the nature of Joel Stein's puerile take on pornography and social deviants. But most damning is the fact that after reading TIME one asks: How in the hell did our world become boring?  Can TIME try emulating The Economist rather than The Enquirer? Someone needs to step in and restore the proud tradition of complete and in-depth coverage--educate the reader about the world in which we live; don't wait until either natural disasters or internal politics shine the spotlight on any of the various cultures and countries in which real and interesting events take place every single week. TIME has the history and potential of being a five-star magazine
column15: if only it would just focus on finding and reporting the news

column17: because while (he thought) Mill was wrong
column18: his ideas were expressed with great clarity
column19: allowing them to be more easily evaluated (which in turn facilitated greater understanding). Edelman must be a smart man

column1: Having spent most of my adult life working in the non-profit conservation field
column2: and as a parent
column3: and as someone who had the good fortune to spend lots of time in nature as a child
column4: I read this book in the hopes of learning important things. That turned out to be a forlorn hope.  By a quarter of the way through I was rolling my eyes; by the halfway mark I was actively insulted that this author would expect anyone to buy what he was shoveling. I finished the thing only out of grim curiosity.  Louv has about three major points: (a) American kids circa 2005 are much less active outdoors than American kids circa 1965 were; (b) that change is due to computers
column5: personal-injury lawyers
column6: and various other things that people Louv's age don't like; (c) being "in nature" is important to kids' development and to human health generally.  Point (c) is blindingly obvious
column7: is not news to anyone
column8: and is the only major point for which he offers any actual evidence which wouldn't get laughed out of the offices of a peer-reviewed journal.  For points (a) and (b) he offers zero evidence
column9: nada
column10: zip -- absolutely nothing but anecdotes
column11: leading rhetorical questions
column12: and straw men. He sounds like nothing so much as Joseph McCarthy wondering whether Communists "might be" undermining American foreign policy from within the State Department. Indeed he uses precisely that rhetorical construction repeatedly
column13: always a signpost of intellectual flabbiness.  Obvious logic flaws abound
column14: as do laugh-out-loud factual mistatements. In the first half of the book I started jotting down glaring holes in his argument but gave up in disgust when I realized that most of his factual claims weren't even footnoted! Louv isn't even consistent in his straw men: one moment he's talking about when he was a child (1960s
column15: roughly) and the next moment he's quoting somebody talking about how much kids were outdoors in 1910
column16: or 1860!  While he offers no actual evidence for his broad proposition of a new "nature deficit disorder"
column17: he does throw tangential facts around some of which I am in a professional position to quickly confirm. I checked a half-dozen such
column18: and the score was that he got 1 substantially correct
column19: distorted 2 beyond recognition
column20: and got 3 dead wrong.  I could go on but enough already. This thing isn't worth the paper it was printed on

The fact that Sowell is a black man criticizing other blacks doesn't make him any more right or less racist.   The fact that he perpetuates anti-Southern bigotry and invents a connection with ghetto culture and Southern culture doesn't seem to turn anybody off. What he fails to acknowledge is the true connection with criminal behavior and that is institutionalized urban poverty
column2: not Southern culture.   FBI statistics prove this repeatedly.  I don't think Sowell really knows any rednecks.  I grew up in the South; most of my youth was spent in a very small town in a rural county where I was surrounded by rednecks.   I will grant you that they dislike intellectualism (which made me really unpopular) but they weren't any more violent than anywhere else
column3: and in fact I'm often appalled by stories I've heard from friends' kids about the kinds of things that go on in schools now
column4: and I don't live in North Carolina any more.   The rednecks I grew up around
column5: the vast majority of them had very strong Christian faith
column6: and they worked hard even if (usually especially if) they were poor - just like the vast majority of folks who are in the ghettos.  They dislike shows of money and are extremely thrifty to the point of being just plain cheap
column7: which is a stereotypical Scottish/Irish value that Sowell conveniently ignores.  The other positive value we Southerners have retained that everyone else seems to have forgotten is basic manners.  After I left college and moved out of the South I was appalled at the general lack of basic consideration for other people
column8: who didn't greet you on the street or even use "please" and "thank you."  Last
column9: I challenge anyone to prove that Southerners are overall more violent than the rest of the nation
column10: especially given per capita crime rates are much lower in rural areas and the South is mostly rural.  I'm disappointed that only two people seem to be approaching this book with a critical mind
column11: out of over 60 reviewers
column12: and I'm especially disappointed at all the people who continue to applaud    such bigotry.   How long has the Civil War been over?   Not one of you remember it but somehow you can't seem to get over it.  In short
column13: Sowell's arguments would be great if they were all based on fact

column1: There's no denying that the music on these discs is fabulous (although Ishman Bracey is hardly of the same caliber as Skip James or Son House).  No
column2: the problem with these discs (and JSP discs generally) is that the sound quality is terrible.  Obviously any CDs made from old 78s are going to have loud hiss and pops.  That's to be expected.  What's terrible here is that JSP's solution has
column3: from the sound of it
column4: been to lop off the higher end of the sound
column5: with the result that everything sounds muffled and distant.  It's as though they'd put a heavy blanket over your speakers.  I prefer Yazoo's method
column6: which has more hiss and other noise
column7: but infinitely more clarity and presence.  The difference between JSP's version of Booker T. ("Bukka") White and Yazoo's is like night and day: you'd never know what a subtle vocalist and guitarist he actually was if all you heard were the versions on these discs.  It's even worse with the great Skip James
column8: since in his case the originals are in really bad shape: if you're not careful (and JSP is not)
column9: you end up with mud instead of genius.  In short
column10: the remastering has real consequences for what you can hear of the music.  All the nuance is absent on these discs.  Get the Yazoo or the Biograph or the Roots-n-Blues ones instead: you'll have more background noise
column11: but you'll also know why people rave over these musicians in the first place

column4: and I also have say that majority of the stories are dated for readers in 2006. Stories about telefaxes
column5: etc. are not relevant anymore. But also the general problem of satirical essays is that they are very much tied to the present day when they're written.  Overall
column6: not a bad collection but nowhere near to my expectations

column1: I was really looking forward to reading "Ever After" when I saw the favorable quote on the back cover by  Larry Gelbart. But the book turned out to be a VERY cursory glance at the past 25 years of musical theater with remarkably little insight. Here are the three things I learned from this book: (1) Mega-musicals are almost always artistically corrupt; (2) Andrew Lloyd Webber is the anti-Christ; (3) The only innovative musicals to arrive in the past 25 years started Off-Broadway (mostly at Playwrights Horizons and Lincoln Center). Most of the hundreds of shows mentioned in this book get one paragraph each
column2: with very few illuminating details. Here's what the author says about "Carrie
column3: perhaps the most famous recent Broadway musical flop: Carrie
column4: of course
column5: was an instant classic
column6: a monument in the pantheon of failed Broadway musicals. Adapated by Michael Gore (music) and Don Pitchford (lyrics) from the notorious Stephen King novel (and even more notorious film)
column7: this $7 million musical celebration of prom vengeance and bad taste materialized at the Virginia Theater on the 12th of May
column8: 1988 and was gone by the 15th
column9: touching all who saw it with a timeless reverence for its indelible
column10: monumental ineptitude." Does that really tell us very much about this musical? Did Barry Singer even see the show? You sure wouldn't know it from this description. And just what
column11: I wonder
column12: makes King's novel "notorious" or the movie "even more notorious"? Almost every show in this book rates that brief a mention
column13: but somehow Singer finds time for an entire chapter of Lloyd Webber-bashing where Sir Andrew invites the author to a cocktail party to show off his newest female singing discovery. The chapter sticks out like a sore thumb
column14: if only because it has nothing to do with the rest of the book
column15: but also because it's one of the few times that Singer goes into any detail. Aside from a few interesting Sondheim quotes
column16: this book is a waste of time.

column17: but this machine seems to be a lemon.  We're actually going to write to Panasonic about it--I'll try to post again with the results.  Here is my update
column18: which I wrote November 3:  This is a follow-up review to the one above

column21: of the machine at one of three places they listed. The places were all within a half-hour drive of my home. After doing some research

column23: but in the past few weeks

column26: but I know from the last time with these noises and efforts to read the disks that soon it won't. Avoid this machine. Again
column27: the previous Panasonic model (DMR-E55) we bought hasn't had any of these difficulties and continues to work great. We're still big Panasonic fans
column28: but this particular model is a lemon.

column1: On Amazon.UK the synopsis contains this lovely gem: "the Moon is exactly 400 times smaller than the Sun."  This is false
column2: of course. The diameter of the moon is 400 times smaller than the diameter of the sun; but that does not mean the moon
column3: as a whole
column4: is 400 times smaller. The moon exists in 3 dimensions
column5: not one. For example
column6: the mass of the moon is about 27 million times smaller than the sun.  This is typical of the logic in this book. They go looking for correspondences
column7: and they find them: even if they have to treat celestial objects as one-dimensional to make their numbers look interesting. They simply stir the facts together in a great big soup
column8: until two disassocated numbers look similar. Then they pluck out the pair and declare "Mystery!"  The fact that a book like this could get published is pathetic. If you want science fiction
column9: there's vastly better and more interesting out there; if you want science
column10: there's simply nothing here. If you want baseless
column11: juvenile speculation

column1: The other reviews give you the flavor of this book so I will bring up a few items they and the author ignore.   First
column2: it is a vivid illustration of the more general problem in the world of what constitutes "help".  If what one does causes more misery in the long run then it is clearly not helpful and this is what nearly all of the "aid" to the third world does.  Anything that prolongs lifespans
column3: increases child survival or increases standard of living is eventually disastrous as prosperity is ultimately bought at the expense of the future.  The whole world is going down the drain but Africa is the worst case and likely by mid-century
column4: and certainly by it's end
column5: there will be starvation
column6: disease
column7: social violence and war on a staggering scale and as a permanent state.  The world has only one problem--too many people--and only one solution--decrease the population at any cost.  Of course it's not politically correct to say anything about it and certainly not to do anything really effective and Dettwyler is in a delicate position.   These people seem to average a dozen pregnancies and above all they need birth control.  Regarding her personal choices she tells how her young daughter almost died of malaria and it clearly was quite insane of her to take a young child with her for several years of constant exposure to this and other diseases when she knew that people died of it constantly in spite of medication.  The last point that I could not forget was the fact that she produced three children of her own.  If she does not know the dire situation the world is in due to overpopulation she ought to go back to school.  Like virtually all parents
column8: she is not a responsible member of society.

column1: Genetic engineering was not possible before "we knew about genes".  The public often confuses genetic engineering with selective breeding
column2: but the author of this type of book has no excuse for doing so.  Selective breeding works exactly the same way as natural selection (aka "survival of the fittest")
column3: with humans providing the selection pressure (deciding which animal or plant is "fittest" - and gets to reproduce).  Genetic engineering involves combining genetic material on the molecular level - allowing combinations that would otherwise be impossible.  Genes from fish being spliced into tomato plants to create a more freeze resistant tomato is one example.  Not incidentally
column4: domestic cats (felis catus) originated from species that are about the same size as domestic cats (felis sylvesterus - the European wildcat
column5: and the North African subspecies).  No "shrinking" was involved.  It is interesting to note that the effects of selective breeding as practiced by humans "before we knew about genes" is not always as lasting as we might think.  For instance
column6: myriad pigeon and poultry breeds exibit an amazing array of variety in color
column7: feathering
column8: and build
column9: (an internet search will provide examples).  However
column10: if allowed to breed amongst themselves with no human selection
column11: the offspring will resemble the original "wild" species within a very few generations.

column1: This movie is somewhat difficult to rate in my opinion because there are some good things about "Clownhouse" and some bad things about it.  The movie starts out with a young boy named Casey who is for somereason very afraid of clowns...he wets his bed when he has nightmares about them.  It appears the boy is about 11 years old and he has two brothers named Geoffery and Randy
column2: probably 13 and 16 respectively.  Geoffery is sympathetic towards Casey while Randy is a total jerk and seems determined to torment them both.  Well
column3: a carnival comes into town and Casey apprehensively goes along
column4: but his fear of clowns is incredible.  In this movie
column5: it turns out that his fear was well warranted.  At first
column6: I thought this movie was going to be another "The Funhouse" but it was not.  That being said
column7: "The Funhouse" is superior in every way to "Clownhouse".    As "Clownhouse" moves along
column8: the viewer notices three individuals who appear to be quite malevolent in nature.  Indeed
column9: these three men kill three clowns and dress up in their clown costumes.  The killing scenes were below average and not very effective at all.  What takes place afterwards is a long and sometimes boring chase scene where the clowns follow Casey back to his home.  The chase scenes are quite ridiculous to be honest with you...there is no way that Casey could have outrun these grown men and there is also no way that Casey would not have heard them running behind him.  Ultimately
column10: the scenes move to Casey's house where the horror in this film really takes place.    Frankly
column11: the clowns did not appear to be that scary to me at all...in fact
column12: at times
column13: they looked stupid!.  When one considers the great horror movie villains of the past
column14: the clowns looked pretty weak as far as horror movie villains are concerned
column15: and as a result
column16: these clowns were not very effective in creating horror in and of themselves; but
column17: that being said
column18: Salva does a good job of putting the clowns in position in the house unbeknownst to the boys and that is where this movie is effective as horror movie and becomes quite creepy.  However
column19: this is not enough to put this movie over the hump as a really good horror movie.  I thought the moving around and the boys' lack of knowledge of the clowns in the two story house was quite effective and at times
column20: the movie was quite chilling in this respect
column21: but this is really all the movie has to offer.   Once the clowns were discovered however
column22: the movie declined in the level of horror that it had created and this is a sign of an inferior horror movie in my opinion with respect to the classics at least.  Moreover
column23: I thought the times when the clowns actually engaged the young boys in combat were pretty lame...the three men would have easily killed these boys
column24: but I suppose it wouldn't work if that happened
column25: but I think that the movie would have been more effective and credible if the three boys in this movie were older...say
column27: 18 and 19.  Then
column28: one as a viewer

Another flaw of the movie is the acting in this movie is clearly below average and there is little character development except for Casey. Be careful - and don't forget it is your child not you who has to  live with this - and you should not judge the success of any plan on "if you think he is behaving better" but rather on his/her happiness.  This is not about you - it is about your child.  I think any child who changes his diet will manifest different behaviors.  But ADD is a genetic
column2: neurological disorder - to use the word "onset" and "prevention" of ADD - this is the most demeaning and blaitantly wrong term I have ever heard.  Attention Deficit Disorder is caused by an insufficient release and absorbtion of Dopamine.  Can a diet affect this - maybe a little - but concerta
column3: ritalin
column4: etc - actually do affect the release of dopamine.  I applaud all of you in your research of ADD but be skeptical  - of medication and of "Diets".  What I do know is that I attend middlebury college and for the first three semesters I was getting mostly B's some A-'s (all without medication) - then convinced I was trying too hard or atleast much harder than everyone else for the same outcome
column5: I decided to try concerta - which I refused in my earlier childhood years (seven-ten) as most kids do.  I took an extra class and I pulled off 4A-s and a B+.  I would like to think it was all me - and it really was all me
column6: but the hard thing to understand is that many kids with ADD are intelligent enough - instead it is the neurology.  Don't sell your child short by staking yourself as an anti-pharmaceutical parent...The doctors (experts) prescribe it for a reason.  Keep your child playing  sports
column7: give him structure
column8: have compassion and that is half the battle.

column1: "Internal Combustion" by Edwin Black is an entertaining but uneven history about the control of energy with a purported emphasis on the ascendancy of the gasoline-powered automobile. To his credit
column2: Mr. Black has managed a substantive research project that has uncovered a great deal of arcane historic information about the automotive industry. Unfortunately
column3: this preachy book suffers from an acute lack of focus
column4: where it is suspected that the large amounts of extraneous background material was added in an attempt to obscure the book's shortcomings. Indeed
column5: the author ultimately fails to prove his central thesis
column6: thereby casting doubt about the validity of both his research and his conclusions.  Mr. Black opens the book with a scene depicting the burning of Thomas Edison's research laboratories in December
column7: 1914. Mr. Black's conspiracy theory proposes that sinister forces aligned with the gasoline-burning automotive industry may have intentionally destroyed the world's one and only hope to mass-produce an electric car. Unfortunately
column8: Mr. Black provides no evidence to prove this allegation.    Mr. Black attempts to buttress his case by explaining that electric vehicles were once utilized as taxis in New York and other major cities in the late nineteenth century and
column9: therefore
column10: could have and should have been mass marketed to an appreciative public. We are supposed to accept Mr. Black's thesis that success would have been an inevitable and logical outcome despite the severe weight
column11: cost and range limitations of the electric car when compared with the gasoline automobile. In fact
column12: while Thomas Edison and Henry Ford were still tinkering with an electric alternative a full thirteen years after gasoline-powered vehicles had already been in mass production
column13: it is evident to the reader that internal combustion vehicles prevailed because they were affordable
column14: the first to market and could traverse longer distances than electric cars. That all of this was not a good development for people's health and the environment is not in dispute; rather
column15: it is Mr. Black's contention that the white-hatted purveyors of electric vehicles could have prevailed save for the obstructionism of the black-hatted petroleum industry that remains in question.    In the end
column16: what is conspicuously lacking throughout the book is a credible attempt at analyzing and critiquing the history of governmental and popular struggle with the fossil-fuel industry. But instead of scholarship
column17: we have a vainglorious author who is determined to salvage the barren results of two years' worth of study by substituting analysis with a highly questionable work of narrative. The end result is little more than a masquerade of nonfiction; at best
column18: it is a book that might have limited appeal to readers who crave pseudo-historicism at the expense of intellectual rigor
column19: consistency
column20: insight or coherence.

column1: The topic of this book certainly sounded interesting
column2: especially since I was taking a Media Laws course at the time I read it.  However
column3: this book was bogged down with too many problems for me to recommend it.  First of all
column4: the book is full of small errors that make it seem like it was hastily thrown together and shoved onto the shelves.  The author is listed as "Bob Levin" on the front cover
column5: but as "Bob Levine" on the spine.  A citation on the back page quotes an editor as calling the book "The definitive history of this wonderful
column6: mad (and
column7: I believe
column8: signficant) episode in Amercan [sic] popular culture."  And one of the illustrations and comics in the book are listed as being from 1971
column9: even though Levin later says (correctly) that they were from the mid 90s.  Aside from these annoying but ultimately forgivable problems
column10: the author just doesn't have a very fluid or gripping writing style.  Some of his sentences so grossly overuse punctuation marks that they may discuss three different topics in a single sentence.  I will admit that he does a passable job describing copyright laws
column11: but that was just one part of this book.  His footnotes also tend to be places for him to get in his two cents rather than truly informative additions.  And he ultimately fails to make the characters endearing to the audience
column12: which is frustrating since he admits in the book that each author is trying to sell a story or viewpoint to the reader.  It may be more objective to paint the Air Pirates as nothing more than a bunch of stoned twenty-somethings following an even more-stoned thirty-something
column13: but it sure didn't sell to me that we should be rooting for them.  The ending of the book also let me down.  I won't go into details
column14: but suffice it to say that after discussing a series of lawsuits brought against the Air Pirates
column15: the story ends very abruptly
column16: without describing the final decision in any great detail.  This should have been the climax of the narrative
column17: and it just fizzles out.  So while I appreciate Bob Levin pointing out this interesting case that has apparently gotten very little recognition
column18: I wish that he would have discovered it
column19: and then turned it over to a better author

column1: We bought this because we wanted to be able to send a 10+ page fax well.  It constantly pulls more than one page if you have under 5 pages...this results in you haveing to hold each page separate until the one before it gets sucked up.  The most annoying thing is that it doesn't hold much paper and is constantly running out if you don't frequently check it.  AND! once the paper runs out
column2: We have a hard time getting a new stack of paper to load.  I keeps saying load paper
column3: and you jiggle the stack around and it rotates the roller but never sucks up a new piece and keeps showing "Load Paper"  I will fiddle with it for about twenty min. before it grabs the first page and works properly.  Needless to say I am searching for a new machine and when I find one I am throwing this the L80 into the lake at the next "Load Paper"

column1: Some of the twelve-step groups are absurd. There are groups for an amazing number of "spiritual diseases". Just the short list of the common ones includes:  AA Alcoholics Anonymous  Abusive Parents Anonymous  ACOA Adult Children Of Alcoholics  ADD Anonymous  Al-Anon  Alateen  Alcoholics Victorious of the Institute for Christian Living  ARTS Anonymous (Artists Recovering through the Twelve Steps)  Augustine Fellowship: Sex and Love Addicts Anonymous  CA Cocaine/Crack Anonymous  Calix (a Catholic 12-Step-based recovery organization)  CDA Chemically Dependent Anonymous  CEA Compulsive Eaters Anonymous  CMA Crystal Meth Anonymous  Chronic Illness  CLA Clutterers Anonymous  CODA Codependents Anonymous  COSA Codependents of Sex Addicts  Compulsive Eaters Anonymous  Compulsive Shopping  Debtors Anonymous  Diabetics Anonymous  Divorce Recovery  Dual Diagnosis Anonymous  Drug-Anon Focus  Dual Disorders Anonymous  DRA Dual Recovery Anonymous  EAA Eating addictions anonymous  EA Emotions Anonymous  EDA Eating Disorders Anonymous  EAA Eating Addictions Anonymous  Emotional Health Anonymous  Ethics Anonymous  FA Families Anonymous  FA Food Addicts in Recovery Anonymous  GA Gamblers Anonymous  GamAnon -- families of gamblers  Gangs Anonymous  HCVA Hepatitis C Virus Anonymous  High blood pressure  ISA Incest Survivors Anonymous  Marijuana Anonymous  Methadone Anonymous  MTC Make Today Count (for someone with a terminal disease)  NA Narcotics Anonymous  Nar-Anon - families of addicts  Nick-a-teen Anonymous  Nicotine Anonymous  Obsessive-Compulsive Anonymous  Offenders Anonymous -- for convicts  ODAT One Day At a Time -- pagan recovery  Overcomers Outreach  OE Overeaters Anonymous  PIR Pagans In Recovery  Pagan Sanctum Recovery  Parents Anonymous  Pill Addicts Anonymous  Pills Anonymous  Prostitutes Anonymous  Recovering Couples Anonymous  RSA Rape Survivors Anonymous  S/A Schizophrenics Anonymous  S/A Schizophrenics Anonymous  SA Sexaholics Anonymous  SAA Sex Addicts Anonymous  SAA Sex Addicts Anonymous (alternate URL)  S-Anon - family groups of sex-addicts  SCA Sexual Compulsives Anonymous  S-Anon International Family Groups  SLAA Sex and Love Addicts Anonymous  Sexual Recovery Anonymous  SIA Survivors of Incest Anonymous  Partners and Friends of Incest Survivors Anonymous  Tough Love  WA Workaholics Anonymous  Some of these groups offer their own minor variations on the twelve steps
column2: but all have the same spiritual-religious orientation.            Notice the funny mix of so-called "spiritual diseases" there: you can "cure" some of them just by changing your behavior
column3: like alcoholism
column4: narcotics
column5: smoking
column6: over-eating
column7: sex addiction
column8: gambling
column9: cocaine
column10: or being a compulsive shopper or a clutterer. But the others are not what we might call "voluntary" diseases. You cannot just voluntarily quit having high blood pressure
column11: diabetes
column12: hepatitis C
column13: chronic illness
column14: dual disorder (i.e.: having both mental and drug or alcohol problems) or schizophrenia
column15: so I really want to hear how listing and confessing all of your sins
column16: "moral shortcomings"
column17: and "defects of character" will cure those diseases.   Someone would have to be pretty crazy to think that doing the Twelve Steps -- performing a searching and fearless moral inventory and confessing all of his sins -- is going to cure mental illnesses like schizophrenia and compulsive-obessive disorders.   But
column18: come to think of it
column19: that's just how the game works
column20: isn't it? Go find sick
column21: vulnerable people who are suffering
column22: whose minds aren't too clear
column23: and exploit their weaknesses and talk them into joining a cult religion while telling them that this magical 12-Step program will heal what ails them.    Dumb Question: Why are there three "Dual" recovery groups that appear to treat the same mental problems -- Dual Diagnosis
column24: Dual Disorder
column25: and Dual Recovery?  Dumb Answer: So that the people who have Multiple Personality Disorder4 can send each of their personalities to a different group
column26: so that they don't run into each other at the meetings...      Another dumb question: Why do schizophrenics need 12-Step groups telling them to do Step Eleven
column27: and pray and meditate until they hear God talking to them
column28: when those schizophrenics already hear God and sundry other voices in their heads talking to them all day long anyway?     If Workaholics Anonymous people do 90 meetings in 90 days
column29: are they still being compulsive workaholics?  Shouldn't 180 meetings in 90 days fix the problem?      Last night I joined Gamblers Anonymous. They gave me two to one I don't make it. == Rodney Dangerfield    And the oddest ones have to be "divorce recovery

column1: On our beloved Kay Scarpetta and the illustrious Ms. Cornwell?  Having been an avid fan of her novels from the very beginning
column2: I simply cannot help but ask myself....is she really writing this stuff? Very slow in the beginning
column3: I began to fear a repeat of the struggle that I endured to finish Blowfly.  However
column4: this novel does begin to pick up momentum...but not until the reader is halfway through
column5: and certainly not until this author had left me sufficiently disgusted.  The storyline finds Scarpetta summoned home to the scene of the crime...Richmond
column6: Virginia
column7: where her previous employer seeks her assistance in unwraveling the mysterious death of a young girl.  So Scarpetta---with Marino tagging along of course---heads back to Richmond from her new home in Florida to offer assistance; only to find that her old building is being demolished...and that the new one
column8: under the leadership of Dr. Joel Marcus
column9: is sloppy regarding policies and procedures.  The demoralization of her former staff by Dr. Marcus is also unnerving to Scarpetta; and clearly he resents her intrusion. So why has he asked her to come? Meanwhile
column10: Lucy
column11: as head of The Last Precinct
column12: is once again up to her ears in nonsense.  For such a brilliant
column13: successful young woman (as readers have always been lead to believe)
column14: why must Cornwell insist on making her so completely stupid in her literary life?  In this tale she is once again romantically linked with a narcissistic sociopath who also happens to be her employee. Worse than the weak storyline
column15: and the fact that this novel is just all over the place
column16: is the author's disturbingly sterotypical portrayal of African-Americans throughout.  Drug dealers are black
column17: they're dead of gunshot wounds
column18: and most ludicrous of all is in one instance Cornwell references a dead young man's "conspicuously large organ."  Are you kidding me?  The trash collectors are "big dark men" and of course in an upscale neighborhood
column19: the "old black woman" must WORK in one of the houses.  The author's unbelievably narrow-minded
column20: stereotypical view of other races is disturbing at best
column21: and frankly makes one think that she may just be as stupid from a common sense perspective as Lucy.  Read only if you must
column22: but frankly there are better ways to spend your time.   DY

column1: The science is: brains are like neural nets; a hidden layer with feedback gives nets the ability to detect temporal patterns; information/logic in a net is distributed.  That's it
column2: plus some rambling about Husserl that seems largely irrelevant (if you're curious it's summarised pretty well by the review above (by the "top 100 reviewer" who apparently never gives below 4 stars...))  So if you're at all interested in consciousness
column3: you probably know the science.  If you don't
column4: then I assume you've read a bit more than the typical science nerd and expect a basic level of narrative competence - you're going to be disappointed.  The fiction part is embarassingly bad.  The plotting is appalling; the characterisation cartoon-like.  Some reviewers are saying this would be good for an introductory course.  It would have to be very introductory.  (I see that this book is currently being offered with Papadimitriou's "Turing".  That's not a great book
column5: either
column6: but it's stunningly good compared to this - it has warmth
column7: wit and depth.  The closest this book gets is a painful irony; the cover suggest that someone
column8: somewhere
column9: was hoping for a noir ambience
column10: but the only darkness comes from a power cut).  I feel bad writing a negative review
column11: because I guess this was a work of love.  I can understand the desire to popularise ideas that you find interesting.  But please
column12: if you're going to take my money
column13: give me something at least half-way decent.  If I were the author I'd be pretty mad with the editors at MIT for letting me publish something this bad.  And finally
column14: I note that one star is the lowest rating possible
column15: which is rather sneaky of Amazon (doesn't their use of the arithmetic mean imply a zero-based scale?).  [Later - for a stunning treatment of similar material see Power's Galatea 2.2

column1: Being a fledgling opponent of strong AI
column2: I picked up this book hoping to learn the weaknesses of the strong AI argument. Alas
column3: this was the wrong book to pick up.  I am not even sure what Penrose's main argument is; of course it may be there but was lost in the 450 pages of mostly irrelevant details on physics. To say in the least
column4: his attack is not coherent or well structured. He seems to admit that his position is very vulnerable himself: he constantly admits to mere speculation and weakness of evidence on his part.   If he abridged this book to may 100 or 200 pages
column5: it may have been more effective. When I was half way through
column6: I nearly quit reading because I could tell he was going nowhere
column7: but I figured if I had already wasted this much time
column8: I might was well finish it. I regret that decision now.   TENM may be just another example of a grandiose physicist touting an interesting subject like modern physics as accessible to the layman. If it is accessible
column9: Penrose is not the one to do it. There seems to be a market for these pop physics books (i.e. Elegant Universe) because yuppies out there want a feeling of wonderment about things they don't understand. How much they actually get from these  books questionable.   In the end
column10: Penrose somehow wants to say that modern physics presents an obstacle for strong AI. I hope there are books out there that actually might show this

Did they live in an isoltaed european word or did they take in the chinese atmosphere

Even the principle of religious confession in this story seemed hollow because the killer showed neither repentence nor a willingness to reform--which made him a continued menace to society. Is a priest supposed to shield such a murderer from prosecution on the grounds of "client privilege" while the rest of society remains vulnerable to the killer's next possible murder? What kind of religion is this? The priest didn't even preach to him about the evil of killing and the necessity of accepting punishment for such irresponsible behavior
column10: as a means of reformation and of ultimately becoming worthy of God's forgiveness
column11: grace and the eternal kingdom.   This principle of penance was beautifully exemplified in the movie "The Mission
column12: as Robert DeNiro, playing the part of a mercinary killer, realized the error of his ways and painfully performed penance for his killings ; he not only accepted responsibility for his actions, considering them terribly wrong, but showed a determination to never repeat them; he himself then became a good priest and helped jungle natives live a better, more useful life. This character was worthy of forgiveness and absolution--a far cry from what the O.E. Hasse murderer displays in I confess". Any priest who defends an unrepentent murderer from justice becomes as guilty of the murder as the murderer--even worse--because he risks the lives of other members of society. He in fact becomes a co-conspirator!  And the killer
column13: in the last scene

column1: HART'S WAR had potential. The last months of World War Two as a backdrop with demoralized GI's crammed into an overcrowded POW compound.  If this picture was soley about the hardships endured by surrendered soldiers during the Battle of the Bulge
column2: then it could have had a chance.  Instead the film makers took on too many plots and subplots.    Unintentionally the movie borrows from SLAUGHTERHOUSE FIVE
column3: A SOLDIER'S STORY
column4: THE GREAT ESCAPE and STALAG 17.  A cardinal rule in war films is that the premise has to be simple.  In HART'S WAR we find some good elements lost in a virtual Mulligan stew.    In the story Colin Farrell's character
column5: a rear echelon lawyer
column6: accompanies another officer on what he thinks is a joyride.  Unfortunately for Farrell
column7: the Germans have launched their attack in the Ardennes. The young lawyer is captured
column8: harshly interrogated
column9: and finally shipped out to a German stalag.  There he meets the senior POW officer
column10: played by Bruce Willis
column11: and tries to settle down in the dirty and uncomfortable life of a POW.  A soldier is killed and a recently downed Tuskegee airman is accused of murder.  Yes
column12: you guessed it.  Farrell takes on the aviator's defense during the subsequent courts martial.    If director Gregory Hoblit left the storyline to develop around the trial a decent film could have emerged.  Instead we have additions of Colonel Hart's unexplained behavior
column13: an mass tunnel escape plot
column14: sabotage and the German Commandant's attempt to befriend the American lawyer as superfluous baggage.  HART'S WAR was filmed in the Czech Republic
column15: no doubt to cut costs.   A little more effort and a lot less story and this film would have had a better showing at the box office.  Still
column16: if you enjoy war movies you should probably add this DVD to your collection

column1: Rest Stop (John Shiban
column2: 2006)  Writer/producer John Shiban makes his feature-film directorial debut with Rest Stop
column3: a slick little thriller that wants to be far more than it actually is. While this is an admirable goal
column4: it's never possible to fully forget that the movie's trying a bit too hard. Still
column5: it's a vast improvement over a lot of recent damsel-in-distress flicks.  Nicole (Watch Over Me's Jaimie Alexander) and Jessie (Joey Mendicino in his big-screen debut) have run away from their small-town Texas home and are on their way to Los Angeles when they pull into a rest stop. After the required bathroom break
column6: Nicole comes outside to find Jessie has disappeared. She also discovers the rest stop is the home base for a particularly nasty serial killer who's been picking off young girls there for a very long time. She's forced into a game of cat and mouse with the guy
column7: and finds herself questioning her sanity more and more as the game goes on.  Yes
column8: there are plot holes big enough to drive a yellow pickup truck through. And yes
column9: there are some awe-inspiringly stupid moments (especially the final scene) that make you wonder whether anyone at the production company actually read the entire script before bankrolling this thing (I kept thinking it was the filmed equivalent of a novel published by Xlibris). But Shiban was at least trying
column10: and you have to give him a few brownie points for that. I mean
column11: how seriously can you take a movie that casts Joey Lawrence as a cop? And how seriously are you supposed to take a movie that features the camper family to be found in the middle of this one? It's entirely possible that the most you'll get out of this movie is a few laughs
column12: a few hours of nitpicking with your buddies
column13: and some awesome eye candy in the for of Jaimie Alexander. Still
column14: that's a whole lot more than you got from Haute Tension. *

column1: My mother recently ordered this book by Mr. Chopra and was urging me to read it. She spoke very highly of it and told me that he used science to prove God and such
column2: etc. Allow me to be upfront. I am a skeptic
column3: and a firm Atheist. I do not believe in the backward illogical concept of God that most religion would scare you to believe in. But I decided to keep an open mind
column4: as I always do
column5: and I read Mr. Chopra's "How To Know God" from cover to cover.   First of all
column6: Mr. Chopra does not speak of the God that most religions speak of. He in fact urges the reader to rethink their concept of God
column7: the first chapter is called "A Real and Useful God". Here Mr. Chopra describes a God that all of us can reach directly
column8: and he also describes most people's general view of God and how he is a supposedly unattainable God until death...etc. He then devises 7 Stages of God
column9: that match our human emotions and says there is a God for each stage. He continues to say that whenever we feel this or that
column10: we are experiencing the God of that stage. This is where I begin to have a problem.   Mr. Chopra begins this book with his own concept of God
column11: that is neither supported by scientific evidence or any sort of rational thought at all. I was unable to get anything out of the following pages because I could not help wondering why I was not given any evidence into Mr. Chopra's thought process. He simply creates his own idea and flies with it
column12: assuming the reader will just go along with it and not apply any sort of thought. This is weak and misleading. But I continued to read. He then begins to talk about three versions of reality
column13: the material reality (the material world)
column14: virtual reality
column15: and quantum reality (God's world outside of space-time). He then says that there are many arguments in the material world against God
column16: but none of these can be applied because God is not in the material reality
column17: he is in the Quantum reality. Absolute garbage! Pure assumption! I was outraged by this statement
column18: and saw it as a poor way of denying the logical and rational arguments against God. Mr. Chopra once again maintains excellent continuity by not supporting his claims with any sort of scientific evidence. How can he say that God is in a different reality? What makes him think God isn't in the same reality that we are in? How does he know there is a virtual reality? These so-called "realities" seem very fabricated to me. They are a clever way of escaping arguments against God
column19: if you put God outside of this world then you can't apply any arguments from our reality to his
column20: according to Chopra. I do not buy this
column21: and feel sorry for anyone who does. I am impressed though. That is a clever trick
column22: and nothing more than a trick. Mr. Chopra seems to be exhibiting "wishful thinking" here. He acknowledges that the mind is in search of God and needs God (with scientifc evidence)
column23: I believe Chopra's mind is just like all other minds and wants to justify God and find God
column24: so he will by all means attempt to do that. He wishes for there to be a God
column25: and so there will be. He can change his reality as he pleases. This sort of wishful thinking is dangerous when explaning or proving a point because it makes Mr. Chopra incredibly biased and unreliable.   While reading this book in its early pages I was almost assured that Mr. Chopra was speaking of God in a purely metaphorical sense
column26: but I later found (much to my disappointment) that he was speaking of God in a very real and literal sense. Many will claim that Chopra uses "science" and "quantum physics" to explain God and how we can reach him
column27: but that is a misconception and perversion of the truth. Mr. Chopra does indeed make clever points using theories and stories involving quantum physics
column28: but they do not relate directly to the existence of God
column29: or our ability to reach him. They seem to just be random tidbits Chopra throws in so he can say he proved God and our ability to reach him with "science." It is an absolute mockery.   I did find Mr. Chopra's ending chapters on the paranormal (telepathy
column30: esp
column31: clairvoyance
column32: synchronicity) to be interesting
column33: but once again not supported by anything and pure wishful thinking. Mr. Chopra just plays the God card everytime he is faced with a dilemma that is unexplainable or difficult to understand. The God card in this case is more like a Joker
column34: it serves no purpose and is just a laugh.   Mr. Chopra does have good stories to tell

column1: My mother recently ordered this book by Mr. Chopra and was urging me to read it. She spoke very highly of it and told me that he used science to prove God and such
column2: etc. Allow me to be upfront. I am a skeptic
column3: and a firm Atheist. I do not believe in the backward illogical concept of God that most religion would scare you to believe in. But I decided to keep an open mind
column4: as I always do
column5: and I read Mr. Chopra's "How To Know God" from cover to cover.   First of all
column6: Mr. Chopra does not speak of the God that most religions speak of. He in fact urges the reader to rethink their concept of God
column7: the first chapter is called "A Real and Useful God". Here Mr. Chopra describes a God that all of us can reach directly
column8: and he also describes most people's general view of God and how he is a supposedly unattainable God until death...etc. He then devises 7 Stages of God
column9: that match our human emotions and says there is a God for each stage. He continues to say that whenever we feel this or that
column10: we are experiencing the God of that stage. This is where I begin to have a problem.   Mr. Chopra begins this book with his own concept of God
column11: that is neither supported by scientific evidence or any sort of rational thought at all. I was unable to get anything out of the following pages because I could not help wondering why I was not given any evidence into Mr. Chopra's thought process. He simply creates his own idea and flies with it
column12: assuming the reader will just go along with it and not apply any sort of thought. This is weak and misleading. But I continued to read. He then begins to talk about three versions of reality
column13: the material reality (the material world)
column14: virtual reality
column15: and quantum reality (God's world outside of space-time). He then says that there are many arguments in the material world against God
column16: but none of these can be applied because God is not in the material reality
column17: he is in the Quantum reality. Absolute garbage! Pure assumption! I was outraged by this statement
column18: and saw it as a poor way of denying the logical and rational arguments against God. Mr. Chopra once again maintains excellent continuity by not supporting his claims with any sort of scientific evidence. How can he say that God is in a different reality? What makes him think God isn't in the same reality that we are in? How does he know there is a virtual reality? These so-called "realities" seem very fabricated to me. They are a clever way of escaping arguments against God
column19: if you put God outside of this world then you can't apply any arguments from our reality to his
column20: according to Chopra. I do not buy this
column21: and feel sorry for anyone who does. I am impressed though. That is a clever trick
column22: and nothing more than a trick. Mr. Chopra seems to be exhibiting "wishful thinking" here. He acknowledges that the mind is in search of God and needs God (with scientifc evidence)
column23: I believe Chopra's mind is just like all other minds and wants to justify God and find God
column24: so he will by all means attempt to do that. He wishes for there to be a God
column25: and so there will be. He can change his reality as he pleases. This sort of wishful thinking is dangerous when explaning or proving a point because it makes Mr. Chopra incredibly biased and unreliable.   While reading this book in its early pages I was almost assured that Mr. Chopra was speaking of God in a purely metaphorical sense
column26: but I later found (much to my disappointment) that he was speaking of God in a very real and literal sense. Many will claim that Chopra uses "science" and "quantum physics" to explain God and how we can reach him
column27: but that is a misconception and perversion of the truth. Mr. Chopra does indeed make clever points using theories and stories involving quantum physics
column28: but they do not relate directly to the existence of God
column29: or our ability to reach him. They seem to just be random tidbits Chopra throws in so he can say he proved God and our ability to reach him with "science." It is an absolute mockery.   I did find Mr. Chopra's ending chapters on the paranormal (telepathy
column30: esp
column31: clairvoyance
column32: synchronicity) to be interesting
column33: but once again not supported by anything and pure wishful thinking. Mr. Chopra just plays the God card everytime he is faced with a dilemma that is unexplainable or difficult to understand. The God card in this case is more like a Joker
column34: it serves no purpose and is just a laugh.   Mr. Chopra does have good stories to tell
column35: but they serve no relevance to God or finding him. His writing is not bad
column36: but it is also not very good. I find Mr. Chopra to be a very weak thinker who ignores all rational arguments and ways of logic and reason to further exonerate his wishful thinking and enforce the idea of God in his reality. If you are interesting in a book relating Science and Spirituality I would recommend Amit Goswami's "The Self-Aware Universe". I do not recommend this book at all
column37: especially to other skeptics. Mr. Chopra not only seems to have a rather negative and close minded view of skeptics but he completely shuts them out and addresses them in a rude manner.  I have kept an open mind in reading this book
column38: but Mr. Chopra has not
column39: in fact he hasn't shown much evidence of an intelligent "mind" at all.   This book receives two stars just for effort and a few interesting tidbits.

column1: This book is another attempt to capitalize on a name brand (Porter; Harvard) as opposed to providing a substantive
column2: insightful take on what is happening in Japan and what needs to be done in order to correct certain problems in the Japanese economy. It also gives the false impression that Japan is somehow a pre-mature version of the US. Porter is not a Japan expert and I would be very careful
column3: as an American/foreigner
column4: to not to take books on Japan by foreigners who have never lived their or speak the language too seriously. The book is not about Japan
column5: it is a generalized theoretical black box solution to a much more complex problem in which one needs to understand a lot more than just management theory. Japanese management is much more complex and
column6: unlike in the US where a monkey can be trained to fire people
column7: Japanese managers have many more issues to deal with. People tend to forget the fact that Japanese managers have done a much better job (though moving more slowly) at reducing the negative impact of restructuring. Its more difficult to keep a company going and competitive when its against the law to fire people than if you could fire people on the spot-- US management "expertise" is incredibly over-rated the recent market correction shows the incredible amount of resources that are wasted by corporate America on such things as management consulting. Those foreigners who have written on Japan's economy and financial markets who have the language down (speaking; reading) and have been in-country for an extended period of time as expats can provide a very interesting and highly useful perspective for those looking from the outside in a way most Japanese cannot (and will not). Being a "senior advisor" to a few large Japanese companies does not qualify someone to write on this topic

column13: and
column14: with the lack of depth

column16: no doubt

column20: it is quite clear that
column21: they assume understanding can be achieved by loading concepts with words

column24: and go through their implications in more detail.  I think

column1: This book is based upon Brenda Ueland's experience teaching creative writing to adults and her success at freeing many of her students from inhibitions that prevented them from writing well.  It is basically a "pep talk" for anyone who thinks they cannot write or have nothing important to say.   And it has some interesting insights about the mysterious nature of inspiration and the role leisure plays in creativity.  ["Leisure: The Basis of Culture
column2: by Josef Pieper, is a more advanced exploration of this theme.]  However, the book is interlaced with so much dubious philosophy that I cannot recommend it.  For example, on page 129, Brenda begins with this gem:  I have come to think that the only way to become a better writer is to become a better person."  However
column3: she then ruins this thought by saying that by "better person" she does not mean a good person "for a great person often does things that so-called good people think very bad indeed."  She does not explain what she means by a great person.  But it seems to mean someone who is an independent thinker; an astute observer who does not accept social conventions or values that cannot be affirmed through their own inner wisdom.  Brenda does not consider the possibility that one's inner "truth" can be faulty.  She relies upon quotations from the poet William Blake (one of her great people)
column4: entitling Chapter Five: "Sooner Strangle an Infant in its Cradle than Nurse Unacted Desires
column5: based upon one of his noble sentiments about deferred gratification.  Blake saw visions and heard voices which he believed were Divine rather than demonic.  Brenda also prefers this interpretation and thus agrees with Blake's conclusion that our inner voice which says Thou shalt" is our true conscience
column6: while the voice that counsels "Thou shalt not" is the product of learned behavior and should be rejected.  (See page 13 and footnote on page 35.)  Later
column7: on page 174
column8: the author reveals herself to be a ho-hum
column9: garden-variety relativist.  She writes
column10: "If it is true to you
column11: it is true.  Another truth may take its place later.  What is truly from me is true
column12: whether anybody believes it or not.  It is my truth."  The problem with all this philosophy is that the author tells the reader that they too must tend toward the amoral and asocial aspects of the psychopathic personality if they want to be an independent thinker and hence
column13: a great writer.  She teaches that the end justifies the means.  Whatever gets the creative juices flowing is justified.  And the stream of consciousness that gushes forth
column14: whether polluted or pristine
column15: is art.  It is art because it is true to the inner self of the artist
column16: who has learned to cast off all restraint
column17: fear
column18: and ambition.  (I wonder what Brenda would think about the latest notions of modern psychology that radical independence is a less mature emotional state than cooperative inter-dependence?)  Finally
column19: the author presents her view as an either/or scenario.  Either you adopt the reckless and rule-less approach to writing
column20: or you're creativity will be stymied.  She does not allow for the option that one can be creative and value-oriented at the same time.  Potential readers of this work should be aware that behind the enthusiastic pep talk there lurks a relativistic philosophy which may not correspond with their personal beliefs

column1: In a typical neoclassicist's manner Mr. Hanson avoids talking about the Jewish-Christian basis of western culture. The 'death of Homer' is not a modern phenomenon. The following books are a few examples of the vast literature on the subject: Michael Walzer
column2: Exodus and Revolution; Walter Wink
column3: Engaging the Powers; Ramsay MacMullen
column4: Christianizing the Roman Empire
