column1: I was actually glad to read all of the low reviews because I felt like a traitor when I didn't like this book.  I wanted to like it
column2: I really did - but it was very dull.  I ended up skimming most of it because it didn't hold my interest at all.  The first chapter started out with a bang and I was totally hooked.  It didn't take long to lose me.  Boooooring.  I didn't like Sophie
column3: I didn't like Royd (Royd - are you kidding?  Perhaps the author should invest in a baby name book - there are much better choices for names out there.).  I wasn't interested in the direction the book went.    I thought the action scenes were ridiculous compared to the every day scenes.  If Sophie could pull off the every day scenes like she did the action scenes we wouldn't have had such a boring book.  She was da bomb during breaking and entering and getting away but she was pathetic at any other time.  Royd was so very unlikeable I couldn't believe they ended up in bed together.  Ick.  Adding Jane into the book was very contrived.  Plain old artist Jane and her cop stepfather Joe saved the boy from a ruthless trained killer?  It seemed like a ploy to connect Eve Duncan with this book.  Not at all believable.  The one sentence that I found interesting was when Michael thought that Jane resembled or looked like someone familiar.  It seemed to be a lead in to the next book.  The first IJ book I ever read was Ugly Duckling.  Hopefully IJ re-reads that one before starting the next one.  Give us a strong heroine who overcomes her trauma and kicks [...].

column1: I am surprised by all the good reviews this book has received.  To start with

column4: mind you

column8: she makes derogatory assumptions such as:  Housekeeping is a no skills/low skills job People who choose to be housekeepers aren't very smart Children can't be trained to take over housekeeping tasks  And so on--too many to list here

column10: I-shouldn't-have-to-do-this-demeaning-work type
column11: and she brings up the tired
column12: "traditional" man vs. woman arguments

column18: why not spend that quality time training your children instead? Not to mention that
column19: if you're truly willing to pay for housekeeping
column20: why not pay family first?  She has a cost justification worksheet

column22: no

column24: by the way

column28: and their first book

column33: the little that is left to do could easily be accomplished by her children
column34: her
column35: and her husband. For example

column37: living room

column41: or even every other week.    After reading this book

column44: although it might make you feel better.   Now
column45: on the other hand

column49: you're recovering from surgery
column50: etc.
column51: and for someone in these situations

column53: let's be honest

column56: some tips on getting your point across

column3: meandering and overly negative in others.  The first half of the book runs through some interesting observations about the genetics of dogs and their behavioural links to wolves.  This is interesting and you can read through it in one enjoyable sitting.  However
column4: as the book goes on you notice that Budiansky gets more and more negative about dogs
column5: using a thinly veiled veneer of science to try and make his arguments look objective.  He basically describes domestic dogs as being inferior mutations of wolves.  He seems to be trying to tell us that we need to face up to the fact that our dogs don't love us
column6: but that instead they are using us like parasites.  Moreover
column7: all their signs of affection
column8: play and obedience are actually just instinctive behaviours that have evolved to help them in the wild.  OK - if this corresponds to your experience with dogs then this is the book for you.  For me
column9: I haven't got time to read all the underlying scientific papers but this just doesn't square away with empirical evidence.  Budinsky himself makes a point of the fact that comparatively little scientific research has been conducted on dogs.  This doesn't seem to stop him from using what has been done to denigrate them.  Overall this book doesn't give man's best friend any credit at all
column10: and I suspect that many dog owners would find it quite disturbing.  The fact that it tries to use science to back up its bias claims is even more troubling

column1: Does Turtledove devoutly wish the South had won the Civil War for its own sake
column2: or is he just one of those admirers of Robert E. Lee (there were many at my alma mater
column3: Vanderbilt) who can't bear that his hero came out on the losing side? Either way
column4: surely Turtledove could have come up with a better vehicle for reversing the outcome of the Civil War than South African racists traveling back in time to arm the American rebels with yet-to-be-invented guns. The thugs of the 21st century have misjudged the motives of the noble South and the nobler-still Lee
column5: but the general will accept their weapons anyway
column6: thank you. This trick presages the wooden plotting and shallow characterizations to come. Turtledove's main non-historical character is a teacher-soldier who seems to come out of and return to nowhere
column7: with no mention of family or background. Characterization in general has Turtledove stumped
column8: so he turns to cliches
column9: such as the prostitute with a heart of gold (this one masquerades as a male and dons a uniform to serve the Confederacy and service the main character). Turtledove even has a tragic mulatto woman on a postwar auction block. Blacks are few and rare in Turtledove's novel
column10: and they are swept off the stage after the briefest of appearances
column11: speaking only conventional phrases
column12: and in dialect
column13: of course. Both the rupture of the American Union and the continued births and deaths of millions of Americans in slavery (his Lee fashions a gradual emancipation in which blacks will "earn" their freedom decades into the 20th century) are treated by Turtledove as worthy of little more than a shrug. The more ambitious but nearly as wooden "alternate history" novel
column14: Ward Moore's "Bring the Jubilee
column15: at least was very sober about the consequences of a rebel victory. If you are going to reverse the outcome of a war so momentous in American and world history, don't do it as trivially as Turtledove has done in this book. There is potential for a great story in the fictional reversal of the outcome of our Civil War, but The Guns of the South" is not it

column1: This is a work of poor scholarship.  The author's account of Egyptian Jewry is politically filtered.  First
column2: he claims that Egyptian Jews were not supportive of Zionism.  Every Zionist movement was representated in Egypt
column3: and active.  He also suppresses evidence that some prominent Egyptian Jewish personalities were Zionists.  For example
column4: he talks at length about Mourad Farag
column5: but does not mention that he was a passionate Zionist.  Farag's work
column6: Al Kudsiyat
column7: goes unmentioned.     MOreover the largest percentage of Egyptian Jews (45%) went to Israel.  The remainder were scattered between the U.S.
column8: France
column9: and other countries
column10: so Israel got the lion's share  The author also trivializes the anti-semitism that existed in Egypt long before the Zionist movement.  There were at least 10 cases of blood libels in the second half of the 19th century.  Moreover
column11: even Egyptian Jews who lived in Egypt for generations were denied citizenship.  He only briefly mentions the Company Law that denied Eygptian JEws their livelihood.  Though he mentioned the three massacres of 1948 in which nearly 90 Jews were murdered
column12: he forgets to tell the reader that no serious trial took place.    The author dwells extensively in the Lavon affair
column13: but only because he can blame Israel.  He does not tell the reader that not one Egyptian or foreign soul was killed or hurt during the sabotage operation.  He also refuses to admit that Egypt committed a crime by condemning two of the ring leaders to death.  The author's political bias blinded him and turned him into a poor schola

column1: What is the longevity of John Bradshaw's book
column2: and how does his writing stand up in the perspective of time?  The book was published over ten years ago
column3: and it seems to have dropped through the cracks of the large and populous human growth floorboards
column4: of which it was a part.  The first thing I noticed about Bradshaw's writing is its sheer verbosity.  He writes in a roundabout way
column5: rather than concisely and to the point.  Contrast him
column6: for example
column7: with a writer on Buddhism or Taoism (say
column8: Alan Watts?).    Writing on Buddhism or Taoism may provide authors with a natural impetus to be concise
column9: but the human growth movement is broad and billowy
column10: and concise writing may not be important to the authors.    And Bradshaw seems to drag in every alley cat he ever heard meow in the human growth movement
column11: to help him reflect on what he sees as the underlying principle of it all: Shame.  Bradshaw reports that he is a theologian
column12: but also someone who recovered from alcoholism
column13: and was deeply shamed as a child
column14: which shame he finally learned to deal with and overcome.    There are many fine snippets from his book
column15: which may be of use to folks
column16: but overall
column17: I think most people looking for direction are going to be repelled by his constant conceptualizations.  To paraphrase another well-known quotation
column18: "People cannot live on concepts alone."  If he had given more personal studies or little case histories
column19: it would have been much more helpful.  Instead
column20: he includes page after page of some "guided" meditations or shame inquiries
column21: which were totally useless to me.  If you are looking for guided meditations
column22: this is the place for you.    So
column23: in all
column24: Bradshaw's book does not hold up to scrutiny after time
column25: in my opinion.  It's one of the many from its era and niche that was forgotten and will be unlikely to remembered henceforth.  Anyway
column26: it was a bestseller once
column27: and that's what counts
column28: I guess.  It did have its 15 minutes of fame
column29: and a lot of books never even get that.  Diximus.

as most of these folks use Compton as the launching point for their graduate school applications. I'd like to read a book about a teacher who has stayed in the classroom for more than a couple of years. TFA is a nice idea, but I question whether they do more harm than good by becoming part of children's lives and then taking the first bus out of town

 I'll just start out by saying that the artwork was very misleading.  It looks like the music would have been dark and disturbing or violent (the Parental Advisory supports it).  This music is not disturbing, nor is it violent, there are only 3 songs with swears (why is there the parental advisory?) etc.  I enjoy disturbing things so this assumption was my fault.  However this doesn't mean that I was unable to enjoy the music simply because it didn't live up to my assumption from the artwork.  A few songs like the Closest are good and the keyboard usage is good, but the thing that mainly brings this band down is the vocalist.  It sounds as if he's stretching the lyrics, taking forever to say what could have been said in a normal amount of time.  It got very annoying, very quickly.  A lot of the music is very calm, but is surprising as my eye caught the fact that it was produced by Ross Robinson (Korn, Limp Bizkit, Slipknot, Amen) so I find that this is a step away from producing his normal Nu-Metal and into things that are more calm.  Anyways, a few of the songs are good and have good riffs, but it's the vocalist that drags this band down the most.  Vex Red isn't that great, sorry to disappoint you.  I'll give this 2 stars because of the song the Closest and the fact that a few parts of the songs instrumental wise are good but over all Vex Red offers nothing special.  
 Just outside Bulawayo, Zimbabwe, is the small township of Kezi, where life revolves around the bus that comes in from Bulawayo and the Thandabantu store, where everything can be bought and where the population gathers on the veranda to discuss the events of life. During the liberation struggle the old men are replaced by soldiers - both male and female- that take a rest here. But it becomes apparent in the book that a lot of these soldiers are quite deranged. One such soldier kills a girl, Thenjiwe, and mutilates her sister, Nonceba. After a long stay in the hospital, where she tries to regain her physical well-being and mental health, Nonceba follows the ex-lover Cephas of her dead sister to Bulawayo, where they live as brother and sister, two people forever wounded by the war of independence.  When written this way the book seems to hold a lot of promise for a very moving book. However, it took me nearly the whole book to get into the story. Yvonne Vera uses a lot of metaphors in which she couples different senses: she describes sounds in visual terms, tastes  she compares to sounds etc and the book is really packed with this. I really had problems understanding what was going on to a point that it actually got me very irritated. However, the end of the book (with the least metaphors) is a very loving description of two hurt people trying to make the most of their lives

column1: This book is essentially a prediction -- a prediction of how a given generation of teens would turn out. As such
column2: it is particularly easy to rate -- all one has to do is wait a few years and see whether the prediction came true. As defined by the authors
column3: the first batch of Millenials graduated from college a year ago
column4: and the second one will graduate in two month. So..  Academic performance throughout US colleges has remained at 1990's level: "high-octane academic achievement" did not materialize. Prediction failed.  Use of marijuana among high school and college students is INCREASING after a continuous decrease in 1980's and 90's. Prediction failed.  Alcohol abuse among the same group is holding steady
column5: instead of decreasing. Prediction failed.  Teen pregnancies as a whole are decreasing
column6: but pregnancies among unmarried teens are actually RISING; total statistic is due to sharp decrease of pregnancies among MARRIED teenagers. Prediction failed.  Politically
column7: "Millenial" college students are more fiscally conservative and more socially liberal than any generation on record -- EXACT OPPOSITE of what Howe predicted. College Republicans are on the rise
column8: and their Libertarian branch especially so. Prediction failed dismally.  If the authors were in weather forecast business
column9: they'd be out of job by now

column1: I am in great shape.  However

I am not profoundly muscular bound. As is common in men of my age
column3: lower back problems are not unusual. I have a 32" waist.  Is that not "Medium" sized?   I think we simply need to get rid of the elastic waist band altogether.  One size fits all doesn't work and it is dangerous to those many of us that fight our lower back problems.    The draw string is fine.  It allows flexibility.  So what if your pants fall down?  It seems to be the fashion
column4: anyway.  Just give us the option of pulling the shorts back up instead of pinching nerves with a static elastic waist band that causes ridiculous lower back problems because of unnecessary

column1: This book does not present any new information. Several books
column2: notably Duncan's "The Dollar Crisis" does a much better job of explaining the fundamental dangers of a managed currency. This book adds smugness and some barely comprehensible jibes at the current American system for not being libertarian enough
column3: but throughout the book there is barely a suggestion of a practical solution for any of the problems it describes. Duncan provides some pie in the sky solutions
column4: (a global minimum wage)
column5: but at least he says something.  Wiggins' final advice is to buy gold. Hope I didn't spoil it for ya. The reason why you should amounts to
column6: "because it was good enough for ancient Rome". There is VERY much repetition of the basic points
column7: and many of the anecdotes don't support the point he makes in the same chapter. The entire chapter on John Law could have been explained in a sentence
column8: and then he could have taken some time to tell us what we could do to avoid the temptation to inflate the currency! This is supposed to be a book about the coming of the reckoning day
column9: but other than a timid assertion that the current bear market could last as long as 18 years
column10: we don't even get a hint of what factors would have to combine to create the catastrophic financial conditions that the book's title seems to presuppose.  All in all worthless. Read Duncan

column1: I really liked Suzanne Summers. I've read all her other books and have her tai chi exercise video. When I saw her on the Today show advertising this book I couldn't wait to get it.  She promotes the Schwarzbein Principle which states that being a vegetarian is unhealthy. Suzanne has an entire chapter dedicated to someone named Wendy who after 10 years of being a vegetarian was convinced to start eating meat again! Just because Wendy's particular diet was unhealthy
column2: that doesn't mean that all vegetarians are unhealthy. There are meat eaters that have unhealthy diets. Look at all the Hindus in India
column3: they're lifetime vegetarians and are healthy.   I know that soy has been a controversial subject recently
column4: but it's the pill form of soy that is questionable
column5: soy it it's natural form is healthy for you. How can you say that soy is bad for you when millions of East Asians eat soy as part of their daily diet? I've read countless books and research that supports the benefits of soy.  I eat a balanced vegetarian diet and get all the nutrients my body needs.  Just because one doctor doesn't believe that a vegetarian diet is healthy
column6: doesn't make it a fact. Suzanne you've really gone too far to tell everyone to stop being a vegetarian. With that misinformation in your book
column7: I have a hard time believing that anything else is true and fact.

column1: If I could give this book zero stars I would.  This book came highly recommended as a great way to introduce Egyptian History to children.  I was stunned to read the book only to find it was horridly inaccurate!  While I realize this is supposed to be historical fiction
column2: at least some attempt at historical accuracy should have been attempted.  Not every parent has an interest or knowledge of Egyptian History so many wouldn't notice
column3: but since this book is reccomended by at least two homeschool curricula
column4: and parents expect the authors of those curricula to have at least passing knowledge of the history they are teaching
column5: I think fair warning is needed.    According to this book
column6: Tutankhamen was the son of Amenhotep III.   Amenhotep III was actually Tutankhamen's grandfather.  Tutankhamen was the son of Amenhotep IV
column7: Akhenaten.  Not Amenhotep IV's younger brother as portrayed in the book.  Also
column8: Akhenaten didn't die after a short time as Pharaoh
column9: he ruled for at least 17 years.  About the only thing the book got correct was that Akhenaten did change the religion from poly-theism to mono-theism and that Egypt was returned to poly-theism after Tutankhamen became Pharaoh.  If you are looking to teach your children Egyptian History
column10: and want accurate Egyptian History
column11: skip this one.

column1: This is the worst book of Shakespeare criticism I have ever read.  Bloom makes no attempt to link one paragraph to the next.  It reads like 30 years of lecture notes piled together haphazardly
column2: handed to a graduate student
column3: and entered into a computer over a weekend.  He contradicts himself several times.  I donated my copy to the library as soon as I was done reading it
column4: so I cannot cite the pages where the contradictions occur; but several times I recall reading a passage where Bloom had just said the exact opposite a few pages earlier.  To make matters worse
column5: he even says the bard contradicts HIMself.  He points to supposed paradoxes regarding Hamlet's age
column6: stating that his seeming age does not jive with textual evidence that would put his age at about 30.  Apparently the point is that if Shakespeare contradicts himself
column7: so can Bloom.  Bloom ignores the obvious conclusion that Hamlet is a slacker.  He has not grown up yet.  That is why his parents tell him to come home from school and not to waste his time as a professional student when he should be learning how to run a kingdom.  Some of the book's observations are interesting
column8: but they are glossed over and presented as a random jumble from Bloom's notes.  Interespersed between the passages scribbled down from Bloom's lectures are outbursts where Bloom reminds us that Shakespeare is without any question whatsover the greatest writer
column9: in verse or prose
column10: who ever lived.  Bloom is a great critic when he still tries
column11: but in this book he was not even trying

column1: The author admittedly started this project as part of his masters or doctoral thesis and that's just how the story is presented.  Let's just say it's not an easy read. While the book does begin with a general overview of the history of Native Americans and the wrongs inflicted on them by Europeans ... the rest of the book then takes a DEEP dive into New Mexico and Oklahoma.  The title of the book should more accurately reflect a deep focus on Soutwestern Indians
column2: as that is the primary subject of the book.  Bottom line
column3: it is clearly an extremely well researched book
column4: but a poorly written book.  Much like sitting down on a Sunday and reading Case Law transcripts.  The beginning chapter gives an interesting insight into the events that shaped the laws governing Indian Gaming
column5: but unless you're interested in the minutia of New Mexico or Oklahoma
column6: then the rest of book is pretty much a sleeper.  I wouldn't recommend buying it

column1: Nathalie Dupree is an adoptive Southerner -- she was born in New Jersey. Now there's nothing wrong with that; we welcome everyone down here
column2: but she is not Southern and she is decidedly not "country folk." Anyone with a certificate from Cordon Bleu who owned a restaurant in Social Circle
column3: GA
column4: is not Daisy Duke.  I don't know how Ms. Dupree came by her vaunted reputation. When I watched her PBS series in 1986
column5: I could not believe what a mess she made of her kitchen. Dirt and grit from leeks flew like gnats
column6: landing on the countertops and the floor. The cake batter she accidentally poured through the handles of a Dutch oven spilled all over the counter. While making a half-hearted effort at cleaning it up
column7: she said to the camera
column8: "I'm sure you'll do better when you make it at home." Ya think?  The grits roll which sounds so good
column9: and which Ms. Dupree claims won somebody $6000 in a cooking contest
column10: does not work. ALL chess pies are made with a little cornmeal -- she seems stunned that her friend's recipe calls for it. OK
column11: so the ham biscuits work
column12: and are tasty. The homemade applesauce is very good. But two decent recipes out of 200 is nothing to brag about.  I was born and raised in North Carolina
column13: and have lived here all my life. I thought it was just me
column14: but over the past 20 years I've made a point of asking practically every Southerner I meet this question
column15: and we all agree: NO ONE eats chicken gravy on cantaloupe. I have no idea where that came from.  A bright
column16: fledging cook of 12 or 13 can tell you that if you throw the butter
column17: flour and milk in a saucepan all at the same time and start whisking
column18: you are not going to get a cream sauce. Most good home cooks can tell you that you cannot freeze a chicken dish made with cucumbers.  I could go on
column19: except I haven't gotten to why I think Ms. Dupree is a snob. There are numerous recipes in this book which she prefaces by saying
column20: "this recipe is from my dear friend/former student/cooking teacher... it's *wonderful
column21: * but here's *my* version." There's even a recipe called "Puff Pastry MY WAY." P.S. It's no better than puff pastry made anybody else's way.   I'm glad I didn't spend any money on my copy; it was a gift. I'll stick with my files of my grandmothers' recipes
column22: Mrs. Dull's 1928 "Southern Cooking" and the 1950 "Southern Cookbook" from the UNC Press

column1: I truly wanted to like this book.  After years of avoidance I had just finished Moby Dick and found it not only more readable than I'd feared but downright enjoyable.  In addition I'd heard nothing but good things about this novel whose premise certainly intrigued me
column2: and like its predecessor it has one of the truly great opening lines in literature:  "Captain Ahab was neither my first husband nor my last."  Alas
column3: it was all down hill from there; overall this is one of the worst books I've ever forced myself to finish.  This came as quite a surprise because the author is no untalented hack.  Author of two other published novels and a short story collection
column4: director of a university level creative writing program
column5: long-term teacher of writing
column6: and holder of a Ph.D. in same
column7: all to considerable critical acclaim
column8: she should be correcting and grading (failing) garbage like this not producing it.  So what went wrong?  How did this novel end up so awful?  The answer is brick by brick and piece by piece.  There is no one great thing wrong with it but rather a lot of little things.  LENGTH: If "brevity is the soul of wit"
column9: this novel's witlessness is easily explained.  At 666 pages (interesting number that) this novel is about three times as long as it should have been.  It would seem that
column10: to some extent like Melville before her
column11: Naslund confused Length with Importance
column12: but Melville was a lot more skilled at padding than she is.  IMHO this desire to fill too many pages made many of the other problems worse by allowing Naslund both to go into unnecessary detail about things no one else cares about and to repeat herself to the point of self-parody.  Somewhere under the barnacle encrustations may be the finely lined hull of a short novel
column13: but this was a manuscript desperately in need of editing... with a meat axe or a chainsaw.  THE NAME DROPPING: One of the pleasures of any historical novel is the encounters between fictional characters and historical figures
column14: but if badly handled these encounters can un-suspend disbelief and downright offend.  They are badly handled here.  An almost uneducated hick from the backwoods of Kentucky encounters by chance a significant number of the thoughtful elites of mid-nineteenth century New England and those she doesn't utterly charm with her brilliance and erudition she gets the better of as in her unintentionally hilarious encounter with Naslund's peculiar imagining of Nathaniel Hawthorne.  One or two of these
column15: developed at greater length could have added to the verisimilitude.  As it is
column16: it is a Zelig or a Forrest Gump without the humor (or the self-awareness).  THE POLITICS: Even the most conservative readers would probably find the popular views of a majority of mid-nineteenth century New Englanders a bit disconcerting if espoused straight in a modern novel
column17: so a certain amount of modernizing would be appropriate just to reduce the cringing.  However
column18: Naslund takes this to the opposite extreme by having Una espouse the Politically Correct view on every single controversy of the day (and some that only exist in our significantly sillier day) from slavery to whaling
column19: from feminism to free love
column20: from homosexuality to sensitivity towards the differently abled
column21: all without consequence or even criticism.  This latter is the most offputting because to have actually championed such views back then would have taken considerable courage whatever one thinks of the ideas themselves.  Una espouses them with all the negative consequences that Naslund receives for espousing them today
column22: which is to say: none.  THE ANTI-CHRISTIAN BIGOTRY: There is nothing so very wrong with characters in a mid-nineteenth century novel exhibiting agnosticism or atheism as both views were gaining more and more credence at the time
column23: but it is downright silly to suggest that such views would have been widely accepted.  It is even sillier to portray Christianity as something confined exclusively to the foolish
column24: the bigoted
column25: the future apostate
column26: or the mentally ill.  It tells us more about the author than anything else that Una is openminded towards every religious and quasi-religious idea of the time EXCEPT Christianity.  THE FARFETCHED SCENARIOS: I sensed the novel was in trouble during the opening scene in which Una loses both her mother and her baby but manages to withstand this blow by making friends with a runaway slave with whom she has a quasi-lesbian encounter....  After this the novel goes into flashback and becomes unrealistic.  After her crazy Christian father threatens to kill her (a sentiment the reader will come to know and understand)
column27: Una is raised in a lighthouse by her ludicrously liberal-minded aunt and uncle
column28: encounters two young men who both fall in love with her
column29: disguises herself as a cabin boy and sails on the same whaler with them
column30: successfully avoids detection
column31: is sunk by a whale
column32: survives by committing cannibalism
column33: marries the surviving young man after he goes insane
column34: and is abandoned by him after he goes to live with the Indians
column35: leaving her free to "marry" Captain Ahab (Una never really "marries" anybody but of course nobody ever criticizes).  Things don't get more realistic in the second half
column36: which includes Una's clever and successful investment in the crazy newfangled idea of obtaining oil from the ground instead of from a whale.  Riiiight.  THE MARY SUE: However
column37: the absolute worst thing about this novel is the fact that it is a "Mary Sue" that peculiarity of fan fiction in which a laughably idealized and practically perfect in every way alter ego of the author fulfills some basic psychological need while inducing a combination of anger and nausea in the reader.  A more realistic main character might have saved it.  Una never learns anything from her life's too-many-to-be-believed experiences because she already knows everything.  She doesn't change because she is already perfect.  She doesn't have to deal with the criticism of others because she doesn't receive any
column38: and she doesn't have to beg the forgiveness of those she has wronged because they forgive her so easily and besides
column39: Una had her reasons (and they were very good ones you can be sure).  The only thing I can figure is that her publisher approved this book on concept alone WITHOUT anyone ever reading it.  I feel like I've just waded through the inept scribbling of a delusional teenage girl who insists on rereading Moby Dick in her bedroom... with the door locked.

column1: Although well enough written it failed to address the importance of the Black Sea to Eurasian mytho-history as well as it might have.  By skittering from period to period it left this reader wanting more about the essential place of the sea.  An analytical approach would have been more effective.  And by relegating only a small space to the creation of the Black Sea at the end of the last Ice Age and its place in the Flood myths that grew up around this the book failed to really place it ideologically.    Not a bad book but overall disappointing for this reader.    However
column2: I would recommend this book as a fair introduction to the Black Sea and its history...but I was hoping for a more perceptive read.

column1: My thoughts about this book can be summed up by a quote by Lanfear herself:  "you don't use one tenth of your potential".  The most frustrating element of this book (and the series as a whole
column2: for that matter) is the wasted potential.  The world of this series was so vividly realized and the plot was complex and engaging.  Now
column3: it is difficult not to sit back and wonder where exactly Jordan went off track.  Most other reviewers commented on the fact that all the characters did not "miraculously" end up in the same place for the last battle.  Personally
column4: I found it very disapointing.  Three of the four plot lines are resolved satisfactorally (even the Nynaeve/Elaine one...though I will admit it wrapped up too neatly and had me hoping at the end that the Black Ajah would come back at the last minute and wipe the self satisfied smile off Nynaeve's face).  Even so
column5: I was left wondering whether the weeks I'd spent reading this book were worth it.    What this book lacked most was direction.  It was very much a filler book for the characters/readers to take a breather in between major plot movements (at least I think that was what the original idea was).  Readers can debate about whether the book was a success or not until they turn blue in the face (as I know they will) but for me
column6: the book (and the series a sa whole) has fallen very flat

column1: Adler must be given his due for making philosophy more accessible to the average
column2: non-professional reader. He deliberately tackles six classical ideas and gives reasons for their importance. For the non-specialist
column3: these six essays may provoke interesting discussion and dialectic
column4: or perhaps starting points for further inquiry.  Such topics as beauty
column5: truth
column6: justice
column7: etc. often have been lost in philosophy for the narrower
column8: Anglo-American analysis of propositional logic. That doesn't means Adler's ideas are useless or less interesting
column9: but they aren't the type of topics one encounters in most academic philosophy departments
column10: for good or ill.  Of all Adler's books
column11: this is far my least favorite. It concerns itself with essences
column12: something that has given way to Wittgenstein's "family of resemblances." Talking about "essences" is antediluvian
column13: unless
column14: like Adler
column15: you're an Aristotlean. Reading about such abstract concepts -- the six great ideas
column16: is rather like talking about "red" with someone. There's not much one can really do or say about "red
column17: except to point out examples. I'm afraid that Adler has boxed himself into a corner by pursuing such absract concepts like liberty" as if it were any different than "red."  It's not that I oppose Adler's good intentions; I really wish his kind of philosophy was more visible
column18: tackling some of these important concepts in an intellectually rigorous manner. But ambiguity raises its ugly head
column19: and the student of philosophy is left bereft of very important philosophical concepts.   Tackling enormous concepts without intellectual rigor seems rather useless and pointless. Thus
column20: two stars for effort
column21: but really no stars for success. Yet
column22: if one really wants a place to start his or her inquiry
column23: this little book may be of singular importance

column1: There is a point

column3: when "a spiritually dumb culture" is exemplified by an American businessman who has "absorbed goals that make no sense just because he learned them at  Harvard."  This seems to assume that great minds have always been  gluttons for things that make no sense.  Part of getting a great education  was being exposed to some variety

column1: Easum and Bandy make excellent points regarding the difficulties of traditional churches.  Who can argue with the reality of decline; the substitution for institutional maintenance for evangelism?  Unfortunately their response to the challenge is gimmicky and shallow.  For example

The other thing that bothered me was that you have to RINSE off the stuff after you scrub; from watching the commercial I feel misled because you get the impression that you just scrub and you're done. column1: I should have known better than ordering another worthless guitar instruction book. I have been trying to learn how to play the guitar for over 50 years now and I have yet to find an instruction book that tells you how really to play more than simple chords and strumming. I have stacks of such books that have not helped me at all. It seems to me that there in a conspiracy to try to keep people from learning what all the great guitar players know. Even the private instructors keep you taking lessons for years without really teaching you anything of value. When I learned to play wind instruments the lessons were concise and they followed a definate pattern to help you achieve a high level of ability. All the guitar books I've seen so far start somewhere in the middle and go nowhere. It is my firm belief that a person is born to be a real
column2: all around
column3: good guitar player and if he isn't there is very little anyone can do to teach you.

column1: I read this short novel because I greatly admired Shaara's Pulitzer Prize winning "Killer Angels
column2: and because I'm a baseball fan.  The novel feels more like an outline or first draft than a completed work about an aging pitcher.  It's a bit shallow and predictable in its plot.  The characters are what one expects in all too many sports novels and short stories.  The feel or atmosphere just isn't quite there.  Any baseball fan will see flaws in the book right away, flaws that distract and damage the work.  Shaara sets most of the novel in Yankee Stadium with the Hawks playing the Yankees.  Why the author chose to have one real team against a fictional team is unclear.  The Hawks apparently are from Atlanta, but an Atlanta team, Braves or Hawks, whichever, would not be playing the Yankees interleague on the next to last day of the season.  Finally, when a visiting pitcher goes out to warm up before the game, he does so in the semi-hidden bull pen down the left field line in Yankee Stadium--not on the mound on the field.  This book was published posthumously and Mr. Shaara perhaps never had a chance to polish his prose--prose that was excellent in Killer Angels."  It's unfortunate.  There are glimmers of interest in the book
column3: but not enough to recommend it to baseball fans or fans of the author's other book

column2: "Laugh so hard I had to buy several copies" or "when I need a laugh I pick this book up". I got my book and after ripping off the plastic wrap the first thing I realized is that I just paid about 6 bits a page for the thing. I liked the illustrations
column3: a lot.  I liked the humor.  Did I buy several copies? No.  Did I laugh hard.  Hardly. Did I pee my pants. Only because the bathroom door was locked from the inside by mistake that day. It was not that funny to me.   I was pretty much done with it and donated it to the library after an hour.  They put it in with the kids picture books.   If you want to get a really good laugh.  Read Pat McManus
column4: Richard Amour and Christopher Moore.  If this book makes you laugh
column5: more power to you and spread it around. We need more laughter these days. The Library spread mine back to me and it sits on a shelf. Apparently a couple of parents thought this was a book that developing readers should start with. I can only imagine the look in their eyes when their 4-year old pointed into the book
column6: looked up questionably and asked "what's that word mean?". So I guess this book did make me laugh to some extent.

column1: The author is a journalist
column2: but he seems straight out of the Chamber of Commerce or a right-wing think tank. Like business elites
column3: the author basically does not particularly like democracy. In his view societies should be run by elites from several areas - even authoritarians if needed. He is a proponent of constitutional liberalism
column4: based on laws
column5: rights
column6: especially property rights
column7: separation of powers
column8: with much of that power being held in unelected bodies
column9: and most of all free-market capitalism. He finds that set of conditions to be far more important than the exercise of democracy. His low regard for democracy is easily seen in his minimal interest in the manner in which a society of laws is created or even its exact nature and who benefits. Most in the West do care. Rights and legal systems are not neutral: the manner of construction determines relative winners and empowerment.   Though the author's real target is US society
column10: he looks at the results of democracy over the world. And of course
column11: he finds plenty of examples where democracy doesn't work. A country in the grip of fanatics will invariably elect and support leaders who are little concerned with rights and legalisms. But it is ridiculous to imply that those situations have any bearing on democracy in the US.   In the US
column12: the author is most concerned with what he calls the democratization of society over the last fifty or so years. In actuality
column13: he is focusing on mass culture that is spread through mass consumption as vigorously promulgated by globalizing capitalism. In this era
column14: elites in finance
column15: business
column16: law
column17: banking
column18: health care
column19: various media
column20: etc have likewise been swept up
column21: in fact are the driving force
column22: in a money-first culture. He contends that such elites once had an ethos of service and basically kept our democracy on track via subtle pressures on the masses. It is simply a cynical misrepresentation to hold that massive shopping at Wal-mart and the like represents democratic empowerment. The actual test of democracy would be the ability of a community to stop the Wal-mart juggernaut.   He especially decries direct citizen actions. He is correct to observe that referenda and initiatives have had unintended consequences
column23: often being usurped by special interests with deep pockets. However
column24: he little notes that citizens have taken those routes due to the unresponsiveness of legislative processes. It's hard to take seriously the stance that the robber barons of the late 19th century
column25: and their heirs
column26: should be viewed as elites who kept our democracy on course
column27: after bribing entire state legislatures as well as members of Congress to accumulate vast sums. If citizens had actually been democratically empowered
column28: such distortions of the political process could have been prevented. The theme that cash sanitizes crooks is as American as apple pie. His view that such unelected bodies as the Supreme Court and the Federal Reserve Board prevent illiberal democracy is also questionable. Who could be unaware of the politicization of those bodies: the embarrassing handling of the presidential election of 2000 or the cheerleading role of the Fed during the stock market bubble of the late 1990s benefiting financial elites? No
column29: rule by elites has very frequency distorted and usurped democracy
column30: not buttressed it.   If the author put journalism first
column31: instead of being an apologist for 21st century capitalism
column32: he would note the death grip that corporations now have over our society and the political process
column33: actually foiling democracy. First and foremost that control is solidified through the mass media and the education system
column34: distorting and muting all challenging ideas. It is not surprising that Americans have been unable to mount any significant challenge to this latest version of laissez-faire
column35: free-market capitalism that is involved in such harmful developments as free-trade agreements
column36: worker visa programs
column37: massive immigration
column38: out-of-control energy policies
column39: broken health care systems
column40: huge cutbacks in various safety net programs
column41: massive redistribution of wealth upwards
column42: the gutting of our manufacturing base
column43: etc. The list could go on. Informed
column44: empowered citizens would not permit this system of corporate rule to exist. The US most decidedly is not in a state of too much democracy
column45: but is in the throes of democratic failure
column46: which election hoopla very conveniently disguises periodically. This is the story of democracy that the author chooses to ignore.   It is surprising to see the fairly high ratings of this book. Americans are supposedly fiercely democratic. Yet here is a book that clearly advocates elite rule
column47: even anti-democratic generals if need be. The book is really worth reading only to see the willingness of some to contain citizen empowerment.

column1: A former British Intelligence officer
column2: Lewis was one of those postwar travel writers whose books sold like gangbusters but have since largely faded into obscurity. Having recently traveled to Thailand
column3: Laos
column4: and Cambodia
column5: and being a fan of the travelogue genre
column6: I thought this might be a fitting introduction to his work. Originally published in 1951
column7: the book documents his trip of the previous year to French Indochina (Vietnam
column8: Laos
column9: and Cambodia) -- an era when the French colonial rule was in decline and the Viet Minh had already taken up arms to drive them out. The majority of the book is spent in Vietnam
column10: although certain spots on the modern tourist routes are given their due
column11: such as Siem Reap (Angkor) and Luang Prabang.  Lewis writes clean
column12: crisp
column13: one might say "British" prose
column14: which is easily digested -- so much so
column15: in fact
column16: that it takes a while to realize that the book is actually quite boring. His trip is somewhat of a litany of banal travel clichés: descriptions of bad roads
column17: worse bus drivers
column18: decrepit vehicles
column19: inscrutable natives
column20: "exotic" food
column21: and so forth. Despite his evident interest in various small rural tribes
column22: he doesn't seem to know very much about them
column23: and thus
column24: isn't able to tell the reader much of anything useful about them either. The most interesting parts of the book are his interactions with other Westerners
column25: especially the missionaries
column26: plantation lords
column27: and various French civil and military administrators who are eager to show him around.  The missionaries and plantation bosses come in for pretty heavy scorn from Lewis
column28: and anyone interested in the roots of the Vietnam War would be well advised to read the chapter where Lewis witnesses firsthand how the French system in Vietnam operated along feudal relationships of power and local villagers were forced to labor on plantations. Alas
column29: there's also plenty of scorn (albeit less direct) for the natives of the places he visits. There are no end of terms such as "squalid"
column30: "barbaric"
column31: "indolent"
column32: "immoral"
column33: "sinful" and the like applied to various tribespeople along the way. The levels of condescension are rather disappointing from someone eulogized by the Telegraph after his death as "perhaps the best
column34: and certainly the most underrated
column35: English travel writer of the 20th century."This is the book that allegedly inspired Graham Greene to go to Vietnam and then produce The Quiet American
column36: but most contemporary readers will find Greene's book to be far more engaging than this dated work.

column7: it's a sequel to a simply average comedy that lacks any of the sparks or intelligence that kept the original from total despair.

column1: Pushing the envelope for explicit
column2: over the counter home videos
column3: 9 SONGS (Tartan) is about one year of sex and rock'n roll in the life of two lovers.    Matt is a young glaciologist.  He meets Lisa at a London rock concert.  That night they start an affair.  In between attending more concerts
column4: they make passionate love.  It's for real and explicit.  Nine live-concert song footage is intercut with their coke-snorting
column5: sexual encounters creating a sometimes ironic reflection of their intense physical but otherwise rather bland relationship.  And finally
column6: all this takes place in the memory of Matt as he flies across the vast frozen wastelands of the South Pole.    This unscripted film is part musical
column7: part drama
column8: part documentary and part performance.  It raises questions about the difference between pornography and art. Controversial and much buzzed about
column9: this not fully satisfying experiment is of interest mainly as a novelty item by a usually innovative and creative director for what it could have been.  And of course the sex.  A special feature eliminates everything but the concert performances.

column1: When I read Michael Cunningham's A Home at the End of the World
column2: I was so dazzled by his prose that I found myself stopping again and again to reread and admire his sentences. In The Hours
column3: he combined the same stylistic virtuosity (paragraph after paragraph imitating Virginia Woolf's style
column4: for example) with a novelistic structure that took three separate narratives set in different times and slowly wound them together to devastating effect. Specimen Days also presents three linked narratives
column5: but everything that we admired about Cunningham's earlier books is missing here. The prose is utterly pedestrian
column6: the plotting ranges from the unlikely to the preposterous
column7: and the links between the three narratives are disappointingly mechanical and superficial.  The three narratives of Specimen Days are set in New York in different eras--the late nineteenth century
column8: the present
column9: and some time a century or so from now. To be fair
column10: there's a thematic connection between them: in each case
column11: one character sacrifices everything for the good of another character whom he or she knows only superficially. But the sad difference between Specimen Days and The Hours is this: in The Hours the three narratives merge to create something larger than each one is by itself
column12: but in Specimen Days the three stories
column13: presented sequentially
column14: fail to illuminate--or even to relate to--one another. Instead
column15: they're connected merely by a quirk (in each
column16: there's a character who recites lines from Walt Whitman's Leaves of Grass)
column17: a prop (a white porcelain bowl)
column18: and the characters' similar names. One thinks longingly of the subtly with which Cunningham evolved the stories in The Hours and wonders what went wrong here.  Each of the stories in Specimen Days is more improbable than the last. The most successful is the first
column19: about a boy who gives up everything to save another character from a disaster he only imagines and ends up saving her from an actual unimagined real disaster. (Since this story is the one most worth reading
column20: I won't give away more of the plot.)  In the second story
column21: a police hotline operator/psychologist unaccountably walks away from her career and her boyfriend to go on the lam with a child bomber whom the police are seeking and who
column22: she thinks
column23: will eventually kill her anyway. Sure. The third story is set in a United States that has been visited by a new species (think large versions of the Geico gecko
column24: but without the engaging British accent) and that has been largely laid waste by some kind of unspecified nuclear or ecological disaster. The story has to do with a lizard character who helps a near-human android get from New York to Denver so that the android can contact his creator. The android suffers from an inability to experience human emotions
column25: but through a turn of events when they reach Denver
column26: he discovers that he can experience beauty and compassion like a full human being after all. "It seems I did a better job with you than I'd realized
column27:
says the android maker approvingly. That's right: think Star Trek's Mr. Data meets the Tin Man from the Wizard of Oz. How amazing, how disappointing, that such derivative dreck is coming from the pen of Michael Cunningham.   
 First, I would like to make clear, or to put it more aptly, this book was written by an academic and not someone who is in the actual business. In other words, lots of theory but nothing practical to back it up. If I'm not mistaken, the author has never, ever actually written a screenplay and have it produced. Those are strikes one and two against this book. Strike three is that, yes there is some valuable information contained between the covers but it's SO disjointed, you have to constantly go back and forth throughout it in order to try to make any sense out it. My advice? Buy something written by people who ARE in the movie business and NOT from the Joe College" types who live off of tenure so they really don't have to prove anything to anyone. It's one thing to talk about writing and quite another to sell something for a six figure amount to a production company

column8: 'Ships Of The Line' needs to head back to the literary version of space dry dock for a content refit

column1: The Last Samurai is a re-do of the 1990 borefest Dances With Wolves.  Once again
column2: a formerly evil American U.S. Army officer comes to the aid of an indigenous people who are threatened by evil predatory U.S. imperialism.  At least that is what the filmmakers would like you to believe.    Actually
column3: the Japanese samurai were an oppressor class in their own right.  The samurai preyed on the peasants.  Eventually
column4: as reformers took hold in 19th Century Japan
column5: a new national army based on the peasantry was formed.  When the samurai rose in revolt against the reform government and attempted to restore their traditional privileges. the national army defeated them.    The Last Samurai fails as both movie and history.  Avoid it like the plague.

column1: Instead of a testament to his climbing expeditions
column2: this book might best serve as a testament to what seems to be Jim Wickwire's blatant misogyny and egocentrism.  After detailing how he decided his wife should leave college to support him
column3: Wickwire regales us semi-boastfully with anecdotes relating how he expected his wife to be nothing more than a housekeeper
column4: child-rearer
column5: and "sex object" (his words).  After insisting on a large family
column6: and getting offended at a well-meaning priest who gently suggested birth control
column7: Wickwire  (by his own admission) proceeds to by-and-large shirk his duties as a father to all five of his children
column8: supporting them only in the economic sense.    We then get to read his thoughts about the innate subordinism of female climbers
column9: and their tendency toward sexual hijinks on the mountains.  The brunt of Wickwire's finger-pointing rests solidly on the shoulders of the female climbers he discusses
column10: until he falls "in love" with Marty Hoey
column11: a talented female climber with the sense
column12: it seems
column13: never to have gotten seriously involved with Wickwire
column14: despite his attempts to the contrary.  Wickwire seems to read much into incidents like feet (separated by different sleeping bags) accidentally touching in a overcrowded tent.  After the reader is forced to endure reading a series of desperate
column15: petulant
column16: and adolescent notes and conversations directed from Wickwire to Hoey
column17: he recounts her death on Everest perfunctorily
column18: for the most part
column19: and in terms of how his wife forgave him for this one-sided indiscretion. All things considered
column20: I'm not sure who should be more outraged: Mary Lou Wickwire
column21: reading her husband's embarassing account of "falling in love" with Hoey (and knowing all her friends and peers will be reading it too)
column22: or Marty Hoey herself
column23: to whom Wickwire attributes a number of childish and maudlin love notes
column24: and who is no longer here to defend herself.  To be fair
column25: Wickwire may not be the narrow-minded boor he appears to be as when
column27: he sadly acknowledges of the inevitable entry of women into the legal profession (one wonders what rock he was living under
column28: or climbing over
column29: not to know that women entered the legal profession long before then).  The book
column30: while also hampered by a ridiculous title
column31: is full of stilted prose and dialogue.  In Wickwire's world
column32: climbers never say things like "We've gotta get down the mountain
column33: fast." Instead
column34: they make proclamations like
column35: "We must descend quickly
column36: or we shall perish upon the mountain." If they were climbing in King Arthur's time
column37: maybe; in this day and age
column38: no one speaks like that.  As a result
column39: the dialogue sounds stilted and fictitious
column40: even if it had a basis in fact.  The prose lingers too long
column41: and clumsily
column42: on Wickwire's relationships with those around him
column43: even though his relationships seem rather shallow.  Again
column44: this may be the fault of the co-writer or the source
column45: one never knows.  I would heartily recommend saving your money and time
column46: and reading a more climbing-related and less self-centered and angsty text

column1: Dear author
column2: reader
column3: brother
column4: sister
column5: friend
column6: I apologize for being the bearer of bad news
column7: but the traditions in the Andes just arent quite what they used to be.  The author of this book conducted her so-called research in 1996
column8: but a lot has changed in less than ten years.  The communities of Qeros have changed a lot too
column9: and the supposed Reality the author tries to come to terms with in this book is very different from what she describes.    Tourism and the Mystical Tourism industry in Peru have severely transformed the spiritual climate in Qeros
column10: as well as elsewhere.  Most
column11: but not all
column12: so-called traditions that exist today are for the benefit of foreign tourists with money.  (I find it hard to believe that the author is unaware of that fact
column13: though she doesnt mention it much.)  The supposedly mystical experiences and knowledge herein Must be received as one receives a report from a tourist.  In other words
column14: take this book as the information gathered by someone who does Not speak the language
column15: hasnt done her homework
column16: got some of the names wrong
column17: and interpreted what she saw through decidedly western eyes.    While claiming to present the Andean Mystical tradition as a self-contained and unromanticized whole
column18: the author does little more than reveal her own lack of cultural immersion and over-simplifications in the face of an entirely alien religious
column19: mystical
column20: and spiritual system (as bound
column21: importantly
column22: in a deep
column23: ancient
column24: and wholly unique cultural framework).  What little she does to reveal spiritual insights (and frankly
column25: many of these insights are just cases of poor interpretation
column26: or simply incorrect
column27: period) is perverted by a lack of cultural awareness and sensitivity
column28: paramount in giving the spiritual issues context.    For many years I have studied firsthand with and have close friends among the Qeros
column29: conversing in their language (Quechua)
column30: not mine.  What I have come to understand is that it is NOT vital that we understand their spiritual tradition-- in our western arrogance and self-importance
column31: indeed it is insulting-- unless we are willing to do what it takes to KNOW the traditions.    The author seeks to explain and understand
column32: but just doesnt know at all.  I wish her well on her continued spiritual journey
column33: but truly wonder what she hopes to gain by furthering a romanticized and westernized image of a very distinct spiritual and cultural tradition.  I give her the benefit of the doubt
column34: though
column35: and lament that perhaps she truly has no idea how far from the truth she is.    (...

column1: I read all of the reviews here and thought these would be the best option for easy transport AND low ambient sound i-pod headpohones without breaking the bank (I'm on a plane frequently). I wanted something that I wouldn't cry over breaking or losing during my many travels. I found that the uneven cord lengths are very irritating- especially if you like to use only one plug (like maybe at your desk at work). The weight of the shorter cord pulls on the longer cord and it is quite uncomfortable- even when sitting still. So then I thought these will be great workout headphones (won't be upset if I break or lose them)
column2: HOWEVER
column3: the cords produce noise in the ear pieces everytime they rub on your clothing or your hand. The effect is very loud and disruptive to your music listening experience (even when you are sitting stationary at your desk). It is similar to wearing a stethescope
column4: which defeats the point of wearing in-the-ear headphones (which are supposed to reduce the ambient noise). I do not recommend these headphones
column5: because of this stethescope effect- I could get over the uneven cord lengths for certain uses (they are after all designed to wear behind the head). I'm on the hunt for better quality headphones

column1: This is the worst
column2: most depressing piece of fiction I have ever read.  There is no real protoganist and not one singular character worthy of admiration--and after a while
column3: their actions just become inexplicable.  The author's soul must truly be an ugly one to have devoted so much time and energy to using his mind to generate so many casual acts of evil throughout the book.  It starts out promising but by the time you get to about halfway through the book or so you get a nagging sense that your very own soul might be sucked out of you and permanently stolen by the heart of Neil Gaiman's darkness or one of his minions.  Additionally
column4: the characters' motivations change like the shifting sands
column5: nothing they do makes any real sense except some inexplicable movement towards doing greater and more evil en masse like some sort of coagulating bacteria or disease.  What is so creepy about this book is the casualness of it all.  Unlike some of Stephen King's work (ie: The Stand)
column6: there is absolutely no redeeming thread here--no rallying or marshalling the troops to combat the emerging evil.  It's evil in evil vs. evil surrounded by evil.  All I can say is that this book is ugly
column7: ugly
column8: ugly.  At least writers like Joyce Carol Oats and Joseph Conrad's intentions when writing about such things is to effectively demonstrate the ill effects of such darkness
column9: but to make heroes of characters one should avoid is unconscionable.  The choices the supposed protoganist makes make no sense--and you do root for  him in the very beginning but you find he is just like one of them after all.  I suspended my doubt and disbelief as long as I could but finally became so incensed by the audacity of both the literary critics and the author to pass this off as excellence
column10: I literally stopped mid-sentence and chose to never read this author's work again.  It's a shame too because he has allied himself in other incarnations with a truly gifted artist
column11: Dave McKean
column12: who maybe hasn't completely gone over to the dark side like Neil has.  His association with Dave McKean is the only reason I even opened-up the book--and maybe a little because the title intrigued me.  But it's unfortunate that the industry rewards "clever" works such as Mr. Gaiman's with undue praise.  I've never so strongly disliked a book.  Have you ever found yourself getting angry because you felt robbed or duped by a book?  Well
column13: don't believe the hype
column14: this is the one to throw in the trash or disintegrate with X-men eyeball laserbeams before all your humanity is sucked out of you

column1: Considering the reputation of this book
column2: I was quite shocked to read some of the errors it contains with regard to Australia and New Zealand to the extent I cannot take for granted anything else within its pages.  A short list:   1. Anzacs
column3: pie floaters and lamingtons are not "food traditions" bought from Britain by migrants and convicts.  All of them originated in Australia in the 20th century.  2. The swagman boiling potatoes in his billy can is a new one to me. Billies were generally used for making tea. Most swaggies did not get more than bully beef
column4: flour
column5: sugar and tea.  3. Anzacs are biscuits
column6: not cakes.  4. The "pie floater" is a meat pie in a bowl of pea soup
column7: not tomato sauce
column8: and is not our national dish unless a national dish by definition is something almost universally derided and never eaten.  5. In what appears to be an attempt to cater for different terminology in different countries
column9: the authors have put corn syrup in brackets after golden syrup. However
column10: these are not the same thing
column11: golden syrup being derived from sugar cane and having an entirely different flavour.  6. As above
column12: icing and frosting are not the same thing.  Any attempt to make lamingtons with frosting will result in total failure.  7. In New Zealand
column13: food is not "simple" meat and veg
column14: but rather a reflection of the diversity of the country's population due to immigration.  In particular
column15: food from Thailand
column16: Malaysia and India is common and modern New Zealand cuisine strongly reflects its influences. The book's information may have been accurate 20-30 years ago
column17: but certainly not now.  8. In New Zealand
column18: kiwifruit is most certainly not eaten with every meal!  This is just a sample from the information regarding Australia and New Zealand and clearly demonstrates extremely poor research. The sort of nonsense you might expect from people who still believe Australians ride kangaroos to work.  I suppose for people who don't know any better
column19: it's great
column20: though to me it smacks of the Emperor's new clothes. I shudder to think that anyone has 100% faith in this book. Given Larousse's reputation (not to mention price) I expect a lot more.

column1: From the start
column2: Trotsky always thought that revolution in any one country could only succeed if it received the active support of revolutions in other countries. But similarly
column3: these other revolutions would also need to receive help from others: the Russian revolution could not survive without a revolution in Germany
column4: but neither could a German revolution survive without a Russian. This mutual dependence meant that no country could ever start a revolution: it would have to wait on the success of another.  So to provoke these indispensable other revolutions
column5: Trotsky was quite prepared to invade other countries. For example
column6: in 1919 he wrote
column7: "A cavalry corps of 30-40
column8: 000 horsemen must be formed to invade India." Similarly
column9: at Brest-Litovsk in February 1918
column10: Trotsky made the Soviet revolution's very survival depend on the putative German revolution
column11: risking total defeat by the German army on the throw of a revolution in Germany. He said
column12: "We declare we end the war but do not sign a peace. They will be unable to make an offensive against us. If they attack us
column13: our position will be no worse than now ..." This phrase-mongering did not frighten the German generals
column14: who saw only that Trotsky was refusing to sign the offered peace. They then attacked
column15: as he said they could not do
column16: and seized millions of square miles of Soviet territory
column17: making the Soviet position far worse than before. In the 1930s
column18: the Opposition leagued with Hitler. Churchill wrote
column19: "The German government was in touch with important Russian personalities through the Soviet embassy in Prague. The plot aimed at overthrowing Stalin and introducing into Russia a new pro-German regime. Soviet Russia carried out a merciless but doubtless useful purge of political and economic circles. The Soviet army was purged of pro-German elements." Goebels admitted
column20: "Stalin got rid of all the opposition circles in the Red Army and thus succeeded in making sure there were no more defeatist groups in the Army." The Opposition fought against the programmes of industrialisation and collectivisation that made possible all the Soviet Union's heroic achievements. For instance
column21: in April 1930
column22: Trotsky's Bulletin of the Opposition said
column23: "Put a stop to `mass collectivisation'. ... Put a stop to the hurdle race of industrialisation. ... Abandon the `ideals' of self-contained economy. Draw up a new variant of a plan providing for the widest possible intercourse with the world market." In 1938
column24: Trotsky called for the collective farms to be closed down
column25: and for Soviet enterprises to be handed over to foreign powers.  He consistently called on the Soviet people to overthrow the Soviet government when Hitler attacked. He called for a `revolutionary uprising'
column26: an `insurrection' against the Soviet government
column27: when Hitler attacked the Soviet Union. He wrote
column28: "the impetus to the Soviet workers' revolutionary upsurge will probably be given by events outside the country." "The first social shock
column29: external or internal
column30: may throw the atomized Soviet Society into civil war." He asked
column31: "Can we expect that the Soviet Union will come out of the coming great war without defeat? To this frankly posed question
column32: we will answer as frankly: If the war should remain only a war
column33: the defeat of the Soviet Union would be inevitable. In a technical
column34: economic and military sense
column35: imperialism is incomparably more strong. If it is not paralysed by revolution in the West
column36: imperialism will sweep away the present regime." "The defeat of the Soviet Union is inevitable in case the new war shall not provoke a new revolution. ... If we theoretically admit war without revolution
column37: then the defeat of the Soviet Union is inevitable." He wrote
column38: "It would be childish to think that the Stalin bureaucracy can be removed by means of a Party or Soviet Congress. Normal
column39: constitutional means are no longer available for the removal of the ruling clique. ... They can be compelled to hand over power to the Proletarian vanguard only by FORCE." "Inside the Party
column40: Stalin has put himself above all criticism and the State. It is impossible to displace him except by assassination. Every oppositionist becomes ipso facto a terrorist." Trotsky lied to the `Dewey Commission' when he told them that that he had not been organising an underground in the Soviet Union. The leader of Trotsky's Fourth International
column41: Ernest Mandel
column42: openly applauded Boris Yeltsin
column43: the key figure in the counter-revolution that finally restored capitalism in the Soviet Union. He wrote
column44: "The reformer Yeltsin represents the tendency which wants to reduce the gigantic state apparatus. Consequently he follows in Trotsky's footsteps." The Socialist Workers Party backed the US-organised and funded terrorists
column45: which spawned bin Laden
column46: against the people of Afghanistan. "Mujehadin victory will encourage the opponents of Russian rule everywhere in the USSR and Eastern Europe."

column1: I have never typed a review before
column2: but after reading this book
column3: I felt compelled to voice my opinion.  I was raised Catholic and as I grew older found myself questioning my own faith.  I have many of the same conflicting feelings between science and religion that the author himself claimed to have.  When I read the description for "The Case for a Creator"
column4: I was filled with anticipation of what lay within the pages.  However
column5: once I reached page 50
column6: I felt like the air had been let out of the tires.  How
column7: I wondered
column8: could the book claim to present a "case"
column9: when the mention of a "case" leads the reader to believe that
column10: as in the court of law
column11: both sides will be presented and argued fairly
column12: and the final determination will rest in the hands of the jury
column13: or in the case of a book
column14: in the hands of the reader.  However
column15: in the "One-Sided Case for a Creator"
column16: Strobel destroys his own credibility by not even attempting to cleverly conceal his agenda towards the idea of an intelligent and divine creator.  It is almost an insult to the reader
column17: as if Strobel is saying to us
column18: "I don't want or expect you to think about
column19: analyze
column20: or question what I am saying
column21: I just expect you to lap it up and accept it as truth."  I find Strobel's writing to be maddening...at the end of each chapter I was left with a hungry feeling
column22: as though I had just eaten a plate of air.  With each chapter
column23: I hoped that Strobel would redeem himself by presenting both sides to his so-called "case"...however
column24: he consistently disappointed by presenting only his side.  After reading the book
column25: I was left confused
column26: skeptical
column27: and felt the need to research the side of the case that Strobel conveniently neglected.  A book that could have been a masterpiece falls far short and is an insult to any reader who is looking for a well-rounded argument.  If you agree with Strobel's point of view
column28: you will love it and will lap it up...but why read it if you already believe in the idea of a divine creator???  If you are searching for a convincing book of substance
column29: look elsewhere.

I have read this book (and its companion volume) a couple of times
column2: and to be honest I am not a fan.  Many of Jan Fennell's suggestions are useful
column3: but none are original.   Ms Fennell's method is based on the idea of using the non-violent language of the wolf pack to put your dog in his rightful subordinate place
column4: and therefore gain his understanding and cooperation.  Alpha wolves eat first - so Ms Fennell has the dog owner eat dinner before his dog.  Alpha wolves take the pack out hunting - so we are bid to walk our dogs daily.  Alpha wolves aren't demonstrative - so we are told to ignore our dogs for five minutes each time we arrive home from work.  These suggestions are sensible
column5: but they are hardly revolutionary.  Maintaining dominant status by behaving like an "alpha" wolf is a technique that has been championed by many other authors - the only difference is that Ms Fennell gives this process the cutesy name of "Amichien bonding".  The technique is a good one for restoring a relationship with a dog that has been spoiled or confused in the past by weak or misinformed owners. Its success lies not only in the owner mimicking canine behaviour
column6: but also in the institution of house rules and a predictable daily routine for the dog.    So what is wrong with this book?  The first fatal flaw is the unrealistic simplicity of the method.  Ms Fennell seems to believe that all canine behavioural problems are caused by the dog wishing to be alpha.  It is certainly true that a dog with a misplaced sense of his own importance will probably become a problem dog.  However
column7: dogs can also behave badly for a plethora of other reasons - poor training
column8: learned fear
column9: boredom
column10: health issues
column11: confusion and inherent high prey drive
column12: to name just a few.  Ms Fennell's insistence that all canine problems are dominance problems that can be cured by "Amichien bonding" is unfortunately just not realistic.       For a professional dog trainer
column13: Ms Fennel also displays a rather disturbing lack of knowledge about several dog breeds.  At one point she states that it may be impossible to fully train Bull Terriers "and dogs of this type" due to their inherent "savage natures"!  One gets the impression that she has been unable to train this type of dog herself and holds a grudge about it.  Whatever the reason
column14: I find it somewhat disingenuous of her to ignore the fact that other trainers have managed to train these breeds to very high standards
column15: and blame her own failure to do so on the dogs instead of on her own methods.  In short?  If you know very little about dog behaviour and have a mildly pushy dog
column16: then this book isn't a bad buy.  Certainly
column17: applying the "Amichien bonding" advice won't hurt.  It is the same type of programme as recommended by dog behaviourists the world over (you can get much of the same information for free on the internet
column18: from Shirley Chong's website for example).    However
column19: Ms Fennell's book is not a comprehensive guide to solving every dog's problems.  If your dog has moderate to serious behavioural problems
column20: save your money and book a consultation with a professional behaviourist.  Your dog will thank you for it.
