column1: This is not a review of Ms. Yates's writing.  Instead
column2: I am awarding the single star to the physical book perpetrated by the University of Chicago Press in 1991.  The good news is that this edition doesn't cost very much.  The bad news is that the 1991 edition is a bad reproduction of an earlier edition.  The ink bleeds all over some of the pages.  There are diagonal streaks on many pages.  Sometimes the ink is light grey on one side of a diagonal streak
column3: while it is dark and smudged on the other side.  Parts of letters that landed in the streak are missing.  A note on the back of the title page claims only that "The paper used in this publication meets the minimum requirements of the ... Standard ... for Library Materials."  Does this less than ringing endorsement mean that the paper is acidic and will soon deteriorate?  If so
column4: it won't be much of a loss

column1: I bought this hoping to learn more about the Vietnamese people and their history. I got bogged down with all the poetry and prose quoted by the writer. While he brushes off the importance of the battle of Dien Bien Phu in a couple of lines; he drones on quoting (translating) obscure Vietnamese writers until the reader becomes weary. His premise seems to be that if you understand some writer (who he thinks is interesting) and attach importance to what he said then you will understand Vietnam. His annoying treatment of Yin and Yang finally caused me to put the book down and look for another way to understand Vietnam. If you like words such as "efficacy" and "entropy" you will love this writer; if such words irritate you
column2: give this book a pass

column1: Chromosome 6 has a great premise: what happens if medical technology accelerates to the point that scientists can create genetic doubles for people; doubles who serve as living organ reservoirs for possible future organ transplant needs-a sort of biological insurance policy? How much would people pay for this service? How far would they go to protect it? What are the moral implications?  Robin Cook comes full circle
column2: returning to the themes of his 1970s novel
column3: Coma. Coma is the novel that first made us aware of the dangers of corporate medicine and greed; of the subtle but relentless destruction of the long-standing relationships patients had with doctors
column4: and the dignity those relationship once preserved. Now
column5: a quarter century later
column6: Robin Cook is shown to have been eerily prescient as technology has caught up to his nightmare.  Chromosome 6 is a very believable scenario of a technology designed with the best of intentions being corrupted for the sake of profit. In this novel
column7: there is mystery and murder; medical sleuthing and exotic
column8: international sets. There are a host of characters whose paths will intersect at some point-the set up is brilliant and we read with eager anticipation-but...this novel is so poorly written that I cannot believe it has Robin Cook's name on it. Though not high literature
column9: Robin Cook's novels have always been tight and suspenseful
column10: with believable characters and settings that seemed real. The characters in Chromosome 6 are as flat as road kill
column11: the action as watered down as a glass of coke left in the sun until all of the ice has melted. Turn a page and the story just ends...what? That's it? Are you kidding? Did Robin Cook really write this? I don't think so.

column1: The literature of September 11 is never attacked.  When a book speaks of September 11 (or of terrorism in general)
column2: it is more or less guaranteed immunity from criticism; it will almost inescapably be greeted with sympathy.  Jonathan Safran Foer's EXTREMELY LOUD AND INCREDIBLY CLOSE banks on such sympathy
column3: on such reverence.  The narrative
column4: which concerns a nine-year-old boy named Oskar Schell in search of a key that would unlock / unshell the enigma of his dead father (a narrative stolen
column5: in its basic outline
column6: from Guenther Grass's DIE BLECHTROMMEL)
column7: could have been written entirely without its scattered references to the terrorist interventions.  Nor is this trauma the only one presented in the novel: the others include Hiroshima / Nagasaki
column8: the Staten Island Ferry crash
column9: and the Dresden bombings.  Each disaster is generalized to the point at which what is addressed is not a traumatizing event in its specificity
column10: but historical "trauma" itself and the overcoming of trauma through bereavement-inspired creation.  Oskar
column11: the insufferable brat
column12: attempts to complete the work of mourning for his father
column13: Thomas Schell
column14: Jr.
column15: a victim of September 11
column16: by compiling an almanac of self-inflicted wounds
column17: the collage of images and letters which is the book we are "reading"---an almanac which
column18: most likely
column19: is written sometime in the indefinite future (Thomas Shell
column20: Sr.'s manuscript of 4/12/78 is heavily edited (pp. 208-216).  Who has done the editing?  Almost certainly an older version of his grandson Oskar).  If the term
column21: "reading" even applies.  Whenever a "pregnant" image is described
column22: Foer literally re-presents it in the form of a pictorial image.  When a flock of birds rises into the sky
column23: it is not enough that we read of these birds---we must see them as well.  Words may not be left in their invisibility; we are presented with supplementary photographs
column24: illustrations
column25: since mere verbality is not enough.  (Indeed
column26: the entire novel oozes with misologos --- the mistrust or hatred of language --- in terms of both its content and its form.)  Photographs
column27: yes
column28: and also a superabundance of blank pages and nearly blank pages.  Space is not used in the manner it is in the works of Edmond Jabes
column29: for instance.  Typography does not substitute for a well-wrought sentence.  Foer abrogates himself of all responsibilities --- most specifically
column30: the responsibility to write well.  Why bother when the pyrotechnics of typography are at his disposal?  As far as the writing is concerned
column31: it is composed of nothing other than mind-numbingly
column32: soul-deadeningly repetitive phrases ("heavy boots
column33: raison d'etre
column34: etc.) and Sunday school platitudes: Sometimes one simply wants to disappear" (184); "There's nothing wrong with not understanding yourself" (184); "Everything that's born has to die
column35: which means our lives are like skyscrapers" (245); "How can you say I love you to someone you love?...  It's always necessary" (314).  Whenever the author writes something that he finds "beautiful" and "true" (165)
column36: he congratulates himself on his brilliance and tells us that that thing is "beautiful" and "true."  The entire book reeks of such unearned profundity.  We also learn that most dust is made up of human detritus---a very deep truth indeed
column37: one that Foer also communicates in his essay
column38: "Emptiness" (originally published in PLAYBOY) with all of the sanctimoniousness and self-righteousness of the faux naif who serves as the center of the novel
column39: a Sunday school lecture in which we learn that famous musicians (Ringo Star) and scientists (Stephen Hawking) are unthreateningly approachable: everything is familiarized.  Perhaps it is wrong to criticize Foer for including so many blank pages in EXTREMELY LOUD AND INCREDIBLY CLOSE
column40: since the entire book is a vacuum: null space into which readers may project their own meanings.  Joseph Suglia
column41: Ph.D.
column42: the author of WATCH OUT

column1: Don't buy this edition. Get the first edition

column5: who has edited out crucial fragments in order to support his own "Analytical Philosophy" take on the Presocratics. As an example
column6: he has removed crucial fragments which link Parmenides with the Pythagoreans.   So make sure you acquire the 1st Edition of this crucial sourcebook which was edited in an honest fashion by G.S. Kirk and J.E. Raven
column7: and ignore any later edition which has been corrupted and invalidated by M. Schofield.  Also

column9: In the Dark Places of Wisdom
column10: and Ancient Philosophy
column11: Mystery
column12: and Magic: Empedocles and Pythagorean Tradition." These books will give you the real fragments
column13: and provide you with a real take on why scholars with the intellectual dishonesty of an M. Schofield will rewrite and even abandon the original texts in order to further their own misguided agendas.

column1: I purchased Dr. Street's book out of curiousity of what the author would write to defend the evangelical method of altar calls and the ever so popular sinner's prayer.  Sadly
column2: the book lacks any serious theological treatment of salvation and completely ignores the sovereignty of God in salvation.  The book seeks to be a guide both to evangelists and pastors to how to deliever an "effective" invitation (emphasis on numbers being the key word for effective.)  Dr. Street should have rightly named this book
column3: "The Effective Manipulation Methods" and then traced the poor theology of Charles Finney right down to Billy Graham.  While Dr. Street does try to answer his critics (such as Martin Llyod-Jones) he never truly gives any answers but simply lists Llyod-Jones' nine reasons not to give an altar call and never gives any biblical reason we should do so.  Dr. Street works from a Baptist theology that ignores election and the work of the Holy Spirit (John 6:44; Acts 14:48) and places the emphasis on man (both pastors and hearers).  He cites not one biblical example of an actual altar call or genuine invitation but uses various Scriptures out of context to try to make his point.  He also gives justification to the sinner's prayer method although he never deals with any Scriptures concerning this matter (since there are none I would expect him to do so).    Overall
column4: unless you are an Arminian in your evangelistic approach
column5: then I would not encourage you to purchase this book.  It offers nothing in the means of theological content.  You would be better to read Iain Murray's book THE INVITATION SYSTEM or John MacArthur's ASHAMED OF THE GOSPEL
column6: THE GOSPEL ACCORDING TO JESUS
column7: or HARD TO BELIEVE.

column1: The overall story of "Pure
column2: about a girl who becomes addicted to pain , is interesting - but that's about all this book has to offer. Most of her sentences don't even make sense. For example: I didn't like Dawn's smile
column3: wandering through to sit next to me." Many times you don't know who's moving or who's speaking because Ray's nouns don't connect to her verbs.   A good editor would do wonders for this novel. If some of the unnecessary poor grammar were fixed and if the mundane
column4: everyday scenes were cut
column5: this book would read a lot better. There are some really great moments in this book (like when the narrator realizes she wants to break up with her first boyfriend). column6: her first relationship
column7: and the abuse Robin gives her - but all of this could have happened in 20 pages. column1: "We all have a personal money blueprint ingrained in our subconscious minds
column2: and this blueprint will determine your financial life. You can know everything about marketing
column3: sales
column4: negotiations
column5: stocks
column6: real estate
column7: and the world of finance
column8: but if your blueprint isn't set for a high level of success
column9: you'll never make a lot of money-and if by chance you do
column10: you'll most likely lose it!" - T. Harv Eker  Author of the international bestselling book Secrets of the Millionaire Mind
column11: T. Harv Eker intends to show you how to think and act like a millionaire in the 50-card deck of the same name.  Each colorful card features an affirmation on one side and an expansion of the idea on the other. Some of the messages in the Secrets of the Millionaire Mind Cards include:  "Be the Best at What You Do - To get paid the best
column12: you must BE the best. Rich people are experts in their field
column13: middle-class people are mediocre in their field
column14: and poor people are poor in their field."  "Associate With Successful People - Birds of a feather flock together. The rich associate with successful people
column15: the poor often associate with unsuccessful people. Energy is contagious. If you want to fly with the eagles
column16: you'll have to stop swimming with the ducks."  "Don't Listen to Broke People - Rich people take advice from people who are richer than they are. Poor people take advice from their friends
column17: who are just as broke as they are."  "Embrace Responsibility - Most people run from responsibility-that's why they're broke. Rich people are willing to take on big responsibilities-that's why they're rich."  As you can see
column18: the Secrets of the Millionaire Mind Cards is full of materialistic tripe. Eker tries to add some "spiritual" messages to this deck with cards like "Become Conscious"
column19: "Learn to Live in Your Higher Self"
column20: and "Enhance Your Energy". However
column21: most of the cards are full of polarizing messages with the dividing line between "rich" and "poor". The assumptions and dualistic philosophy are disturbing. The messages promote an "us versus them" attitude
column22: in addition to focusing on others as both competition and as a measuring stick for "success".  Eker uses the word "success" quite often
column23: and it would appear that his personal standard is the United States. Many of his assertions are so off the mark
column24: it's hard to pick where to start! For example
column25: I grew up in a lower-middle class environment
column26: and my father was the local butcher. He was the best in the area
column27: with many stores trying to lure him away to join their company. His reputation was excellent
column28: he took great pride in his work
column29: always paid the bills
column30: and went to work despite illness. In fact
column31: I remember him going to work with a broken ankle-which wasn't easy considering he spent much of his day in frigid conditions.  However
column32: according to the Secrets of the Millionaire Mind Cards

column3: knew of Lucy

column6: everyone knew of Lucy.  She was the one who'd had cancer as a child and whose chemotherapy treatments had left her with a severely disfigured face that continued to need surgery after surgery until the end of her life.  Lucy was mistreated by her peers when she was a child
column7: but it seemed that for the rest of her life everyone was trying to make up for that cruelty.  She was cheered for and spoken to warmly wherever she went
column8: despite the fact that she seemed to have few redeeming qualities that would make her so popular.  Even Ann admits that she followed the gossip about Lucy's medical condition and she felt close to her even when Lucy had no idea who Ann was.  Ann couldn't be more delighted when Lucy decides to move in with her after college.  She continues to be thrilled and grateful for the rest of Lucy's life
column9: as Lucy drifts through existence
column10: needing constant reassurance that people loved her
column11: that she was beautiful and talented.  She also needs money
column12: and someone to clean her apartment
column13: and someone to do her bidding after her surgeries.  That person is always Ann
column14: who seems to simply accept that this is the way their relationship should be.  I was confused.  How could an intelligent
column15: educated person allow herself to be treated so poorly?  What was Ann getting out of this relationship that I couldn't see?  Or was it simply that she befriended someone prone to depression and suicide attempts
column16: so she felt she couldn't drop Lucy without putting her life in danger?  Ann is a much better friend than I could ever imagine being; I would have stopped speaking to Lucy after about the fiftieth page

column1: The first thing that came to mind as I trudged through Macintyre's wordy book was how could something called "concise" seem so long? This book is informative but entirely humorless
column2: like reading an ingredient list. Macintyre seems more concerned with showcasing his vocabularity then with enticing you with the facinating history of Australia's past. There is plenty of information in this book if you can make it through to the end while maintaining consciousness. If you are about to visit Australia and you are looking for an entertaining and informative book to stimulate your enthusiasm I strongly recommend Bill Bryson's In a Sunburned Country. If you are looking for a strong sedative then this is the book for you.

column1: I have been a musician and writer for over 50 years
column2: and glory of glories
column3: in Whitney Balliett's book
column4: American Musicians II
column5: he achieves perfect pitch in his prose when capturing the heart and soul of what music is
column6: and the men and women who make it happen. His stories pulse with an energy that is seemingly boundless.  Here is a man who has somehow gotten inside these legendary figures
column7: some of whom I knew and many of whom I've heard in person. Balliett lets you listen through his own ears
column8: giving you a guided tour not only of the notes on the page
column9: and then as they take flight in the air
column10: but also of the fascinating daily lives of these gifted individuals.  I can't play like Art Tatum
column11: but Balliett lets me sit beside him as he lays down his "perfect storm" of notes
column12: at the end of which is this huge rainbow whose image we carry in our mind forever.  If you love good music and good writing
column13: you've come to the perfect book.  Balliet is no longer with us
column14: but he has left us a legacy that should be treasured for 32 bars unto infinity. Ron Levin

Looking for a bit of sea adventure?  Fancy a run with some real life salts who face whatever the hurricane ravaged winter seas throw at them?  Well don't go looking to Redmond O'Hanlon's "Trawler".  O'Hanlon takes two potentially fascinating subjects - trawler fishing and the biology behind the creatures of the seas - and blends them into a putrid stew of nothingness.  This is a very difficult book to read. Physically difficult! Aye!  O'Hanlon's pointless
column2: manic use of exclamation and emphasis - EMPHASIS! Aye! - lends nothing to the story but then there is so little story
column3: it's really no loss.  "Trawler" dredges the bottom of literary technique and hauls up nothing but stream of consciousness drivel.  I found the book a total waste of time and will certainly never read another piece of work by O'Hanlon.  Aye!  I won't!  Never!

I recorded this film off of the IFC and watched it all the way through.  My only reward for this act is that I will never have to do it again.  I was initially intrigued by the film because it starred Sarah Polley of "The Road To Avonlea" fame
column2: and I thought that the plot synopsis sounded interesting.  I still think that the raw material was very good
column3: but The Sweet Hereafter has to be one of the most boring films I have ever seen.  The pace was so slow and so drawn out that I found myself wanting it to be over.  I think that this film is an example of what happens when depth and character analysis run amok and take over the film.  The Sweet Hereafter has so much depth and so much character analysis
column4: nuances
column5: and points of view that it is weighed down to the point of stagnation.  The film is so heavy that it cannot even prop itself up on a pillow.  I give it only two stars
column6: one for Ian Holm and one for Sarah Polley.  You could pass this one by and you wouldn't miss anything.

If one of the goals of this movie is to convince nonChristians of Christ's imminent return than the movie fails because even while I'm up on some of the end time paranoia the movie itself is very confusing and the subplot of "Buck" getting involved with a jealous Christian girl is worse than a Growing Pains sitcom scenario. column1: When purchasing audiobooks
column2: I normally follow a simple but very effective rule: never
column3: never
column4: never buy an audiobook read by the author. Even if the author is a talented writer
column5: he/she is invariably a terrible narrator. Always look for audiobooks performed by experienced readers
column6: as in Bryson's own "Notes From a Small Island" and "A Walk in the Woods"
column7: read by Ron Mclarty.  In Bryson's case I made a rare exception when I listened to "In a Sunburned Country" - the audio version had received reasonable reviews and his performance was indeed adequately entertaining. For this reason I assumed that "Neither Here Nor There" would be equally enjoyable. I was wrong. Bryson's deadpan monologue makes it sound as though he was bored out of his mind while reading this book. Passages that may have seemed amusing in the written version are herein delivered in a sleep-inducing monotone. The sardonically comedic talent he displayed in his reading of "In a Sunburned Country" is totally lacking. I would recommend this audiobook only as a cure for insomnia

The author attempts to wrap it up at the end with a sentence about the Greeks' "variety of human response
column4: lightening quick transmutations
column5: resourcefulness
column6: and inexhaustible creativity."    A subtitle like "A Greek Treasury of Personal Vignettes" might have been more descriptive and merited another star. But it falls short as a "hinge of history" with impoverished and even maladaptive connections (FDR as Solon - really?) to the modern world. I am sorry to not recommend it.

column1: The Secular Squeeze:  Reclaiming Christian Depth in a Shallow World.  What a fantastic title
column2: I thought to myself as I snatched the book from the bookshelf at my local Christian bookstore and raced hurriedly to the checkout counter.  I could hardly wait to get back home to my easy chair and begin reading this tome that seemed to echo my take on modern civilization in These United States.  I was anxiously looking forward to partaking of the views
column3: insights and philosophy of a person who would be so moved as to write a book such as this.  Sadly
column4: after completing the book
column5: some 307 pages later
column6: I'm still waiting.  What a letdown.  With such an incredible piece of subject matter
column7: how could a book such as this not be exciting?  Well
column8: truth be told
column9: it was as flat and shallow as the secular world it was trying to describe.  Yes
column10: modern society has lost its spiritual base and is totally caught up with the acquisition of things and the idea that "it is not enough for me to succeed
column11: you have to fail"
column12: but there was little more than cursory reference made to this. Mostly the book was made up of weak analogies and philosophies run wild.  If reference was made one more time to Andy Wharhol's paintings of soup cans
column13: or Arnold Schwarzenegger or Julia Roberts as being symbols of what is right and what is wrong with modern civilization
column14: I think I would have screamed.  The Schwarzenegger ("Total Recall") and Roberts ("Pretty Woman") references were meant to mean their movies I gather
column15: but the reference was to them as people rather than actors playing roles.  Schwarzenegger was depicted as what is wrong with society
column16: when in fact he would be a stellar role model for anyone.  He has a good marriage
column17: great kids and is a good citizen.  Julia Roberts on the other hand was depicted as what is right.  Am I missing something here?  She's a good actress
column18: but has had serious problems with relationships.  Then again
column19: elsewhere in the book
column20: the references to these two seems to flip flop.  But flip flopping seems to be a major problem with the book.  Every time I thought I'd caught on to where the book was heading
column21: it doubled back and ran in the opposite direction.  The author got so caught up in right-brained/left-brained diatribe that I often lost the point of what he was saying - but maybe that's because I'm just to the left of middle-brained and don't look at any one thing from totally one perspective.  The author also needs to understand that many words do not a point make.  Over three hundred pages of utter drivel could have been reduced to about twenty pages of possibly meaningful dialog - I think.  In short
column22: John F. Alexander
column23: do us all a favor.  Please don't write a sequel

column1: Although the poems are beautiful... and I certainly don't mean to bash Whitman with this 2-star rating... it's the wrong book. NOT AS ADVERTISED. This was supposed to be the original 1855 edition. That's what I expected
column2: and therefore (in my mind) what I was paying for. The original 1855 edition
column3: according to modern literary analysis
column4: was the "strongest/purest" version. It was the true starting point of Whitman's own (and consequently America's) poetic awakening. Consisting of just 12 "perfect" poems
column5: it was THAT edition which Emerson praised so highly.  Whitman never put out another book... just revision after revision
column6: addition after addition
column7: and edition after edition of Leaves Of Grass... until you wind up with "the deathbed edition" which is a severely bloated and different work from the original.   I was very much looking forward to a slender volume of the original edition. Which is what the item description says this is. It's not. Be forewarned... it's the Deathbed Edition of 1892... nearly 500 pages. And frankly
column8: there are MUCH better versions of the deathbed edition. Sturdier versions with nicer pages exist (this is a pretty weak paperback
column9: printed on pulp pages)
column10: with better footnotes and more authoritive introductions. Shop around.   To sum up... the 2 star rating is because lying about which edition this is
column11: is a terrible way to sell the book. Whitman was fantastic and the poetry contained in the book itself is first rate. It just would have been nice to get what I paid for. The "true" editon
column12: written by a YOUNG Whitman at the height of his powers..

I was dissapointed by all of the hype and rave reviews this book was given.  The author has good subject matter but has chosen a most difficult and almost incoherent writing style in which to convey her thoughts.  The novel jumps from place to place faster than rabbit being chased by a fox.  Chapters consist of bits of images pasted together like a collage rather than in a coherent
column2: logical order.  The novel reads like a MTV rap video.  Perhaps some consider this innovation.  I consider it bad prose.    The prose is choppy
column3: awkward and at times obscured by so much symbolism as to be obscure and unintelligable.  Many sentences fail to follow logically what was written previously.  CHapters are broken down into one or two sentence subchapters that seem loose and unconnected.    All this makes for painful reading that in the end seems not worth the effort.  The reviewers seem to be attracted to the unique style
column4: glitz that may impress some but ultimately loses its shine

column6: cutting all frequencies above 4600 hz. I have to say that except for the one or two that were processed beyond recall (with that lovely underwater digital sound)

column8: screeching
column9: piercing digital noise.  Mr. Hebden always finds such delightful
column10: rare records--and vandalizes them.  Good stuff here
column11: hence two stars rather than one.  Still
column12: I can't recommend this CD unless you are willing to re-equalize out the higher frequencies and you particularly wish to hear some of the selections.

I have never been a fan of Danielle Steel's books and have only read a couple in my lifetime
column2: and those many years ago.  I'm not sure what motivated me to pick up Toxic Bachelors -- extreme boredom? insanity? -- but I slogged through it last night and have to say that it confirmed all my bad impressions of this writer's work.  Actually
column3: I think I was a little surprised by how awesomely bad it was.  The writing was completely repetitive and superficial
column4: and I rather felt that I was reading a treatment for a novel rather than the novel itself.  It read like a poor book report:  "...and then he did this
column5: and then he did this
column6: and after that he did this
column7: and then he laughed."  We are TOLD that the bachelors -- who struck me as commitment-phobic
column8: a little neurotic
column9: and fairly immature despite their (middle) age
column10: but not necessarily toxic -- are decent
column11: likable guys
column12: but we never really see too much proof of that.  When the "proof" does come
column13: it's so ham-handed as to be laughable:  Charlie's eyes well up with tears when he meets a young girl who was abused by her mother
column14: and so we know that he truly does have a loving and compassionate soul and untold complexities to his character.  Yeahsurerightwhatever.  Most of the story is told through narration
column15: with little bits and pieces of ho-hum dialogue.  The author adopted a third-person point of view
column16: but there's certainly nothing omniscient about it
column17: and the reader is never sucked into the head of one of these characters.  Throughout the book they remain about as interesting and dimensional as paper dolls
column18: and their interactions with one another always struck me as being fairly unbelievable.  THIS is how men behave and relate to one another?  I find that hard to believe
column19: considering that none of the men I know run around telling each other how much they love one another and how important they are to each other.    I liked the female characters of the book initially.  They all seemed to be strong
column20: capable
column21: independent and emotionally healthy women.  But my opinion of each diminished greatly toward the end of the book
column22: as each woman seemed all too willing to disregard her personal boundaries and put up with extreme schmuckiness from her man.  And the conflicts Steel generated amongst the couples seemed ridiculous:  mountains out of molehills.  For instance
column23: Gray
column24: the 50-year-old artist who has always been phobic about family
column25: refuses to meet the ADULT children of the woman he's been with for several months and whom he claims to love.  Nevermind the fact that he's known about the ADULT children since the very beginning.  Nevermind the fact that the ADULT children live in England and Italy
column26: while Gray and Sylvia are New Yorkers.  Nevermind the fact that they have their own lives and are independent
column27: self-sufficient ADULTS who maintain their relationship with their mother through frequent phone calls and less frequent face-to-face visits.  Evidently Gray can't see beyond the fact that they are "kids" and therefore "family" and therefore not to be tolerated.  Sorry
column28: but whatever sympathy I'd developed for Gray by this point disappeared altogether when confronted by this monstrous display of immaturity.  Dump the weenie
column29: Sylvia.  You can do better.  The other two guys had similar displays of gross ridiculousness
column30: and of course everything was wrapped up magically
column31: with sudden capitulation
column32: as if the men had just suddenly come to their senses.    Considering what little time and effort was spent on these characters
column33: their conflicts and resolution
column34: I have to wonder why Steel even bothered writing this book.  And why I bothered reading i

column1: This book is about a Jewish girl named Hannah Green who flees from Spain in fear of the Spanish Inquisition after witnessing her mother being captured and burned alive at the stakes for being a Jew.  She comes to England with her father and lives as a Christian while following the Jewish religion in secrecy.  Through a chain of events she becomes a royal fool and a spy - for both Queen Mary and Elizabeth.   Throughout the book Hannah talks about how she misses her mother and can still smell her mother's burning flesh from the stakes and then also professes her love for Queen Mary and what a wonderful woman she is.  It is well documented in history as well as this book about Queen Mary's burning of hundreds of non-Catholics at the stakes.  A practice that earned her the name - Bloody Mary.  The book is very sympathetic towards Queen Mary and portrays her as a virtuous woman who believed that she was burning people for their own sake - "only doing what she believed to be right in her heart".    The fact that Hannah was living her life in fear of being discovered as a Jew and continued to deeply love Queen Mary was extremely unbelievable and ridiculous. I could not help but roll my eyes every time I read how much Hannah loved and admired Queen Mary.

column1: Amartya Sen is a serious economist
column2: who has some serious ideas
column3: but they are not in this book.  The book purports to be an philosophical/economic argument for "freedom now" as both the means and the goal of economic and social policy
column4: and an argument against the postponement of "freedom" until after "purely" economic development has occurred.    Freedom
column5: Sen claims -and not merely wealth or the rule of law- is the best vehicle to promote...well...freedom itself.  If this reasoning sounds circular to you
column6: you are not alone.  On one interpretation
column7: this strikes me as trivially true.  Sure: promote freedom and you will indeed get freedom.  If
column8: on the other hand
column9: Sen is stating that freedom is "the solution" to global poverty
column10: his thesis is dubious at best.  And this is especially so because Sen's book is NOT really a polemic against Confucian statism (i.e. the "Lee thesis")
column11: it is a polemic against economic liberalism.  Lee is just a straw man used to advance Sen's more fundamental claim: that freedom -properly understood- is actually what he refers to as "capability."  In other words: freedom is not merely the absence of external constraints
column12: but the capability to accomplish things in the world.  This is NOT "Development as Freedom" but rather "Freedom as Capability."  And this is where Sen really loses me.  Even IF "capability" is a quantifiable
column13: measureable
column14: controllable
column15: predictable variable that can be maximized (extremely dubious
column16: since the list of possible verbs of which one can be capable is practically infinite)
column17: this argument is nothing even remotely new.  Sen's allegedly groundbreaking discovery is simply the modern incarnation of Isaiah Berlin's "positive freedom
column18: FDR's freedom from want
column19: and the other muddled reinventions of the concept of freedom" which together date back to the early Counter-Enlightenment.    These ideas sound like doublethink because they are doublethink.  Public health care and make-work jobs simply do not leap to mind when one thinks of "freedom" - if they did
column20: there would be no need for this book.  The conceptual epitome of "freedom" is one's release from prison.  That's not the necessarily the "capability" to do anything.  If we want to discuss welfare economics
column21: on the other hand
column22: that's fine -- but let's not confuse our students by misappropriating the language of liberty.  But I am not deterred from this work merely by the fact that I disagree with Sen's thesis.  In the end
column23: I am turned off by the massive acclaim this book has recieved
column24: despite its glaring intellectual mushiness.  Sen has supplanted Marx as the English professor's favorite economist
column25: distracting attention from those thinkers whose ideas might actually make a modest difference in combating global poverty

column1: This has to be the most boring book I have ever read. Well
column2: I haven't quite finished it yet as it's taking forever to push my way through it. And I'm sure that more boring books exist
column3: I just haven't read them.    I wanted to learn about KKR and LBOs - particularly as a division of KKR recently bought one of the vendors supplying my own employer. I was hoping for the big picture of what took place as well as some entertaining anecdotes. But this book consists largely of page after page of uninteresting minutiae of conversations between the various parties involved. There really is no need for such detail and a little bit of editing could have halved the size of the book without losing any essential information. And a bit of theoretical discussion would have been far more valuable than some of the biographical material. It felt a bit like watching someone else's home video. It probably means a lot to the people involved
column4: especially as they'll get the in jokes and quirks of the participants
column5: but it's painfully boring for strangers forced to watch it out of politeness.  I'm sure that much of the conversation is fiction anyway. People don't reliably remember this level of detail of converstaions over a period of years. What are remembered are broad brushstrokes - and this is what the author should have written.  There are occasional moments of entertainment - like Ted Forstmann obsessing about the evils of junk bonds. But most of the characters seem quite flat and uninteresting.   The fact is: I wanted some of this information in this book. As it provided some of this
column6: albeit with a lot of suffering on my part
column7: I'll give it two stars.  Update: Well I did finish this book eventually. My final opinion is much the same

column1: Keynes was no doubt an influential economist.  His theories and 'expertise' on economics influenced the post-New Deal economic policies of the United States and the internationalist wealth redistribution schemes like IMF.  However
column2: his ideas on economics failed miserably and it was application of Keynesian ideas that wrecked so much havoc on the U.S. particularly in the 1970s with the stagflation (an inflationary recession with unemployment which was theoretically impossible accordingly to Keynesism.)  We have Keynes to thank for budget deficits and the nebulous idea that we can spend ourselves into prosperity through the largesse of the federal government.  Read Planning for Freedom or Socialism by Ludwig von Mises instead

column1: Day is superior to both Night and Dawn
column2: the first two books in Elie Wiesel's Night trilogy. However
column3: six aspects of Day really bug me:  First
column4: Day's plot lacks cohesion and is out of chronological order
column5: unlike Night and Dawn. The heart of a novel should either consist of either solid storytelling and an advancing plot or delicately crafted interwoven stories. In Day
column6: it is instead largely a jumble of disparate memories - typically of women in steamy situations. This is not conducive to seamless communication.  Second
column7: Wiesel originally wrote The Accident separately from Dawn and Night. As such
column8: it is the least connected to the other two books. He decided at some point to change the title to Day
column9: tack it on to his first two books
column10: and call the resulting mumbo-jumbo a "trilogy." This is sloppy
column11: self-centered
column12: and ultimately irritating because now students at my school are required to read all three volumes.  Third
column13: my same old complaint about Wiesel's writing holds true in Day: too much crying! I find it absurd how many times people cry in the Night trilogy - readers of Night and Dawn (as many of you readers this review are) can attest to this. Rather than making his readers more sympathetic to the feelings of his characters
column14: Wiesel conditions them to indifference with this blatant overuse of sadness.  Fourth
column15: Wiesel's comparisons in Day are too often uncreative at best
column16: stale at worst. Too often he compares one woman to another
column17: typically his mother or grandmother. Comparing one woman to another does nothing. These comparisons would be acceptable once or twice
column18: but
column19: one's patience wears thin after reading paragraph after paragraph of them. Wiesel should keep in mind that he is writing to other people who did not grow up with these women. Much more interesting and effective would be to compare the women to romantic inanimate objects such as the sun
column20: the moon
column21: or a budding rose.  Fifth
column22: Wiesel shies away from many chances to show us a lurking literary prowess throughout Day. These opportunities crop up whenever somebody "talked for hours." It's hard to imagine that these terse
column23: two-dimensional characters are really capable of speaking for hours without seeing the monologue on paper. Why does Wiesel hold these soliloquies back from us?  Sixth
column24: and last
column25: Wiesel doesn't vary his sentence structure enough
column26: in Day or either of the other books in his Night trilogy. This is a run-of-the-mill high school error
column27: and I'm surprised that neither he
column28: nor Oprah
column29: nor the legions of devoted oprah&wiesel fans pick up on this. His short
column30: choppy sentences should be reserved those rare pulse-pounding moments
column31: but Wiesel uses them everywhere.  I will quote from the text to illustrate my points:  Kathleen's face was twisted with pain. She looked like a sorceress who has lost her true face from having put on too many masks. A great fire burned around her. Suddenly she cried out and began to sob. My mother
column32: I had never seen my mother cry. (p.74)  Kathleen. Tears were coming to her eyes. My mother didn't cry. At least not when other people were there. She only offered her tears to God. Kathleen looked a little like my mother; she had her high forehead
column33: and her chin had the same pure lines. But Kathleen wasn't dead. And she was crying. (p.89)  These selections are the concluding paragraphs of two back-to-back chapters. And yet they say the same thing. That's not any kind of plot advancement that I've ever heard of. I hung my head upon reading the following
column34: though I agree with it:  Nothing is more sacred than life
column35: or healthier
column36: or greater
column37: or more noble. To refuse life is a sin; it's stupid and mad. You have to accept life
column38: cherish it
column39: love it
column40: fight for it as if it were a treasure
column41: a woman
column42: a secret happiness. (p.67)  This "profound" realization flies in the face of what the narrator previously thought - that life wasn't worth fighting for. However
column43: I knew that "life is all we have" before I even knew who Wiesel was. I know we humans must simultaneously struggle for our lives while still finding time to cherish them. I don't need an emotionally-estranged Holocaust-survivor narrator to take me by the hand and lead me through the way he discovered that truth
column44: which is essentially the only task that Day accomplishes for society. Day certainly doesn't make one happier
column45: unless one derives pleasure from knowing one can write better than a Nobel Peace Prize winner. I cannot speak for how this book affects other readers
column46: however. Perhaps this book will save someone from suicide someday?  I will make you suffer though one more irresistible passage before I quit:  In the beginning she didn't cry. We were on the same level. We dealt with each other like equals. We were free. Each one free from himself and free from the other. When I didn't feel like keeping a date
column47: I didn't. She did the same. And neither of us was angry or even hurt. When I didn't talk for a whole night
column48: she didn't try to make me explain. The familiar question asked by lovers
column49: "What are you thinking about?" didn't enter our conversations. Hardness had become our religion. Nothing was said that wasn't essential. We tried to convince each other that we could live
column50: hope
column51: and despair
column52: alone. Each kiss could have been the last. At any moment the temple could have collapsed. The future didn't exist since it was useless. At night we made love silently
column53: almost like our own witnesses. A stranger watching us in the street could easily have taken us for enemies. Rightly so
column54: perhaps. True enemies aren't always the ones who hate each other. (p.90)  I prefer that my novels not read like Chicken Soup for the Soul.  Gyula arrives near the end of the book
column55: providing the comic relief and fog-cutting outsider's insight that the rest of Wiesel's Night trilogy needed so desperately to keep from being the bore that it was. In Gyula's laughing light and portrait-mirror
column56: the narrator sees himself for who he truly has become and discovers that he needs to change his outlook. Day was a more satisfying novel than either Night or Dawn in part due to this resolution and promised change in attitude.  I have concluded my reading of the Night trilogy
column57: and of Wiesel
column58: for good. I can't wait to discuss this trilogy in English class - fur will fly
column59: for sure
column60: as most readers of Wiesel whom I've met become insta-fans. I will conclude by saying this - if you enjoyed Night and Dawn
column61: then Day will be right up your alley

column4: music
column5: history and other such subjects to be taught in a science classroom. Neither should religious beliefs. I

column8: anyone who feel that the honest teaching of science is a threat to their religious beliefs is someone who has great doubts about their religious beliefs!

column1: In his book
column2: The Four Agreements
column3: Don Miguel Ruiz
column4: embodies four principles for experiencing personal freedom in life.  He says that we should be impeccable with our words
column5: not to take anything personally
column6: don't make assumptions
column7: and to always do our best. The basis for some of the agreements we make with ourselves stem from early childhood training through a series of rewards and punishments from our parents.  He calls this process "domestication" (p. 6). Ruiz says that 95% of the beliefs we hold are nothing but lies and that most of our agreements are based upon the fear of rejection.  The agreements that he gives are meant to free us from the emotional bonds that get in the way of our personal energy and to transform our lives.  While there are various nuggets of truth throughout the book
column8: some of it goes off into the abyss where he takes a thought and carries it to what I would consider to be to be an illogical conclusion. In some instances he uses biblical scripture to support his claims; however
column9: in looking further
column10: he takes some of the passages from the Bible out of context.  Some of his ideas are presented as if they were new ideas
column11: but I would think most of us by a young age
column12: should already an understanding of these principles. Although his book has been highly rated
column13: I hold the position that Mr. Ruiz lacks credibility and logic as a writer
column14: therefore
column15: losing good standing with me as a reader.  According to Ruiz
column16: as children we are not given the opportunity to choose our own beliefs.  When we go against the rules we are punished (or rewarded for compliance). The fear of rejection leads us to agree with
column17: or become something that we are not. In essence
column18: we become a carbon copy of someone else
column19: such as our parents.  He says our normal tendencies are lost and we judge other people based upon these agreements.  He boldly states
column20: lacking statistical data to back it up
column21: that 95% of our beliefs are based upon a lie (13).  The implication is that we are merely nothing more than a society of mindless
column22: "domesticated" individuals
column23: hurting ourselves
column24: judging and victimizing other people along the way.  This kind of thinking negates the teachings associated with parenthood and the positive aspects they bring to our lives. By his interpretation
column25: if 95% of what we believe is a lie
column26: then 95% of what our parents taught us is also a lie.  I would disagree.  There are many people who exist today as viable
column27: productive members of society who I'm sure would point out they too became a copy of someone else's beliefs and values.  If these role models are only filling our heads with lies and teaching us how not to be ourselves
column28: by his interpretation
column29: we don't need parents
column30: teachers
column31: or leaders. He undermines our personal paradigms and omits that as adults we do have the ability to choose a different path
column32: which I believe is our right of passage. By his rational we lose the ability to choose our own destiny.  Instead
column33: we become victims of it.    One of the few things we agree upon is his first agreement
column34: be impeccable with your word; however
column35: he misquotes the bible (John 1:1) when he says "In the beginning was the word and the word was with God
column36: and the word was God."  He uses it to epitomize the use of "word" as in what one speaks (26).  Looking a little further down in that passage
column37: it also says "The word was made flesh and dwelt among us".  This passage is not talking about a form of speech
column38: or speaking
column39: but rather "Jesus Christ".  Christ became flesh and dwelt among us.  In that same chapter he says that "sin begins with rejection of yourself" (31).  However
column40: in Christianity it says that sin is a transgression of the law (1 John 3:4) and that sin is neglecting to do God's will (James 4:7).  It's not about self
column41: but about disobeying God's ordinances. While I agree that watching what we say is something we all need to strive for
column42: this is not a new concept.  Most children have learned by the age of 6 that if you don't have something nice to say
column43: don't say it at all.  In his second agreement
column44: don't take anything personally; he says that nothing people do is because of you. While this is true to some degree
column45: he leads the reader down a path of illogical extremes when he says that even if someone took a gun and shot you in the head
column46: it was nothing personal.  So in essence
column47: when Mary Jo Buttafuoco was shot by Amy Fisher
column48: her expression of displeasure regarding Amy's behavior was nothing more than a fundamental form of projection because according to Ruiz "you are dealing with yourself
column49: not me" (51).  No
column50: realistically
column51: Mary Jo Buttafuoco was shot because Amy Fisher wanted her dead. This kind of logic encourages victims to remain in dysfunctional relationships and perpetrators to continue abusing victims.  As an American
column52: I'm glad that someone took 9/11 personally.   According to Mr. Ruiz he takes neither destructive nor constructive criticism.  It seems arrogant to place myself so far above reproach
column53: that I would turn a deaf ear to all forms of criticism.  When my College writing professor
column54: gave me his opinion regarding my work
column55: if I were following the authors line of reasoning
column56: I would believe that my professor was "trying to poison my mind and was feeding me his emotional garbage" as Mr. Ruiz suggests (49). I would rather believe that my instructor has my best interests at heart and is seeking to teach me how to become a better writer.  Another agreement is about not making assumptions in life.  He says when we make assumptions
column57: in essence
column58: we create unnecessary drama.  Unfortunately we live in a world where that is not entirely possible.  Assumption is a necessary part of a thought and reason; even within the scientific community a hypothesis (or assumption) is formed in order to test a theory.  In order come to school each day I must make assumptions that my instructor has a college degree
column59: and that he or she must be reliable enough in life to make it to work everyday.  In his forth agreement
column60: always do your best
column61: he claims it is based upon the actions of the other three agreements
column62: stating they will only work if you do your best.  Again
column63: these are fundamental principles that almost any child has learned.    While Ruiz does indeed present some viable ideas
column64: his concepts begin to unravel when he doesn't back up his statements with facts
column65: but instead takes a basic concept and follows an illogical line of reasoning to reach his final conclusion.  I can't completely discount everything that he says
column66: but he lost credibility with me by some of his assumptions and weak rationalizations.

column1: This book is a great example of the problem with the contemporary left: a paralysis by analysis by academics too comfortable in their lofty ivory tower to actually take any political action. There was a time when left intellectuals were more concerned class struggle than making tenure or getting published in the most trendy post-modern theory journal. Try to imagine the look on the face of any working class Joe sipping beer at a sports bar when confronted with the language this book is couched in. Ivory tower Marxist serve as an "outlet" for revolutionary energy in a capitalist society. The ivory tower radicalism espoused by this book is nothing but another system of control.

column1: The title appears to be a ripoff of Pete Hammil's book
column2: "Why Sinatra Matters". A more accurate title to this book would be
column3: "Why New Orleans Matters to Me". Almost all of the author's reasons are subjective. He likes the Mardi Gras Indians
column4: the neighborhood restaurants and music clubs. So what? What is the objective significance of them? The author mentions but does not evaluate the objective effects of the high crime rate
column5: welfare dependence and the political corruption. He also dodged the objective fact that before Hurricane Katrina 40% of city residents could not read and write and 50% refused to work. Does New Orleans matter to him because a majority of its residents are stupid and lazy? The truth is that New Orleans has mattered for one objective reason: its geographical location near the mouth of the Mississippi River. The U.S. cannot effectively compete in the global economy without a safe and secure New Orleans. If coastal erosion does not inundate the city
column6: it will continue to matter. But this book will not

column1: This review refers to the translation by William Creasy. Several have tried to bring the devotional classic
column2: "The Imitation of Christ" into the twentieth century and all have failed. I can think  of few  devotional books as morose and melancholy as this one. I have attempted to  read it on several occasions due to its reputation throughout Christian  history but have never been able to draw any strength or comfort from a  work whose message consists of these themes: "Abandon the world and  hate it"
column3: "Withdraw from all people into yourself"
column4: "Think often of death and judgment". This is Christianity!  It  sounds like the scribblings of a manic-depressive in need of Prozac and  some long term attitude adjustment!  A real downer. Not something that  would encourage me to continue with my day to day reading and meditation  time. Where is the encouragement and refreshment that one would expect from  devotional reading? How in the dickens is someone supposed to draw strength  from a book that seems designed to rob you of all positive emotions and  hopes? The emphasis here is on everything dark and depressing that one can  imagine. It is my opinion that one would have to distort the message of the  New Testament to an incredible degree to make the message of "The  Imitation" be in synchrony with it. One further point: while the cross  of Jesus is mentioned over and over and over in this
column5: I do not recall a  single mention of the Resurrection of Jesus-which shows how distorted this  is if it fails to see any point worth mentioning to the central mystery of  Christianity
column6: right

column1: I very much enjoyed the movie "Smoke Signals"
column2: which was based on Sherman Alexie's "The Lone Ranger and Tonto Fistfight in Heaven"
column3: so it was with substantial anticipation I sat down to read "Indian Killer" as part of a book club selecton.  Right away the language was easy and light
column4: and the first few chapters flew by quickly. However
column5: it soon became evident that the story and the writing in general would not hold its appeal for me.  It is set up as a typical "who-dunnit" albeit with an Indian flair.  We are treated to lots of stereotypical "observations" about Indians and about Whites
column6: all from the other's viewpoint.  There is a desperate attempt to portray political incorrectness; however
column7: it more or less boils down to a meaningless shouting match between people who have in some way been wronged. And the solution to the mystery is a complete let-down. All that for this???  I found various historical tidbits and descriptions of customs interesting; however
column8: I often found myself questioning the amount of objectivity in certain factual-sounding statements. This became especially evident after a certain description of a neighborhood in Seattle mainly inhabited by Scandinavians.  The narrator explains the lack of trees in this neighborhood as a direct result of these Scandinavians' wish to emulate the "monotonous flat landscape of their homelands" and thus they proceded to cut down all the trees. Well
column9: I can hardly think of a more inaccurate way to describe the mountainous and forrested countries of Sweden and Norway... After such a blunder
column10: I became perhaps overly sceptical of the remainder of the story.  From the reviews it seems as if most people agree this is not Alexie's best book
column11: and that his first work is far superior.  I will therefore conclude that I need to read another of his books to appreciate his writing and popularity
column12: and all I can offer is that if you are reading Sherman Alexie for the first time
column13: this is defintely not a recommended start.

column1: Ethan Frome paints a vivid portrait of the beauty that is wintertime New England. Unfortunately
column2: that's about all it does right. I was surprised to find the lack of both interesting and sympathetic characters in a novel that appears to be a character study.  Ethan Frome
column3: the protagonist
column4: is selfish and cruel toward his wife's illness. At times I despised him more than any character due to his extreme self-centeredness. In fact
column5: his only characteristic that I can almost relate to
column6: a repressed intellectualism
column7: is barely even mentioned.  Mattie Silver
column8: Ethan's object of desire
column9: is an underdeveloped character in the most extreme sense of the phrase. It is unclear what her motives and feelings are even by the end of the story. However
column10: this underdevelopment may have been for the best. The little that we are told about Mattie only adds to the disenchanting strangeness and sloppiness of the book. Most of the time
column11: she comes off at immature and thoughtless.  Zeena
column12: the supposed antagonist
column13: is actually the easiest character to feel for. But don't get me wrong
column14: she's unlikable just like the rest of the characters.  Overall
column15: I suggest you avoid this book if at all possible. It's a loppy book with no real purpose or message.

column1: Mark Rank proposes many interesting ideas that attempt redefine how we think about poverty in America.  Most of his ideas are solid
column2: but my deepest concern is with the readers who gave this book 5 stars and used the word "interesting" to describe it.  Did they actually read it?  This book is an unending parade of boring and repeated ideas presented in different
column3: yet equally boring ways.  I honestly beleive that this book has destroyed the thrill of musical chairs for me forever.  This book could have been written in about 150 pages instead of the 250 it actually took if he simply used his original
column4: not to mention solid
column5: ideas.  The nature of the book greatly weakened his overall argument.    Not only was the book dry
column6: but it also seemed to fail to acknowledge the global system the US is a part of
column7: and in particular
column8: the role that immigration plays on poverty in the US.  He talks about the US and the people in it as if they were static
column9: but we live in a very fluid world
column10: growing more fluid everyday
column11: and I feel that his failure to ackowledge this fact truly hurts his overall argument.

column1: This might have been an interesting book had the author concentrated more on the plot and less on the peripheral items.  the heroine is pretty
column2: intelligent and has an interesting career and background.  The author
column3: however
column4: appears to place more emphasis on her fashion and sexual exploits than on developing her as a real character.  Is it really necessary to describe every skimpy outfit that the heroine wore and every sexual encounter that she has in order to further the plot?  It appears that the author feels compelled to throw some of this in every few pages in a poorly disguised attempt to hold the reader's interest.  I was also disappointed by the actual plot itself.  Some of the items were so transparent that the reader could predict them pages before the heroine came to the obvious conclusion.  Could anybody not see the significance of the ski lodge?  Other items were never adequately explained and left the reader guessing why the obvious was omitted.  If she knew that the lodge was bugged why didn't she ask Abel if he could provide some evidence?  Hopefully
column5: in future novels
column6: the author will leave out most of the fashion and the sex and build her character into one with the depth to be more interesting

column1: Like many others
column2: I first got acquainted with Howards work through Conan
column3: and lamented the "readability coating" later added to his work by other authors (L. Sprague de Camp
column4: Lynn Carter
column5: etc). Solomon Kane's adventures forced me to review such opinion: they are dull and immature; a work in progress rather than a finished literary work (even by pulp fiction standards).    In Conan's stories
column6: Howard's narrative shortcomings are balanced by the fact that they play a role in the the course of the story. Conan brutishness
column7: ethnocentrism and lack of scruples are understandable and even enjoyable in the excellent setting of the Hiborian Age.     In Solomon Kane's saga
column8: instead
column9: the ethnocentric comments of the author seem totally gratuitous
column10: the setting of the stories is unverisimilar
column11: and half of the time one doesn't understand why the character acts like he does. One is willing to do an intellectual parenthesis for a congenial barbarian of a mythical  era
column12: but no so for a somber
column13: socially handicapped and sanctimonious English Calvinst of the XVI century. The character never really connects.  All of the above would be forgivable if the plots were engaging; unfortunately that's not the case
column14: they are far-fetched and uninteresting. The black ink illustrations by Gari Gianni are the best part of the book: they are so good
column15: that they almost succeed in conferring to the poor stories an aura of verisimilitude and decadence
column16: in a way parallel to how Frazetta did with Conan.      In my eyes
column17: this book only for the very fans of Howard's
column18: or some collector who might want to place the rest of his work in context
column19: but it doesn't have much worth per se. But even this endeavor might be frustrated by the poor binding of the book: it literally comes apart in your hands.     Gonzalo Día

column1: A friend of mine handed me this one while I was convalescing and I loved it at the start. The coming of age tale of an art student during his first year of college
column2: it had me laughing myself silly at times and greedily lapping up the aphorisms and insights into mid-twentieth century life that it offered. All the self-absorbed leftish cant of our current academic elite may be found aborning here
column3: in the person of the enigmatic Gary Cooperesque arts instructor Winter Sorbeck and in the antagonistically brilliant arts student
column4: who despises the ordinary
column5: little Miss Himmillsy Dodd. But about two thirds of the way through the book bogs down
column6: particularly when our hero gets the goods on his arrogant professor
column7: and the story starts to trail off to an inconclusive and remarkably unsatisfying end. Sorbeck
column8: who seemed so powerful a character at the outset comes across as a bit of a self-destructive fool
column9: though it seems we are not intended to take him for that by the author
column10: and Miss Dodd solves the class's final problem in a way that only the narrator seems able to grasp. Most peculiar of all is her complete indifference
column11: and even anger
column12: toward our hero for having saved her from the tender ministrations of the madcap frat boys whom she has thoughtlessly baited while in their lair. Instead of gratitude for having been whisked away from the hulk who had her at his mercies
column13: she appears genuinely annoyed with her rescuer instead. Are we to presume she actually sought the experience of being raped or meant to sacrifice herself on the altar of these "Greeks" in some odd form of performance art? The enraged demolition of Baby Laveen which follows her rescue seems to take all the sense out of the tale and the end leaves one merely scratching one's head. After having recommended this one to others as I read it
column14: I was forced to recant at the end. Who really cares about these self-absorbed
column15: self-satisfied college kid rebels who are so convinced they're better than everyone else anyway? As to the graphics (since the author is a graphics designer by trade)
column16: I have to add that I found some of the cover art in my edition more distracting than meaningful and the technique of rolling text over from page to page altogether unhelpful. If you want someone to read something then print it so reading is easy. Otherwise you're just jerking the reader's chain which is pretty much all this book
column17: which began so well
column18: ended up doing. -- SWM

column1: This book is dangerous.  It does not present an overall method (or even practical starting points) for treating people with depression. Throughout the passages the author seems to be speaking to himself and his dead sons as much as to the reader.  It gives readers 30 anecdotal and ideological glimpses into the disorder and it's treatment. This probably does more harm than good in the long run.   I think many readers are likely to start practicing arm-chair psychiatry . . . "it is reasonable to confront them [patients] with the selfishness and anger implied in any act of self-destruction . . ." What a dangerous (angry? guilty?) generalization!  Dealing with depression takes a "patient-centered" approach. Confrontation MAY have it's place
column2: but later in THERAPY. And even then being dependent on multiple factors (patient-doctor relationship
column3: in-patient vs. out-patient
column4: support networks
column5: patient himself).   Someone suffering from depression may get useful insights out of this book. It should NOT be read by family or friends looking for help dealing with a depressed person.

column1: I started off this story with great expectations but am only half way through it and am forcing myself to finish it - only because I spent good money on it!    The story just drags and drags. It's so slow that if I weren't reading the ebook version then I would be skipping pages. I don't like the heroine and I definitely can't stand the hero. She is utterly ridiculous with her head in the clouds living in a dream world. She's supposed to be so enamored of anything that has to do with legends (whining about how she wants to live a legend of her own) but as soon as she is actually involved in one in the form of the St. Legers she balks and wants out. Instead of confronting life she'd rather "fall in love with" a ghost than face a flesh and blood man that she's actually attracted to because he doesn't come with the exact legend that she wants in the way that she wants it.  Truly annoying.   As for the hero...I can't stand a whining
column2: crying

column5: character but he spends all of his time whining about his horrible life and how he's such a horrible person. He's handsome

column9: has a rich history

column11: poor guy. Ok
column12: so he's a little shell-shocked from fighting Napolean and he had a bad love affair when he was 18. He's almost thirty years old. Get over it! Grow up! My goodness
column13: it makes me want to smack the guy. The only believable thing about it is that he feels guilty about his brother's leg being crippled. But he's constantly complaining about the fact that his brother saved him when he really wanted to die; how he didn't deserve to be saved; how he's not good enough to be his father's son; how he's reprehensible; he's a wastrel; blah-blah-blah. Not to mention his intimate friendship with a man who I can tell half-way through the book will probably be the bad guy - a friendship that he insists on despite all good common sense and the opinions of all the people he keeps saying that he's not worthy of. I wonder why? Lastly
column14: is the "love" he supposedly feels for Rosalind. I don't understand why he loves her. It's obvious why she "loves" the ghost - but not him yet - while he's already proclaiming that he loves her. Other than the St. Leger legend there hasn't been enough between them for him to "love" her.   I truly hope this book has a redeeming ending - but I doubt it. I'm more than halfway through it and was so disgusted that I had to voice an opinion. This is the first time I've ever written an opinion without having finished the book. Don't waste your time or your money. I won't be buying any more of this author's books.   For an excellent historical romantic read with supernaturally gifted heros and heroines (while not straying into the paranormal subgenre) I highly recommend Virginia Henley - Tempted

 I adored Mailer's Naked and the Dead, but I just ditched Harlot's Ghost without finishing it. For starters, Mailer was so ignorant that he wrote that schizophrenia was the name for multiple personality syndrome. In reality, those psychiatric conditions have nothing to do with each other, something Mailer would have learned if he had cared to create believable characters. Instead, he exploited his lazy ideas about schizophrenia to fashion a series of Deux ex machina events. The resulting plot is tiresomely simple: all his characters work for the CIA, they each have two personalities, therefore they can do anything whatsoever BECAUSE THEY ARE CRAZY, and this explains why the CIA sucks. Yawn..

column3: but the ending is like something out of a 1930's B-movie. There are so many ways this could have been done that would have been infinitely more plausible (for example
column4: see Richard Morgan's handling of similar issues in a subplot of Broken Angels). I was literally angry as I got to end of the book because it was such a letdown--I was listening to the audiobook version in the car and was actually shouting at the CD player as the ending unfolded.  Hard to believe this is from the same author that gave us The Andromeda Strain and Jurassic Park. Unless you're *really* good at suspending disbelief
column5: avoid this one

column1: Reading "Understanding Digital Photography" by Bryon Peterson is a bit like being at a family get-together
column2: and being given a lot of good advice by friendly Uncle Phil over a couple of beers. Then you later discover that friendly Uncle Phil didn't know what he was talking about! It does mar what was otherwise a good experience.  What makes me think of a family get-together is the folksy
column3: jocular tone and the amusing comparisons between technical subjects and familiar things. Here are a few of Bryan Peterson's more colorful attempts at making digital photography understandable:  - The pixels on the sensor work together like a family
column4: like socialism
column5: and it's too bad Stalin and Mao Tse-tung couldn't see this (pg 16).  - JPEGs are like amnesia or like AM radio or like prepared meat loaf (pg 18
column6: 20).  - TIFFs are like elephants (pg 19).  - ISO is like caffeine
column7: and high ISO is like bloodshot eyes (pg 22).  - Long exposure times cause the pixel family to fall apart and have a nervous breakdown (pg 78).  - Checking the background is important
column8: although typically not done regarding the person you're going to marry (pg 96).  - Over-sharpening a picture makes it glow
column9: which could be used to guide Santa Claus and Rudolph (pg 129).  This style of writing may appeal to some people
column10: but it's definitely not my cup of tea.  The book is richly illustrated with a lot of photographs taken by Bryan Peterson. These pictures do a good job of presenting the various techniques being discussed
column11: and they are all good pictures from a purely technical point of view.  However
column12: my aesthetic opinion of most of the pictures is fairly low
column13: i.e.
column14: they are not the kind of pictures that I'd like to be able to make someday.  Bryan Peterson favors very colorful photos
column15: and he admits that he pushes the color saturation up on most of his pictures. The composition and subjects of many of his pictures leave a kind of artificial taste
column16: as if the pictures were being made just for the sake of making pictures that will impress.  Of course
column17: taste is something that is very individual
column18: and Bryan Peterson is a successful professional photographer so there are obviously many people who like his pictures.  The most serious problem with this book is the large number of technical errors concerning digital photography. Here are some of the more serious examples:  - "... the more pixels the merrier" (pg 16). Only true up to a point.  - "Every time you open and close a JPEG file on your computer
column19: the file degrades due to data being lost..." (pg 18). Not true
column20: and Bryan Peterson's warnings against using JPEGs are mostly incorrect.  - White balance should always be set to "Cloudy+3" (pg 26). Poor advice
column21: especially when photographing people because of the need to get skin colors correct.  - Landscapes should be shot at f/22 (pg 34) and macros at f/32 (pg 118). This doesn't take the light diffraction problem into account.  - Depth of field properties of a lens are independent of sensor size (pg 39 and 119). Not true.  - Noise reduction should be done last in post processing (pg 57). No
column22: it should be done first.  - Clean the sensor with compressed air (pg 127). No
column23: this can damage the camera.  - Take pictures under-exposed by 3 stops in order to stack 8 of them in Photoshop (pg 148). Crazy advice
column24: you should change the opacity of the layers instead.  - "The output size of that file ... will be around 2048 x 3000 ppi (pixels per inch) ..." (pg 156). Meaningless statement.  Bryan Peterson tells us that he shot film for many years and only recently switched to digital. This book was obviously written before he had learned enough about digital photography to explain it properly.  So
column25: I don't like the tone of the writing and I don't particularly like the pictures and I don't think Bryan Peterson's knowledge of digital photography was up to the task. What did I like about this book?  Actually
column26: the basic concepts regarding photography that Bryan Peterson describes are good. The importance of getting the picture right when shooting it (as opposed to Photoshopping it later)
column27: the way in which aperture and shutter speed affect the picture
column28: the importance of how a picture is illuminated and composed
column29: the value of using a tripod; all of this material represents the core concepts of photography that need to be learned in order to be able to consistently take good pictures.  Another thing I appreciated was that Bryan Peterson says that understanding the technology isn't the most important aspect of being a good photographer. "... 99% of all successful photographic images have relied on ... setting a creatively correct exposure and ... creating a well-balanced and compelling composition" (pg 10). This book is inadvertent proof that a lack of technical knowledge does not prevent a person with the proper basic knowledge of photography from taking good pictures.  Still
column30: for a book that is targeted at those who want to learn about digital photography
column31: the many errors disqualify it.  Rennie Peterse

column1: This book provides an intriguing look back at a time when the Dot Com Boom was at its zenith
column2: shortly before the crash. Interestingly
column3: there is no sense of the impending doom that lies just over the horizon.  Lewis' "Liar's Poker" was extremely enjoyable
column4: particularly because of the flash and personality of the central players. In this book
column5: Lewis seems to have lost his way as he tries to wring interest from a much less compelling or likable chief character. The tone of the book is further weakened by the constant labels applied to Clark's disciples as the "smartest
column6: best
column7: greatest
column8: and most ingenious
column9:
individuals in their various fields.  What strains credibility, however, is the attribution of all Clark's successes to his incredible intelligence and foresight, while the fault of his failures is cast on the incompetent actions and short-sighted beliefs of others. History will probably not judge Clark as charitably as Lewis -- especially since most of the Clark's companies have either failed outright or remain but shells of their Dot Com era glory (most notably SGI, Netscape, and Healtheon).  Throughout the book, Jim Clark is touted for wealth that amounts to between $3 and $4 billion. The list of 2004 Forbes 400 Richest in America shows Jim Clark with an approximated net worth of $700 million. For a man who brags he will quit making money when his fortune eclipses that of Oracle's Larry Ellison, today Clark probably most regrets the loss of his favorite designation: billionaire.
